        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Sent from my iPad&gt; On Jun 15, 2018, at 12:02 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; But we can certainly reconsider that.  I’m beginning to believe that our current release pattern doesn’t buy much compared to the time and effort it takes.The only thing I see the monthly test releases really getting us is a way to publicize to users that we have something new we want them to test.  However, if users aren’t actually downloading those releases, they don’t buy us anything over the “daily” builds.Paul</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36343368">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36343368/">[Jmri-developers] Release process (was Re: 4.11.7 and change to merging process</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-06-15 04:02:24</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; On Jun 14, 2018, at 7:01 PM, Robert Middleton &lt;osfan6313@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; &gt; What I generally do is to keep 'master' as the main branch of&gt; development, and create a new branch for each release.  This is very&gt; similar to what happens with the Linux kernel.  For example, fixes are&gt; first applied to 'master', and can then be merged into the other&gt; branches as required.  Here's a concrete example: I fixed a driver in&gt; the kernel and it first appeared in the 4.11 kernel series[2].  It was&gt; later backported to the 3.16 series[3].  The other thing to note about&gt; the kernel updates is that you don't do a pull request directly to&gt; Linus himself; you do a pull request or a patch to the maintainer of&gt; the subsystem, who then passes it up to Linus after it passes the&gt; maintainer's check(this is almost certainly overkill for JMRI).This is exactly what we have been doing.  See <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/scripts/HOWTO-distribution.md" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/scripts/HOWTO-distribution.md</a> specifically <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/scripts/HOWTO-distribution.md#further-changes-to-contents" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/scripts/HOWTO-distribution.md#further-changes-to-contents</a>Some people, who do lots of good work, like to work on their local master branch.  That’s not a problem when they’re making occasional, mostly-independent changes: you can do a PR from your own master just fine.But since they’re not in the habit of working on another branch, they don’t do it during the (comparatively small) periods when we’re asking them to work on a branch that’s behind the HEAD of master.Would be interested in thoughts on a release workflow to let them keep doing that.(Of course, there’s an intrinsic limit to that: Somebody who’s working on multiple fixes at overlapping times, perhaps even while waiting for a PR to merge, won’t be able to keep them separate if they’re all on master. We’ve had examples where that caused real message)&gt; The other thought with this is how exactly are versions numbered?  If&gt; there is a semantic version[4](which is more geared towards&gt; libraries), what do the different JMRI versions mean exactly?  I&gt; didn't see a clear guide on the JMRI website(I found it on the DCC&gt; wiki), but generally my philosophy is to do a micro release for small&gt; fixes, e.g. something like a misspelling, or bug fixes, no new&gt; features.  Doing it that way generally means that your minor version&gt; number will increment faster than it is now though, but it helps to&gt; keep it separate in my mind at least as to what is going on.We haven’t been building releases based on API changes, but rather based on the calendar.<a href="http://jmri.org/download/index.shtml" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/download/index.shtml</a>Test releases update the right-most digit roughly monthly (because they have to update something)Production releases up the center digit (ditto)Big-impact changes, so far only changes in the Java requirements, update the left-most digit.But we can certainly reconsider that.  I’m beginning to believe that our current release pattern doesn’t buy much compared to the time and effort it takes.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36343345">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36343345/">Re: [Jmri-developers] 4.11.7 and change to merging process</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: david d zuhn &lt;zoo@st...&gt; - 2018-06-15 02:42:10</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CAASpJ1z1htsmoX9aQEX_u6Y%3DgL6CrWXxTuJFk_03nQdwY6kTwg%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt;&gt; One thing that you could do would be to follow a gitflow workflow[1]&gt; to separate branches and how they work together.  I've never followed&gt; this workflow(I personally think that it's stupid) but it's certainly&gt; another option.&gt;I think the big issue at hand is that some developers have a problemworking on branches, no matter what the workflow is.I've worked with a couple of developers lately trying to get them throughthe process of working on a feature branch and merging in changes frommaster and creating a pull request.I think that extending that to creating a feature branch off of a releasebranch is just asking too much of some people.   These are modelrailroaders who are dabbling into software, not paid software engineers whocan be expected to follow particular processes.The advantage and thing that I like about the kernel style of&gt; branching is that while your master branch may always be changing, the&gt; release branches only need to pick and choose what they pull back.&gt;This works well enough when you have frequent releases, many helpers, andsufficient history to be able to reject changes because the commit doesn'tstructure well into this workflow.The other thought with this is how exactly are versions numbered?It's certainly not semantic versioning.   In production releases, Bob hasbeen reluctant to got releases to update z (in x.y.z).   In the testreleases, z is just an increment since the last release, with no particularmeaning.y gets bumped each "major release" (even being production, odd being testreleases leading towards the next production [y+1]).x gets incremented whenever Bob gets convinced that it's worthincrementing.   That's obviously been rare.-- david d zuhn  Saint Paul Bridge &amp; Terminal Ry.zoo @ stpaulterminal.org</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36343323">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36343323/">Re: [Jmri-developers] 4.11.7 and change to merging process</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Robert Middleton &lt;osfan6313@gm...&gt; - 2018-06-15 02:01:44</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Just a few thoughts for you based off of my experiences.One thing that you could do would be to follow a gitflow workflow[1]to separate branches and how they work together.  I've never followedthis workflow(I personally think that it's stupid) but it's certainlyanother option.What I generally do is to keep 'master' as the main branch ofdevelopment, and create a new branch for each release.  This is verysimilar to what happens with the Linux kernel.  For example, fixes arefirst applied to 'master', and can then be merged into the otherbranches as required.  Here's a concrete example: I fixed a driver inthe kernel and it first appeared in the 4.11 kernel series[2].  It waslater backported to the 3.16 series[3].  The other thing to note aboutthe kernel updates is that you don't do a pull request directly toLinus himself; you do a pull request or a patch to the maintainer ofthe subsystem, who then passes it up to Linus after it passes themaintainer's check(this is almost certainly overkill for JMRI).The advantage and thing that I like about the kernel style ofbranching is that while your master branch may always be changing, therelease branches only need to pick and choose what they pull back.Now this may not be super relevant for JMRI unless there is somethought into keeping specific versions(e.g. 4.10.y) up to date forpeople to use.The other thought with this is how exactly are versions numbered?  Ifthere is a semantic version[4](which is more geared towardslibraries), what do the different JMRI versions mean exactly?  Ididn't see a clear guide on the JMRI website(I found it on the DCCwiki), but generally my philosophy is to do a micro release for smallfixes, e.g. something like a misspelling, or bug fixes, no newfeatures.  Doing it that way generally means that your minor versionnumber will increment faster than it is now though, but it helps tokeep it separate in my mind at least as to what is going on.-Robert Middleton1: <a href="https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/comparing-workflows/gitflow-workflow" rel="nofollow">https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/comparing-workflows/gitflow-workflow</a>2: <a href="https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/stable/linux-stable.git/commit/?h=linux-4.11.y&amp;id=2cd29f2387be70de9feb4c9f8dbc7c0bd55748ce" rel="nofollow">https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/stable/linux-stable.git/commit/?h=linux-4.11.y&amp;id=2cd29f2387be70de9feb4c9f8dbc7c0bd55748ce</a>3: <a href="https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/stable/linux-stable.git/commit/?h=linux-3.16.y&amp;id=ffb5929e9f0810383ed5095338e78447da5140bd" rel="nofollow">https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/stable/linux-stable.git/commit/?h=linux-3.16.y&amp;id=ffb5929e9f0810383ed5095338e78447da5140bd</a>4: <a href="https://semver.org/" rel="nofollow">https://semver.org/</a>On Thu, Jun 14, 2018 at 9:26 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; For the past two production releases, we’ve been using an approach where we build the last few test releases sequentially. For 4.11 -&gt; 4.12, this was going to play out as 4.11.7 being the last from master, and that fixes after that (i.e. to a 2nd set of 4.11.7 files, or to 4.11.8) would be created _on_ _the_ _4.11.7_ _branch_.  That would let them cleanly merge, while also allowing people to create and merge general-development PRs that would eventually end up in 4.13.1.  Git is good at this kind of separation.&gt;&gt; Unfortunately, I don’t think we can actually make this work.  Many productive people are used to working off “master”, and changing their process at this point isn’t really in the way that they think. People just normally make a change on “master”, whether it’s an incremental fix to 4.11.7 or is intended for general development (hence appear in 4.13.1); thank puts it on top of everybody else’s merged changes to master, so it can only be reliably brought into 4.11.7 with those other changes.&gt;&gt; For 4.9 -&gt; 4.10, the process took a _really_ long time to converge, and it’s already started to look like that’s happening again.&gt;&gt; So for 4.12, we'll be using different process, starting now:&gt;&gt; 0) I’ll rebuild 4.11.7 from the (new) head of master once the most recent PR (#5368) has been merged.&gt;&gt; 1) After that, we _DO_ _NOT_ merge any PRs between now and the release of 4.12 in three weeks.  Yes, that’s a pain, but it’s the least available pain I can think of given how people work; would love to hear of a better one for next time!&gt;&gt; 1.A) As a reminder, maintainers should please add the "After Next Production Release” label on new PRs.&gt;&gt; 2) If you have a fix that should go in to 4.11.8 (10 days from now), please PR it and mention it here.  Because we’re not merging anything else, we can merge just the PRs that are needed for 4.11.8 and build that from master (sort of a “from a master that we’ve restricted the changes in”)&gt;&gt; 3) Then we’ll build 4.12 from 4.11.8 (or 4.11.9 if that’s needed), and merge all those outstanding PRs to start the next test release series.&gt;&gt; This process is not risk free.  Because we’re not merging, we can start accumulating conflicts in changes.  This has caused problems before.&gt;&gt; It would be great to have a better methodology that is both (a) compatible with how people work and (b) allows work that's to-become-the-production-release _and_ is-general-development-for-next-test-release  independently.   Suggestions welcome.  Hopefully we can come up with something better for next time (December).&gt;&gt; Bob&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Thank you for catching that!The 1st and 2nd build files are actually the same:  Jenkins kicked off right before I pushed the final content.  So I’m building a 3rd one, this time with the right branch content.Sorry for the confusion, will let people know when the right files are present.(And, although it was an mistake, it underlines that it’s better to automate these releases:  Every time we do something different, even for good reason, there’s a chance of a mistake or accident)Bob&gt; On Jun 14, 2018, at 12:20 PM, Dan Boudreau &lt;daboudreau@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I believe all three are missing.  Not a problem, can wait for 4.11.8.&gt; &gt; 5477, 5476 and 5475&gt; &gt; Dan&gt; &gt;&gt; -----Original Message-----&gt;&gt; From: Bob Jacobsen [mailto:jacobsen@...]&gt;&gt; Sent: Thursday, June 14, 2018 3:02 PM&gt;&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers &lt;jmri-&gt;&gt; developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Second 4.11.7 files available (was re: 4.11.7 and&gt;&gt; change to merging process&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; On Jun 14, 2018, at 10:36 AM, Dan Boudreau &lt;daboudreau@...&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; I don't see my PRs in the latest set of 4.11.7 files, I tested for 5477, 5476 and&gt;&gt; 5475.  Not an issue if you don't pull them in now, they can wait for 4.11.8.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; !!!!!&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; As far as I know, all the PRs up to this morning should be in there.  Could you&gt;&gt; point me to one that’s missing?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; I didn't realize that merging to the head caused problems when building a&gt;&gt; release.  I thought you could cherry pick the PRs you wanted to merge into the&gt;&gt; final build. I'll go quite unless a nasty bug appears.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Sorry about that,&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Not a problem.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I am hesitant to cherry-pick changes because that has caused errors in the past.&gt;&gt; As a technical process, it certainly can be done, but it bypasses the ways that Git&gt;&gt; ensures the integrity of changes.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Nobody wants to cause a regression, that’s not anybody’s intent, and people are&gt;&gt; trying to get things done as soon as possible.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; But having changes after the testing is a bad practice. If we want to call&gt;&gt; something a “production release” that’s “more reliable”, we should mean it.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; (In passing:  I sometimes think that’s a mistake, often during the process of&gt;&gt; trying to create those production releases. By saying that we’re doing more&gt;&gt; testing i.e. now, we’ve implicitly encouraged less testing earlier.  Hence people&gt;&gt; bring things forward at 4.11.7 plus, essentially 4.12.-1, when they could have&gt;&gt; been discussed months ago. But that’s a conversation for the Fall)&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engaging tech&gt;&gt; sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; On Jun 14, 2018, at 10:36 AM, Dan Boudreau &lt;daboudreau@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I don't see my PRs in the latest set of 4.11.7 files, I tested for 5477, 5476 and 5475.  Not an issue if you don't pull them in now, they can wait for 4.11.8.!!!!!As far as I know, all the PRs up to this morning should be in there.  Could you point me to one that’s missing?&gt; &gt; I didn't realize that merging to the head caused problems when building a release.  I thought you could cherry pick the PRs you wanted to merge into the final build. I'll go quite unless a nasty bug appears.&gt; &gt; Sorry about that,Not a problem.I am hesitant to cherry-pick changes because that has caused errors in the past.  As a technical process, it certainly can be done, but it bypasses the ways that Git ensures the integrity of changes.Nobody wants to cause a regression, that’s not anybody’s intent, and people are trying to get things done as soon as possible.But having changes after the testing is a bad practice. If we want to call something a “production release” that’s “more reliable”, we should mean it.(In passing:  I sometimes think that’s a mistake, often during the process of trying to create those production releases. By saying that we’re doing more testing i.e. now, we’ve implicitly encouraged less testing earlier.  Hence people bring things forward at 4.11.7 plus, essentially 4.12.-1, when they could have been discussed months ago. But that’s a conversation for the Fall)Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36343010/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Second 4.11.7 files available (was re: 4.11.7 and change to merging process</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dan Boudreau &lt;daboudreau@ho...&gt; - 2018-06-14 17:36:46</small> 
           <div class="attachments">

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob,I don't see my PRs in the latest set of 4.11.7 files, I tested for 5477, 5476 and 5475.  Not an issue if you don't pull them in now, they can wait for 4.11.8.I didn't realize that merging to the head caused problems when building a release.  I thought you could cherry pick the PRs you wanted to merge into the final build. I'll go quite unless a nasty bug appears.Sorry about that,Dan&gt; -----Original Message-----&gt; From: Bob Jacobsen [mailto:jacobsen@...]&gt; Sent: Thursday, June 14, 2018 12:17 PM&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers &lt;jmri-&gt; developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: [Jmri-developers] Second 4.11.7 files available (was re: 4.11.7 and&gt; change to merging process&gt; &gt; Following the process below, the 2nd set of 4.11.7 files are now available in the&gt; usual place.&gt; &gt; <a href="http://jmri.tagadab.com/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.7/" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.tagadab.com/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.7/</a>&gt; &gt; We will either release these (or successors) by tomorrow afternoon, or we’ll go&gt; back into development mode and try again around June 28.&gt; &gt; These files have all merged PRs up to #5478.&gt; &gt; As a reminder:  Please _do_ _not_ merge any more PRs until further notice.&gt; People are welcome to create PRs with their changes, to get them through CI,&gt; etc, but please do not merge them.&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt; &gt; On Jun 14, 2018, at 6:26 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; For the past two production releases, we’ve been using an approach where we&gt; build the last few test releases sequentially. For 4.11 -&gt; 4.12, this was going to&gt; play out as 4.11.7 being the last from master, and that fixes after that (i.e. to a&gt; 2nd set of 4.11.7 files, or to 4.11.8) would be created _on_ _the_ _4.11.7_&gt; _branch_.  That would let them cleanly merge, while also allowing people to&gt; create and merge general-development PRs that would eventually end up in&gt; 4.13.1.  Git is good at this kind of separation.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Unfortunately, I don’t think we can actually make this work.  Many productive&gt; people are used to working off “master”, and changing their process at this&gt; point isn’t really in the way that they think. People just normally make a change&gt; on “master”, whether it’s an incremental fix to 4.11.7 or is intended for general&gt; development (hence appear in 4.13.1); thank puts it on top of everybody else’s&gt; merged changes to master, so it can only be reliably brought into 4.11.7 with&gt; those other changes.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; For 4.9 -&gt; 4.10, the process took a _really_ long time to converge, and it’s&gt; already started to look like that’s happening again.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; So for 4.12, we'll be using different process, starting now:&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; 0) I’ll rebuild 4.11.7 from the (new) head of master once the most recent PR&gt; (#5368) has been merged.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; 1) After that, we _DO_ _NOT_ merge any PRs between now and the release of&gt; 4.12 in three weeks.  Yes, that’s a pain, but it’s the least available pain I can think&gt; of given how people work; would love to hear of a better one for next time!&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; 1.A) As a reminder, maintainers should please add the "After Next Production&gt; Release” label on new PRs.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; 2) If you have a fix that should go in to 4.11.8 (10 days from now),&gt; &gt; please PR it and mention it here.  Because we’re not merging anything&gt; &gt; else, we can merge just the PRs that are needed for 4.11.8 and build&gt; &gt; that from master (sort of a “from a master that we’ve restricted the&gt; &gt; changes in”)&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; 3) Then we’ll build 4.12 from 4.11.8 (or 4.11.9 if that’s needed), and merge all&gt; those outstanding PRs to start the next test release series.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; This process is not risk free.  Because we’re not merging, we can start&gt; accumulating conflicts in changes.  This has caused problems before.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; It would be great to have a better methodology that is both (a) compatible&gt; with how people work and (b) allows work that's to-become-the-production-&gt; release _and_ is-general-development-for-next-test-release  independently.&gt; Suggestions welcome.  Hopefully we can come up with something better for&gt; next time (December).&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt; --&gt; &gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; &gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; ----------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; &gt; -------- Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's&gt; &gt; most engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; &gt; _______________________________________________&gt; &gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; &gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; &gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engaging tech&gt; sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36342948/">[Jmri-developers] Second 4.11.7 files available (was re: 4.11.7 and change to merging process</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-06-14 16:16:50</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Following the process below, the 2nd set of 4.11.7 files are now available in the usual place.<a href="http://jmri.tagadab.com/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.7/" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.tagadab.com/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.7/</a>We will either release these (or successors) by tomorrow afternoon, or we’ll go back into development mode and try again around June 28.These files have all merged PRs up to #5478.As a reminder:  Please _do_ _not_ merge any more PRs until further notice. People are welcome to create PRs with their changes, to get them through CI, etc, but please do not merge them.Bob&gt; On Jun 14, 2018, at 6:26 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; For the past two production releases, we’ve been using an approach where we build the last few test releases sequentially. For 4.11 -&gt; 4.12, this was going to play out as 4.11.7 being the last from master, and that fixes after that (i.e. to a 2nd set of 4.11.7 files, or to 4.11.8) would be created _on_ _the_ _4.11.7_ _branch_.  That would let them cleanly merge, while also allowing people to create and merge general-development PRs that would eventually end up in 4.13.1.  Git is good at this kind of separation.&gt; &gt; Unfortunately, I don’t think we can actually make this work.  Many productive people are used to working off “master”, and changing their process at this point isn’t really in the way that they think. People just normally make a change on “master”, whether it’s an incremental fix to 4.11.7 or is intended for general development (hence appear in 4.13.1); thank puts it on top of everybody else’s merged changes to master, so it can only be reliably brought into 4.11.7 with those other changes.&gt; &gt; For 4.9 -&gt; 4.10, the process took a _really_ long time to converge, and it’s already started to look like that’s happening again.&gt; &gt; So for 4.12, we'll be using different process, starting now:&gt; &gt; 0) I’ll rebuild 4.11.7 from the (new) head of master once the most recent PR (#5368) has been merged.&gt; &gt; 1) After that, we _DO_ _NOT_ merge any PRs between now and the release of 4.12 in three weeks.  Yes, that’s a pain, but it’s the least available pain I can think of given how people work; would love to hear of a better one for next time!&gt; &gt; 1.A) As a reminder, maintainers should please add the "After Next Production Release” label on new PRs.&gt; &gt; 2) If you have a fix that should go in to 4.11.8 (10 days from now), please PR it and mention it here.  Because we’re not merging anything else, we can merge just the PRs that are needed for 4.11.8 and build that from master (sort of a “from a master that we’ve restricted the changes in”)&gt; &gt; 3) Then we’ll build 4.12 from 4.11.8 (or 4.11.9 if that’s needed), and merge all those outstanding PRs to start the next test release series.&gt; &gt; This process is not risk free.  Because we’re not merging, we can start accumulating conflicts in changes.  This has caused problems before.  &gt; &gt; It would be great to have a better methodology that is both (a) compatible with how people work and (b) allows work that's to-become-the-production-release _and_ is-general-development-for-next-test-release  independently.   Suggestions welcome.  Hopefully we can come up with something better for next time (December).&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi again,I find it an interesting coincidence that the attached image is exactly 27 pixels high. This is the title bar portion from the PanelPro splash screen. Maybe Windows and Linux count the title part differently when reporting window size.Dick :)On 06/14/2018 10:48 AM, Dick Bronson wrote:&gt; Hi,&gt; I have been frustrated for a time that the splash window often opens &gt; too short to fully display the [Help] and [Quit] buttons. I drag the &gt; bottom of the window down, and then exit, only to have it be to short &gt; again the next time it opens.&gt;&gt; Someplace someone else also claimed the same issue and was told to &gt; simply resize the window and it would remember when saved. As an &gt; experiment I did that, and discovered that apparently there is a bug &gt; in the save because every time it is saved and then reopened again it &gt; is shorter than the last. I went a hunting and discovered that the &gt; data is saved in user-interface.xml. Running a diff shows the &gt; following changes for three consecutive closes.&gt;&gt; &lt;window xmlns="" class="apps.gui3.dp3.DecoderPro3Window:DecoderPro" &gt; height="440.0" locX="2085.0" locY="75.0" width="745.0"&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;window xmlns="" class="apps.gui3.dp3.DecoderPro3Window:DecoderPro" &gt; height="413.0" locX="2085.0" locY="103.0" width="739.0"&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;window xmlns="" class="apps.gui3.dp3.DecoderPro3Window:DecoderPro" &gt; height="386.0" locX="2085.0" locY="131.0" width="733.0"&gt;&gt;&gt; It appears that the PanelPro splash screen loses 27 pixels height and &gt; 6 pixels width each time it is closed.&gt;&gt; Version 4.11.7&gt; Ubuntu Linux 16.4&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt; On 06/12/2018 11:42 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt; First JMRI 4.11.7 files are available in the usual way at:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="http://builds.jmri.org/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.7" rel="nofollow">http://builds.jmri.org/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.7</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Feedback appreciated. I would like to release this sometime tomorrow &gt;&gt; if the files are OK.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; -- &gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ &gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36342858/">Re: [Jmri-developers] First 4.11.7 files available</a></b>

           <small>From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@rr...&gt; - 2018-06-14 14:48:56</small> 
           <div class="attachments">

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi,I have been frustrated for a time that the splash window often opens too short to fully display the [Help] and [Quit] buttons. I drag the bottom of the window down, and then exit, only to have it be to short again the next time it opens.Someplace someone else also claimed the same issue and was told to simply resize the window and it would remember when saved. As an experiment I did that, and discovered that apparently there is a bug in the save because every time it is saved and then reopened again it is shorter than the last. I went a hunting and discovered that the data is saved in user-interface.xml. Running a diff shows the following changes for three consecutive closes.&lt;window xmlns="" class="apps.gui3.dp3.DecoderPro3Window:DecoderPro" height="440.0" locX="2085.0" locY="75.0" width="745.0"&gt;&lt;window xmlns="" class="apps.gui3.dp3.DecoderPro3Window:DecoderPro" height="413.0" locX="2085.0" locY="103.0" width="739.0"&gt;&lt;window xmlns="" class="apps.gui3.dp3.DecoderPro3Window:DecoderPro" height="386.0" locX="2085.0" locY="131.0" width="733.0"&gt;It appears that the PanelPro splash screen loses 27 pixels height and 6 pixels width each time it is closed.Version 4.11.7Ubuntu Linux 16.4Dick :)On 06/12/2018 11:42 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; First JMRI 4.11.7 files are available in the usual way at:&gt;&gt; <a href="http://builds.jmri.org/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.7" rel="nofollow">http://builds.jmri.org/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.7</a>&gt;&gt; Feedback appreciated. I would like to release this sometime tomorrow if the files are OK.&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

      <table id="msg36342794">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36342794/">[Jmri-developers] 4.11.7 and change to merging process</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-06-14 13:26:37</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>For the past two production releases, we’ve been using an approach where we build the last few test releases sequentially. For 4.11 -&gt; 4.12, this was going to play out as 4.11.7 being the last from master, and that fixes after that (i.e. to a 2nd set of 4.11.7 files, or to 4.11.8) would be created _on_ _the_ _4.11.7_ _branch_.  That would let them cleanly merge, while also allowing people to create and merge general-development PRs that would eventually end up in 4.13.1.  Git is good at this kind of separation.Unfortunately, I don’t think we can actually make this work.  Many productive people are used to working off “master”, and changing their process at this point isn’t really in the way that they think. People just normally make a change on “master”, whether it’s an incremental fix to 4.11.7 or is intended for general development (hence appear in 4.13.1); thank puts it on top of everybody else’s merged changes to master, so it can only be reliably brought into 4.11.7 with those other changes.For 4.9 -&gt; 4.10, the process took a _really_ long time to converge, and it’s already started to look like that’s happening again.So for 4.12, we'll be using different process, starting now:0) I’ll rebuild 4.11.7 from the (new) head of master once the most recent PR (#5368) has been merged.1) After that, we _DO_ _NOT_ merge any PRs between now and the release of 4.12 in three weeks.  Yes, that’s a pain, but it’s the least available pain I can think of given how people work; would love to hear of a better one for next time!1.A) As a reminder, maintainers should please add the "After Next Production Release” label on new PRs.2) If you have a fix that should go in to 4.11.8 (10 days from now), please PR it and mention it here.  Because we’re not merging anything else, we can merge just the PRs that are needed for 4.11.8 and build that from master (sort of a “from a master that we’ve restricted the changes in”)3) Then we’ll build 4.12 from 4.11.8 (or 4.11.9 if that’s needed), and merge all those outstanding PRs to start the next test release series.This process is not risk free.  Because we’re not merging, we can start accumulating conflicts in changes.  This has caused problems before.  It would be great to have a better methodology that is both (a) compatible with how people work and (b) allows work that's to-become-the-production-release _and_ is-general-development-for-next-test-release  independently.   Suggestions welcome.  Hopefully we can come up with something better for next time (December).Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Dave H That are not on empty panes. Attached is a snip.On Wed, Jun 13, 2018 at 12:56 AM, Pete Brownlow &lt;pete@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt; If it’s a regression that should be fixed before 4.11.7 goes out,&gt;&gt; #5448 &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5448>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5448&gt;</a>; is a regression, as some&gt; panels that displayed correctly in 4.10 no longer do so without putting all&gt; track into blocks, which many users do not need and I expect lots may not&gt; even know how to do.&gt;&gt; I have suggested some ideas as to how to fix it, but I'm afraid I am too&gt; much of a beginner at JMRI development to know how to implement the fix for&gt; it myself.&gt;&gt; Regards,&gt;&gt; Pete&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 13/06/2018 06:24, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt;  On Jun 12, 2018, at 4:03 PM, Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@...&gt; &lt;cpcrr@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; Will there be another build?  I have the fixes to the Halt Poll button ready.&gt; These can wait if you want to freeze the release.&gt; Chuck Catania&gt;&gt;&gt; Three choices at this point:&gt;&gt; *) If it’s a regression that should be fixed before 4.11.7 goes out, just let me know and make a PR that we can merge.  We need to do this quickly.  When you make that branch, _please_ start with the ‘release-4.11.7 branch. Depending on your setup, that’s something like:&gt;&gt; git fetch&gt; git checkout release-4.11.7&gt; git checkout -b my-new-branch-name&gt;&gt; PRs that are not made from that starting point (or earlier) will not appear in 4.11.7, 4.11.8 hence 4.12.  No exceptions.&gt;&gt; *) If you’re not ready right now, but you still want this in 4.12, there’s an opportunity to get it in 4.11.8 in about 10 days.  Same process: start with a branch from release-4.11.7, commit your changes, make a PR and let me know.  If accepted, that’ll get merged before 4.11.8. Note: only regression bug fixes are accepted at that point:  Last-minute fixes to old issues, one more feature, etc, all go in the next monthly test release.&gt;&gt; *) And there will be a first test release in the new (post 4.12)  series around a month from now, notionally called 4.13.1.  If you branch from master, this is where we will get your change in a test release. New features, fixes, etc are welcome there.  Just PR onto master in the usual way, and the usual thing will happen.&gt;&gt; Bob&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="nethttps://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">nethttps://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; If it’s a regression that should be fixed before 4.11.7 goes out,#5448 &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5448>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5448&gt;</a>; is a regression, as some panels that displayed correctly in 4.10 no longer do so without putting all track into blocks, which many users do not need and I expect lots may not even know how to do.I have suggested some ideas as to how to fix it, but I'm afraid I am too much of a beginner at JMRI development to know how to implement the fix for it myself.Regards,PeteOn 13/06/2018 06:24, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; On Jun 12, 2018, at 4:03 PM, Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Will there be another build?  I have the fixes to the Halt Poll button ready.&gt;&gt; These can wait if you want to freeze the release.&gt;&gt; Chuck Catania&gt;&gt;&gt; Three choices at this point:&gt;&gt; *) If it’s a regression that should be fixed before 4.11.7 goes out, just let me know and make a PR that we can merge.  We need to do this quickly.  When you make that branch, _please_ start with the ‘release-4.11.7 branch. Depending on your setup, that’s something like:&gt;&gt; git fetch&gt; git checkout release-4.11.7&gt; git checkout -b my-new-branch-name&gt;&gt; PRs that are not made from that starting point (or earlier) will not appear in 4.11.7, 4.11.8 hence 4.12.  No exceptions.&gt;&gt; *) If you’re not ready right now, but you still want this in 4.12, there’s an opportunity to get it in 4.11.8 in about 10 days.  Same process: start with a branch from release-4.11.7, commit your changes, make a PR and let me know.  If accepted, that’ll get merged before 4.11.8. Note: only regression bug fixes are accepted at that point:  Last-minute fixes to old issues, one more feature, etc, all go in the next monthly test release.&gt;&gt; *) And there will be a first test release in the new (post 4.12)  series around a month from now, notionally called 4.13.1.  If you branch from master, this is where we will get your change in a test release. New features, fixes, etc are welcome there.  Just PR onto master in the usual way, and the usual thing will happen.&gt;&gt; Bob&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

We need to do this quickly.  When you make that branch, _please_ start with the ‘release-4.11.7 branch. Depending on your setup, that’s something like:git fetchgit checkout release-4.11.7git checkout -b my-new-branch-namePRs that are not made from that starting point (or earlier) will not appear in 4.11.7, 4.11.8 hence 4.12.  No exceptions.  *) If you’re not ready right now, but you still want this in 4.12, there’s an opportunity to get it in 4.11.8 in about 10 days.  Same process: start with a branch from release-4.11.7, commit your changes, make a PR and let me know.  If accepted, that’ll get merged before 4.11.8. Note: only regression bug fixes are accepted at that point:  Last-minute fixes to old issues, one more feature, etc, all go in the next monthly test release.*) And there will be a first test release in the new (post 4.12)  series around a month from now, notionally called 4.13.1.  If you branch from master, this is where we will get your change in a test release. New features, fixes, etc are welcome there.  Just PR onto master in the usual way, and the usual thing will happen.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Walt,Turn off "Show Empty CV Tabs" in Preferences-&gt;Roster-&gt;Programmer. That will hide empty panes.If a definition writer takes the trouble, it is possible to put in a dummy empty pane explaining why that particular pane is blank and where the appropriate settings are. For an example, look at an ESU LokSound V4 decoder with and without "Show Empty CV Tabs" enabled.I added these features quite a few years ago and all is explained at:&lt;<a href="http://jmri.org/help/en/html/apps/DecoderPro/CreateDecoderAdvanced.shtml#pane_best_practice>" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/help/en/html/apps/DecoderPro/CreateDecoderAdvanced.shtml#pane_best_practice&gt;</a>;Sent from my iPad-- Dave&gt; On 13 Jun 2018, at 7:27 AM, Walter Thompson &lt;walter.stanley.thompson.3@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Looks good on Digitrax DCS100.             <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36338336/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Ready for JMRI 4.11.7 Saturday?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Pete Brownlow &lt;pete@up...&gt; - 2018-06-08 20:36:37</small>

            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/cfc01930-2481-4835-0bf8-79e00024c2d7%40upsys.co.uk/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I've been using 4.11.6 with the large West Ealing Layout Editor panel.  I've come across a couple of issues with display and usability of panels loaded from older versions with the new track drawing facilities.I've created these issues:#5447 &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5447>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5447&gt;</a>; #5448 &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5448>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5448&gt;</a>;I have also found some issues with the new track decorations feature:#5449 &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5449>#5450" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5449&gt;#5450</a> &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5450>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5450&gt;</a>; #5451 &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5451>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5451&gt;</a>; #5452 &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5452>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5452&gt;</a>;The first two are important to fix before the next production release, IMHO, because they affect how existing user's panels will display in Layout Editor when they load them in the new version. In particular, #5447 &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5447>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5447&gt;</a>; can make some aspects of editing quite difficult.The remaining 4 issues are less critical, as decorations is a new feature few users will be using it yet and they are aesthetic issues, so I think they could wait for 4.13.Thanks,PeteOn 07/06/2018 15:51, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; JMRI 4.11.7 is intended to be the last “everything from HEAD of master” test release before we start stabilizing things for the summer production release.&gt;&gt; Are we about ready for building it this coming weekend?&gt;&gt; Small changes and bug fixes can still be added for a bit more time, but no big changes will be added to the production-release sequence after JMRI 4.11.7 (they can of course still go into Git and be in the JMRI 4.13.1 test release that comes out at about the same time as the production release)&gt;&gt; So if you’re working on a big change and need just a bit more time, please mention it here to start a discussion.&gt;&gt; Bob&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36337260/">[Jmri-developers] JOAL option for Windows, local.properties and the start-up delay</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@be...&gt; - 2018-06-07 15:58:18</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>(Some) Windows users need this optionjvm.args=-Djogamp.gluegen.UseTempJarCache=falseto prevent a really slow startup of the Audio table(s), which causes a really slow startup of all tables due to the pre-loading.IMHO, the right way to fix this is to get rid of the table preloading. Is it really optimal to condition access to e.g. the Sensor table on preloading all the other tables, including the problematic Audio, just so the common table window doesn’t have to resize?  Particularly since the window size and position are remembered _anyway_?  But given that we’re going to keep doing that, some Windows users need the UseTempJarCache setting.  We do it for all Windows users in the LaunchJMRI.exe procedure.But we can’t do it (yet) as a standard part of the development setup, because it kills Travis CI and some individual setups when it’s added to e.g. Ant’s build.xml. See <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/pull/3880" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/pull/3880</a>  So we say that people who need it should put that option in a local.properties file.Somebody has now suggested that we automatically create a local.properties file with the line as part of git checkout.  That doesn’t work, because (a) that file is supposed to be _local_ (hence the name), and (b) it’ll cause problems for all non-Windows users (who do the vast majority of the JMRI commits).But it might be possible, if somebody with Windows expertise and a test system wants to, to figure out how to put it into Ant’s build.xml in a windows-specific way so that it only acts there, and to also put it (in a Windows-specific way) into the setups for Eclipse, NetBeans, etc.Or is there some better solution?  Maybe have something (Ant? JMRI itself?) issue a reminder if running on Windows without the line in the local.properties file or set some other way?  Bob--Bob Jacobsen, UC Berkeley Physicsjacobsen@... +1-510-642-5640 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36337190">
       <tbody>
        <tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>JMRI 4.11.7 is intended to be the last “everything from HEAD of master” test release before we start stabilizing things for the summer production release.Are we about ready for building it this coming weekend?  Small changes and bug fixes can still be added for a bit more time, but no big changes will be added to the production-release sequence after JMRI 4.11.7 (they can of course still go into Git and be in the JMRI 4.13.1 test release that comes out at about the same time as the production release)  So if you’re working on a big change and need just a bit more time, please mention it here to start a discussion.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36333795/">[Jmri-developers] Discrepancy in OpenLCB EventID formats.</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@rr...&gt; - 2018-06-04 02:07:01</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi,While trying to answer a user question about how to send EventIDs to change a signal aspect I discovered a disconcerting format mismatch. You can easily do a 'Copy' of the EventID from the CDI. For example '02.01.57.10.00.08.01.A8', but if you paste that into the 'OpenLCB Send Can (sic) Frame' tool's Event ID (8 bytes): field and then click on [Send Event Produced] nothing happens. The field apparently only accepts space delimited entries. (e.g. 02 01 57 10 00 08 01 A8) This short coming makes it counterintuitive about how to use the tool.Dick :)</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>PR #5384 <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/pull/5384" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/pull/5384</a>  has a first cut at that. It’s configured from java/src/apps/TrainCrew/InstallFromURL.properties to make it easy to adjust.  As a starting point, it’ll read from <a href="https://github.com/ekapus/TrainCrew/archive/master.zip" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/ekapus/TrainCrew/archive/master.zip</a>  and write to web/TrainCrew.  It ends up with an extra level in the URLs since that .zip file has a head directory of TrainCrew-master, but I’ll leave it to you to decide how to deal with that.          <td class="email-body"><pre>Ed is totally up for supporting the "Install TrainCrew" idea... what wouldbe the best way to make the most recent stable branch/tag of his codeavailable to JMRI's installer?  I assume some sort of consistent name?On Sat, May 26, 2018 at 12:37 PM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt;wrote:&gt; I need to retest the redirect version but I expect it will work.&gt;&gt; Maybe I can work with Ed to create stable release branches or tags that&gt; one could download from github.&gt; On Sat, May 26, 2018 at 12:21 PM Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; Do the sounds work from a web browser using the redirect?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; As to making it easier for users: the best approach might be to make it&gt;&gt; easy for people to install an up-to-date version of the TrainCrew app into&gt;&gt; their JMRI installed version.  That lets updates to the two parts stay&gt;&gt; asynchronous.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; If Mr. Kapuscinski will maintain e.g. a downloadable .zip file, it's&gt;&gt; easy.  We can add an “Install or update TrainCrew” menu item to download&gt;&gt; and unpack.   (See i.e. <a href="http://www.codejava.net/java" rel="nofollow">http://www.codejava.net/java</a>-&gt;&gt; se/file-io/programmatically-extract-a-zip-file-using-java but there are&gt;&gt; lots of other tutorials on doing this)  Happy to do that coding if somebody&gt;&gt; else will help test and document it.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Or we could install it directly from GitHub:  <a href="https://github.com/ekapus/" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/ekapus/</a>&gt;&gt; TrainCrew/archive/master.zip    That’s the current master branch, so it&gt;&gt; might always be the right one for a general user, which is why a blessed&gt;&gt; .zip file is better.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; On May 26, 2018, at 9:07 AM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; OK, further "debug" / testing.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; I tried simply copying the TrainCrew directory tree into the web/&gt;&gt; folder of a copy of JMRI on my computer.  I can now access the app from&gt;&gt; mycomputer:12080/web/TrainCrew/index.html and it is being served up&gt;&gt; locally instead of being redirected to conrail1285.com&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; Sound is working just fine, at least as far as JMRI's web server is&gt;&gt; concerned.  I can visit the page from Chrome and hear just fine.  The lack&gt;&gt; of sound appears to be a limitation of WiThrottle's web browser.  Even&gt;&gt; without the sound, it is still a useful tool.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; Which leads me to the question... assuming Mr. Kapuscinski is&gt;&gt; interested and agreeable (he's already licensed the source code as GPL3)&gt;&gt; would there be interest in adding this app to JMRI's web content so that&gt;&gt; folks can serve it locally from their JMRI computer, vs. loading down his&gt;&gt; conrail1285.com site? Just in mentioning this as a stand-alone (not JMRI&gt;&gt; related) feature, I've heard from folks who would like access to the app&gt;&gt; that doesn't require internet access.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; I'm thinking worst/simplest case, we take a snapshot of the app's code&gt;&gt; and add it to the web/ folder, then  update the snapshot either manually or&gt;&gt; in an automated way each time JMRI has a major release?  Maybe add a link&gt;&gt; to web/index.html (or wherever that home page is coming from).&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; - Mark&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; On Fri, May 25, 2018 at 11:14 PM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt; Hard to say about the sound. Might be that there’s some JavaScript&gt;&gt; that’s looking for sound file URLs that aren’t being redirected.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; Unfortunately, the file-redirect approach only works with HTML, not for&gt;&gt; binary sound files. So you might need to use one other methods.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; Or it might be something else entirely.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; On May 25, 2018, at 7:20 PM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Interesting result.  I created a new file web/traincrew.html that&gt;&gt; contains the content you (Bob) suggested as your third option.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Accessing the JMRI webserver from within WiThrottle, IT WORKED.  Sort&gt;&gt; of. The sound effects don't play, but the web content shows up and the&gt;&gt; countdown timers work.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Any idea why the sounds might not be playing?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; On Fri, May 25, 2018 at 11:55 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; The JMRI web server is provided by Jetty, which provides a URL-rewrite&gt;&gt; engine that (probably) could do this:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite</a>-&gt;&gt; handler.html&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; In some cases, it might be easier to handle it as a move (even though&gt;&gt; the original URL never really existed):&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/</a>&gt;&gt; moved-context-handler.html&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; And the simplest possible thing, perhaps too simple to actually work,&gt;&gt; is to have a web page in JMRI that does a specific redirect:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN" "&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd&quot;>" rel="nofollow">http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd"&gt;</a>;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;html lang="en"&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;head&gt;&lt;TITLE&gt;JMRI: Redirected Page&lt;/TITLE&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;META HTTP-EQUIV="PRAGMA" CONTENT="NO-CACHE"&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;META HTTP-EQUIV="Refresh" CONTENT="0; URL=http:NewURL "&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;/head&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;body&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; This page has been moved to&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;A HREF=“http:NewURL"&gt;http:NewURL&lt;/a&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;/body&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;/html&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; (The new URL goes three places in that)&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Would be interested to hear if any of those work (or don’t) for you.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; On May 25, 2018, at 8:32 AM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Question:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Does the JMRI web server have the ability to serve/redirect/whatever&gt;&gt; a third party site?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; There's a cool app I just found called TrainCrew (&gt;&gt; <a href="http://traincrew.conrail1285.com" rel="nofollow">http://traincrew.conrail1285.com</a>) that provides a simple interface to&gt;&gt; simulate crew ops like handbrake sets, air brake charging, and other&gt;&gt; things, with sound effects.  I thought it would be handy when using&gt;&gt; WiThrottle to be able to access it as one of the JMRI web pages... which&gt;&gt; would (I assume) require it to be served up by the JMRI Web Server...&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; The source code is available (open source), so I *could* integrate&gt;&gt; it into JMRI as a "native" web page, but if the JMRI web server has the&gt;&gt; ability to redirect(?) the existing hosted version that might be easier, I&gt;&gt; dunno.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Thoughts?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; - Mark&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; --&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;  Please consider the environment before printing this email, you&gt;&gt; will save 5g of paper, 250mL of water and at least 35gm of CO2&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; ------------------&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!          <td class="email-body"><pre>I need to retest the redirect version but I expect it will work.Maybe I can work with Ed to create stable release branches or tags that onecould download from github.On Sat, May 26, 2018 at 12:21 PM Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Do the sounds work from a web browser using the redirect?&gt;&gt; As to making it easier for users: the best approach might be to make it&gt; easy for people to install an up-to-date version of the TrainCrew app into&gt; their JMRI installed version.  That lets updates to the two parts stay&gt; asynchronous.&gt;&gt; If Mr. Kapuscinski will maintain e.g. a downloadable .zip file, it's&gt; easy.  We can add an “Install or update TrainCrew” menu item to download&gt; and unpack.   (See i.e.&gt; <a href="http://www.codejava.net/java-se/file-io/programmatically-extract-a-zip-file-using-java" rel="nofollow">http://www.codejava.net/java-se/file-io/programmatically-extract-a-zip-file-using-java</a>&gt; but there are lots of other tutorials on doing this)  Happy to do that&gt; coding if somebody else will help test and document it.&gt;&gt; Or we could install it directly from GitHub:&gt; <a href="https://github.com/ekapus/TrainCrew/archive/master.zip" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/ekapus/TrainCrew/archive/master.zip</a>    That’s the&gt; current master branch, so it might always be the right one for a general&gt; user, which is why a blessed .zip file is better.&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; On May 26, 2018, at 9:07 AM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; OK, further "debug" / testing.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; I tried simply copying the TrainCrew directory tree into the web/ folder&gt; of a copy of JMRI on my computer.  I can now access the app from&gt; mycomputer:12080/web/TrainCrew/index.html and it is being served up locally&gt; instead of being redirected to conrail1285.com&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Sound is working just fine, at least as far as JMRI's web server is&gt; concerned.  I can visit the page from Chrome and hear just fine.  The lack&gt; of sound appears to be a limitation of WiThrottle's web browser.  Even&gt; without the sound, it is still a useful tool.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Which leads me to the question... assuming Mr. Kapuscinski is interested&gt; and agreeable (he's already licensed the source code as GPL3) would there&gt; be interest in adding this app to JMRI's web content so that folks can&gt; serve it locally from their JMRI computer, vs. loading down his&gt; conrail1285.com site? Just in mentioning this as a stand-alone (not JMRI&gt; related) feature, I've heard from folks who would like access to the app&gt; that doesn't require internet access.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; I'm thinking worst/simplest case, we take a snapshot of the app's code&gt; and add it to the web/ folder, then  update the snapshot either manually or&gt; in an automated way each time JMRI has a major release?  Maybe add a link&gt; to web/index.html (or wherever that home page is coming from).&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; - Mark&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; On Fri, May 25, 2018 at 11:14 PM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Hard to say about the sound. Might be that there’s some JavaScript&gt; that’s looking for sound file URLs that aren’t being redirected.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Unfortunately, the file-redirect approach only works with HTML, not for&gt; binary sound files. So you might need to use one other methods.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Or it might be something else entirely.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; On May 25, 2018, at 7:20 PM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Interesting result.  I created a new file web/traincrew.html that&gt; contains the content you (Bob) suggested as your third option.&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Accessing the JMRI webserver from within WiThrottle, IT WORKED.  Sort&gt; of. The sound effects don't play, but the web content shows up and the&gt; countdown timers work.&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Any idea why the sounds might not be playing?&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; On Fri, May 25, 2018 at 11:55 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; The JMRI web server is provided by Jetty, which provides a URL-rewrite&gt; engine that (probably) could do this:&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite-handler.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite-handler.html</a>&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; In some cases, it might be easier to handle it as a move (even though&gt; the original URL never really existed):&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/moved-context-handler.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/moved-context-handler.html</a>&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; And the simplest possible thing, perhaps too simple to actually work,&gt; is to have a web page in JMRI that does a specific redirect:&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN" "&gt; <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd&quot;>" rel="nofollow">http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd"&gt;</a>;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;html lang="en"&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;head&gt;&lt;TITLE&gt;JMRI: Redirected Page&lt;/TITLE&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;META HTTP-EQUIV="PRAGMA" CONTENT="NO-CACHE"&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;META HTTP-EQUIV="Refresh" CONTENT="0; URL=http:NewURL "&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;/head&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;body&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Would be interested to hear if any of those work (or don’t) for you.&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; On May 25, 2018, at 8:32 AM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Question:&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Does the JMRI web server have the ability to serve/redirect/whatever&gt; a third party site?&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; There's a cool app I just found called TrainCrew (&gt; <a href="http://traincrew.conrail1285.com" rel="nofollow">http://traincrew.conrail1285.com</a>) that provides a simple interface to&gt; simulate crew ops like handbrake sets, air brake charging, and other&gt; things, with sound effects.  I thought it would be handy when using&gt; WiThrottle to be able to access it as one of the JMRI web pages... which&gt; would (I assume) require it to be served up by the JMRI Web Server...&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; The source code is available (open source), so I *could* integrate it&gt; into JMRI as a "native" web page, but if the JMRI web server has the&gt; ability to redirect(?) the existing hosted version that might be easier, I&gt; dunno.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Thoughts?&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; - Mark&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; --&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;  Please consider the environment before printing this email, you will&gt; save 5g of paper, 250mL of water and at least 35gm of CO2&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!&gt; <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; --&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; &gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; &gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; &gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!          <td class="email-body"><pre>Do the sounds work from a web browser using the redirect?As to making it easier for users: the best approach might be to make it easy for people to install an up-to-date version of the TrainCrew app into their JMRI installed version.  That lets updates to the two parts stay asynchronous.  If Mr. Kapuscinski will maintain e.g. a downloadable .zip file, it's easy.  We can add an “Install or update TrainCrew” menu item to download and unpack.   (See i.e. <a href="http://www.codejava.net/java-se/file-io/programmatically-extract-a-zip-file-using-java" rel="nofollow">http://www.codejava.net/java-se/file-io/programmatically-extract-a-zip-file-using-java</a> but there are lots of other tutorials on doing this)  Happy to do that coding if somebody else will help test and document it.Or we could install it directly from GitHub:  <a href="https://github.com/ekapus/TrainCrew/archive/master.zip" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/ekapus/TrainCrew/archive/master.zip</a>    That’s the current master branch, so it might always be the right one for a general user, which is why a blessed .zip file is better.Bob&gt; On May 26, 2018, at 9:07 AM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; OK, further "debug" / testing.&gt; &gt; I tried simply copying the TrainCrew directory tree into the web/ folder of a copy of JMRI on my computer.  I can now access the app from mycomputer:12080/web/TrainCrew/index.html and it is being served up locally instead of being redirected to conrail1285.com&gt; &gt; Sound is working just fine, at least as far as JMRI's web server is concerned.  I can visit the page from Chrome and hear just fine.  The lack of sound appears to be a limitation of WiThrottle's web browser.  Even without the sound, it is still a useful tool.&gt; &gt; Which leads me to the question... assuming Mr. Kapuscinski is interested and agreeable (he's already licensed the source code as GPL3) would there be interest in adding this app to JMRI's web content so that folks can serve it locally from their JMRI computer, vs. loading down his conrail1285.com site? Just in mentioning this as a stand-alone (not JMRI related) feature, I've heard from folks who would like access to the app that doesn't require internet access.&gt; &gt; I'm thinking worst/simplest case, we take a snapshot of the app's code and add it to the web/ folder, then  update the snapshot either manually or in an automated way each time JMRI has a major release?  Maybe add a link to web/index.html (or wherever that home page is coming from).&gt; &gt; - Mark&gt; &gt; &gt; On Fri, May 25, 2018 at 11:14 PM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Hard to say about the sound. Might be that there’s some JavaScript that’s looking for sound file URLs that aren’t being redirected. &gt; &gt; Unfortunately, the file-redirect approach only works with HTML, not for binary sound files. So you might need to use one other methods. &gt; &gt; Or it might be something else entirely. &gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt; On May 25, 2018, at 7:20 PM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; Interesting result.  I created a new file web/traincrew.html that contains the content you (Bob) suggested as your third option.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Accessing the JMRI webserver from within WiThrottle, IT WORKED.  Sort of. The sound effects don't play, but the web content shows up and the countdown timers work.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Any idea why the sounds might not be playing?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; On Fri, May 25, 2018 at 11:55 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; The JMRI web server is provided by Jetty, which provides a URL-rewrite engine that (probably) could do this:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite-handler.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite-handler.html</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; In some cases, it might be easier to handle it as a move (even though the original URL never really existed):&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/moved-context-handler.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/moved-context-handler.html</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; And the simplest possible thing, perhaps too simple to actually work, is to have a web page in JMRI that does a specific redirect:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN" "<a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd&quot;>" rel="nofollow">http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd"&gt;</a>;&gt;&gt; &lt;html lang="en"&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;head&gt;&lt;TITLE&gt;JMRI: Redirected Page&lt;/TITLE&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;META HTTP-EQUIV="PRAGMA" CONTENT="NO-CACHE"&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;META HTTP-EQUIV="Refresh" CONTENT="0; URL=http:NewURL "&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;/head&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;body&gt;&gt;&gt; This page has been moved to &gt;&gt; &lt;A HREF=“http:NewURL"&gt;http:NewURL&lt;/a&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;/body&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;/html&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; (The new URL goes three places in that)&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Would be interested to hear if any of those work (or don’t) for you.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; On May 25, 2018, at 8:32 AM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Question:&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Does the JMRI web server have the ability to serve/redirect/whatever a third party site?&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; There's a cool app I just found called TrainCrew (<a href="http://traincrew.conrail1285.com" rel="nofollow">http://traincrew.conrail1285.com</a>) that provides a simple interface to simulate crew ops like handbrake sets, air brake charging, and other things, with sound effects.  I thought it would be handy when using WiThrottle to be able to access it as one of the JMRI web pages... which would (I assume) require it to be served up by the JMRI Web Server...&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; The source code is available (open source), so I *could* integrate it into JMRI as a "native" web page, but if the JMRI web server has the ability to redirect(?) the existing hosted version that might be easier, I dunno.&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Thoughts?&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; - Mark&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; -- &gt;&gt; &gt;  Please consider the environment before printing this email, you will save 5g of paper, 250mL of water and at least 35gm of CO2&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; &gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; &gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!
