         <td class="email-body"><pre>OK, further "debug" / testing.I tried simply copying the TrainCrew directory tree into the web/ folder ofa copy of JMRI on my computer.  I can now access the app frommycomputer:12080/web/TrainCrew/index.html and it is being served up locallyinstead of being redirected to conrail1285.comSound is working just fine, at least as far as JMRI's web server isconcerned.  I can visit the page from Chrome and hear just fine.  The lackof sound appears to be a limitation of WiThrottle's web browser.  Evenwithout the sound, it is still a useful tool.Which leads me to the question... assuming Mr. Kapuscinski is interestedand agreeable (he's already licensed the source code as GPL3) would therebe interest in adding this app to JMRI's web content so that folks canserve it locally from their JMRI computer, vs. loading down hisconrail1285.com site? Just in mentioning this as a stand-alone (not JMRIrelated) feature, I've heard from folks who would like access to the appthat doesn't require internet access.I'm thinking worst/simplest case, we take a snapshot of the app's code andadd it to the web/ folder, then  update the snapshot either manually or inan automated way each time JMRI has a major release?  Maybe add a link toweb/index.html (or wherever that home page is coming from).- MarkOn Fri, May 25, 2018 at 11:14 PM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Hard to say about the sound. Might be that there’s some JavaScript that’s&gt; looking for sound file URLs that aren’t being redirected.&gt;&gt; Unfortunately, the file-redirect approach only works with HTML, not for&gt; binary sound files. So you might need to use one other methods.&gt;&gt; Or it might be something else entirely.&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; On May 25, 2018, at 7:20 PM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; Interesting result. Sort of.&gt; The sound effects don't play, but the web content shows up and the&gt; countdown timers work.&gt;&gt; Any idea why the sounds might not be playing?&gt;&gt; On Fri, May 25, 2018 at 11:55 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; The JMRI web server is provided by Jetty, which provides a URL-rewrite&gt;&gt; engine that (probably) could do this:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite-handler.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite-handler.html</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; In some cases, it might be easier to handle it as a move (even though the&gt;&gt; original URL never really existed):&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/m" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/m</a>&gt;&gt; oved-context-handler.html&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; And the simplest possible thing, perhaps too simple to actually work, is&gt;&gt; to have a web page in JMRI that does a specific redirect:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN" "&gt;&gt;          <td class="email-body"><pre>Hard to say about the sound. Might be that there’s some JavaScript that’s looking for sound file URLs that aren’t being redirected. Unfortunately, the file-redirect approach only works with HTML, not for binary sound files. So you might need to use one other methods. Or it might be something else entirely. Bob&gt; On May 25, 2018, at 7:20 PM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Interesting result.  I created a new file web/traincrew.html that contains the content you (Bob) suggested as your third option.&gt; &gt; Accessing the JMRI webserver from within WiThrottle, IT WORKED.  Sort of. The sound effects don't play, but the web content shows up and the countdown timers work.&gt; &gt; Any idea why the sounds might not be playing?&gt; &gt;&gt; On Fri, May 25, 2018 at 11:55 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; The JMRI web server is provided by Jetty, which provides a URL-rewrite engine that (probably) could do this:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite-handler.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite-handler.html</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; In some cases, it might be easier to handle it as a move (even though the original URL never really existed):&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/moved-context-handler.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/moved-context-handler.html</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; And the simplest possible thing, perhaps too simple to actually work, is to have a web page in JMRI that does a specific redirect:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN" "<a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd&quot;>" rel="nofollow">http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd"&gt;</a>;&gt;&gt; &lt;html lang="en"&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;head&gt;&lt;TITLE&gt;JMRI: Redirected Page&lt;/TITLE&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;META HTTP-EQUIV="PRAGMA" CONTENT="NO-CACHE"&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;META HTTP-EQUIV="Refresh" CONTENT="0; URL=http:NewURL "&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;/head&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;body&gt;&gt;&gt; This page has been moved to &gt;&gt; &lt;A HREF=“http:NewURL"&gt;http:NewURL&lt;/a&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;/body&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;/html&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; (The new URL goes three places in that)&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Would be interested to hear if any of those work (or don’t) for you.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; On May 25, 2018, at 8:32 AM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Question:&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Does the JMRI web server have the ability to serve/redirect/whatever a third party site?&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; There's a cool app I just found called TrainCrew (<a href="http://traincrew.conrail1285.com" rel="nofollow">http://traincrew.conrail1285.com</a>) that provides a simple interface to simulate crew ops like handbrake sets, air brake charging, and other things, with sound effects.  I thought it would be handy when using WiThrottle to be able to access it as one of the JMRI web pages... which would (I assume) require it to be served up by the JMRI Web Server...&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; The source code is available (open source), so I *could* integrate it into JMRI as a "native" web page, but if the JMRI web server has the ability to redirect(?) the existing hosted version that might be easier, I dunno.&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Thoughts?&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; - Mark&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; -- &gt;&gt; &gt;  Please consider the environment before printing this email, you will save 5g of paper, 250mL of water and at least 35gm of CO2&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; &gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; &gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!            <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36326163/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Web Server capabilities?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-05-25 15:55:34</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>The JMRI web server is provided by Jetty, which provides a URL-rewrite engine that (probably) could do this:<a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite-handler.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/rewrite-handler.html</a>In some cases, it might be easier to handle it as a move (even though the original URL never really existed):<a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/moved-context-handler.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/9.0.6.v20130930/moved-context-handler.html</a>And the simplest possible thing, perhaps too simple to actually work, is to have a web page in JMRI that does a specific redirect:&lt;!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN" "<a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd&quot;>" rel="nofollow">http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd"&gt;</a>;&lt;html lang="en"&gt;&lt;head&gt;&lt;TITLE&gt;JMRI: Redirected Page&lt;/TITLE&gt;&lt;META HTTP-EQUIV="PRAGMA" CONTENT="NO-CACHE"&gt;&lt;META HTTP-EQUIV="Refresh" CONTENT="0; URL=http:NewURL "&gt;&lt;/head&gt;&lt;body&gt;This page has been moved to &lt;A HREF=“http:NewURL"&gt;http:NewURL&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/body&gt;&lt;/html&gt;(The new URL goes three places in that)Would be interested to hear if any of those work (or don’t) for you.Bob&gt; On May 25, 2018, at 8:32 AM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Question:&gt; &gt; Does the JMRI web server have the ability to serve/redirect/whatever a third party site?&gt; &gt; There's a cool app I just found called TrainCrew (<a href="http://traincrew.conrail1285.com" rel="nofollow">http://traincrew.conrail1285.com</a>) that provides a simple interface to simulate crew ops like handbrake sets, air brake charging, and other things, with sound effects.  I thought it would be handy when using WiThrottle to be able to access it as one of the JMRI web pages... which would (I assume) require it to be served up by the JMRI Web Server...&gt; &gt; The source code is available (open source), so I *could* integrate it into JMRI as a "native" web page, but if the JMRI web server has the ability to redirect(?) the existing hosted version that might be easier, I dunno.&gt; &gt; Thoughts?&gt; &gt; - Mark&gt; &gt; &gt; -- &gt;  Please consider the environment before printing this email, you will save 5g of paper, 250mL of water and at least 35gm of CO2&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Question:Does the JMRI web server have the ability to serve/redirect/whatever athird party site?There's a cool app I just found called TrainCrew (<a href="http://traincrew.conrail1285.com" rel="nofollow">http://traincrew.conrail1285.com</a>) that provides a simple interface tosimulate crew ops like handbrake sets, air brake charging, and otherthings, with sound effects.  I thought it would be handy when usingWiThrottle to be able to access it as one of the JMRI web pages... whichwould (I assume) require it to be served up by the JMRI Web Server...The source code is available (open source), so I *could* integrate it intoJMRI as a "native" web page, but if the JMRI web server has the ability toredirect(?) the existing hosted version that might be easier, I dunno.Thoughts?- Mark--  Please consider the environment before printing this email, you will save5g of paper, 250mL of water and at least 35gm of CO2</pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36323550/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-05-22 17:02:34</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I think I'd feel better with the case of 'convenience' forms converting tothe standard form on entry. The NCE example for the AIU is one of these, itconverts.I'd like to think that 99%+ of the time, they have user names and wouldnever be normally presented with whichever internal form exists. But I knowthat is not near that level and likely never will be. But the upside is anyconversions help to push the belief that user names are the way they shouldgo. It would mean they have to see (whichever form) of system name less andless of the time.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36323514/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dave Sand &lt;dave@sa...&gt; - 2018-05-22 16:13:24</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>With pick lists, combo boxes and the emphasis on user names, multiple system name formats such as CMRI become less of an issue.When manual entry is allowed, appropriate checks have to be in place.  The open question is what action should be taken.  Logix Conditionals notify the user of the bad name.  Layout Editor accepts the name (with the text box in red), creates an orphan icon and generates a NPE.  I am not aware of any process which substitutes the proper system name.  My preference is to reject with notification.Dave Sand&gt; On May 22, 2018, at 9:08 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; On May 21, 2018, at 1:19 PM, Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; The current behavior is that the sensor table allows one or the other form, but rejects an attempt to add the alternate format later.  A getSensor returns null if the matching format is not used.  A provideSensor with the alternate format generates a java.lang.IllegalArgumentException argument exception due to a create failure if the primary format exists.  The conditional editor displays a sensor not found message if the wrong format is keyed in.&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks!&gt; &gt; Is this how we want these to behave?  It’s basically leaving to the user to remember which form was used when creating the Sensor/Turnout/etc&gt; &gt; Some other cases, e.g. MERG and OLCB et al, have lots of alternatives for entering a form: leading zeros or not, optional prefixes, etc.&gt; &gt; Another alternative would be a have a canonical form, which is what JMRI always displays. If you enter a different form, it gets changes right then, so the different forms are just for convenience of entry.&gt; &gt; The C/MRI case is a bit unique, as the CSnnBnnnn format is _needed_ in rare cases, but most people prefer the CSnnnnn form.  The CSnnnnn form could be the canonical one where it works, and in the rare cases where CSnnBnnnn is needed it could be used.&gt; &gt; Right now, C/MRI does a bit of that.  If you enter 09003 (i.e. node 9 with leading zero) in the Add panel, it becomes CS9003 (no leading zero). But if you enter 9B4, that appears in the table as CS9B4 (no leading zeros); 9B005 becomes 9B5&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt; &gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36323499">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36323499/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@ch...&gt; - 2018-05-22 15:55:12</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I use the canonical form in my C/MRI panel development to promote consistency and ease of support.I agree with Ken, a C/MRI node with more than 999 devices of a particular type would be very unique.  The 999 limit is not really an impediment as the node count can be large.  Depending upon the RS-422/485 driver chips used, 32 or 255 is the maximum number of network loads (nodes) which can be supported.In a new client's panel, one which he was doing the table entries, were duplicate un-detected node zero sensor entries.  They appeared to be allowed when not filling out the full bit number with leading zeros.  Subsequent panel loads would throw an error and stop the load process.  Forcing the bit numbers to be three digits was the work around.I planned to include in the next round of C/MRI documentation, some tips on forming system and user names which follow my field use and experience.  In my CMRI/JMRI clinic for NMRA KC I will be using these concepts.  All of the table examples in the clinic slides use the CTnnBBB/CSnnBBB format.If we want to have a consistent canonical form be the result of valid shorthand data entries, I would vote to have the bit number be leading zero filled, at least in the C/MRI case.  I'm not sure how this would affect managers which deal with DCC accessory addresses.Chuck CataniaMRCSOn May 22, 2018, at 7:08 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; On May 21, 2018, at 1:19 PM, Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; The current behavior is that the sensor table allows one or the other form, but rejects an attempt to add the alternate format later.  A getSensor returns null if the matching format is not used.  A provideSensor with the alternate format generates a java.lang.IllegalArgumentException argument exception due to a create failure if the primary format exists.  The conditional editor displays a sensor not found message if the wrong format is keyed in.&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks!&gt; &gt; Is this how we want these to behave?  It’s basically leaving to the user to remember which form was used when creating the Sensor/Turnout/etc&gt; &gt; Some other cases, e.g. MERG and OLCB et al, have lots of alternatives for entering a form: leading zeros or not, optional prefixes, etc.&gt; &gt; Another alternative would be a have a canonical form, which is what JMRI always displays. If you enter a different form, it gets changes right then, so the different forms are just for convenience of entry.&gt; &gt; The C/MRI case is a bit unique, as the CSnnBnnnn format is _needed_ in rare cases, but most people prefer the CSnnnnn form.  The CSnnnnn form could be the canonical one where it works, and in the rare cases where CSnnBnnnn is needed it could be used.&gt; &gt; Right now, C/MRI does a bit of that.  If you enter 09003 (i.e. node 9 with leading zero) in the Add panel, it becomes CS9003 (no leading zero). But if you enter 9B4, that appears in the table as CS9B4 (no leading zeros); 9B005 becomes 9B5&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt; &gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36323400/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>

           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-05-22 14:09:12</small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; On May 21, 2018, at 1:19 PM, Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; The current behavior is that the sensor table allows one or the other form, but rejects an attempt to add the alternate format later.  A getSensor returns null if the matching format is not used.  A provideSensor with the alternate format generates a java.lang.IllegalArgumentException argument exception due to a create failure if the primary format exists.  The conditional editor displays a sensor not found message if the wrong format is keyed in.&gt; Thanks!Is this how we want these to behave?  It’s basically leaving to the user to remember which form was used when creating the Sensor/Turnout/etcSome other cases, e.g. MERG and OLCB et al, have lots of alternatives for entering a form: leading zeros or not, optional prefixes, etc.Another alternative would be a have a canonical form, which is what JMRI always displays. If you enter a different form, it gets changes right then, so the different forms are just for convenience of entry.The C/MRI case is a bit unique, as the CSnnBnnnn format is _needed_ in rare cases, but most people prefer the CSnnnnn form.  The CSnnnnn form could be the canonical one where it works, and in the rare cases where CSnnBnnnn is needed it could be used.Right now, C/MRI does a bit of that.  If you enter 09003 (i.e. node 9 with leading zero) in the Add panel, it becomes CS9003 (no leading zero). But if you enter 9B4, that appears in the table as CS9B4 (no leading zeros); 9B005 becomes 9B5Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36323023/">Re: [Jmri-developers] AbstractMRTrafficController question</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-05-22 05:57:34</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>The place to start is the JavaDoc: <a href="http://www.jmri.org/JavaDoc/doc/jmri/jmrix/AbstractMRTrafficController.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org/JavaDoc/doc/jmri/jmrix/AbstractMRTrafficController.html</a>That gives you links to the classes that use it, and shows the abstract methods you’re supposed to implement. I think <a href="http://www.jmri.org/JavaDoc/doc/jmri/jmrix/easydcc/EasyDccTrafficController.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org/JavaDoc/doc/jmri/jmrix/easydcc/EasyDccTrafficController.html</a>  might be the simplest case, although it doesn’t poll for anything. Perhaps that’s too simple?The <a href="http://www.jmri.org/JavaDoc/doc/jmri/jmrix/nce/NceTrafficController.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org/JavaDoc/doc/jmri/jmrix/nce/NceTrafficController.html</a> polls, but it’s got some complicated logic in it to decide whether to poll the AIU or have them send unsolicited messages. If the issue is where messages go when received, then consider how simply you can implement these methods:abstract protected void forwardMessage(AbstractMRListener client, AbstractMRMessage m) - just forward it, nothing elseabstract protected void forwardReply(AbstractMRListener client, AbstractMRReply m); - handles reply to a sent message (not a poll reply_abstract protected AbstractMRListener pollReplyHandler()  - handles the reply to a poll, not a sent message.They should be _really_ simple.Bob&gt; On May 21, 2018, at 11:45 AM, Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Hi Bob,&gt; &gt; &gt; The code is indeed on the JMRI master branch.&gt; &gt; Kevin Dickerson created the original Tams code and I enhanced it.&gt; &gt; The main TamsTrafficController message logic was done by Kevin and I mainly enhanced the message decoding and implemented sending of binary messages to greatly enhance the performance.&gt; &gt; I didn't, still don't to certain degree, really understand what the generic AbstractMRTrafficController could do so I started adding logic in the TamsTrafficController to most probably do what the AbstractMRTrafficController does off the shelf.&gt; &gt; So I'm looking for a basic example to correctly use the AbstractMRTrafficController code to send/receive messages in a synchronous way.&gt; &gt; With that I hope to be able to rework the TamsTrafficController so it does what it needs to do.&gt; &gt; The sending of messages works.&gt; &gt; Alas when e.g. receiving Sensor poll replies these also get forwarded to e.g. the TamsPowerManager etc.&gt; &gt; &gt; I'm pretty sure things can be much simpler and better if done correctly.&gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks,&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Jan&gt; &gt; &gt; Op 21/05/18 om 20:35 schreef jmri-developers-request@...:&gt;&gt; Send Jmri-developers mailing list submissions to&gt;&gt; 	jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; or, via email, send a message with subject or body 'help' to&gt;&gt; 	jmri-developers-request@...&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; You can reach the person managing the list at&gt;&gt; 	jmri-developers-owner@...&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; When replying, please edit your Subject line so it is more specific&gt;&gt; than "Re: Contents of Jmri-developers digest..."&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Today's Topics:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;    1. Re: AbstractMRTrafficController question (Bob Jacobsen)&gt;&gt;    2. Re: First 4.11.6 files available (Dick Bronson)&gt;&gt;    3. Re: "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can 	we stop? (Dave Sand)&gt;&gt;    4. Re: 4.11.6 hanging during startup (Ken Cameron)&gt;&gt;    5. Re: 4.11.6 hanging during startup (Bob Jacobsen)&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ----------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Message: 1&gt;&gt; Date: Mon, 21 May 2018 08:27:13 -0700&gt;&gt; From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;&gt;&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers&gt;&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] AbstractMRTrafficController question&gt;&gt; Message-ID: &lt;84307756-A29B-43F6-AEA4-799D0464EC80@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I can take a look in a day or two.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Is this the code that?s on JMRI/JMRI/master in GitHub? Or some other branch?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Also, could you give me an example of a message sequence that?s not working, so I can create a test?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Thanks!&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Op 21 mei 2018 11:53:08 schreef Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt;:&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Hi all, but most probably Bob Jacobsen and/or Bob Bender,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm trying to get my head around the simplest way to change the&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; TamsTrafficController, which extends AbstractMRTrafficController, so&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; that it works in truly synchronised mode with the Tams MasterControl CS&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; in normal operations.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The message format is the old (Uhlenbrock) P50x, both ASCII messages and&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; binary messages.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Via the Serial/USB port JMRI sends a message and must get a reply in&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; less than 100 ms.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; If received then the next message can be sent if not then wait for time&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; out and send the next message.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Normally unsolicited messages from the CS are not allowed (or at least&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; not expected).&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think the generic AbstractMRTrafficController already supports this&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; off the shelf.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The current implementation correctly handles the various incoming&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; messaged but they are not forwarded to the appropriate listeners and I&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; think I simply made an overcomplicated mess of it.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Any clarification or help would be highly welcome.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; I was off line over the weekend.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I am happy to report that the issue with OPs mode reading tab of our&gt;&gt; LocoNet based decoders seems to have been corrected. The new&gt;&gt; &lt;mode&gt;LOCONETOPSBOARD&lt;/mode&gt; option seems to now be working and the&gt;&gt; appropriate tab is there and operational again.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; On 05/19/2018 04:45 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; First JMRI 4.11.6 files are available in the usual way at:&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="http://builds.jmri.org/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.6" rel="nofollow">http://builds.jmri.org/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.6</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Feedback appreciated. I would like to release this tomorrow if the files are OK.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Message: 3&gt;&gt; Date: Mon, 21 May 2018 12:47:45 -0500&gt;&gt; From: Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt;&gt;&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers&gt;&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can&gt;&gt; 	we stop?&gt;&gt; Message-ID: &lt;4D3F57FA-AFF9-4F7B-AE01-2681E11DDB44@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain; charset="utf-8"&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; As an exercise, I decided to ?normalize? the Logix create process.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; This involves taking the implicit normalization and validation in 6 processes, using 4 system name prefixes, and consolidating them in the Logix manager.  The calling routines are simpler and are subject to a common set of rules.  Any future or third party processes requesting a Logix would automatically use the new process.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; The only exception is the panel xml file load process has to bypass normalization since existing Logix names cannot be changed.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; This is the current rule set for Logix system names:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;     @CheckReturnValue&gt;&gt;     @Override&gt;&gt;     public @Nonnull&gt;&gt;     String normalizeSystemName(@Nonnull String inputName) throws BadSystemNameException {&gt;&gt;         String sName = inputName.toUpperCase().trim();&gt;&gt;         if (sName.startsWith("IX") &amp;&amp; sName.length() &gt; 2) return sName;&gt;&gt;         if (sName.startsWith("RTX") &amp;&amp; sName.length() &gt; 3) return sName;&gt;&gt;         if (sName.equals("SYS")) return sName;&gt;&gt;         if (sName.startsWith("USS CTC")) return sName;&gt;&gt;         if (sName.equals("IX") || sName.equals("RTX")) {&gt;&gt;             // name equals prefix&gt;&gt;             throw new BadSystemNameException();&gt;&gt;         }&gt;&gt;         return "IX" + sName;&gt;&gt;     }&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I think this approach makes for ?smarter? handling of Logix system names.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I don?t think we should undo what has been done so far and revert to adhoc normalization.  That means moving ahead, preferably one bean at a time to keep the scope manageable.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Dave Sand&gt;&gt; -------------- next part --------------&gt;&gt; An HTML attachment was scrubbed...&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Message: 4&gt;&gt; Date: Mon, 21 May 2018 14:01:44 -0400&gt;&gt; From: "Ken Cameron" &lt;kcameron@...&gt;&gt;&gt; To: "'Discussions between JMRI developers'"&gt;&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] 4.11.6 hanging during startup&gt;&gt; Message-ID: &lt;00a001d3f12d$ca0824b0$5e186e10$@twcny.rr.com&gt;&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain;	charset="us-ascii"&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob,&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I've got a bunch of different profiles, some don't have LocoNet, I'll try&gt;&gt; them. I did create a brand new profile which started up fine.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Should I setup with non-simulator connections or just try simulators for&gt;&gt; other vendors than Digitrax? On ones that still hang, do you want dumps from&gt;&gt; them too? Or look at the dump, compare to your 'meaningful' list, and report&gt;&gt; ones that seem to be hanging somewhere else?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Message: 5&gt;&gt; Date: Mon, 21 May 2018 11:35:46 -0700&gt;&gt; From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;&gt;&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers&gt;&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] 4.11.6 hanging during startup&gt;&gt; Message-ID: &lt;C7B3EE96-49C6-4448-9CB9-5933CA4EF8C4@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I?m away from hardware until Thursday.  If you could try whatever profiles are straight-forward to test, I?d appreciate it.  Full thread dumps are most useful, as sometimes it takes a bit of digging to see what went wrong.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Thanks.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; On May 21, 2018, at 11:01 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Bob,&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; I've got a bunch of different profiles, some don't have LocoNet, I'll try&gt;&gt;&gt; them. I did create a brand new profile which started up fine.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Should I setup with non-simulator connections or just try simulators for&gt;&gt;&gt; other vendors than Digitrax? On ones that still hang, do you want dumps from&gt;&gt;&gt; them too? Or look at the dump, compare to your 'meaningful' list, and report&gt;&gt;&gt; ones that seem to be hanging somewhere else?&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Subject: Digest Footer&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; End of Jmri-developers Digest, Vol 142, Issue 21&gt;&gt; ************************************************&gt; --Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Egbert,That was CMRI about the 'more than 999 pins' on a node had to use the 'B'format. Otherwise how could you tell that LS21456 mean pint 1456 on board 2vs ping 456 on board 21. Only the option for LS2B1456 would make it clear.But I have no clue what the system would retain for this! But that wouldrequire a whole bunch of DOUT or DIN cards on one poor little USIC node. Youwould need at least 31 boards off the one mast node!-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36322862/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: dcc2 &lt;dcc2@eb...&gt; - 2018-05-21 21:46:59</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/D2F8762E-8AA7-48AD-AB8E-1602DCFD50B9%40ebroerse.nl/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Some of this is documented in the "Entry Format Summary” table on the Naming documentation page <a href="http://jmri.org/help/en/html/doc/Technical/Names.shtml" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/help/en/html/doc/Technical/Names.shtml</a>including modification from the entered format to a (common) stored format. If changes are implemented, please also include the results in this cross system table which I synchronised with each of the hardware system help pages.While writing the manager specific entry tool tips I noted that the hardware help pages in some cases suggested entering in a form that is not validated nor stored in the table. I added a few for MERG; the others are described in the table mentioned above.I remember there was one particular system that only allowed nodes over 999 to be entered using something like the “B” entry format, so in that case it seems useful to allow it.Egbert&gt; Op 21 mei 2018, om 21:54 heeft jmri-developers-request@... het volgende geschreven:&gt; &gt; Van: Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@... &lt;mailto:cpcrr@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Onderwerp: Antw.: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?&gt; Datum: 21 mei 2018 om 21:54:42 CEST&gt; Aan: Discussions between JMRI developers &lt;jmri-developers@... &lt;mailto:jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob,&gt; It may depend on the connection hardware requirements.  The potential impact on existing panels needs to be considered.&gt; &gt; For new panel work, I enforce two digit C/MRI node addresses and use leading zeros in bit numbers.  For me, this provides a clearer visual name scheme, especially for multiple C/MRI connection environments.  I only use User names in Logix conditionals.  &gt; &gt; In existing panels where classic node addresses 0,1,2, etc. are present, the User name can mask any system name ambiguity.   For most users with classic C/MRI nodes, single digit node addresses are easier to set in the DIP switches.&gt; &gt; Chuck Catania&gt; &gt; On May 21, 2018, at 11:43 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; I’m currently trying sort out some Really Weird Problems due to somebody defining a C/MRI sensor as CS2B23 in the panel file, but then referring to both CS2B23 and CS2023 in Logix Conditionals. (Those two both refer to the same Sensor, i.e. same input pin)</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36322810/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>The alternate forms used in the Conditionals must be old.The current behavior is that the sensor table allows one or the other form, but rejects an attempt to add the alternate format later.  A getSensor returns null if the matching format is not used.  A provideSensor with the alternate format generates a java.lang.IllegalArgumentException argument exception due to a create failure if the primary format exists.  The conditional editor displays a sensor not found message if the wrong format is keyed in.Dave Sand&gt; On May 21, 2018, at 1:43 PM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I’m currently trying sort out some Really Weird Problems due to somebody defining a C/MRI sensor as CS2B23 in the panel file, but then referring to both CS2B23 and CS2023 in Logix Conditionals. (Those two both refer to the same Sensor, i.e. same input pin)&gt; &gt; I’m not even sure how this can happen with the current code for editing Logix. Perhaps it’s a hold over from earlier code?  &gt; &gt; There are lots of other places where a Sensor, Turnout or Light can have more than one valid system name, so it’s not just C/MRI.&gt; &gt; What do we need to ensure works here? Can we force names entered one way into a standard form, or do we have to keep them around as entered? &gt; &gt; Bob&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi Bob,The code is indeed on the JMRI master branch.Kevin Dickerson created the original Tams code and I enhanced it.The main TamsTrafficController message logic was done by Kevin and I mainly enhanced the message decoding and implemented sending of binary messages to greatly enhance the performance.I didn't, still don't to certain degree, really understand what the generic AbstractMRTrafficController could do so I started adding logic in the TamsTrafficController to most probably do what the AbstractMRTrafficController does off the shelf.So I'm looking for a basic example to correctly use the AbstractMRTrafficController code to send/receive messages in a synchronous way.With that I hope to be able to rework the TamsTrafficController so it does what it needs to do.The sending of messages works.Alas when e.g. receiving Sensor poll replies these also get forwarded to e.g. the TamsPowerManager etc.I'm pretty sure things can be much simpler and better if done correctly.Thanks,JanOp 21/05/18 om 20:35 schreef jmri-developers-request@...:&gt; Send Jmri-developers mailing list submissions to&gt; 	jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; To subscribe or unsubscribe via the World Wide Web, visit&gt; 	<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; or, via email, send a message with subject or body 'help' to&gt; 	jmri-developers-request@...&gt;&gt; You can reach the person managing the list at&gt; 	jmri-developers-owner@...&gt;&gt; When replying, please edit your Subject line so it is more specific&gt; than "Re: Contents of Jmri-developers digest..."&gt;&gt;&gt; Today's Topics:&gt;&gt;     1. Re: AbstractMRTrafficController question (Bob Jacobsen)&gt;     2. Re: First 4.11.6 files available (Dick Bronson)&gt;     3. Re: "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can 	we stop? (Dave Sand)&gt;     4. Re: 4.11.6 hanging during startup (Ken Cameron)&gt;     5. Re: 4.11.6 hanging during startup (Bob Jacobsen)&gt;&gt;&gt; ----------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Message: 1&gt; Date: Mon, 21 May 2018 08:27:13 -0700&gt; From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] AbstractMRTrafficController question&gt; Message-ID: &lt;84307756-A29B-43F6-AEA4-799D0464EC80@...&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8&gt;&gt; I can take a look in a day or two.&gt;&gt; Is this the code that?s on JMRI/JMRI/master in GitHub? Or some other branch?&gt;&gt; Also, could you give me an example of a message sequence that?s not working, so I can create a test?&gt;&gt; Thanks!&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt; Op 21 mei 2018 11:53:08 schreef Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt;:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Hi all, but most probably Bob Jacobsen and/or Bob Bender,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm trying to get my head around the simplest way to change the&gt;&gt;&gt; TamsTrafficController, which extends AbstractMRTrafficController, so&gt;&gt;&gt; that it works in truly synchronised mode with the Tams MasterControl CS&gt;&gt;&gt; in normal operations.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The message format is the old (Uhlenbrock) P50x, both ASCII messages and&gt;&gt;&gt; binary messages.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Via the Serial/USB port JMRI sends a message and must get a reply in&gt;&gt;&gt; less than 100 ms.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; If received then the next message can be sent if not then wait for time&gt;&gt;&gt; out and send the next message.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Normally unsolicited messages from the CS are not allowed (or at least&gt;&gt;&gt; not expected).&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think the generic AbstractMRTrafficController already supports this&gt;&gt;&gt; off the shelf.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The current implementation correctly handles the various incoming&gt;&gt;&gt; messaged but they are not forwarded to the appropriate listeners and I&gt;&gt;&gt; think I simply made an overcomplicated mess of it.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Any clarification or help would be highly welcome.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; Message: 2&gt; Date: Mon, 21 May 2018 11:50:44 -0400&gt; From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt;&gt; To: jmri-developers@...&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] First 4.11.6 files available&gt; Message-ID: &lt;12388dca-a80f-08aa-4d67-49b39ec533b6@...&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8; format=flowed&gt;&gt; Bob,&gt; Sorry for the delay in responding. I was off line over the weekend.&gt;&gt; I am happy to report that the issue with OPs mode reading tab of our&gt; LocoNet based decoders seems to have been corrected. The new&gt; &lt;mode&gt;LOCONETOPSBOARD&lt;/mode&gt; option seems to now be working and the&gt; appropriate tab is there and operational again.&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt; On 05/19/2018 04:45 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt; First JMRI 4.11.6 files are available in the usual way at:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="http://builds.jmri.org/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.6" rel="nofollow">http://builds.jmri.org/jenkins/job/TestReleases/job/4.11.6</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Feedback appreciated. I would like to release this tomorrow if the files are OK.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; Message: 3&gt; Date: Mon, 21 May 2018 12:47:45 -0500&gt; From: Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt;&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can&gt; 	we stop?&gt; Message-ID: &lt;4D3F57FA-AFF9-4F7B-AE01-2681E11DDB44@...&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain; charset="utf-8"&gt;&gt; As an exercise, I decided to ?normalize? the Logix create process.&gt;&gt; This involves taking the implicit normalization and validation in 6 processes, using 4 system name prefixes, and consolidating them in the Logix manager.  The calling routines are simpler and are subject to a common set of rules.  Any future or third party processes requesting a Logix would automatically use the new process.&gt;&gt; The only exception is the panel xml file load process has to bypass normalization since existing Logix names cannot be changed.&gt;&gt; This is the current rule set for Logix system names:&gt;&gt;      @CheckReturnValue&gt;      @Override&gt;      public @Nonnull&gt;      String normalizeSystemName(@Nonnull String inputName) throws BadSystemNameException {&gt;          String sName = inputName.toUpperCase().trim();&gt;          if (sName.startsWith("IX") &amp;&amp; sName.length() &gt; 2) return sName;&gt;          if (sName.startsWith("RTX") &amp;&amp; sName.length() &gt; 3) return sName;&gt;          if (sName.equals("SYS")) return sName;&gt;          if (sName.startsWith("USS CTC")) return sName;&gt;          if (sName.equals("IX") || sName.equals("RTX")) {&gt;              // name equals prefix&gt;              throw new BadSystemNameException();&gt;          }&gt;          return "IX" + sName;&gt;      }&gt;&gt; I think this approach makes for ?smarter? handling of Logix system names.&gt;&gt;&gt; I don?t think we should undo what has been done so far and revert to adhoc normalization.  That means moving ahead, preferably one bean at a time to keep the scope manageable.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Dave Sand&gt; -------------- next part --------------&gt; An HTML attachment was scrubbed...&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; Message: 4&gt; Date: Mon, 21 May 2018 14:01:44 -0400&gt; From: "Ken Cameron" &lt;kcameron@...&gt;&gt; To: "'Discussions between JMRI developers'"&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] 4.11.6 hanging during startup&gt; Message-ID: &lt;00a001d3f12d$ca0824b0$5e186e10$@twcny.rr.com&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain;	charset="us-ascii"&gt;&gt; Bob,&gt;&gt; I've got a bunch of different profiles, some don't have LocoNet, I'll try&gt; them. I did create a brand new profile which started up fine.&gt;&gt; Should I setup with non-simulator connections or just try simulators for&gt; other vendors than Digitrax? On ones that still hang, do you want dumps from&gt; them too? Or look at the dump, compare to your 'meaningful' list, and report&gt; ones that seem to be hanging somewhere else?&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; Message: 5&gt; Date: Mon, 21 May 2018 11:35:46 -0700&gt; From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] 4.11.6 hanging during startup&gt; Message-ID: &lt;C7B3EE96-49C6-4448-9CB9-5933CA4EF8C4@...&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8&gt;&gt; I?m away from hardware until Thursday.            <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36322793/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@ch...&gt; - 2018-05-21 19:54:51</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob,It may depend on the connection hardware requirements.  The potential impact on existing panels needs to be considered.For new panel work, I enforce two digit C/MRI node addresses and use leading zeros in bit numbers.  For me, this provides a clearer visual name scheme, especially for multiple C/MRI connection environments.  I only use User names in Logix conditionals.  In existing panels where classic node addresses 0,1,2, etc. are present, the User name can mask any system name ambiguity.   For most users with classic C/MRI nodes, single digit node addresses are easier to set in the DIP switches.Chuck CataniaOn May 21, 2018, at 11:43 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; I’m currently trying sort out some Really Weird Problems due to somebody defining a C/MRI sensor as CS2B23 in the panel file, but then referring to both CS2B23 and CS2023 in Logix Conditionals. (Those two both refer to the same Sensor, i.e. same input pin)&gt; &gt; I’m not even sure how this can happen with the current code for editing Logix. Perhaps it’s a hold over from earlier code?  &gt; &gt; There are lots of other places where a Sensor, Turnout or Light can have more than one valid system name, so it’s not just C/MRI.&gt; &gt; What do we need to ensure works here? Can we force names entered one way into a standard form, or do we have to keep them around as entered? &gt; &gt; Bob&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36322784/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-05-21 19:15:20</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob,Just to make sure I'm reading right, the one form (usual seen) is node 2,pin 23 input as CS2023. The other form is keeping the form of node 2 and pin23 by using the 'B' in the system name.To my view, we should be doing one of two things when there are multipleways to make up the same physical destination:1. Preserve the form used first by the user, which would then throw an error(duplicate or invalid or something) if the other form was used. Effectivelyforcing a user to pick a form, and then be consistent2. . Another case I'm thinking is NCE code. It has a similar node and pinform for addresses. But there it translated it into the single number form,losing the original form entered by the user. Follow like the NCE sensorsdo, it converts the one form to a single internal representation.It would make it simpler in the xml check if the 'saved' version onlysupported one form. But in the case of #1, how would the xml check know thatit has to enforce a 'one or the other' within the file after (it somehow)figured out which form the user is using? So it sounds like #2 would be moresensible.Now if the conversion to the single form was part of the normalize, the usercould continue to enter whichever fit their fancy at the time, but thesystem would end up with the right answer either way.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36322761/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I’m currently trying sort out some Really Weird Problems due to somebody defining a C/MRI sensor as CS2B23 in the panel file, but then referring to both CS2B23 and CS2023 in Logix Conditionals. (Those two both refer to the same Sensor, i.e. same input pin)I’m not even sure how this can happen with the current code for editing Logix. Perhaps it’s a hold over from earlier code?  There are lots of other places where a Sensor, Turnout or Light can have more than one valid system name, so it’s not just C/MRI.What do we need to ensure works here? Can we force names entered one way into a standard form, or do we have to keep them around as entered? Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>

          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36322718/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dave Sand &lt;dave@sa...&gt; - 2018-05-21 17:47:56</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/4D3F57FA-AFF9-4F7B-AE01-2681E11DDB44%40sandsys.org/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>As an exercise, I decided to “normalize” the Logix create process.This involves taking the implicit normalization and validation in 6 processes, using 4 system name prefixes, and consolidating them in the Logix manager.  The calling routines are simpler and are subject to a common set of rules.  Any future or third party processes requesting a Logix would automatically use the new process.The only exception is the panel xml file load process has to bypass normalization since existing Logix names cannot be changed.This is the current rule set for Logix system names:    @CheckReturnValue    @Override    public @Nonnull    String normalizeSystemName(@Nonnull String inputName) throws BadSystemNameException {        String sName = inputName.toUpperCase().trim();        if (sName.startsWith("IX") &amp;&amp; sName.length() &gt; 2) return sName;        if (sName.startsWith("RTX") &amp;&amp; sName.length() &gt; 3) return sName;        if (sName.equals("SYS")) return sName;        if (sName.startsWith("USS CTC")) return sName;        if (sName.equals("IX") || sName.equals("RTX")) {            // name equals prefix            throw new BadSystemNameException();        }        return "IX" + sName;    }I think this approach makes for “smarter” handling of Logix system names.  I don’t think we should undo what has been done so far and revert to adhoc normalization.  That means moving ahead, preferably one bean at a time to keep the scope manageable.Dave Sand</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36322624">
       <tbody>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I can take a look in a day or two.Is this the code that’s on JMRI/JMRI/master in GitHub? Or some other branch?Also, could you give me an example of a message sequence that’s not working, so I can create a test?Thanks!Bob&gt; Op 21 mei 2018 11:53:08 schreef Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt;:&gt; &gt;&gt; Hi all, but most probably Bob Jacobsen and/or Bob Bender,&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I'm trying to get my head around the simplest way to change the&gt;&gt; TamsTrafficController, which extends AbstractMRTrafficController, so&gt;&gt; that it works in truly synchronised mode with the Tams MasterControl CS&gt;&gt; in normal operations.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; The message format is the old (Uhlenbrock) P50x, both ASCII messages and&gt;&gt; binary messages.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Via the Serial/USB port JMRI sends a message and must get a reply in&gt;&gt; less than 100 ms.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; If received then the next message can be sent if not then wait for time&gt;&gt; out and send the next message.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Normally unsolicited messages from the CS are not allowed (or at least&gt;&gt; not expected).&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I think the generic AbstractMRTrafficController already supports this&gt;&gt; off the shelf.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; The current implementation correctly handles the various incoming&gt;&gt; messaged but they are not forwarded to the appropriate listeners and I&gt;&gt; think I simply made an overcomplicated mess of it.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Any clarification or help would be highly welcome.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Thanks,&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Jan&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!            <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36322556/">Re: [Jmri-developers] AbstractMRTrafficController question</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@sb...&gt; - 2018-05-21 14:54:38</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Op 21 mei 2018 11:53:08 schreef Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt;:&gt; Hi all, but most probably Bob Jacobsen and/or Bob Bender,&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm trying to get my head around the simplest way to change the&gt; TamsTrafficController, which extends AbstractMRTrafficController, so&gt; that it works in truly synchronised mode with the Tams MasterControl CS&gt; in normal operations.&gt;&gt; The message format is the old (Uhlenbrock) P50x, both ASCII messages and&gt; binary messages.&gt;&gt; Via the Serial/USB port JMRI sends a message and must get a reply in&gt; less than 100 ms.&gt;&gt; If received then the next message can be sent if not then wait for time&gt; out and send the next message.&gt;&gt; Normally unsolicited messages from the CS are not allowed (or at least&gt; not expected).&gt;&gt; I think the generic AbstractMRTrafficController already supports this&gt; off the shelf.&gt;&gt;&gt; The current implementation correctly handles the various incoming&gt; messaged but they are not forwarded to the appropriate listeners and I&gt; think I simply made an overcomplicated mess of it.&gt;&gt;&gt; Any clarification or help would be highly welcome.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan</pre></td>
        </tr>

    <div class="sandiego"> 
     <section class="project-masthead"> 
      <div class="backdrop" style="box-sizing: content-box; padding-bottom: 24px"></div> 
      <div class="content"> 
       <nav id="breadcrumbs" class="breadcrumbs"> 
        <ul> 
         <li itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb"><a itemprop="url" href="/">Home</a></li> 
         <li itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb"><a itemprop="url" href="/directory">Browse</a></li> 
         <li itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb"><a itemprop="url" href="/p/jmri/">JMRI Model Railroad Interface</a></li> 
         <li itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb">Mailing Lists</li> 
        </ul>

       <div class="overview"> 
        <div class="project-icon    show-border"> 
         <img itemprop="image" alt="JMRI Model Railroad Interface Icon" src="/p/jmri/icon?1353521697"> 
        </div> 
        <div class="title"> 
         <h1 itemprop="name"><a href="/p/jmri/" itemprop="url">JMRI Model Railroad Interface</a></h1> 
         <h3 class="summary"> Java applications to control a model railroad layout. </h3> 
         <h3 class="brought-by"> Brought to you by: <a href="/u/jacobsen/">jacobsen</a>, <a href="/u/kevin-dickerson/">kevin-dickerson</a>, <a href="/u/matthewharris/">matthewharris</a>, <a href="/u/plocher/">plocher</a>, <a href="/u/zoo/">zoo</a> </h3> 
        </div>
       </div> 
      </div>
     </section> 
    </div> 
   </div>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36318866/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Script conversion</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-05-16 11:45:18</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small>

          </div> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob,Thanks, that fixed it. I thought I was close.The script runs some fast clocks in sync with the computer clock. They hadmechanical parts that were close to the 4:1 but the script does selectivepower interrupting to slow them up a bit to keep together. So off for onefast minute, on for X fast minutes type of thing. After 3 real hours theyare still within 5 minutes of each other. It was kind of a kludge, but youwork with what some people come up with for hardware.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Generally, you should fully-qualify the class names for InstanceManager:InstanceManager.getDefault(jmri.Timebase)Bob&gt; On May 15, 2018, at 7:43 PM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I've found one of my scripts was using:&gt; &gt;        self.mainClock = jmri.InstanceManager.timebaseInstance()&gt; &gt; But I've got to change that since that was depreciated. A look into the&gt; other scripts, nobody else was doing things like this and the clock. So I'm&gt; trying to figure out the syntax. I think it is close to this:&gt; &gt;        self.mainClock = jmri.InstanceManager.getDefault(Timebase.class);&gt; &gt; But that isn't quite it. So figuring the right class to ask for is what I'm&gt; trying to figure out.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36318539/">[Jmri-developers] Script conversion</a></b>
           </div>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I've found one of my scripts was using:        self.mainClock = jmri.InstanceManager.timebaseInstance()But I've got to change that since that was depreciated. A look into theother scripts, nobody else was doing things like this and the clock. So I'mtrying to figure out the syntax. I think it is close to this:        self.mainClock = jmri.InstanceManager.getDefault(Timebase.class);But that isn't quite it. So figuring the right class to ask for is what I'mtrying to figure out.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36318468/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Steve G &lt;RailRodder@sy...&gt; - 2018-05-16 00:13:41</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>IMHO1 - only one routine to normalize/validate.2 - until we stop using text files for storing data we have to validate on every read.Steve G.On May 15, 2018 4:21:42 PM EDT, George Warner &lt;geowar1@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; On May 14, 2018, at 8:33 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt;&lt;mailto:kcameron@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; If data read in from a file was previously edited with JMRI, then it&gt;should NEVER need normalization, but it is currently normalized, and&gt;that is extra work.&gt;&gt;What if it's from a previous version of JMRI that allowed&gt;non-normalized forms? Would we then just keep the non-normalized form&gt;or report it ("Warning: non-normalized name ' Foo'") or normalize it?&gt;&gt;&gt; Data entered by the user could certainly be normalized, but I think&gt;that should happen at the user interface, and I think it should be&gt;limited to trimming of names.&gt;&gt;&gt;I agree; but at least use BobJ's normalization routine (so if (/when?)&gt;we change our minds later we'll only need to fix one place instead of&gt;many).-- Sent from my Android device with K-9 Mail. Please excuse my brevity.</pre></td>
        </tr>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36318219/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-05-15 17:10:02</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; On May 15, 2018, at 9:32 AM, Robert Middleton &lt;osfan6313@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Looking at this as (mostly) an outsider, it sounds like it would make more sense to split apart these names into their own object that can then compare themselves and see what connection they are for and what number they are.  Obviously this is a big change, so it may not be the right way to go.Doesn’t really solve the problem, though it can certainly help, because you’ve still got Strings in JTextFields and other GUI elements, as part of serialization, and in calls to scripts, CATS and other code.You can solve all those too with better GUI widgets, smarter serialization, and forcing migration of (i.e. restriction of) the external interfaces to scripts, et al. But that’s a huge amount of work.  And inevitably somebody will say “why bother?” and add String code, and somebody will have to either clean it up in advance or deal with the problems later. The more that’s not migrated, the more likely that is."We" actually tried to do something like that with the NamedBeanHandle class, which provided an earlier form of name-munging for Beans.  The “we” is in quotes because after all the initial enthusiasm a couple of us got left holding the bag on the migration, and after a bit it was noticed that we were actually losing ground:  People were adding old-style code faster than the willing were able to migrate the existing code in their hobby time.  So the effort dried up and  it was just left in place as a good-but-partial solution. That’s why the “do it right” option in my earlier note was phrased in terms of _doing_ it on a branch.  I think it takes a lot of effort to get just a tiny bit of return, but if people are willing to do that, that would be great:  Having it 100% done, even 95% done, would resolve the question.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36318181">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36318181/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Robert Middleton &lt;osfan6313@gm...&gt; - 2018-05-15 16:32:39</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CAKpcJVYXS45F6aRQJOTct4f9q0-kOmPr2%2Bg0OdqyfOpPK-kMrA%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I haven't really delved deeply into the JMRI code in a while, but is therea particular reason that everything is encoded inside of a string?  Itseems like this is the source of a lot of problems.  I'm assuming that thisis more of a historical thing that was added on to since it was alreadyexisting.  Looking at this as (mostly) an outsider, it sounds like it wouldmake more sense to split apart these names into their own object that canthen compare themselves and see what connection they are for and whatnumber they are.  Obviously this is a big change, so it may not be theright way to go.(or I could be missing the concept here completely)-Robert MiddletonOn Tue, May 15, 2018 at 11:57 AM, Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt; wrote:&gt; The basic concept of don’t mess with the user supplied names is a good one&gt; with two exceptions.&gt;&gt;    - When a name is being created, it needs to be trimmed to eliminate&gt;    hidden leading and trailing spaces.&gt;    - For user supplied system names, the appropriate two character upper&gt;    case prefix is added if necessary.&gt;&gt; These two cases are handled by the GUI code, along with the normal checks&gt; for duplicates, etc.&gt;&gt; If names are created using third party software, including Python scripts,&gt; they are accepted *as is* with two exceptions.&gt;&gt;    - A system name has to have the appropriate prefix based on the object&gt;    class.  For example, this means that a provideSensor(‘xyz’) call will&gt;    return null if xyz is not a sensor user name and cannot be a sensor system&gt;    name.&gt;    - For creating new objects, the system name, and user name if&gt;    supplied, have to be unique.&gt;&gt; The second item does mean that the duplicate checks occur twice for normal&gt; GUI actions.&gt;&gt; System and user names need to be case sensitive.  This ensures&gt; uniqueness.  I think a case insensitive search creates complications due to&gt; the possibility of multiple results.&gt;&gt; I think  a couple of other changes are necessary to complete this process.&gt;&gt; The *AbstrackManager#register()* method needs to throw a duplicate system&gt; name/bean exception.  It does not make sense to register a bean that has&gt; already been registered (which can have subtle side effects) and will help&gt; identify incomplete upstream code.&gt;&gt; The other change is to retire the *Original Order List* concept.  This&gt; was the initial cause for issue #5303.  I don’t know the history or the&gt; rational for retaining the object order within each class in the panel XML&gt; files.  A third bean related list, in addition to _tsys and _beans, adds&gt; complexity and risk.&gt;&gt;&gt; Dave Sand&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;</pre></td>
