      <table id="msg36318153">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36318153/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dave Sand &lt;dave@sa...&gt; - 2018-05-15 15:57:54</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/E9896574-11B8-4799-8AE4-67F471ED2880%40sandsys.org/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>The basic concept of don’t mess with the user supplied names is a good one with two exceptions.When a name is being created, it needs to be trimmed to eliminate hidden leading and trailing spaces.For user supplied system names, the appropriate two character upper case prefix is added if necessary.These two cases are handled by the GUI code, along with the normal checks for duplicates, etc.If names are created using third party software, including Python scripts, they are accepted as is with two exceptions.A system name has to have the appropriate prefix based on the object class.  For example, this means that a provideSensor(‘xyz’) call will return null if xyz is not a sensor user name and cannot be a sensor system name.For creating new objects, the system name, and user name if supplied, have to be unique.The second item does mean that the duplicate checks occur twice for normal GUI actions.System and user names need to be case sensitive.  This ensures uniqueness.  I think a case insensitive search creates complications due to the possibility of multiple results.I think  a couple of other changes are necessary to complete this process.The AbstrackManager#register() method needs to throw a duplicate system name/bean exception.  It does not make sense to register a bean that has already been registered (which can have subtle side effects) and will help identify incomplete upstream code.The other change is to retire the Original Order List concept.  This was the initial cause for issue #5303.  I don’t know the history or the rational for retaining the object order within each class in the panel XML files.  A third bean related list, in addition to _tsys and _beans, adds complexity and risk.Dave Sand</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36317501">

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36317501/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Paul Bender &lt;paul.bender@ac...&gt; - 2018-05-14 21:05:23</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; On May 14, 2018, at 8:33 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Being on the support side of things, I've seen the use of the trim() to have&gt; made users life much better. Since spaces are invisible to the user, they&gt; can't see if they type something wrong. To my life of supporting them, it&gt; has been a great improvement. To step back from that would be folly.I understand where you are coming from, but I also understand Bob’s point.I think in the big picture, the current normalization is at least happening in the wrong place.If data read in from a file was previously edited with JMRI, then it should NEVER need normalization, but it is currently normalized, and that is extra work.Data entered by the user could certainly be normalized, but I think that should happen at the user interface, and I think it should be limited to trimming of names.Here is a thought however on how to handle the case of should ‘XYz’ and ‘XYZ’ be the same or different: Let the user decide.  We implement a case sensitive SEARCH and a case insensitive search and call the one the user has requested any time we look for existing objects in the list of NamedBeans.  I believe this should actually work, since we use getXXX and provideXXX to find objects, even in scripts.The case sensitive search off case would be the equivalent of no normalization, so if what I propose doesn’t work for some reason I have not thought about, that is the direction I would lean.Paul</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36317259">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36317259/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: david d zuhn &lt;zoo@st...&gt; - 2018-05-14 15:36:12</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CAASpJ1zEvsLpVqN7db7kOrxZ5xf0nhKSEJB2MW4HTnQhPv8mTg%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt;&gt; I think we should stop.  In fact, I think we should remove the existing&gt; attempts, and go back to “the program trusts what you type”.  This note is&gt; to discuss that, and see if people want to step up for another solution.&gt;I'll respond even though this touches areas of JMRI that I have pretty muchnever used.I think there are two types of "trusting what is typed".   What's visibleand what isn't.Asking someone to distinguish between "XYZ" and "XYZ " is pretty hard.When there isn't any delimiter or other visual indicator of the start andend of the string, it's an exercise in frustration for the user.But "knowing" that when a user types "XYz" that they really meant "XYZ" canbe tough, and I think that's hard to do consistently, and that's the cruxof most of the argument from Bob.  If it's not done uniformly everywhere,it shouldn't be done at all.I'd prefer UI elements that would automatically perform the trimoperation[1], so that the rest of the code doesn't have to worry about it. Then the data is in the correct form, and shouldn't be touched afterthat.   The XML could be considered "good", since the values came from theuser via tools that did the right thing (or from manual editing, which isalways a giant snare).   If things aren't right in the XML, it's a failure,not an opportunity to divine what the user really wanted.1: I don't think as a GUI user for many decades that I have *ever* wanted atrailing space.   Nor a leading one either.-- david d zuhn  Saint Paul Bridge &amp; Terminal Ry.zoo @ stpaulterminal.org</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36317094">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36317094/">Re: [Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-05-14 12:33:33</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Being on the support side of things, I've seen the use of the trim() to havemade users life much better. Since spaces are invisible to the user, theycan't see if they type something wrong. To my life of supporting them, ithas been a great improvement. To step back from that would be folly.&gt;From working with users, I think the improvements that let them ignore thesystem names most of the time has been a great step forward. I recall weeven had some discussion about how to eventually make them go away from thenormal user experience. Long term this may still be a big helping step, butI don't recall we could see a good way to make this work.Now on the case of further formatting, that's something with more wiggleroom. Some systems require specific casing, others do not. But I recallhaving to help users debug their systems often enough where they had endedup with two (or more) objects they had meant to be one, but due to casedifferences, they system had the separate objects. We have to keep in mindthat we are mostly programmers who understand the use of case. Many of ourlanguages use case differences to distinguish different items in our code.This is far from how most users think. They are modelers, not programmers.They want tools to 'just work', and we still come up short in this area.Trying to explain much of this seems to get a glazed over look from manyusers.So from supporting the users view of things, option one is the way we shouldgo.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36316791">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36316791/">[Jmri-developers] "Smarter" handling of names isn't; can we stop?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-05-14 03:41:41</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Over the years, people have thought it useful to do things like force some kinds of system names to upper case (so that ISxyz and ISXYZ refer to the same thing), trim leading and trailing spaces from user names, and even to fix curly quotes in names.A lot of work has gone into doing this.I think we should stop.  In fact, I think we should remove the existing attempts, and go back to “the program trusts what you type”.  This note is to discuss that, and see if people want to step up for another solution.Why stop? Because there’s never going to be an end to the effort needed to get even simple forms of this correct, and it’s just not worth it. It’s not worth the people time it’s taking and will take, and it’s not worth the code complexity and brittleness that it’s causing. And, even if we get past all that, we have to make sure that everybody writing code for JMRI includes the right string handling; it’ll never ever end.Why is it so hard to do?  After all, it’s “easy to add trim() in the provideSensor call”.  Well, like most things, just because it’s easy to do some one case in the one place you know about doesn’t mean it’s easy to find all the other places that all the other cases needs to be handled.  Dave Sand and I have been working on current issue (#5303) about this. That’s made it _really_ clear that there are _lots_ of places in the code where we compare strings representing system or user names. And every one of those is a possible place for a problem due to allowing the user to think it’s OK to assume that sloppy entry will be OK.  Either we protect _every_ _one_ of those with normalization code (hard, tedious, slow) or we systematically find every place where a name string can enter the code and normalize there (pretty much impossible, tedious, but not so slow).  Don’t think that happens often in the code?  While listening to a boring graduation speech this afternoon, working on just a phone, I easily found five which I’ve now confirmed with test cases. That sample indicates there are a lot more fish in the pond.Once you start allowing people to try things inconsistently in one place, it’s a terrible user interface to require them to do it consistently somewhere else.  And we get stuck on an never-ending quest to find places where things can come in. Just “go through the GUI and handle (it) there”: Want guess how many places that is? Over a hundred, probably.  Plus scripts can call pretty much anything with user-provided Strings (see the test in #5303). Plus code like CATS that we don’t even know about.We already have about a hundred normalizeSystemName and normalizeUserName calls in the code, plus a bunch more toUpperCase() and trim() operations which never migrated (evidence in itself for how hard it will be for us to organize a solution to this).  That’s extra complexity. Plus extra complexity in the corresponding tests. Given the complexity that’s already there, plus the user cost of inconsistent behavior, it seems to me that as a group we have several options:1) Create a proposal that handles matching _throughout _the code. Document (i.e. on the Names page) how to write future code so that new code remains consistent. Identify the list of places where changes are needed, and find people to do them systematically.Or2) Right after 4.12 is released, take all the normalization out:  4.13 (which we can call 5.0 if it makes people feel better) will use names as entered. Update the documentation. I’d be happy to do the work for this, including fixing any issues that are found by the tests.  If people want to add user friendliness, they can add better user-level interactions to the code in places where things don’t match, e.g. add a “Create new one or re-enter the existing name?” prompt if something doesn’t match via a standard interface widget.  (Exiting panel files will be fine if they were written out with a 4.8-4.12 release; hand-edited files may not be, but can be written out or fixed; scripts that count on i.e. lower-case names -&gt; upper case will have to be updated)We actually tried (1) about 15 months ago. The normalizeSystemName and normalizeUserName calls were put in place, and some migration was done.  But we’re _still_ not done with that (see #5303), despite lots of time spent.  I now think we’re not even half way there.I’d be happy to hand (1) off to others who will commit to get it done.  Some of it is tricky work, because people are tempted to treat the symptoms instead of the cause, and that just results in downstream problems. Most of it is just finding all the places with one of the documented issues and making the fix recommended  in the new documentation.Staying where we are now is not one of the options: We’re paying a price in complexity and we’re not providing a consistent user experience. I’ve got some time for a project like this during a trip in the latter half of June, which is the right timing for (2).  So, in the absence of a successful start on (1) by then, I can do (2) and get it ready for 4.13.1 (or 5.0).Thoughts?Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36316235">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36316235/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Change to LocoNet OPs Mode Read</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: &lt;db123@be...&gt; - 2018-05-12 22:28:51</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I think this is also true for Digitrax Zephyr Extra. If I power on Digitrax Zephyr Extra with track power off, there will be a huge amount of LocoNet traffic. By turning track power on, this problem is solved.Regards,Daniel2018-05-12 19:54 skrev Robin Becker:&gt; I just discovered that the Ops Mode Read issue I was seeing was related &gt; to&gt; the specific LONG_ACK response sent by a DCS240 when track power is &gt; OFF.&gt; Turns out that the DCS240 sends a LONG_ACK failure response to an Ops &gt; Mode&gt; Read requests when Track Power is OFF.  This is causing JMRI to fail &gt; the&gt; Read and ignore the subsequent Ops Read response from the Loconet &gt; stationary&gt; decoder.  My test bench always had track power ON when running earlier &gt; test&gt; releases which is why I never saw this before.&gt; &gt; There appears to be a similar issue during Loconet Stationary &gt; Interrogate&gt; when JMRI starts if the Turnout Handling option is set to Normal.  With&gt; Track Power OFF, the DCS240 sends a LONG_ACK failure response to every&gt; Loconet Stationary Interrogate message (Switch Request) from JMRI.  &gt; Even&gt; though all the Loconet Stationary decoders respond properly right after&gt; that, the LONG_ACK failure response causes JMRI to keep retrying the&gt; Stationary Interrogate message.&gt; &gt; So it appears that tweaking the LONG_ACK response handling in JMRI for &gt; the&gt; DCS240 is probably the solution.&gt; &gt; Regards,&gt; &gt; Robin&gt; &gt; -----Original Message-----&gt; From: Robin Becker &lt;rbgroups@...&gt;&gt; Sent: Monday, May 07, 2018 1:03 PM&gt; To: 'Discussions between JMRI developers'&gt; &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: RE: [Jmri-developers] Change to LocoNet OPs Mode Read&gt; &gt; Dick,&gt; &gt; Hi!  Hope you and Karen are well and enjoying the Spring.  In 4.11.5 &gt; there&gt; were changes in Loconet Ops Mode Read handling.  For Loconet Stationary&gt; Decoders the new  LOCONETOPSBOARD property must be added to the decoder&gt; definitions for Ops Mode Read to work.  I believe that Bob J may have&gt; updated the decoder definitions for your products already?  As an&gt; alternative checking the "Transponding" box under &gt; Connection-&gt;Additional&gt; Properties will enable Ops Mode Read.&gt; &gt; Once I added the new LOCONETOPSBOARD to the QuadLN decoder files &gt; everything&gt; worked until 4.11.6.  Now I find that Ops Mode Read commands are issued &gt; but&gt; the response is not handling correctly so things are broken again.  I &gt; opened&gt; issue 5300 on this.&gt; &gt; FYI there is a separate thing I ran into where the "Read Changes on &gt; Sheet"&gt; and "Read Sheet" buttons come up disabled but the "Read Changes on All&gt; Sheets" and "Read All Sheets" buttons come up enabled.  Not sure &gt; everyone&gt; sees this but it happens consistently on my system.  Clicking the "Read&gt; Changes on All Sheets" button once "fixes" this.  I opened issue 5523 &gt; on&gt; this one.&gt; &gt; Regards,&gt; &gt; Robin&gt; &gt; Robin Becker&gt; San Diego, CA&gt; &nbsp;&gt; -----Original Message-----&gt; From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt;&gt; Sent: Monday, May 07, 2018 10:49 AM&gt; To: Discussions about changes to the code; design, intent, etc&gt; &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: [Jmri-developers] Change to LocoNet OPs Mode Read&gt; &gt; Hi,&gt; &gt; It appears that someplace between 4.11.4 and 4.11.5 someone has &gt; disabled the&gt; LocoNet OPs mode 'Read full sheet' tabs in Decoder Pro. PLEASE DON'T DO&gt; THAT!!! It completely disables the ability to configure our products.&gt; Every once in a while someone decides that this is a good thing to do&gt; because a command station can not normally do this. However this is a&gt; legitimate action used by many products.&gt; &gt; Unfortunately, I have not been able to identify when or where this &gt; change&gt; was made, so it may have been done during some more generic fixes &gt; and/or&gt; cleanup.&gt; &gt; Currently our users are stuck at 4.11.4.&gt; &gt; Dick :)&gt; &gt; &gt; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; --&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most &gt; engaging&gt; tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36316147/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Change to LocoNet OPs Mode Read</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Robin Becker &lt;rbgroups@n3...&gt; - 2018-05-12 17:55:06</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I just discovered that the Ops Mode Read issue I was seeing was related tothe specific LONG_ACK response sent by a DCS240 when track power is OFF.Turns out that the DCS240 sends a LONG_ACK failure response to an Ops ModeRead requests when Track Power is OFF.  This is causing JMRI to fail theRead and ignore the subsequent Ops Read response from the Loconet stationarydecoder.  My test bench always had track power ON when running earlier testreleases which is why I never saw this before.There appears to be a similar issue during Loconet Stationary Interrogatewhen JMRI starts if the Turnout Handling option is set to Normal.  WithTrack Power OFF, the DCS240 sends a LONG_ACK failure response to everyLoconet Stationary Interrogate message (Switch Request) from JMRI.  Eventhough all the Loconet Stationary decoders respond properly right afterthat, the LONG_ACK failure response causes JMRI to keep retrying theStationary Interrogate message.So it appears that tweaking the LONG_ACK response handling in JMRI for theDCS240 is probably the solution.Regards,Robin-----Original Message-----From: Robin Becker &lt;rbgroups@...&gt; Sent: Monday, May 07, 2018 1:03 PMTo: 'Discussions between JMRI developers'&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: RE: [Jmri-developers] Change to LocoNet OPs Mode ReadDick,Hi!  Hope you and Karen are well and enjoying the Spring.  In 4.11.5 therewere changes in Loconet Ops Mode Read handling.  For Loconet StationaryDecoders the new  LOCONETOPSBOARD property must be added to the decoderdefinitions for Ops Mode Read to work.  I believe that Bob J may haveupdated the decoder definitions for your products already?  As analternative checking the "Transponding" box under Connection-&gt;AdditionalProperties will enable Ops Mode Read.  Once I added the new LOCONETOPSBOARD to the QuadLN decoder files everythingworked until 4.11.6.  Now I find that Ops Mode Read commands are issued butthe response is not handling correctly so things are broken again.  I openedissue 5300 on this.FYI there is a separate thing I ran into where the "Read Changes on Sheet"and "Read Sheet" buttons come up disabled but the "Read Changes on AllSheets" and "Read All Sheets" buttons come up enabled.  Not sure everyonesees this but it happens consistently on my system.  Clicking the "ReadChanges on All Sheets" button once "fixes" this.  I opened issue 5523 onthis one.  Regards,RobinRobin BeckerSan Diego, CA&nbsp;-----Original Message-----From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; Sent: Monday, May 07, 2018 10:49 AMTo: Discussions about changes to the code; design, intent, etc&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: [Jmri-developers] Change to LocoNet OPs Mode ReadHi,It appears that someplace between 4.11.4 and 4.11.5 someone has disabled theLocoNet OPs mode 'Read full sheet' tabs in Decoder Pro. PLEASE DON'T DOTHAT!!! It completely disables the ability to configure our products. Every once in a while someone decides that this is a good thing to dobecause a command station can not normally do this. However this is alegitimate action used by many products.Unfortunately, I have not been able to identify when or where this changewas made, so it may have been done during some more generic fixes and/orcleanup.Currently our users are stuck at 4.11.4.Dick :)------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engagingtech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>There are some unresolved obvious bugs I think we should address before the next production release:<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5330" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/5330</a> has been reported multiple times.<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/4845" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/4845</a> is not as serious, but affects me significantly in my definition development work.Unfortunately I've had no dev environment access for three weeks, will only have so for some days, during which I have a lot of personal commitments as well as a long-promised (since late last year) complex new ESU definition to finish in time for 4.12. I will then again have no access for some time, so can't address any of the above.Sent from my iPad-- Dave&gt; &gt; You can see our notional release schedule in the usual place: <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/milestones?direction=asc&amp;sort=due_date&amp;state=open" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/milestones?direction=asc&amp;sort=due_date&amp;state=open</a>&gt; &gt; Leading up to JMRI 4.12, the current notional sequence is:&gt; &gt; *) 4.11.6 roughly May 12, 2018 - usual release from master HEAD&gt; &gt; *) 4.11.7 roughly June 1, 2018 - from master HEAD, this is the last “take everything” release before 4.12.  Note that this is earlier in the month than our usual “2nd full weekend”.&gt; &gt; *) 4.11.8 roughly June 16, 2018 - Only selected and necessary changes to bring the 4.11 series up to a production 4.12 release e.g. last minute decoder changes, specific fixes to _new_ bugs, etc.&gt; &gt; (Additional bug update test releases as needed)&gt; &gt; *) 4.12 July 8, 2018 - production release&gt; &gt; *) 4.13.1 July 9, 2018 - test release from master HEAD with all PRs since 4.11.7&gt; &gt; &gt; Two key take-aways from this:&gt; &gt; *) If you have a big project, please get it done and PR’d this month (May) if you want it in 4.12.  If not, no problem, it’ll be in the next series and be available to users in 4.13.1 at about the same time.&gt; &gt; *) Since people will be paying attention to these deadlines, if you anticipate wanting to push them back, please speak up soon.</pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36315074/">Re: [Jmri-developers] JMRI 4.10 USB port problems under Ubuntu</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Gary Matthews &lt;gmsolutions@ho...&gt; - 2018-05-11 03:45:21</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>As a ubuntu user this problem exists for me as well so to fix it make sure that all yourdevices are plugged in. shutdown the puter and then power it on. start jmri and configurewith the devices that are assigned at boot time. Unplugging and plugging devices while theoperating system is up and running will be configured on a first come first serve basis. Byconfiguring JMRI to use the devices the os finds at boot time you can eliminate the problemfor the most part.During hardware development this option is not always available so using virtual ports is abetter option with the added advantage of spying on traffic.On 02/05/18 01:05, Kai Vehmersalo wrote:&gt; I have had problems with the JMRI when using USB ports.&gt;&gt; After many problems as the computer (Windows or Ubuntu)&gt; seems to pick new USB ports as a lottery the result has&gt; been that JMRI is dropping off turnouts and some other&gt; required items at new starts.&gt;&gt; I have moved to Ethernet connection (I do not know if&gt; Tams is supporting Ethernet) as it is reliable if you&gt; do remember to start the Ethernet first in your network.&gt;&gt; ESU ECoS and JMRI and MERG support Ethernet connections.&gt; With Ethernet you may have 4 concurrent connections.&gt;&gt; I think it is a bug in the JMRI if it really drops out&gt; items you have been using earlier. I do not check that&gt; any more as I am using only Ethernet connection to JMRI.&gt;&gt; Kai "Waiski" Vehmersalo, Finland&gt;&gt; ###&gt; On 18.03.2018 18:54, Jan Boen wrote:&gt;&gt; Hi,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Not sure if this problem has already been flagged or already been &gt;&gt; resolved.&gt;&gt; On a couple of older Ubuntu machines (running 32-bit versions) we &gt;&gt; have a problem when combining the Tams MasterControl with JMRI 4.10.&gt;&gt; All looks fine but JMRI simply doesn't communicate with the command &gt;&gt; station even after after updating the preferences.&gt;&gt; Just use JMRI 4.8 and all works just fine.&gt;&gt; Any suggestions?&gt;&gt; As I'm writing this I will check if it is also related to the local &gt;&gt; settings (Dutch vs English).&gt;&gt; On Windows this is not a problem at all.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ &gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!          <td class="email-body"><pre>Dick,Hi!  Hope you and Karen are well and enjoying the Spring.  In 4.11.5 therewere changes in Loconet Ops Mode Read handling.  For Loconet StationaryDecoders the new  LOCONETOPSBOARD property must be added to the decoderdefinitions for Ops Mode Read to work.  I believe that Bob J may haveupdated the decoder definitions for your products already?  As analternative checking the "Transponding" box under Connection-&gt;AdditionalProperties will enable Ops Mode Read.  Once I added the new LOCONETOPSBOARD to the QuadLN decoder files everythingworked until 4.11.6.  Now I find that Ops Mode Read commands are issued butthe response is not handling correctly so things are broken again.  I openedissue 5300 on this.FYI there is a separate thing I ran into where the "Read Changes on Sheet"and "Read Sheet" buttons come up disabled but the "Read Changes on AllSheets" and "Read All Sheets" buttons come up enabled.  Not sure everyonesees this but it happens consistently on my system.  Clicking the "ReadChanges on All Sheets" button once "fixes" this.  I opened issue 5523 onthis one.  Regards,RobinRobin BeckerSan Diego, CA&nbsp;-----Original Message-----From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; Sent: Monday, May 07, 2018 10:49 AMTo: Discussions about changes to the code; design, intent, etc&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: [Jmri-developers] Change to LocoNet OPs Mode ReadHi,It appears that someplace between 4.11.4 and 4.11.5 someone has disabled theLocoNet OPs mode 'Read full sheet' tabs in Decoder Pro. PLEASE DON'T DOTHAT!!! It completely disables the ability to configure our products. Every once in a while someone decides that this is a good thing to dobecause a command station can not normally do this. However this is alegitimate action used by many products.Unfortunately, I have not been able to identify when or where this changewas made, so it may have been done during some more generic fixes and/orcleanup.Currently our users are stuck at 4.11.4.Dick :)------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engagingtech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

PLEASE DON'T DO THAT!!! It completely disables the ability to configure our products. However this is a legitimate action used by many products.Unfortunately, I have not been able to identify when or where this change was made, so it may have been done during some more generic fixes and/or cleanup.Currently our users are stuck at 4.11.4.Dick :)------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Chuck,It sounds to me like you've been bitten by the problem where Netbeans wantsto do what it wants to do, not what we want it to do.  Netbeans has beenknown to IGNORE the "three-sided" development methodology which is preferredby leading JMRI developers.  It might even change the git configuration - ithas been so long since I stopped fiddling with Netbeans GIT functionality, Idon't remember!In my work with JMRI, I have found it easiest to do my development work inNetbeans, but do anything related to git via a command-line git operation.That way, Netbeans CANNOT mess with my git configuration!I STRONGLY recommend that you STOP using Netbeans "git integration", untilthe point when a Netbeans-literate, Git-literate developer can figure outhow to prevent Netbeans from being stupid, and communicate the requiredtweaks to those of us who are Netbeans-based developers.Do you have git support on the command line?  If not, you should get itconfigured.  What operating system do you run?I STRONGLY recommend that you re-configure your local git repository for the"three-cornered" development methodology recommended for JMRI development.Specifically, use "git command-line" tools to ensure that the "git remote-v" command returns something like:origin  <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI.git" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI.git</a> (fetch)origin  <a href="https://github.com/CCatania01/JMRI.git" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/CCatania01/JMRI.git</a> (push)Specifically note that the "push" operations by default will go to -your-remote repository on Github, while the "fetch" (or "pull") operations willby default come from the main JMRI repository on Github.When I use a git command from the command line to "push" my local git branchto -my- remote repository (<a href="https://devel-bobm/JMRI" rel="nofollow">https://devel-bobm/JMRI</a> ), the command-line gitimplementation will recognize that -my- remote repository doesn't have abranch by that name and will automatically create the branch in -my- remoterepository.  Then I can log into Git via a web browser, and, from -my-repository, make a "pull request" to the JMRI repository.Regards,Bob M.&gt; -----Original Message-----&gt; From: Chuck Catania [mailto:cpcrr@...]&gt; Sent: Wednesday, May 02, 2018 12:40 PM&gt; To: Jmri-developers@...&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Push Upstream Error&gt; &gt; When doing the Push to Upstream, the first dialog presented indicates thatthe&gt; push is about to create a new branch (mrcs-dev2) in the remote repository.The&gt; repository listing from NetBeans shows that branch does not exist in the&gt; remote.&gt; &gt; Chuck Catania</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36306871/">[Jmri-developers] Release sequence leading to JMRI 4.12</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-05-01 22:00:03</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>You can see our notional release schedule in the usual place: <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/milestones?direction=asc&amp;sort=due_date&amp;state=open" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/milestones?direction=asc&amp;sort=due_date&amp;state=open</a>Leading up to JMRI 4.12, the current notional sequence is:*) 4.11.6 roughly May 12, 2018 - usual release from master HEAD*) 4.11.7 roughly June 1, 2018 - from master HEAD, this is the last “take everything” release before 4.12.  Note that this is earlier in the month than our usual “2nd full weekend”.*) 4.11.8 roughly June 16, 2018 - Only selected and necessary changes to bring the 4.11 series up to a production 4.12 release e.g. last minute decoder changes, specific fixes to _new_ bugs, etc.(Additional bug update test releases as needed)*) 4.12 July 8, 2018 - production release*) 4.13.1 July 9, 2018 - test release from master HEAD with all PRs since 4.11.7Two key take-aways from this:*) If you have a big project, please get it done and PR’d this month (May) if you want it in 4.12.  If not, no problem, it’ll be in the next series and be available to users in 4.13.1 at about the same time.*) Since people will be paying attention to these deadlines, if you anticipate wanting to push them back, please speak up soon.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I have had problems with the JMRI when using USB ports.After many problems as the computer (Windows or Ubuntu)seems to pick new USB ports as a lottery the result hasbeen that JMRI is dropping off turnouts and some otherrequired items at new starts.I have moved to Ethernet connection (I do not know ifTams is supporting Ethernet) as it is reliable if youdo remember to start the Ethernet first in your network.ESU ECoS and JMRI and MERG support Ethernet connections.With Ethernet you may have 4 concurrent connections.I think it is a bug in the JMRI if it really drops outitems you have been using earlier. I do not check thatany more as I am using only Ethernet connection to JMRI.Kai "Waiski" Vehmersalo, Finland###On 18.03.2018 18:54, Jan Boen wrote:&gt; Hi,&gt;&gt; Not sure if this problem has already been flagged or already been &gt; resolved.&gt; On a couple of older Ubuntu machines (running 32-bit versions) we have &gt; a problem when combining the Tams MasterControl with JMRI 4.10.&gt; All looks fine but JMRI simply doesn't communicate with the command &gt; station even after after updating the preferences.&gt; Just use JMRI 4.8 and all works just fine.&gt; Any suggestions?&gt; As I'm writing this I will check if it is also related to the local &gt; settings (Dutch vs English).&gt; On Windows this is not a problem at all.&gt;&gt; Thanks,&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ &gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi Jan,There's some good JMRI Git info here: <a href="http://jmri.sourceforge" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.sourceforge</a>.net/help/en/html/doc/Technical/GitFAQ.shtmlMany (most?) of the JMRI devs will tell you to use the command line git, soif you heed that, you can stop reading here. :)I access git inside of Eclipse, using the same three-way repo setup shown.Team, Git, Pull and Team, Git, Push both have ".." versions which allow meto setup and verify that I'm going in the right direction.Push goes to my repo: <a href="https://github.com/mstevetodd/JMRI" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/mstevetodd/JMRI</a> and Pull comesfrom the JMRI repo: <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI</a>Eclipse will remember your choices for subsequent pull/pushes.When I created my "remotes" (the URLs listed above), I gave them meaningful(to me) names, as I found "origin" unhelpful. My remote names are "JMRI"and "mstevetodd".So, to recap, I pull from JMRI regularly. If I make a change, I commitlocally, then push to mstevetodd. Then I create a PR from mstevetodd toJMRI using github.If you have more questions about using Eclipse with JMRI, feel free toemail me directly and I'll do my best to help.Regards,  SteveTOn Tue, May 1, 2018 at 5:51 AM, Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Hi all,&gt;&gt; Sorry to be bothering with an ignorance question...&gt; I have installed a new hard drive and am now getting my JMRI/GIT&gt; development set-up working again.&gt; I installed a fresh copy of Eclipse and have gotten the latest JMRI master&gt; code into it.&gt; How do I now make sure that what I do ends up in my JMRI fork instead of&gt; directly going to the master when I do a pull?&gt;&gt; Thanks,&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt; ---&gt; Dit e-mailbericht is gecontroleerd op virussen met Avast antivirussoftware.&gt; <a href="https://www.avast.com/antivirus" rel="nofollow">https://www.avast.com/antivirus</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>It sounds like you have a bad Logix that gets into a loop.  Use the Browse option for a Logix that causes the problem. Copy and paste the window contents.Dave Sand&gt; On Apr 29, 2018, at 7:22 AM, Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; &gt; Hi all,&gt; &gt; So far we/I have successfully used JMRI with Tams MasterControl, DCC controlled turnouts and signals, Logix and internal sensors.&gt; &gt; We now have an S88 module with 16 switches connected with JMRI 4.10, Tams MasterControl, DCC controlled devices, Logix, internal and external sensors.&gt; As long as we don't enable the Logix which work in conjunction with the external sensors everything works just fine.&gt; Toggle switches = see status changes in Tams sensors under Tables&gt; Control turnouts and signals = things happen on the layout&gt; Power control works etc.&gt; In command monitor you see the commands being sent and the polling taking place for checking status changes (power, dcc turnouts, sensors).&gt; The moment we activate 1 single Logix that uses S88 connected switches things go wrong.&gt; An endless stream of turnout commands is being sent to which the Tams MC duly replies.&gt; As this stream of commands never stops the polling also stops.&gt; The sensors end up in bogus states which makes the turnout unreliable as well.&gt; When using Tams simulator mode this doesn't (seem) to happen.&gt; &gt; What are we missing?&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Thanks,&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ---&gt; Dit e-mailbericht is gecontroleerd op virussen met Avast antivirussoftware.&gt; <a href="https://www.avast.com/antivirus" rel="nofollow">https://www.avast.com/antivirus</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!            <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36305755/">[Jmri-developers] JMRI, Tams MasterControl, S88 and Logix strange problem</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@sb...&gt; - 2018-04-29 15:27:38</small> 
           <div class="attachments">

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi all,So far we/I have successfully used JMRI with Tams MasterControl, DCC controlled turnouts and signals, Logix and internal sensors.We now have an S88 module with 16 switches connected with JMRI 4.10, Tams MasterControl, DCC controlled devices, Logix, internal and external sensors.As long as we don't enable the Logix which work in conjunction with the external sensors everything works just fine.Toggle switches = see status changes in Tams sensors under TablesControl turnouts and signals = things happen on the layoutPower control works etc.In command monitor you see the commands being sent and the polling taking place for checking status changes (power, dcc turnouts, sensors).The moment we activate 1 single Logix that uses S88 connected switches things go wrong.An endless stream of turnout commands is being sent to which the Tams MC duly replies.As this stream of commands never stops the polling also stops.The sensors end up in bogus states which makes the turnout unreliable as well.When using Tams simulator mode this doesn't (seem) to happen.What are we missing?Thanks,---Dit e-mailbericht is gecontroleerd op virussen met Avast antivirussoftware.<a href="https://www.avast.com/antivirus" rel="nofollow">https://www.avast.com/antivirus</a></pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36307398/">Re: [Jmri-developers] [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Lynn Grandle &lt;LGrandle@ms...&gt; - 2018-04-29 12:33:48</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/BN6PR22MB0449DEF892FB8F1B3753FABFDE830%40BN6PR22MB0449.namprd22.prod.outlook.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Not to sound stupid, but if this generated so much discussion on what to do, why not make it a preference option.  Then those of us who do not want to wait for the list scan and use the default fonts can turn off the option to scan the font lists and the problem goes away.Bob________________________________From: jmri-developers-request@... &lt;jmri-developers-request@...&gt;Sent: Saturday, April 28, 2018 11:10 PMTo: jmri-developers@...Subject: Jmri-developers Digest, Vol 141, Issue 38Send Jmri-developers mailing list submissions to        jmri-developers@...To subscribe or unsubscribe via the World Wide Web, visit        <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>or, via email, send a message with subject or body 'help' to        jmri-developers-request@...You can reach the person managing the list at        jmri-developers-owner@...When replying, please edit your Subject line so it is more specificthan "Re: Contents of Jmri-developers digest..."Today's Topics:   1. Re: [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux (Bob Jacobsen)   2. Re: [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux      (db123@...)   3. Re: [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux (Dick Bronson)   4. Re: [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux (Ken Cameron)----------------------------------------------------------------------Message: 1Date: Sat, 28 Apr 2018 10:38:40 -0700From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;To: Discussions between JMRI developers        &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in        LinuxMessage-ID: &lt;4610F0FC-4414-49C2-86E4-5B312B797449@...&gt;Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8I agree on the negative impact.The purpose is to be able to provide lists of e.g. monospaced fonts, which in turn becomes s selector box for those.Many programs provide lists of all fonts, and only when you select them do they retrieve the characteristics. Doing that in JMRI would be faster. It ?risks somebody selecting an inappropriate font? (quote is from the long bikeshedding conversation earlier about the feature).It seems to me that somebody who selects Noto Sans CJK JP Regular and doesn?t like how it looks can just select something else.The earlier discussion of this feature ended up with lots of people arguing about how other people ?should? use the program. That rarely ends well, so I try to stay out of those.Bob&gt; On Apr 27, 2018, at 10:24 PM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; Bob,&gt; There is disk activity, but only short winks and blinks. If the disk activity itself was responsible for the slow down, then I would expect the activity light to be on a lot more.&gt;&gt; Is all this pre-fetched information actually used at some point, or would it work just as well to only get the specific metrics required when a font is actually selected for use? I can not imagine why JMRI needs to know the font metrics of Noto Sans CJK JP Regular, UnBatang, KacstFarsi, or any number of the 100's of other fonts that lurk on my system, much less to recalculate all that information every time the program gets started up.&gt;&gt; Word processing programs seem to get along just fine by selecting their fonts on an as needed basis. That a model railroad control program has any legitimate need to do all this font pre-processing seems really, really, strange. I feel pretty sure that if the developer that added this had more than a few fonts available on his system, it never would have happened in the first place, because he would have seen the huge negative impact that it can have on JMRI performance for some users. Sorry, but yes, I do consider a 50% reduction in my processor availability for 5-6 minutes after JMRI is started to be a "huge negative" impact.&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt; On 04/28/2018 12:00 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt; Thanks.  If those samples are representative (no reason to believe they?re not, but just in case) then that huge chunk of time really is in java.awt.Component.getFontMetrics(), the method we?re calling repeatedly to get information on each font.  AFAIK, there?s not much we can do to speed that up from JMRI other than to not call it. (Don?t know if there?s anything that can be done outside JMRI to pre-index fonts or anything like that)&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Not sure why you?re not seeing the disk light working.  There are calls to java.nio methods from the PrepareFontLists thread in those snapshots, so somebody is requesting I/O (probably getFontMetrics() but I can?t say that for sure).  Maybe that info is somehow already cached somewhere?  That would be consistent with the font thread running (close to) 100% of one core on your machine, i.e. not waiting for anything.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Apr 26, 2018, at 7:31 PM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob,&gt;&gt;&gt; Hopefully this is what you need. I can't make any sense of it.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 04/20/2018 09:25 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks for the CPU plot.  The lack of disk activity makes this appear to be Yet Another Problem, separate from the Windows ?load font so you can check it? problem.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; When you get time, could you send me a couple of snapshots taken during that high-CPU phase?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; To do that, open jvisualvm and target JMRI?s running Java process.  Select ?Sampler?, then click ?CPU?.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;samp-1.nps&gt;&lt;samp-2.nps&gt;&lt;samp-3.nps&gt;&lt;samp-4.nps&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-10-28.png&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-09-42.png&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-08-42.png&gt;------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! (not realizing the resulting unintended consequences)Actually we could be fairly certain that the person selecting Noto SansCJK JP Regular would be able to read Japanese. &lt;G&gt;Dick :)On 04/28/2018 01:38 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; I agree on the negative impact.&gt;&gt; The purpose is to be able to provide lists of e.g. monospaced fonts, which in turn becomes s selector box for those.&gt;&gt; Many programs provide lists of all fonts, and only when you select them do they retrieve the characteristics. Doing that in JMRI would be faster. It ?risks somebody selecting an inappropriate font? (quote is from the long bikeshedding conversation earlier about the feature).&gt;&gt; It seems to me that somebody who selects Noto Sans CJK JP Regular and doesn?t like how it looks can just select something else.&gt;&gt; The earlier discussion of this feature ended up with lots of people arguing about how other people ?should? use the program. That rarely ends well, so I try to stay out of those.&gt;&gt; Bob------------------------------Message: 4Date: Sat, 28 Apr 2018 23:09:53 -0400From: "Ken Cameron" &lt;kcameron@...&gt;To: "'Discussions between JMRI developers'"        &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in        LinuxMessage-ID: &lt;027c01d3df67$8ccf55a0$a66e00e0$@twcny.rr.com&gt;Content-Type: text/plain;       charset="US-ASCII"This is a presumption, but when it comes to selecting fonts, most peopleseem to use the 'try and see' method. Few people do it by parameters, likeserif, non-serif, etc...So delaying the full font metrics until somebody is looking at a specificfont, and then passing that data, would seem ok.But I think letting those who came up with this idea reconsider the valueof:1. Using the font metrics at all?2. Deferring it until the font is picked from the list?3. Somehow caching the results from the font metrics?My recall on this was it got added just as a way to help people select theright font. The goal was the mono-spaced fonts work best for things likeconsole display and many other program displays, it makes it easier to aligndisplays that way. So being able to tell people these are mono-spacing wouldbe worth some effort.Getting a clear idea of what was the goal that came up with this idea wouldbe helpful at this time.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org<http://www.jmri.org>" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org&lt;http://www.jmri.org&gt;</a>; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org<http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org>" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org&lt;http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org&gt;</a>; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com<http://www.cnymod.com>" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com&lt;http://www.cnymod.com&gt;</a>; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org<http://www.syracusemodelrr.org>" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org&lt;http://www.syracusemodelrr.org&gt;</a>;------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>------------------------------Subject: Digest Footer_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>------------------------------End of Jmri-developers Digest, Vol 141, Issue 38************************************************</pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36305553/">Re: [Jmri-developers] [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-04-29 03:51:01</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>The actual current status is that  <a href="http://jmri.org/JavaDoc/doc/jmri/util/swing/FontComboUtil.html" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/JavaDoc/doc/jmri/util/swing/FontComboUtil.html</a> class (which is where all this happens) defines four font type symbols: CHARACTER, MONOSPACED, PROPORTIONAL, SYMBOL (plus ALL). ALL fonts are divided into SYMBOL and CHARACTER; CHARACTER is further divided into MONOSPACED and PROPORTIONAL.In JMRI’s Java source code (e.g. not counting any uses that be in tests, scripts, CATS, etc), the uses are:ALL:	PrintOptionPanelCHARACTER: (None)MONOSPACED:	PrintOptionPanel	SystemConsoleConfigPanel	SystemConsolePreferencesManagerPROPORTIONAL: (none)SYMBOL: (None)So there are three places that want to present just the fonts that are found to be monospaced:From java/src/jmri/jmrit/operations/setup/PrintOptionPanel.java:    private void loadFontComboBox() {        fontComboBox.removeAllItems();        List&lt;String&gt; fonts = FontComboUtil.getFonts(FontComboUtil.ALL);        if (tabFormatCheckBox.isSelected() || !manifestFormatComboBox.getSelectedItem().equals(Setup.STANDARD_FORMAT)) {            fonts = FontComboUtil.getFonts(FontComboUtil.MONOSPACED);        }        for (String font : fonts) {            fontComboBox.addItem(font);        }        fontComboBox.setSelectedItem(Setup.getFontName());    }That method is private, hence is only used in PrintOptionPanel; it appears to be part of the print setup.From java/src/apps/SystemConsoleConfigPanel.java:    private static final JComboBox&lt;String&gt; fontFamily = FontComboUtil.getFontCombo(FontComboUtil.MONOSPACED, 14);I believe this requires the font combobox to be created when the class is first referenced for loading or storing the Console in the Preferences, but I haven’t traced that in detail.From java/src/apps/systemconsole/SystemConsolePreferencesManager.java    public void setFontFamily(String fontFamily) {        if (FontComboUtil.isReady()) {            if (FontComboUtil.getFonts(FontComboUtil.MONOSPACED).contains(fontFamily)) {                String oldFontFamily = this.fontFamily;                this.fontFamily = fontFamily;                this.firePropertyChange(FONT_FAMILY, oldFontFamily, fontFamily);                SystemConsole.getInstance().setFontFamily(this.getFontFamily());            } else {                log.warn("Incompatible console font \"{}\" - using \"{}\"", fontFamily, this.getFontFamily());            }        } else {            ThreadingUtil.runOnGUIDelayed(() -&gt; {                this.setFontFamily(fontFamily);            }, 1000); // one second        }    }This is referenced from SystemConsoleConfigPanelXml (for persisting the console configuration), SystemConsoleConfigPanel (configuration GUI) and SystemConsolePreferencesManager.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36305540/">Re: [Jmri-developers] [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-04-29 03:10:07</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>This is a presumption, but when it comes to selecting fonts, most peopleseem to use the 'try and see' method. Few people do it by parameters, likeserif, non-serif, etc...So delaying the full font metrics until somebody is looking at a specificfont, and then passing that data, would seem ok.But I think letting those who came up with this idea reconsider the valueof:1. Using the font metrics at all?2. Deferring it until the font is picked from the list?3. Somehow caching the results from the font metrics?My recall on this was it got added just as a way to help people select theright font. The goal was the mono-spaced fonts work best for things likeconsole display and many other program displays, it makes it easier to aligndisplays that way. So being able to tell people these are mono-spacing wouldbe worth some effort.Getting a clear idea of what was the goal that came up with this idea wouldbe helpful at this time.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36305523/">Re: [Jmri-developers] [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux</a></b>

           <small>From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@rr...&gt; - 2018-04-29 02:07:51</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob,I must have either missed the discussion, or blown it off as unimportant. (not realizing the resulting unintended consequences) Actually we could be fairly certain that the person selecting Noto Sans CJK JP Regular would be able to read Japanese. &lt;G&gt;Dick :)On 04/28/2018 01:38 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; I agree on the negative impact.&gt;&gt; The purpose is to be able to provide lists of e.g. monospaced fonts, which in turn becomes s selector box for those.&gt;&gt; Many programs provide lists of all fonts, and only when you select them do they retrieve the characteristics. Doing that in JMRI would be faster. It “risks somebody selecting an inappropriate font” (quote is from the long bikeshedding conversation earlier about the feature).&gt;&gt; It seems to me that somebody who selects Noto Sans CJK JP Regular and doesn’t like how it looks can just select something else.&gt;&gt; The earlier discussion of this feature ended up with lots of people arguing about how other people “should” use the program. That rarely ends well, so I try to stay out of those.&gt;&gt; Bob</pre></td>
        </tr>

      </table> 
      <table id="msg36305446">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36305446/">Re: [Jmri-developers] [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux</a></b>
           </div>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>It seems to me that a simple solution is to save which fonts are monospaced and which are not. That should never change. I have very hard to believe that a font that is monospace later become not monospace, or vice versa.RegardsDaniel2018-04-28 19:38 skrev Bob Jacobsen:&gt; I agree on the negative impact.&gt; &gt; The purpose is to be able to provide lists of e.g. monospaced fonts,&gt; which in turn becomes s selector box for those.&gt; &gt; Many programs provide lists of all fonts, and only when you select&gt; them do they retrieve the characteristics. Doing that in JMRI would be&gt; faster. It “risks somebody selecting an inappropriate font” (quote is&gt; from the long bikeshedding conversation earlier about the feature).&gt; &gt; It seems to me that somebody who selects Noto Sans CJK JP Regular and&gt; doesn’t like how it looks can just select something else.&gt; &gt; The earlier discussion of this feature ended up with lots of people&gt; arguing about how other people “should” use the program. That rarely&gt; ends well, so I try to stay out of those.&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt;&gt; On Apr 27, 2018, at 10:24 PM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; &gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob,&gt;&gt; There is disk activity, but only short winks and blinks. If the disk &gt;&gt; activity itself was responsible for the slow down, then I would expect &gt;&gt; the activity light to be on a lot more.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Is all this pre-fetched information actually used at some point, or &gt;&gt; would it work just as well to only get the specific metrics required &gt;&gt; when a font is actually selected for use? I can not imagine why JMRI &gt;&gt; needs to know the font metrics of Noto Sans CJK JP Regular, UnBatang, &gt;&gt; KacstFarsi, or any number of the 100's of other fonts that lurk on my &gt;&gt; system, much less to recalculate all that information every time the &gt;&gt; program gets started up.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Word processing programs seem to get along just fine by selecting &gt;&gt; their fonts on an as needed basis. That a model railroad control &gt;&gt; program has any legitimate need to do all this font pre-processing &gt;&gt; seems really, really, strange. I feel pretty sure that if the &gt;&gt; developer that added this had more than a few fonts available on his &gt;&gt; system, it never would have happened in the first place, because he &gt;&gt; would have seen the huge negative impact that it can have on JMRI &gt;&gt; performance for some users. Sorry, but yes, I do consider a 50% &gt;&gt; reduction in my processor availability for 5-6 minutes after JMRI is &gt;&gt; started to be a "huge negative" impact.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; On 04/28/2018 12:00 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks.  If those samples are representative (no reason to believe &gt;&gt;&gt; they’re not, but just in case) then that huge chunk of time really is &gt;&gt;&gt; in java.awt.Component.getFontMetrics(), the method we’re calling &gt;&gt;&gt; repeatedly to get information on each font.  AFAIK, there’s not much &gt;&gt;&gt; we can do to speed that up from JMRI other than to not call it. &gt;&gt;&gt; (Don’t know if there’s anything that can be done outside JMRI to &gt;&gt;&gt; pre-index fonts or anything like that)&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Not sure why you’re not seeing the disk light working.  There are &gt;&gt;&gt; calls to java.nio methods from the PrepareFontLists thread in those &gt;&gt;&gt; snapshots, so somebody is requesting I/O (probably getFontMetrics() &gt;&gt;&gt; but I can’t say that for sure).  Maybe that info is somehow already &gt;&gt;&gt; cached somewhere?  That would be consistent with the font thread &gt;&gt;&gt; running (close to) 100% of one core on your machine, i.e. not waiting &gt;&gt;&gt; for anything.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Apr 26, 2018, at 7:31 PM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Hopefully this is what you need. I can't make any sense of it.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 04/20/2018 09:25 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks for the CPU plot.  The lack of disk activity makes this &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; appear to be Yet Another Problem, separate from the Windows “load &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; font so you can check it” problem.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; When you get time, could you send me a couple of snapshots taken &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; during that high-CPU phase?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; To do that, open jvisualvm and target JMRI’s running Java process.  &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Select “Sampler”, then click “CPU”.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;samp-1.nps&gt;&lt;samp-2.nps&gt;&lt;samp-3.nps&gt;&lt;samp-4.nps&gt;&lt;Screenshot from &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 2018-04-26 22-10-28.png&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 22-09-42.png&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 22-08-42.png&gt;------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!             <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36305380/">Re: [Jmri-developers] [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux</a></b>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I agree on the negative impact. The purpose is to be able to provide lists of e.g. monospaced fonts, which in turn becomes s selector box for those. Many programs provide lists of all fonts, and only when you select them do they retrieve the characteristics. Doing that in JMRI would be faster. It “risks somebody selecting an inappropriate font” (quote is from the long bikeshedding conversation earlier about the feature). It seems to me that somebody who selects Noto Sans CJK JP Regular and doesn’t like how it looks can just select something else. The earlier discussion of this feature ended up with lots of people arguing about how other people “should” use the program. That rarely ends well, so I try to stay out of those. Bob&gt; On Apr 27, 2018, at 10:24 PM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Bob,&gt; There is disk activity, but only short winks and blinks. If the disk activity itself was responsible for the slow down, then I would expect the activity light to be on a lot more.&gt; &gt; Is all this pre-fetched information actually used at some point, or would it work just as well to only get the specific metrics required when a font is actually selected for use? I can not imagine why JMRI needs to know the font metrics of Noto Sans CJK JP Regular, UnBatang, KacstFarsi, or any number of the 100's of other fonts that lurk on my system, much less to recalculate all that information every time the program gets started up.&gt; &gt; Word processing programs seem to get along just fine by selecting their fonts on an as needed basis. That a model railroad control program has any legitimate need to do all this font pre-processing seems really, really, strange. I feel pretty sure that if the developer that added this had more than a few fonts available on his system, it never would have happened in the first place, because he would have seen the huge negative impact that it can have on JMRI performance for some users. Sorry, but yes, I do consider a 50% reduction in my processor availability for 5-6 minutes after JMRI is started to be a "huge negative" impact.&gt; &gt; Dick :)&gt; &gt;&gt; On 04/28/2018 12:00 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt; Thanks.  If those samples are representative (no reason to believe they’re not, but just in case) then that huge chunk of time really is in java.awt.Component.getFontMetrics(), the method we’re calling repeatedly to get information on each font.  AFAIK, there’s not much we can do to speed that up from JMRI other than to not call it. (Don’t know if there’s anything that can be done outside JMRI to pre-index fonts or anything like that)&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Not sure why you’re not seeing the disk light working.  There are calls to java.nio methods from the PrepareFontLists thread in those snapshots, so somebody is requesting I/O (probably getFontMetrics() but I can’t say that for sure).  Maybe that info is somehow already cached somewhere?  That would be consistent with the font thread running (close to) 100% of one core on your machine, i.e. not waiting for anything.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; On Apr 26, 2018, at 7:31 PM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Bob,&gt;&gt;&gt; Hopefully this is what you need. I can't make any sense of it.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 04/20/2018 09:25 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks for the CPU plot.  The lack of disk activity makes this appear to be Yet Another Problem, separate from the Windows “load font so you can check it” problem.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; When you get time, could you send me a couple of snapshots taken during that high-CPU phase?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; To do that, open jvisualvm and target JMRI’s running Java process.  Select “Sampler”, then click “CPU”.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;samp-1.nps&gt;&lt;samp-2.nps&gt;&lt;samp-3.nps&gt;&lt;samp-4.nps&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-10-28.png&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-09-42.png&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-08-42.png&gt;------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!         <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob,There is disk activity, but only short winks and blinks. If the disk activity itself was responsible for the slow down, then I would expect the activity light to be on a lot more.Is all this pre-fetched information actually used at some point, or would it work just as well to only get the specific metrics required when a font is actually selected for use? I can not imagine why JMRI needs to know the font metrics of Noto Sans CJK JP Regular, UnBatang, KacstFarsi, or any number of the 100's of other fonts that lurk on my system, much less to recalculate all that information every time the program gets started up.Word processing programs seem to get along just fine by selecting their fonts on an as needed basis. That a model railroad control program has any legitimate need to do all this font pre-processing seems really, really, strange. I feel pretty sure that if the developer that added this had more than a few fonts available on his system, it never would have happened in the first place, because he would have seen the huge negative impact that it can have on JMRI performance for some users. Sorry, but yes, I do consider a 50% reduction in my processor availability for 5-6 minutes after JMRI is started to be a "huge negative" impact.Dick :)On 04/28/2018 12:00 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; Thanks.  If those samples are representative (no reason to believe they’re not, but just in case) then that huge chunk of time really is in java.awt.Component.getFontMetrics(), the method we’re calling repeatedly to get information on each font.  AFAIK, there’s not much we can do to speed that up from JMRI other than to not call it. (Don’t know if there’s anything that can be done outside JMRI to pre-index fonts or anything like that)&gt;&gt; Not sure why you’re not seeing the disk light working.  There are calls to java.nio methods from the PrepareFontLists thread in those snapshots, so somebody is requesting I/O (probably getFontMetrics() but I can’t say that for sure).  Maybe that info is somehow already cached somewhere?  That would be consistent with the font thread running (close to) 100% of one core on your machine, i.e. not waiting for anything.&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt; On Apr 26, 2018, at 7:31 PM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob,&gt;&gt; Hopefully this is what you need. I can't make any sense of it.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 04/20/2018 09:25 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks for the CPU plot.  The lack of disk activity makes this appear to be Yet Another Problem, separate from the Windows “load font so you can check it” problem.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; When you get time, could you send me a couple of snapshots taken during that high-CPU phase?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; To do that, open jvisualvm and target JMRI’s running Java process.  Select “Sampler”, then click “CPU”.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;samp-1.nps&gt;&lt;samp-2.nps&gt;&lt;samp-3.nps&gt;&lt;samp-4.nps&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-10-28.png&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-09-42.png&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-08-42.png&gt;------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
