        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Thanks.  If those samples are representative (no reason to believe they’re not, but just in case) then that huge chunk of time really is in java.awt.Component.getFontMetrics(), the method we’re calling repeatedly to get information on each font.  AFAIK, there’s not much we can do to speed that up from JMRI other than to not call it. (Don’t know if there’s anything that can be done outside JMRI to pre-index fonts or anything like that)Not sure why you’re not seeing the disk light working.  There are calls to java.nio methods from the PrepareFontLists thread in those snapshots, so somebody is requesting I/O (probably getFontMetrics() but I can’t say that for sure).  Maybe that info is somehow already cached somewhere?  That would be consistent with the font thread running (close to) 100% of one core on your machine, i.e. not waiting for anything.Bob&gt; On Apr 26, 2018, at 7:31 PM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Bob,&gt; Hopefully this is what you need. I can't make any sense of it.&gt; &gt; Dick :)&gt; &gt; On 04/20/2018 09:25 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt; Thanks for the CPU plot.  The lack of disk activity makes this appear to be Yet Another Problem, separate from the Windows “load font so you can check it” problem.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; When you get time, could you send me a couple of snapshots taken during that high-CPU phase?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; To do that, open jvisualvm and target JMRI’s running Java process.  Select “Sampler”, then click “CPU”.&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; &lt;samp-1.nps&gt;&lt;samp-2.nps&gt;&lt;samp-3.nps&gt;&lt;samp-4.nps&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-10-28.png&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-09-42.png&gt;&lt;Screenshot from 2018-04-26 22-08-42.png&gt;------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Andrew,Not sure if it is only related to 'stealing' a loco - it seems related to a cab session ending (although that happens when a session is stolen).A dialogue pops up when a session-end message arrives in JMRI saying that the session is no longer active.The 'release' button' is still active, but IIRC clicking it simply changes the state of the button - I don't think it sends any more messages,so it might be just a UI issue...Dave</pre></td>

          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36304088/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Minor bug</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Andrew Crosland &lt;andrew@cr...&gt; - 2018-04-26 19:21:00</small> 
           <div class="attachments">

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Daniel,Thanks for the suggestion.&nbsp; Just changing the TEMP variable from the command line did not help.&nbsp; Seems out logout/login is required for the Temp location to actually change.&nbsp; Changed TEMP via advanced System settings so it would persist across login and then I was able to install.&nbsp; The install took really long time though, as the TEMP location was now on the FlashDisk.&nbsp; (The only choices for TEMP location on this box are RamDisk and FlashDisk. ). It would have been faster to change the RamDisk size, reboot, install, change the RamDisk size back...So I do have 2 options that work.&nbsp; Could live with this, but still wonder if there is something better?&nbsp; In the meantime&nbsp; I plan to increase the Ram to 4Gb.&nbsp; If that works, I'll just permanently increase the RamDisk size.RobinOn Tue, Apr 24, 2018 at 1:33 PM -0700, &lt;db123@...&gt; wrote:One thing you could try is to change the temp folder. I don't know how the installer works, but maybe it uses the environment variable "TEMP".If I launch a command prompt on Windows 8.1 and execute the command "set", one row is:TEMP=C:\Users\daniel\AppData\Local\TempIf I then execute the command:set temp=c:\danieland then run the command "set" again, one of the rows are:TEMP=c:\danielIf you do this, and then run the installer from the command prompt, maybe it uses the new temp folder.RegardsDaniel2018-04-23 21:47 skrev Robin Becker:&gt; Question for Matt Harris or anyone familiar with the windows installer&gt; operation.  I've been testing JMRI on a thin client running Windows&gt; Embedded Standard 7 that I picked up for cheap.   JMRI runs just fine&gt; once installed (and once I managed to find the needed drivers to&gt; interface to the layout and install them).  The system TEMP folder on&gt; the thin client is mapped to a RamDisk that is nominally just 100 MB.&gt; The jmri installer fails part way through with this config, but if I&gt; increase the RamDisk size to 300 MB then the jmri installer runs to&gt; completion.  It's kind of a pain to switch the RamDisk size back and&gt; forth (don't want to leave it at 300 MB since there is only a total of&gt; 2GB RAM in this system).  Perhaps the installer unpacks all the files&gt; to a temporary location prior to copying to the install directory, or&gt; maybe it is just leaving the unpacked files around in the temporary&gt; location until the install is complete?  In any case I was wondering&gt; if it is possible to configure the installer so that it can work with&gt; a TEMP folder that is smaller than 300 MB?  Thanks.&gt; &gt; Robin&gt;------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Question for Matt Harris or anyone familiar with the windows installeroperation.  I've been testing JMRI on a thin client running Windows EmbeddedStandard 7 that I picked up for cheap.   JMRI runs just fine once installed(and once I managed to find the needed drivers to interface to the layoutand install them).  The system TEMP folder on the thin client is mapped to aRamDisk that is nominally just 100 MB.  The jmri installer fails part waythrough with this config, but if I increase the RamDisk size to 300 MB thenthe jmri installer runs to completion.  It's kind of a pain to switch theRamDisk size back and forth (don't want to leave it at 300 MB since there isonly a total of 2GB RAM in this system).  Perhaps the installer unpacks allthe files to a temporary location prior to copying to the install directory,or maybe it is just leaving the unpacked files around in the temporarylocation until the install is complete?  In any case I was wondering if itis possible to configure the installer so that it can work with a TEMPfolder that is smaller than 300 MB?  Thanks.  Robin</pre></td>
        </tr>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36300201/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Layout Editor: Zero length track segments</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dave Sand &lt;dave@sa...&gt; - 2018-04-22 15:06:17</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Final ImplementationZero length is defined as the turnout circle radius.  This is used by the drag/drop automatic segment creation.  This value is the constant SIZE, value of 3, times the selected turnout circle size which defaults to 4, resulting in a radius of 12.  Dropping a turnout point within one grid width of the target results in the automatic segment.  Changing the circle size to 3 requires that the dropped turnout point has to be closer than 9.The automatic track segment gets the block from the stationary turnout.Changes to turnout blocks result in updating each connected track segment if the the track segment length is less than the turnout circle radius.  This occurs regardless of what the track segment is connected to on the other end.Dave Sand&gt; On Apr 21, 2018, at 12:28 PM, George Warner &lt;geowar1@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; On Fri, 20 Apr 2018 15:51:55 -0500, Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; Along those same lines:  If the block assignment for A or B is changed (including removed), the new value is propagated to the zero length track segment if there is one.&gt;&gt; What has not been discussed is the definition of zero length.  If the connection points are on a grid boundary, it probably has a true length of zero.&gt;&gt; There is also the issue of what I call the reversed connecting segment.  This occurs when the turnout legs overlap and the connecting track segment is flipped.&gt; &gt; Perhaps you could define "zero-length" as any length less than the grid size (defaults to 10).&gt; &gt; Initially, I'd just fix the drag-n-drop to connect create zero-length track segment issue (IIRC this is one place in the code)… then look into the other cases.&gt; &gt; -- &gt; Enjoy,&gt; George Warner&gt; eMail, Message, or FaceTime: &lt;geowar1@...&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

           <small>From: George Warner &lt;geowar1@ma...&gt; - 2018-04-21 17:28:13</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/6F9237AA-02CA-4C2E-8C27-AD69AC105EAD%40mac.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>On Fri, 20 Apr 2018 15:51:55 -0500, Dave Sand &lt;dave@... &lt;mailto:dave@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt; Along those same lines:  If the block assignment for A or B is changed (including removed), the new value is propagated to the zero length track segment if there is one.&gt; What has not been discussed is the definition of zero length.  If the connection points are on a grid boundary, it probably has a true length of zero.&gt; There is also the issue of what I call the reversed connecting segment.  This occurs when the turnout legs overlap and the connecting track segment is flipped.Perhaps you could define "zero-length" as any length less than the grid size (defaults to 10).Initially, I'd just fix the drag-n-drop to connect create zero-length track segment issue (IIRC this is one place in the code)… then look into the other cases.-- Enjoy,George WarnereMail, Message, or FaceTime: &lt;geowar1@...&gt;</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36299332">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36299332/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Layout Editor: Zero length track segments</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dave Sand &lt;dave@sa...&gt; - 2018-04-20 20:52:03</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/B511B46A-7066-422B-9596-CE4ADE4CE2D5%40sandsys.org/1/">text/plain</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Along those same lines:  If the block assignment for A or B is changed (including removed), the new value is propagated to the zero length track segment if there is one.What has not been discussed is the definition of zero length.  If the connection points are on a grid boundary, it probably has a true length of zero.There is also the issue of what I call the reversed connecting segment.  This occurs when the turnout legs overlap and the connecting track segment is flipped.This kind of connection segment is also hidden. But definitely not zero length.Dave Sand&gt; On Apr 20, 2018, at 1:34 PM, George Warner &lt;geowar1@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; On Fri, 20 Apr 2018 16:11:23 +0000, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; On Fri, Apr 20, 2018 at 12:10 PM Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;   - If neither turnout has a block, the connecting segment does not have&gt;&gt;&gt;   a block.&gt;&gt;&gt;   - If either turnout has a block, use that block for the connecting&gt;&gt;&gt;   segment.&gt;&gt;&gt;   - If both turnouts have blocks that are different, pick one.&gt;&gt;&gt;   - If both turnouts have the same block, use that block for the&gt;&gt;&gt;   connecting segment.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; The rules would be applied when the connecting track segment is&gt;&gt;&gt; automatically created or when the block assignment for either turnout is&gt;&gt;&gt; changed.  Manual changes to the connecting track segment would be allowed&gt;&gt;&gt; since the segment no longer has a zero length.&gt;&gt; Isn?t rule 4 a degenerate case of rule 3?&gt; &gt; Actually the simplest (degenerate case) rule would be:&gt; &gt; When dragging object A onto object B if object A has an assigned block use it otherwise use object B's block (assigned or not).&gt; &gt; This handles all the above cases.&gt; &gt; (In theory you could randomly swap objects A &amp; B (if they have different assigned blocks) but there's no real value added in doing that for a zero-length track segment.)&gt; -- &gt; Enjoy,&gt; George Warner&gt; eMail, Message, or FaceTime: &lt;geowar1@...&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36299256">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36299256/">[Jmri-developers] Layout Editor: Zero length track segments</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: George Warner &lt;geowar1@ma...&gt; - 2018-04-20 19:34:33</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/86F3E53D-37F6-43F0-9CE1-E4D0DF814856%40mac.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>On Fri, 20 Apr 2018 16:11:23 +0000, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@... &lt;mailto:msunderwd@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt; On Fri, Apr 20, 2018 at 12:10 PM Dave Sand &lt;dave@... &lt;mailto:dave@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;   - If neither turnout has a block, the connecting segment does not have&gt;&gt;   a block.&gt;&gt;   - If either turnout has a block, use that block for the connecting&gt;&gt;   segment.&gt;&gt;   - If both turnouts have blocks that are different, pick one.&gt;&gt;   - If both turnouts have the same block, use that block for the&gt;&gt;   connecting segment.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; The rules would be applied when the connecting track segment is&gt;&gt; automatically created or when the block assignment for either turnout is&gt;&gt; changed.  Manual changes to the connecting track segment would be allowed&gt;&gt; since the segment no longer has a zero length.&gt; Isn?t rule 4 a degenerate case of rule 3?Actually the simplest (degenerate case) rule would be:When dragging object A onto object B if object A has an assigned block use it otherwise use object B's block (assigned or not).This handles all the above cases.(In theory you could randomly swap objects A &amp; B (if they have different assigned blocks) but there's no real value added in doing that for a zero-length track segment.)-- Enjoy,George WarnereMail, Message, or FaceTime: &lt;geowar1@...&gt;</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Mark,It took me a while to understand what you meant by degenerate, but I got there.The fourth rule is eliminated and the third one becomes:If both turnouts have blocks (which may or may not be the same), pick one for the connecting segment.Thanks.Dave Sand&gt; On Apr 20, 2018, at 11:11 AM, Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Isn’t rule 4 a degenerate case of rule 3?&gt; On Fri, Apr 20, 2018 at 12:10 PM Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Ken,&gt; &gt; That covers the case where the two turnouts have different blocks.&gt; &gt; What I am looking at fixing is the case where the two turnouts have the same block and the resulting “gap” which breaks the contiguous track component requirement for blocks. &gt; &gt; New rules:&gt; 	• If neither turnout has a block, the connecting segment does not have a block.&gt; 	• If either turnout has a block, use that block for the connecting segment.&gt; 	• If both turnouts have blocks that are different, pick one.&gt; 	• If both turnouts have the same block, use that block for the connecting segment.&gt; The rules would be applied when the connecting track segment is automatically created or when the block assignment for either turnout is changed.  Manual changes to the connecting track segment would be allowed since the segment no longer has a zero length.&gt; &gt; &gt; Dave Sand&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; On Apr 20, 2018, at 10:28 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Dave S,&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I had thought there was discussion of this issue a few months ago. The&gt;&gt; conclusion at the time was picking either attached block would be valid.&gt;&gt; Since it was invisible, it doesn't really matter which block.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Isn’t rule 4 a degenerate case of rule 3?On Fri, Apr 20, 2018 at 12:10 PM Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Ken,&gt;&gt; That covers the case where the two turnouts have different blocks.&gt;&gt; What I am looking at fixing is the case where the two turnouts have the&gt; same block and the resulting “gap” which breaks the contiguous track&gt; component requirement for blocks.&gt;&gt; New rules:&gt;&gt;    - If neither turnout has a block, the connecting segment does not have&gt;    a block.&gt;    - If either turnout has a block, use that block for the connecting&gt;    segment.&gt;    - If both turnouts have blocks that are different, pick one.&gt;    - If both turnouts have the same block, use that block for the&gt;    connecting segment.&gt;&gt; The rules would be applied when the connecting track segment is&gt; automatically created or when the block assignment for either turnout is&gt; changed.         <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Ken,That covers the case where the two turnouts have different blocks.What I am looking at fixing is the case where the two turnouts have the same block and the resulting “gap” which breaks the contiguous track component requirement for blocks. New rules:If neither turnout has a block, the connecting segment does not have a block.If either turnout has a block, use that block for the connecting segment.If both turnouts have blocks that are different, pick one.If both turnouts have the same block, use that block for the connecting segment.The rules would be applied when the connecting track segment is automatically created or when the block assignment for either turnout is changed.  Manual changes to the connecting track segment would be allowed since the segment no longer has a zero length.Dave Sand&gt; On Apr 20, 2018, at 10:28 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Dave S,&gt; &gt; I had thought there was discussion of this issue a few months ago. The&gt; conclusion at the time was picking either attached block would be valid.&gt; Since it was invisible, it doesn't really matter which block.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; </pre></td>

      <table id="msg36299036">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36299036/">[Jmri-developers] Layout Editor: Zero length track segments</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dave Sand &lt;dave@sa...&gt; - 2018-04-20 14:38:27</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>When creating a track plan, it is possible to connect turnouts together by dragging one so that the connection points overlap.  This automatically creates the required track segment between the turnouts.  The track segment has a zero length and is effectively invisible unless one of the turnouts is moved to expose the track segment.Since this track segment is not visible, it is frequently missed when assigning blocks.  This results in unpredictable behavior for features that rely on block connectivity. Which then result in numerous support questions.The fix that I plan to create is that when two *turnouts* with the same block are connected by a track segment without a block assignment or a different block, the track segment is changed to use the turnout block.*turnout* includes cross-overs, slips and level crossings.Any feedback?Dave Sand</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36298958">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header">

           </div>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Thanks for the CPU plot.  The lack of disk activity makes this appear to be Yet Another Problem, separate from the Windows “load font so you can check it” problem.  When you get time, could you send me a couple of snapshots taken during that high-CPU phase?  To do that, open jvisualvm and target JMRI’s running Java process.  Select “Sampler”, then click “CPU”.You get “Sampling in progress” followed by some “hot spots” which will update occasionally. That might point to were all the CPU time is going,but if there’s nothing obvious there, click “Snapshot” (which changes the screen layout) and then the odd “export to” icon:That lets you store the snapshot into a file (by convention, with a .nps extension).  Two or three of these might make it possible to track this down a bit.  Not sure I can fix it, of course, because what we’ve got there is now quite complex.  In that case, the right solution (which I favor anyway) is to go back to the nice clean code that Matt Harris originally wrote.Bob&gt; On Apr 20, 2018, at 5:28 AM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Bob,&gt; OK, running JMRI.4.11.6ish+jenkins+20180419T2149Z+Raca91d7.tgz&gt; &gt; It still hogs resources like they were free for 5-6 minutes, (see attached) but it no longer blocks the opening of the Preferences window. It looks cleaner on the thread monitor as well running as a single thread.&gt; &gt; Thanks for re-arranging whatever you did. You mentioned that the delay might be from disk accesses, but that doesn't seem to be evident. I.e. my disk activity is not high based on the front panel LED.&gt; &gt; Thanks,&gt; &gt; Dick :)&gt; &gt; &gt; On 04/19/2018 12:54 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt; Oops, sorry for the confusion.             <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36298186/">Re: [Jmri-developers] [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux</a></b>
           </div>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36298113/">Re: [Jmri-developers] [jmriusers] Delayed Window Opening in Linux</a></b>

           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-04-19 15:11:01</small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>There is fix to make this quite a bit better. Bob J did some coding so veryfew parts of JMRI will care about this font processing. Normal startup,preferences, and tables don't delay waiting for this. The core problem ofwhy it takes so long with certain fonts still exists, but only if somethingneeded those fonts as I understand it.This has been merged and will be part of 4.11.6 and is part of the dailybuilds now. It was impacting a lot of Windows systems too, but only when youhad other software loaded that installed lots of fonts. So if you had acomputer that only was (ever) used with simple things like JMRI, it wouldn'tbe noticeable. But if it had big packages of software like the Office suitesor Adobe larger products, you had a long wait.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Could you try development build #2466 or later please?  (<a href="http://jmri.tagadab.com/jenkins/job/Development/job/Builds/2466/" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.tagadab.com/jenkins/job/Development/job/Builds/2466/</a> though it’s always nice to have somebody try the latest <a href="http://jmri.tagadab.com/jenkins/job/Development/job/Builds/" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.tagadab.com/jenkins/job/Development/job/Builds/</a> )  That has some code to try to mitigate the problem that seems to help on Windows.  If it doesn’t help on Linux, that would be _very_ interesting.Bob &gt; On Apr 19, 2018, at 7:27 AM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; John,&gt; Actually this IS related to the font loading issue. I have copied your message over to the developers group to let the developer that added the font preprocessing know that it is still broken. I have complained about this multiple times since it was introduced, but it has still not been either fixed or removed. Maybe the developer doesn't use Linux so it doesn't affect him.&gt; &gt; I use Ubuntu with very different system interfaces and it has the same problem. On my machine it blocks for over 5 minutes which can be a real issue when I am trying to do tech support. Part of the problem seems to be that it only checks one font style per second, and some operations (like opening preferences) seem to be blocked until the process has completed. Apparently this issue is not limited to Linux users, but apparently the delay is not as extreme under Windows, or the mass of users complaining about this would be huge. (maybe Windows users just have fewer font styles to check)&gt; &gt; Dick :)&gt; &gt; On 04/18/2018 09:29 AM, jdltrains@... [jmriusers] wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; When trying to open the preferences window in either Decoder Pro or Panel Pro it takes anywhere from 3 to 5 minutes to load the window. I can go to the windows menu on the main Panel Pro screen and can see the preferences in the dropdown. If I check the box the window opens but it’s blank for 3-5 minutes before it populates. This sounds very similar to the issue in this thread Re: Roster Edit only not working in 4.11.5 decoder pro <a href="https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/jmriusers/conversations/topics/148580;_ylc=X3oDMTJzYWhmNmlzBF9TAzk3MzU5NzE1BGdycElkAzY2MDI3NTgEZ3Jwc3BJZAMxNzA1MDYzNTc2BG1zZ0lkAzE0ODU4MARzZWMDZG1zZwRzbGsDdm1zZwRzdGltZQMxNTIzOTgxNDgw" rel="nofollow">https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/jmriusers/conversations/topics/148580;_ylc=X3oDMTJzYWhmNmlzBF9TAzk3MzU5NzE1BGdycElkAzY2MDI3NTgEZ3Jwc3BJZAMxNzA1MDYzNTc2BG1zZ0lkAzE0ODU4MARzZWMDZG1zZwRzbGsDdm1zZwRzdGltZQMxNTIzOTgxNDgw</a> but it only happens to me when trying to open the preferences window. All my tables, rosters, panels work fine and there are no warnings or errors in either the system console or session logs. I was running 4.11.4 so I tried the latest test version of 4.11.5 and still have the same problem.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Dell Inspiron 15 Laptop&gt;&gt; Linux Mint Cinnimon 18.03 64x&gt;&gt; Java 1.8.0_161 64x&gt;&gt; JMRI 4.11.4 then 4.11.5&gt;&gt; NCE thru Keyspan 19 HS USA&gt;&gt; CMRI thru Keyspan 19HS USA&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I also saw some posts and issues posted in Github about fonts loading causing delayed window openings which may or may not be my issue.          <td class="email-body"><pre>John,Actually this IS related to the font loading issue. I have copied your message over to the developers group to let the developer that added the font preprocessing know that it is still broken. I have complained about this multiple times since it was introduced, but it has still not been either fixed or removed. Maybe the developer doesn't use Linux so it doesn't affect him.I use Ubuntu with very different system interfaces and it has the same problem. On my machine it blocks for over 5 minutes which can be a real issue when I am trying to do tech support. Part of the problem seems to be that it only checks one font style per second, and some operations (like opening preferences) seem to be blocked until the process has completed. Apparently this issue is not limited to Linux users, but apparently the delay is not as extreme under Windows, or the mass of users complaining about this would be huge. (maybe Windows users just have fewer font styles to check)Dick :)On 04/18/2018 09:29 AM, jdltrains@... [jmriusers] wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; When trying to open the preferences window in either Decoder Pro or &gt; Panel Pro it takes anywhere from 3 to 5 minutes to load the window. I &gt; can go to the windows menu on the main Panel Pro screen and can see &gt; the preferences in the dropdown. If I check the box the window opens &gt; but it’s blank for 3-5 minutes before it populates. This sounds very &gt; similar to the issue in this thread Re: Roster Edit only not working &gt; in 4.11.5 decoder pro &gt; <a href="https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/jmriusers/conversations/topics/148580;_ylc=X3oDMTJzYWhmNmlzBF9TAzk3MzU5NzE1BGdycElkAzY2MDI3NTgEZ3Jwc3BJZAMxNzA1MDYzNTc2BG1zZ0lkAzE0ODU4MARzZWMDZG1zZwRzbGsDdm1zZwRzdGltZQMxNTIzOTgxNDgw" rel="nofollow">https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/jmriusers/conversations/topics/148580;_ylc=X3oDMTJzYWhmNmlzBF9TAzk3MzU5NzE1BGdycElkAzY2MDI3NTgEZ3Jwc3BJZAMxNzA1MDYzNTc2BG1zZ0lkAzE0ODU4MARzZWMDZG1zZwRzbGsDdm1zZwRzdGltZQMxNTIzOTgxNDgw</a> &gt; but it only happens to me when trying to open the preferences window. &gt; All my tables, rosters, panels work fine and there are no warnings or &gt; errors in either the system console or session logs. I was running &gt; 4.11.4 so I tried the latest test version of 4.11.5 and still have the &gt; same problem.&gt;&gt;&gt; Dell Inspiron 15 Laptop&gt; Linux Mint Cinnimon 18.03 64x&gt; Java 1.8.0_161 64x&gt; JMRI 4.11.4 then 4.11.5&gt; NCE thru Keyspan 19 HS USA&gt; CMRI thru Keyspan 19HS USA&gt;&gt;&gt; I also saw some posts and issues posted in Github about fonts loading &gt; causing delayed window openings which may or may not be my issue.          <td class="email-body"><pre>I’m sorry, but there’s a limit to how much time I’m going to put into a problem that I advised against creating in the first place. The branch is here <a href="https://github.com/bobjacobsen/JMRI/tree/font-synchronization" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/bobjacobsen/JMRI/tree/font-synchronization</a> the only relevant commit is: <a href="https://github.com/bobjacobsen/JMRI/commit/e4d008e75464ae280432a48c5461ec7e3f7f7d78" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/bobjacobsen/JMRI/commit/e4d008e75464ae280432a48c5461ec7e3f7f7d78</a>  There are multiple sets of instructions around for how to access a remote branch, depending on one’s local setup, favorite IDE, etc.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>In this case my profile had a LocoNet simulator, NCE simulator, NCE monitorand the main window. Next I tried to open the preferences.            <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36294167/">[Jmri-developers] Font survey problem still three (was: Re: First 4.11.5 files available</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-04-15 18:13:12</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>That’s the same problem with pre-loading all the fonts.  The “PrepareFontListsThread” thread is running. Meanwhile, 147 “FontComboUtil Prepare” threads are blocked. (It would be interesting to know where those all come from; are you opening a bunch of windows at the start?) The “init prefs” thread is blocked in jmri.util.swing.FontComboUtil.prepareFontLists(..) That’s all tangled up in this wait:"TabbedPreferencesAction actionPerformed" #74 prio=6 os_prio=0tid=0x0000000022ea2800 nid=0xe4 waiting for monitor entry[0x000000002817e000]  java.lang.Thread.State: BLOCKED (on object monitor)       at apps.gui3.TabbedPreferences.init(TabbedPreferences.java:138)       - waiting to lock &lt;0x0000000082c3e928&gt; (aapps.gui3.TabbedPreferences)       atapps.gui3.TabbedPreferencesAction.lambda$0(TabbedPreferencesAction.java:87)       atapps.gui3.TabbedPreferencesAction$$Lambda$133/386599598.run(Unknown Source)       at java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source)The real problem here is that we’re trying to be smarter than Java by creating a bunch of pre-loaded status information for fonts.  That’s not a supported operation in the JVM.  Java gives you fast access to the names of fonts, but as we’ve learned access to the property set of a font can be slow, and there can be a lot of fonts.So we have two choices:1) Either get serious about it, and create caching utilities that work across all the various OS, font type, etc combinations2) Or just stop trying to do it.Personally, if this was my problem to solve, I’d go with (2).Bob&gt; On Apr 15, 2018, at 10:47 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Bob,&gt; &gt; Here is one from the 4.11.5. I waited 30 seconds, no preference getting&gt; filled in. I did have it open via the windows tab.&gt; -ken c&gt; &gt; 2018-04-15 13:44:04&gt; Full thread dump Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (25.161-b12 mixed mode):&gt; &gt; "FontComboUtil Prepare" #198 prio=6 os_prio=0 tid=0x00000000235c7000&gt; nid=0x24c0 waiting for monitor entry [0x000000003077f000]&gt;   java.lang.Thread.State: BLOCKED (on object monitor)&gt;        at&gt; jmri.util.swing.FontComboUtil.prepareFontLists(FontComboUtil.java:94)&gt;             <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36294117/">Re: [Jmri-developers] First 4.11.5 files available</a></b>

           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-04-15 16:40:35</small>

            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/75E7F353-C45B-4550-B5DB-8A714ED01596%40mac.com/1/">text/plain</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Almost.  I think you selected the jvisualvm process instead of the JMRI one.  On a Mac, there’s a place on the upper right side of the jvisualvm screen that’ll lets you pick the process you want to watch; it’s probably somewhat similar on Linux. Please select the one that’s showing e.g. PanelPro:Bob&gt; On Apr 15, 2018, at 5:35 AM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; On 04/14/2018 10:49 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt; Could we get a thread trace while it’s stalled, please?  If you’re running from the command line, ctrl-\ should do it.          <td class="email-body"><pre>Matt,Thanks.  Bob mentioned the long strings but I didn't get the part aboutgoing to "Special Builds" on nsis.sourceforge.net.  I downloaded the largestrings built, copied the files over the existing ones in ProgramFiles(x86)/NSIS, then rebuilt launchjmri.exe.   The new launchjmri.exesuccessfully brings up jmri on my test box, although it still doesn't matchthe .exe on jmri master so it shows up as a change in the Github app.   Thisis NSIS 3.03 so maybe that is the reason?  In any case think I'm going now.Robin-----Original Message-----From: Matthew Harris &lt;matthew.john.harris@...&gt; Sent: Friday, April 13, 2018 2:58 AMTo: Discussions between JMRI developers&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] issue building launchjmri.exe with EclipseRobin,This sounds pretty indicative of compiling LaunchJMRI.exe using the regularNSIS compiler as opposed to the long strings version - see comment at top ofsource file&lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/scripts/WinInstallFiles/LaunchJMRI" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/scripts/WinInstallFiles/LaunchJMRI</a>.nsi#L21&gt;The standard NSIS compiler reserves 1024 bytes for strings - this has provento be too short for our generated classpath in the vast majority ofcircumstances. The alternate long-strings NSIS compiler reserves 8192 bytesfor strings which has been demonstrated to be sufficient.To verify the string length in your compiled version, add the `/debug` flagto the LaunchJMRI.exe command line - see&lt;<a href="http://jmri.org/install/WindowsNew.shtml#startupissues>" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/install/WindowsNew.shtml#startupissues&gt;</a>; and look for thevalue reported by 'MaxLen' - if it's 1024, that indicates the wrong compilerhaving been used.The installer, however, is fine to be compiled using the standard NSIScompiler.Hope that helps.Best regards,Matt HOn 13 April 2018 at 02:15, Robin Becker &lt;rbgroups@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Dave,&gt;&gt; So it appears that my symptoms are a bit different from yours?  I can &gt; build launchjmri.exe without error, but the resulting .exe doesn't &gt; match the .exe in JMRI master.  The Windows package also builds fine &gt; and the install of the package goes fine.  After that JMRI hangs on &gt; launch if I use the launchjmri.exe that I built, but if I replace it &gt; with the one from JMRI master then JMRI runs fine.&gt;&gt; Robin&gt;&gt;&gt; -----Original Message-----&gt; From: Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@...&gt;&gt; Sent: Thursday, April 12, 2018 3:20 PM&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers &gt; &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] issue building launchjmri.exe with &gt; Eclipse&gt;&gt; Clarification. The installation seem to work fine and I was able to &gt; build the Windows package, but it always hung during install on Windows.&gt;&gt; Maybe I should try it again...&gt;&gt; Sent from my iPad&gt; --&gt; Dave&gt;&gt;&gt; On 13 Apr 2018, at 8:17 AM, Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I did try using Homebrew to install the required version of NSIS with &gt;&gt; long&gt; string support following some instructions given to me by Randall, but &gt; it didn't work for either of us.&gt;&gt; ----------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------&gt; --&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most &gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!             <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36291631/">Re: [Jmri-developers] issue building launchjmri.exe with Eclipse</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Matthew Harris &lt;matthew.john.harris@gm...&gt; - 2018-04-13 09:57:43</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Robin,This sounds pretty indicative of compiling LaunchJMRI.exe using theregular NSIS compiler as opposed to the long strings version - seecomment at top of source file&lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/scripts/WinInstallFiles/LaunchJMRI.nsi#L21>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/scripts/WinInstallFiles/LaunchJMRI.nsi#L21&gt;</a>;The standard NSIS compiler reserves 1024 bytes for strings - this hasproven to be too short for our generated classpath in the vastmajority of circumstances. The alternate long-strings NSIS compilerreserves 8192 bytes for strings which has been demonstrated to besufficient.To verify the string length in your compiled version, add the `/debug`flag to the LaunchJMRI.exe command line - see&lt;<a href="http://jmri.org/install/WindowsNew.shtml#startupissues>" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/install/WindowsNew.shtml#startupissues&gt;</a>; and look forthe value reported by 'MaxLen' - if it's 1024, that indicates thewrong compiler having been used.The installer, however, is fine to be compiled using the standard NSIS compiler.Hope that helps.Best regards,Matt HOn 13 April 2018 at 02:15, Robin Becker &lt;rbgroups@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Dave,&gt;&gt; So it appears that my symptoms are a bit different from yours?  I can build&gt; launchjmri.exe without error, but the resulting .exe doesn't match the .exe&gt; in JMRI master.  The Windows package also builds fine and the install of the&gt; package goes fine.  After that JMRI hangs on launch if I use the&gt; launchjmri.exe that I built, but if I replace it with the one from JMRI&gt; master then JMRI runs fine.&gt;&gt; Robin&gt;&gt;&gt; -----Original Message-----&gt; From: Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@...&gt;&gt; Sent: Thursday, April 12, 2018 3:20 PM&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers&gt; &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] issue building launchjmri.exe with Eclipse&gt;&gt; Clarification. The installation seem to work fine and I was able to build&gt; the Windows package, but it always hung during install on Windows.&gt;&gt; Maybe I should try it again...&gt;&gt; Sent from my iPad&gt; --&gt; Dave&gt;&gt;&gt; On 13 Apr 2018, at 8:17 AM, Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I did try using Homebrew to install the required version of NSIS with long&gt; string support following some instructions given to me by Randall, but it&gt; didn't work for either of us.&gt;&gt; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; --&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engaging&gt; tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Not sure if it’s related, but on Jenkins we have a special version of the NSIS tool installed.  I _think_ that’s because some of the strings (i.e. the classpath) are so long that the original NSIS couldn’t handle them.  There’s a note in scripts/HOWTO-distribution.md* You need to have installed NSIS from <a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net" rel="nofollow">http://nsis.sourceforge.net</a> (we use version 3.01 with long string support; see [Issue 3913](<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/3913" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/3913</a>) for instructions on how to build that for Linux)Bob&gt; On Apr 11, 2018, at 10:03 AM, Robin Becker &lt;rbgroups@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Hi.          <td class="email-body"><pre>Can that new version of the FREDI use a bit to control “address valid” or not instead of a magic value?  In that case, your choice (2) seems much better.  Although I understand that legacy equipment can make them necessary, magic values like 0xFFFF, 0x3FFF, or -1 always seem a bit forced and confusing to me.Bob&gt; On Apr 8, 2018, at 1:34 AM, Martin Pischky &lt;martin@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Hello Bob, Hello *,&gt; &gt; Thanks to all for your suggestions and help.&gt; &gt; Am 07.04.2018 um 18:09 schrieb Bob Jacobsen:&gt;&gt; Knut, there’s something here I don’t understand.  It sounds like you&gt;&gt; want to, under some circumstances, put the value 65535 into a DCC&gt;&gt; long address field. &gt; &gt; Yes. But it's the loco address field of FREDI throttle. The&gt; meaning of the value should be "NO LOCO IS ASSIGN". This&gt; value will never be send to Master over loconet. We need&gt; such value when no loco should be controlled by the throttle&gt; (Daniel explained that). Current software version uses "0"&gt; for this purpose, but "0" disables use of DC controlled&gt; locos what is supported by some LocoNet-CUs. So&gt; we would like to use different value (0xFFFF for example)&gt; for next software version.&gt; &gt; From this discussion I see two solutions we should try:&gt; &gt; 1.) Use -1 to 10239 as range for SV 8 and 9 and hope&gt; that value -1 gets 0xFFFF when written. May be we have to&gt; use upperMask="VVVVVVVV" for this.&gt; &gt; 2.) Add a second control (Drop-Down-List or Checkbox)&gt; labeled "NO LOCO ASSIGNED" that sets bit 7 of SV 8 and/or 9.&gt; &gt; Martin&gt; &gt; -- &gt; ----------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Martin Pischky, Oisseler Strasse 1C, 30559 Hannover, Germany&gt; <a href="http://www.pischky.de" rel="nofollow">http://www.pischky.de</a> mailto:martin@...&gt; tel: +49 511 7000665 mobile: +49 151 11592222&gt; ----------------------------------------------------------------&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hello Bob, Hello *,Thanks to all for your suggestions and help.Am 07.04.2018 um 18:09 schrieb Bob Jacobsen:&gt; Knut, there’s something here I don’t understand.  It sounds like you&gt; want to, under some circumstances, put the value 65535 into a DCC&gt; long address field.Yes. But it's the loco address field of FREDI throttle. Themeaning of the value should be "NO LOCO IS ASSIGN". Thisvalue will never be send to Master over loconet. We needsuch value when no loco should be controlled by the throttle(Daniel explained that). Current software version uses "0"for this purpose, but "0" disables use of DC controlledlocos what is supported by some LocoNet-CUs. Sowe would like to use different value (0xFFFF for example)for next software version.&gt;From this discussion I see two solutions we should try:1.) Use -1 to 10239 as range for SV 8 and 9 and hopethat value -1 gets 0xFFFF when written. May be we have touse upperMask="VVVVVVVV" for this.2.) Add a second control (Drop-Down-List or Checkbox)labeled "NO LOCO ASSIGNED" that sets bit 7 of SV 8 and/or 9.Martin-- ----------------------------------------------------------------Martin Pischky, Oisseler Strasse 1C, 30559 Hannover, Germany<a href="http://www.pischky.de" rel="nofollow">http://www.pischky.de</a> mailto:martin@...tel: +49 511 7000665 mobile: +49 151 11592222----------------------------------------------------------------</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hello Bob, Hello *,Thanks to all for your suggestions and help.Am 07.04.2018 um 18:09 schrieb Bob Jacobsen:&gt; Knut, there’s something here I don’t understand.  It sounds like you&gt; want to, under some circumstances, put the value 65535 into a DCC&gt; long address field. Yes. But it's the loco address field of FREDI throttle. Themeaning of the value should be "NO LOCO IS ASSIGN". Thisvalue will never be send to Master over loconet. We needsuch value when no loco should be controlled by the throttle(Daniel explained that). Current software version uses "0"for this purpose, but "0" disables use of DC controlledlocos what is supported by some LocoNet-CUs. Sowe would like to use different value (0xFFFF for example)for next software version.&gt;From this discussion I see two solutions we should try:1.) Use -1 to 10239 as range for SV 8 and 9 and hopethat value -1 gets 0xFFFF when written. May be we have touse upperMask="VVVVVVVV" for this.2.) Add a second control (Drop-Down-List or Checkbox)labeled "NO LOCO ASSIGNED" that sets bit 7 of SV 8 and/or 9.Martin-- ----------------------------------------------------------------Martin Pischky, Oisseler Strasse 1C, 30559 Hannover, Germany<a href="http://www.pischky.de" rel="nofollow">http://www.pischky.de</a> mailto:martin@...tel: +49 511 7000665 mobile: +49 151 11592222----------------------------------------------------------------</pre></td>

      <table id="msg36287140">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36287140/">Re: [Jmri-developers] XML Handling</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: &lt;db123@be...&gt; - 2018-04-08 01:56:46</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>The FRED throttle can have two different states. Either it has a loco address or it doesn't. The FRED itself has no way to enter an address so it gets the loco address by dispatching from the LocoNet central. What I mean is that is that another throttle needs to dispatch the loco address to the FRED.Under some circumstances the FRED may lose its loco address, for example if some other controller is using that address or if the user decides to undispatch the loco address.RegardsDaniel2018-04-07 18:09 skrev Bob Jacobsen:&gt; I think the email below is where the “can CVs be signed” subthread&gt; started. Instead of getting diverted by that, I think we should stick&gt; with the actual issue presented.&gt; &gt; Knut, there’s something here I don’t understand.  It sounds like you&gt; want to, under some circumstances, put the value 65535 into a DCC long&gt; address field. Since that’s not possible  (the NMRA definition for&gt; long address doesn’t have space for that value), I must be&gt; misunderstanding something.&gt; &gt; What does that value do?  In what sense are CV 8 and 9 a “DCC long &gt; address”?&gt; &gt; Also, that masks in that element define a 14-bit field that doesn’t&gt; include the MSB in CV 8 and 9.  That doesn’t allow a value as big as&gt; 65535.  Is this just an mistake, or is there some need to reserve&gt; those two bits for another purpose?&gt; &gt; Thanks and sorry for the confusion.&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt;&gt; On Apr 6, 2018, at 11:50 AM, Knut Schwichtenberg &lt;kschwi@...&gt; &gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Hello,&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I'm trying to improve FREDi XML file. My problem is the value range &gt;&gt; for&gt;&gt; the DCC address. DCC addresses are valid in the range from 0 to 10239.&gt;&gt; To define the undispatched in FREDi status, the address value of 65535&gt;&gt; (0xffff) is defined. Currently "Public_Domain_FREDi_LNSV2.xml" is&gt;&gt; implement as below.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ....&gt;&gt; &lt;variable CV="9" item="Advanced Group 1 Option 6"&gt;&gt;                       readOnly="no" mask="XVVVVVVV"&gt;&gt;                       comment="Loco address"&gt;&gt;&gt;                 &lt;splitVal highCV="8" upperMask="XVVVVVVV" /&gt;&gt;&gt; &lt;/variable&gt;&gt;&gt; ...&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Currently "min" and "max" are missing, which only extends the address&gt;&gt; range. How can I define the value of 0xffff (-1) as valid within the&gt;&gt; JMRI dialogue?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I think the email below is where the “can CVs be signed” subthread started. Instead of getting diverted by that, I think we should stick with the actual issue presented.Knut, there’s something here I don’t understand.  It sounds like you want to, under some circumstances, put the value 65535 into a DCC long address field. Since that’s not possible  (the NMRA definition for long address doesn’t have space for that value), I must be misunderstanding something.  What does that value do?  In what sense are CV 8 and 9 a “DCC long address”?Also, that masks in that element define a 14-bit field that doesn’t include the MSB in CV 8 and 9.  That doesn’t allow a value as big as 65535.  Is this just an mistake, or is there some need to reserve those two bits for another purpose?Thanks and sorry for the confusion.Bob&gt; On Apr 6, 2018, at 11:50 AM, Knut Schwichtenberg &lt;kschwi@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Hello,&gt; &gt; I'm trying to improve FREDi XML file. My problem is the value range for&gt; the DCC address. DCC addresses are valid in the range from 0 to 10239.&gt; To define the undispatched in FREDi status, the address value of 65535&gt; (0xffff) is defined. Currently "Public_Domain_FREDi_LNSV2.xml" is&gt; implement as below.&gt; &gt; ....&gt; &lt;variable CV="9" item="Advanced Group 1 Option 6"&gt;                       readOnly="no" mask="XVVVVVVV"&gt;                       comment="Loco address"&gt;&gt;                 &lt;splitVal highCV="8" upperMask="XVVVVVVV" /&gt;&gt; &lt;/variable&gt;&gt; ...&gt; &gt; Currently "min" and "max" are missing, which only extends the address&gt; range. How can I define the value of 0xffff (-1) as valid within the&gt; JMRI dialogue?&gt; &gt; --Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Thanks for trying that. “Negative” CV values aren’t something that’s come up, so there are no JUnit tests in place, so various systems probably don’t handle them.I agree there are are lots of other things to work on. As to whether it should get any attention, was the original question just speculation, or is there some specific need?Bob&gt; On Apr 7, 2018, at 2:34 AM, Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Just tried entering -1 in a CV value on the CVs pane.&gt; &gt; Any negative value causes the write to be transmuted into a Read Command in the NCE Simulator, but the displayed value in the pane doesn't change and instead a 301 No Loco Detected is returned, despite the simulator returning a 7B 21 (value 123 was read successfully).&gt; &gt; Doing the same on another pane (where there is a decVal with implicit 0-255 range) is displayed as the unsigned equivalent (-1 =&gt;255, -10=&gt;246) after entry is done and the correct unsigned value equivalent is written.&gt; &gt; All is not well on the CVs pane... I doubt it's the simulator at fault.&gt; &gt; I'm not about to go looking for the cause. Had a relaxing day with a return train trip for a luncheon and too many irons in the fire at present with WIP code.&gt; &gt; Sent from my iPad&gt; -- &gt; Dave&gt; &gt;&gt; On 7 Apr 2018, at 8:31 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; By default, the ‘min’ attribute is zero. You can set it negative in decimal formatted (DecVal) variables and it should work as an entry field, slider, etc. it still becomes “just bits” when written to the device, so the device has to handle it properly. And masking the value may make that confusing....&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Negative min values would probably not work for enumerated values; hex values will “work”, in the sense they’ll be mathematically correct,  but I expect that most people will consider the behavior odd especially when masked. &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Just tried entering -1 in a CV value on the CVs pane.Any negative value causes the write to be transmuted into a Read Command in the NCE Simulator, but the displayed value in the pane doesn't change and instead a 301 No Loco Detected is returned, despite the simulator returning a 7B 21 (value 123 was read successfully).Doing the same on another pane (where there is a decVal with implicit 0-255 range) is displayed as the unsigned equivalent (-1 =&gt;255, -10=&gt;246) after entry is done and the correct unsigned value equivalent is written.All is not well on the CVs pane... I doubt it's the simulator at fault.I'm not about to go looking for the cause. Had a relaxing day with a return train trip for a luncheon and too many irons in the fire at present with WIP code.Sent from my iPad-- Dave&gt; On 7 Apr 2018, at 8:31 AM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; By default, the ‘min’ attribute is zero. You can set it negative in decimal formatted (DecVal) variables and it should work as an entry field, slider, etc. it still becomes “just bits” when written to the device, so the device has to handle it properly. And masking the value may make that confusing....&gt; &gt; Negative min values would probably not work for enumerated values; hex values will “work”, in the sense they’ll be mathematically correct,  but I expect that most people will consider the behavior odd especially when masked. </pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36286562">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36286562/">Re: [Jmri-developers] XML Handling</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@gm...&gt; - 2018-04-07 09:19:39</small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Since a single CV (as in decVal) is only 8 bits  and two CVs (as in splitVal) are only 16 bits but all are stored in int variables (32 bits) the range comparisons are de-facto unsigned as no high bit extension is done. But there's no way Knut can get 0 to 65353 with the bit masks he has that limit the stored value to 14 bits (0 to 16383).Sent from my iPad-- Dave &gt; On 7 Apr 2018, at 6:39 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Would you say the correct answer is the CV's are unsigned numbers? So it&gt; would never think of the two byte value as a -1 only as 0xffff? Or is there&gt; a signed value choice in the decoder processing?</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36286384">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36286384/">Re: [Jmri-developers] XML Handling</a></b>

           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-04-06 22:31:35</small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>By default, the ‘min’ attribute is zero. You can set it negative in decimal formatted (DecVal) variables and it should work as an entry field, slider, etc. it still becomes “just bits” when written to the device, so the device has to handle it properly. And masking the value may make that confusing....Negative min values would probably not work for enumerated values; hex values will “work”, in the sense they’ll be mathematically correct,  but I expect that most people will consider the behavior odd especially when masked. Bob&gt; On Apr 6, 2018, at 1:39 PM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Dave,&gt; &gt; Would you say the correct answer is the CV's are unsigned numbers? So it&gt; would never think of the two byte value as a -1 only as 0xffff? Or is there&gt; a signed value choice in the decoder processing?&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Variables are generally unsigned in JMRI so min="0" max="65535" in the splitVal element would be correct EXCEPT that your mask="XVVVVVVV" and upperMask="XVVVVVVV" limit your maximum value to 14 bits (range 0 to 16383)Sent from my iPad-- DaveThe New England Convention 2018<a href="http://www.newenglandmodelrailwayclub.com/content/convention.shtml" rel="nofollow">http://www.newenglandmodelrailwayclub.com/content/convention.shtml</a>&gt; On 7 Apr 2018, at 4:50 AM, Knut Schwichtenberg &lt;kschwi@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I'm trying to improve FREDi XML file. My problem is the value range for&gt; the DCC address. DCC addresses are valid in the range from 0 to 10239.&gt; To define the undispatched in FREDi status, the address value of 65535&gt; (0xffff) is defined. Currently "Public_Domain_FREDi_LNSV2.xml" is&gt; implement as below.&gt; &gt; ....&gt; &lt;variable CV="9" item="Advanced Group 1 Option 6"&gt;                       readOnly="no" mask="XVVVVVVV"&gt;                       comment="Loco address"&gt;&gt;                 &lt;splitVal highCV="8" upperMask="XVVVVVVV" /&gt;&gt; &lt;/variable&gt;</pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36286256/">[Jmri-developers] XML Handling</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Knut Schwichtenberg &lt;kschwi@we...&gt; - 2018-04-06 18:50:12</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hello,I'm trying to improve FREDi XML file. My problem is the value range forthe DCC address. DCC addresses are valid in the range from 0 to 10239.To define the undispatched in FREDi status, the address value of 65535(0xffff) is defined. Currently "Public_Domain_FREDi_LNSV2.xml" isimplement as below.....&lt;variable CV="9" item="Advanced Group 1 Option 6"&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; readOnly="no" mask="XVVVVVVV"&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; comment="Loco address"&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &lt;splitVal highCV="8" upperMask="XVVVVVVV" /&gt;&lt;/variable&gt;...Currently "min" and "max" are missing, which only extends the addressrange. How can I define the value of 0xffff (-1) as valid within theJMRI dialogue?Cheers,Knut</pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I’d like to build the next JMRI test release on the nominal schedule, if possible  (It’s good to hold the schedule occasionally, if just to keep people guessing).  That would mean starting with all PR’s ready to merge sometime in the evening, California time, of Friday April 13th.Let me know if that’s not OK, please.Although SourceForge brought back yesterday the last of the tools we’d been been using for building releases, this one will (if things go well) will be the first one entirely built without SourceForge support.  Extra copies of the downloadable files will still be put there, as some people look there by habit, but the rest of the process will be Jenkins, GitHub, etc. Fingers crossed...Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36281441/">Re: [Jmri-developers] SplitVal / Operations on CV</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@gm...&gt; - 2018-04-01 12:00:12</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>On 1 Apr 2018, at 8:46 PM, Alain LM via Jmri-developers &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; SplitVal can be used to perform certain operations on CVs (factor, offset) provided that it uses two different CVs. I tried to use it with one single CV, but it did not work.&gt; &gt; Is there an already built-in mechanism to perform operations on CVs, like scaling i.e. displaying a value of a CVs multiplied by a certain factor and conversely dividing with that factor when writing?Not that I know of.&gt; Likewise is there a built-in mechanism to perform splitval over more than 2 CVs, namely 4 CVs, or would it require modifying the Java code to extend the existing function?I've written working code that will extend splitVal to more than 2 CVs and also handle text strings, and extract date/time encoded in multiple CVs (the RailCom CVs being a typical example) with differing scaling factors and epoch starts.It's at the to-be-tidied-up stage but has been pushed aside many times due to family, personal and JMRI commitments. I desperately want to get it finished but life keeps getting in the way.It is backward compatible with the existing 2 CV splitVal, including masks, scaling and offsets for the 2 CV case.It may not be too difficult for me to allow the degenerate case of 1 CV with scaling and offset.Dave</pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Related to this, can the XML check offer a warning? I mean it would give amessage that something is 'depreciated' and in the future this would countas a failure. This would be an example of where it could have been handy.Once we knew we were changing the format to use sensible system names, itcould have started warning users, and they could use their existing versionto fix it. A user pretty much did this when we explained what the issue was.He did a rename trick of his JMRI and his old JMRI to run the old versiononce so he could fix the file.         <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36267536/">[Jmri-developers] Remove classes subdirectory during Windows install</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-03-19 15:53:40</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>The JMRI Windows installer currently leaves the “classes” directory in place when doing an upgrade.  This is unlike Linux and macOS, which do a complete replacement.  That directory is on the classpath early, so anything there will be taken in preference to what’s in e.g. jmri.jar.This might be a good thing: Somebody has put something there for a reason, and it will continue to do whatever happy thing motivated that.More likely, it’ll cause hard-to-diagnose problems, because the contents are out-of-date with the new JMRI version. This happened over the weekend at a local layout who updated to JMRI 4.10 with old content in classes that looks like it was a patch on a 3.something release.  (There were lots of other problems on that update, though; it hadn’t been done in many years)PR #5113 (<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/pull/5113" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/pull/5113</a>) updates the Windows installer to remove the classes subdirectory, just like the other installs. I’m not a NSIS expert, but I think that it’s backed up during an earlier part of the install.I don’t have a good way to check this.  Could somebody please pull it, make a Windows installer, and check it? Alternately, I can merge it, wait for Jenkins to build the installer, and then somebody could please try that.Thanks.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36267273">
       <tbody>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi all,Following up with Steve via private e-mails onRe: JMRI 4.10 web server not showing the same panel conditionCheers,JanOn 19-Mar-18 13:13, jmri-developers-request@... wrote:&gt; Send Jmri-developers mailing list submissions to&gt; 	jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; To subscribe or unsubscribe via the World Wide Web, visit&gt; 	<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; or, via email, send a message with subject or body 'help' to&gt; 	jmri-developers-request@...&gt;&gt; You can reach the person managing the list at&gt; 	jmri-developers-owner@...&gt;&gt; When replying, please edit your Subject line so it is more specific&gt; than "Re: Contents of Jmri-developers digest..."&gt;&gt;&gt; Today's Topics:&gt;&gt;     1. Re: JMRI 4.10 web server not showing the same panel condition&gt;        (Steve Todd)&gt;     2.          <td class="email-body"><pre>There was some discussion recently about changes that were made to the connection status in DP3. Has any work been done to revert the confusing green "Internal Is Online" message?I have just noticed in 4.11.4 (but may be also earlier releases) that immediately after creating a new SPROG profile the display is as it used to be, and still desired to be, i.e., in programmer mode it shows green "Service Mode SPROG Programmer Is Online" and red "No Operations Mode Programmer Available".On subsequent startups it shows green "Service Mode SPROG Programmer Is Online" and green "Operations Mode Programmer Internal is Online".See attached screen shots.Can we revert to the original red/green display in all cases? The fact that the status changes after restarting is even more confusing to some users.Andrew</pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36265925/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Turn on HTML scan in CI?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-03-18 05:47:16</small> 
           <div class="attachments">

           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>PR #5105 turned on the HTML scan of the help/en tree during Travis CI.  If there are any problems (using the same criteria as the Jenkins job), the Travis “headless static” job will fail with more info near the end of the log.If you want to execute that check before committing, use  ant scanhelpThanks for the feedback, and to Egbert Broerse for getting us to zero on these warnings so the check could be turned on.Bob</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; On Mar 17, 2018, at 5:42 AM, Steve G &lt;RailRodder@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Ken, I normally create mine myself, in the sections section. If you entered the name in and it didnt exist it used to create them, sometime in january that changed. But why its suddenly asking for them I dont know, They used to be optional. Mind you lots of ssl and sml benefits from them, and automated trains really benefits from them.If you’ve got a repeatable case, like this one, where you can see a problem, you can rapidly track it down with “git bisect”.See <a href="http://jmri.org/help/en/html//doc/Technical/GitFAQ.shtml#bisect" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/help/en/html//doc/Technical/GitFAQ.shtml#bisect</a>In this case, start with the current code and set up:git checkout mastergit bisect startgit bisect badgit bisect good v4.10Then go through a cycle of ant clean panelproand checking the result, followed by eithergit bisect goodorgit bisect baddepending on whether you saw the problem or not. (If for some reason a particular step won’t compile or run, ‘git bisect skip’)At the end, it will tell you exactly which change caused the change.  And that makes it _much_ easier to track down.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36264582/">Re: [Jmri-developers] First 4.11.4 files available</a></b>

           <small>From: Dave Sand &lt;dave@sa...&gt; - 2018-03-16 17:51:01</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/5BCC527D-91FC-4CDD-B722-952D476E8BF3%40sandsys.org/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I have tested using multiple LE based implementations.  Everything works as expected.This will be the first release with the new LE track drawing options.There is an intermittent (~1 in10 PanelPro panel loads) ConcurrentModificationException that affects LE layouts with multiple panels.
