           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36263808/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Turn on HTML scan in CI?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: david d zuhn &lt;zoo@st...&gt; - 2018-03-16 02:53:44</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CAASpJ1xzuhXMc-33F9-Kt%2B4FTW8gf%2BMFJvWX9V7HDHGt%2Beva0g%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt;&gt; I'd say it sounds good to turn on. One question about the tests, how clear&gt; are the messages about what needs to change? If the errors/warnings are&gt; clear enough, then I'd say even new contributors could manage to deal with&gt; them. But if the messages are really not clear, then it takes a longer&gt; learning curve. Any I recall seeing are clear enough about how to fix&gt; things. Combine that with the current state of zero, I think we would gain&gt; from it.&gt;It might be a longer curve, but the fact that something that's undesirablegets found out faster, and there's a feedback cycle that's positive.   Addsomething bad, get an error.   Fix it, and get a clean build.Even if the messages aren't completely clear, they point to the fact that*something* is wrong, and the committer will either research and find theissue on their own, or they can ask for help.   I don't recall anyone whoasks a question like "I'm seeing an error on build #321 and I don'tunderstand it" get shot down.   The ensuing discussion usually enlightensmore than one person.I'm of the school that says once warnings are reduced to zero, there's notolerance for additional warnings.   That's cause for pushing back on thepull request until the code is fixed.   Now, that needs to be doable withcode that's available to everyone.   It doesn't necessary have to be "easy"for everyone, but that wouldn't hurt.   Standard tool versions; standardbuild targets (no need to fiddle with obscure commands; run 'antcheck-this' or 'mvn check' should be all that's needed).Publish the standards, the tools and the expectations.   Work withcontributors to bring the code up to the level the project expects (don'tleave them hanging).    Running the tests on the pull-requests would beideal - so the results can be checked and the info available to thereviewer.   Nobody commits (or merges) unless the warnings are clear.-- david d zuhn  Saint Paul Bridge &amp; Terminal Ry.zoo @ stpaulterminal.org</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I'd say it sounds good to turn on. One question about the tests, how clearare the messages about what needs to change? If the errors/warnings areclear enough, then I'd say even new contributors could manage to deal withthem. But if the messages are really not clear, then it takes a longerlearning curve. Any I recall seeing are clear enough about how to fixthings. Combine that with the current state of zero, I think we would gainfrom it.The other thing that confuses new contributors is lots of 'old' warnings, soif there are none, no confusion. If a warning shows up, they know they hadsomething to do with it.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36262991/">[Jmri-developers] Turn on HTML scan in CI?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-03-15 13:10:46</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/0A079BC6-977F-4D1D-AE54-917853D2B5B0%40mac.com/1/">text/plain</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>TLDR: I’d like to add the HTML scan step to CI and am looking for comments. - BobThrough the recent excellent work of Egbert Broerse (see PR #5085 and #5097), the Jenkins HTML scan is showing zero items:This is great, but it’s hard to keep these scans at low values.  The Java warnings scan, for example, seems to be in dynamic equilibrium between “new items creeping in” and “people spending time resolving them”, occasionally falling back pretty far:(At least part of the time, those Java warnings are highlighting real bugs:I’ll fix that one shortly, no problem; I put it here to show the value of having multiple kinds of scans and tests)I’d like to add the HTML scan to our CI tests and require that new PRs show zero errors to pass.  The scan takes less than 30 seconds on Jenkins, and probably similar during CI. I’d add it to one of the shorter jobs so there’s no overall delay in getting a PR checked. There will eA quick scan of the last three weeks’ PRs shows that only a small fraction (roughly 8%) of PRs even have HTML commits, and those (except for Egbert’s) typically only touch a couple files.  I doubt that anybody will introduce lots of HTML issues all at once.  But I think this is the best way of keeping one item at a time from building up to something large.On the other hand, we do want new people to feel like they can contribute things, even imperfect things.  I occasionally will correct bits of a new piece of contributed code after the fact.  Having CI fail on the original contribution makes that a bit harder, though not impossible.One possible issue is that the scan is done [1] using the Unix ‘tidy’ command [2].  That works on macOS and the two Linux versions I tried, as tidy was pre-instaleld.  Although a Windows version definitely exists, I don’t know whether it’s commonly installed; developers using Windows might have to install that as a separate step before being able to check their work.Thoughts appreciated.Bob[1] The current script (see  <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/scripts/tidy-scan.sh" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/scripts/tidy-scan.sh</a> ) formats its output for Jenkins, so we’ll need a similar script to do a yes/no check for CI. [2] <a href="http://www.html-tidy.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.html-tidy.org</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>The integration _looks_ correct in GitHub.Might be an issue on SourceForge's end.Will need to dig furtherOn 14 March 2018 at 13:23, Matthew Harris &lt;matthew.john.harris@...&gt; wrote:&gt; I'll have a look.&gt;&gt; On 14 March 2018 at 12:27, Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; I haven't received any Commit reports on JMRI-commits mailing list for a while. Checked the archive and no posts recorded since end of February.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Sent from my iPad&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Dave&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36261380/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Layout Editor: changing icons for a turnout</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@al...&gt; - 2018-03-14 09:42:24</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/BABC8E54-54DF-4220-862C-C74C8E3B7142%40alexandriasoftware.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>FWIW, the web server has special handling for panels to avoid screen scraping them; a transform of the XML is sent to the web client (its more complex than an XSLT transform), and the individual panel elements are all rendered locally on the client along with the javascript logic to allow interaction with the panel. Its a significant pain, and frequently, whoever is making changes to the panel code is breaking the web panel code.Randall Wood&gt; On Mar 13, 2018, at 23:17, Robert Middleton &lt;osfan6313@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I realize that I am a long-time lurker here and thus perhaps don't&gt; have much to contribute, but some thoughts here:&gt; &gt; One thing that I have had trouble with is determining what exactly all&gt; of the panel editors are for.  This has now been clarified from Bob in&gt; that all of the editors were designed for different things.  My&gt; suspicion is that most other people have this problem as well.  They&gt; will simply try to do what they want with one of the editors and use&gt; it as they see fit.&gt; &gt; What it seems like to me is that there should really be only editor,&gt; and this editor can do all the different types of panels.  If you want&gt; it to be for a local control panel, you simply style the panel&gt; differently(a la CSS).  In some ways this would also make a local&gt; control panel a subset of the general panel editor.  I think the best&gt; analogy that I can come up with here is if you are using&gt; Word/Powerpoint, when you create a new document you can choose a&gt; template.  The data in the document doesn't change, but when you&gt; change the template the visual style changes.&gt; &gt; To Randall's point, if the GUI is properly decoupled from the data, it&gt; would be easier to display it would make putting it into a webpage&gt; much easier.  If somebody was clever enough you could do an XSLT&gt; translation on the XML for the panel and have it display automatically&gt; in the web, as opposed to the screen-scrape like thing that is there&gt; now.  (For the record, I don't actually know how to do XSLT, but I&gt; know that it is possible).  This would actually be a very nice thing&gt; for my club layout, as we want to put in soft panels to have local&gt; control.  The actual software needed would only have to be a web&gt; browser at that point in order to properly implement the panels.&gt; &gt; To Randall's last point, although it may be easier to completely re-do&gt; the code, it may be a good idea to try and switch over everything that&gt; is possible automatically, since otherwise you would have 4 editors at&gt; once.  <a href="https://xkcd.com/927/" rel="nofollow">https://xkcd.com/927/</a>&gt; &gt; -Robert Middleton&gt; &gt; On Tue, Mar 13, 2018 at 8:43 PM, Randall Wood&gt; &lt;randall.h.wood@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; I would love to see the Editors decoupled from their displays (all of them&gt;&gt; really), so that a headless JMRI instance could display a panel in a web&gt;&gt; server.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I tried about three years to begin that, but after about six months gave up&gt;&gt; on it—this was before we switched to git, and there was strong and vocal&gt;&gt; opposition to doing the separation.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; So yes, disentangling model from view is of long term benefit, and is hard&gt;&gt; (see how hard it is turning out to be even for the WiThrottle), although it&gt;&gt; may be, at this point, easier to start over from scratch than to modify&gt;&gt; existing code.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Randall Wood&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; On Mar 13, 2018, at 19:37, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Maybe time to revisit a discussion about how/whether to focus/unfocus Layout&gt;&gt; Editor.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; As a reminder:  When David Duchamp wrote the basics of layout editor, it&gt;&gt; _wasn’t_ intended to be something that would be used to run a railroad.  It&gt;&gt; was for Editing information about the Layout:  How track was connected,&gt;&gt; where signal(heads)s were located, etc.  Panel Editor, and later Control&gt;&gt; Panel Editor, were meant to be for Editing of Panels you’d use to Control,&gt;&gt; so they had lots of visual controls.  LE didn’t.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Over time, LE received some updates to show the status of track, etc.  It’s&gt;&gt; nothing near the level of CATS in that respect, but it’s definitely moving&gt;&gt; in the direction of being useful for layout operation.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; But LE is still fundamentally an Editor of Layout information, and so is&gt;&gt; very tightly tied to that information.  Unlike PE and CPE, which can provide&gt;&gt; multiple flexible views across a single underlying (model) railroad, LE is&gt;&gt; ties the underlying objects directly to their display:  That’s why multiple&gt;&gt; turnouts with the same address, overlapping sections, etc are difficult.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; It would be a huge effort to change that, but it might be worthwhile.  The&gt;&gt; hard part would be the initial separation of view from model; they’re very&gt;&gt; tightly tangled by many interventions to add monolithic code so that the&gt;&gt; LayoutEditor class is now 10670 lines long with 122 case statements and over&gt;&gt; 900 if statements. Several methods are hundreds of lines long with one over&gt;&gt; a thousand.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; This code is brittle, and getting brittler.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Do we want to keep welding on bells and whistles, in hopes we can keep it&gt;&gt; together incrementally? (For an example of the likely end point, see&gt;&gt; <a href="http://top-gear-car.blogspot.com/2011/12/1969-mustang-skull-art-car-falls-on.html" rel="nofollow">http://top-gear-car.blogspot.com/2011/12/1969-mustang-skull-art-car-falls-on.html</a>&gt;&gt; )&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Do we want to (try to) organize some people to work on improving its&gt;&gt; internals (instead of extending it’s externals)?  That’s tricky, thankless&gt;&gt; work in this environment: The odds are that it’ll generate a lot of carping&gt;&gt; before it generates a lot of progress.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Note:  I’m not volunteering right now. I’ve got three other infrastructure&gt;&gt; projects in flight, all of which got enthused discussion at the start and&gt;&gt; now I’m the one sweating the details.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; On Mar 13, 2018, at 9:23 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I forgot in LE, turnouts don't have icons. So it seems this isn't going to&gt;&gt; be easy.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36261120/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Layout Editor: changing icons for a turnout</a></b>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I realize that I am a long-time lurker here and thus perhaps don'thave much to contribute, but some thoughts here:One thing that I have had trouble with is determining what exactly allof the panel editors are for.  This has now been clarified from Bob inthat all of the editors were designed for different things.  Mysuspicion is that most other people have this problem as well.  Theywill simply try to do what they want with one of the editors and useit as they see fit.What it seems like to me is that there should really be only editor,and this editor can do all the different types of panels.  If you wantit to be for a local control panel, you simply style the paneldifferently(a la CSS).  In some ways this would also make a localcontrol panel a subset of the general panel editor.  I think the bestanalogy that I can come up with here is if you are usingWord/Powerpoint, when you create a new document you can choose atemplate.  The data in the document doesn't change, but when youchange the template the visual style changes.To Randall's point, if the GUI is properly decoupled from the data, itwould be easier to display it would make putting it into a webpagemuch easier.  If somebody was clever enough you could do an XSLTtranslation on the XML for the panel and have it display automaticallyin the web, as opposed to the screen-scrape like thing that is therenow.  (For the record, I don't actually know how to do XSLT, but Iknow that it is possible).  This would actually be a very nice thingfor my club layout, as we want to put in soft panels to have localcontrol.  The actual software needed would only have to be a webbrowser at that point in order to properly implement the panels.To Randall's last point, although it may be easier to completely re-dothe code, it may be a good idea to try and switch over everything thatis possible automatically, since otherwise you would have 4 editors atonce.  <a href="https://xkcd.com/927/" rel="nofollow">https://xkcd.com/927/</a>-Robert MiddletonOn Tue, Mar 13, 2018 at 8:43 PM, Randall Wood&lt;randall.h.wood@...&gt; wrote:&gt; I would love to see the Editors decoupled from their displays (all of them&gt; really), so that a headless JMRI instance could display a panel in a web&gt; server.&gt;&gt; I tried about three years to begin that, but after about six months gave up&gt; on it—this was before we switched to git, and there was strong and vocal&gt; opposition to doing the separation.&gt;&gt; So yes, disentangling model from view is of long term benefit, and is hard&gt; (see how hard it is turning out to be even for the WiThrottle), although it&gt; may be, at this point, easier to start over from scratch than to modify&gt; existing code.&gt;&gt; Randall Wood&gt;&gt; On Mar 13, 2018, at 19:37, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; Maybe time to revisit a discussion about how/whether to focus/unfocus Layout&gt; Editor.&gt;&gt; As a reminder:  When David Duchamp wrote the basics of layout editor, it&gt; _wasn’t_ intended to be something that would be used to run a railroad.  It&gt; was for Editing information about the Layout:  How track was connected,&gt; where signal(heads)s were located, etc.  Panel Editor, and later Control&gt; Panel Editor, were meant to be for Editing of Panels you’d use to Control,&gt; so they had lots of visual controls.  LE didn’t.&gt;&gt; Over time, LE received some updates to show the status of track, etc.  It’s&gt; nothing near the level of CATS in that respect, but it’s definitely moving&gt; in the direction of being useful for layout operation.&gt;&gt; But LE is still fundamentally an Editor of Layout information, and so is&gt; very tightly tied to that information.  Unlike PE and CPE, which can provide&gt; multiple flexible views across a single underlying (model) railroad, LE is&gt; ties the underlying objects directly to their display:  That’s why multiple&gt; turnouts with the same address, overlapping sections, etc are difficult.&gt;&gt; It would be a huge effort to change that, but it might be worthwhile.  The&gt; hard part would be the initial separation of view from model; they’re very&gt; tightly tangled by many interventions to add monolithic code so that the&gt; LayoutEditor class is now 10670 lines long with 122 case statements and over&gt; 900 if statements. Several methods are hundreds of lines long with one over&gt; a thousand.&gt;&gt; This code is brittle, and getting brittler.&gt;&gt; Do we want to keep welding on bells and whistles, in hopes we can keep it&gt; together incrementally? (For an example of the likely end point, see&gt; <a href="http://top-gear-car.blogspot.com/2011/12/1969-mustang-skull-art-car-falls-on.html" rel="nofollow">http://top-gear-car.blogspot.com/2011/12/1969-mustang-skull-art-car-falls-on.html</a>&gt; )&gt;&gt; Do we want to (try to) organize some people to work on improving its&gt; internals (instead of extending it’s externals)?  That’s tricky, thankless&gt; work in this environment: The odds are that it’ll generate a lot of carping&gt; before it generates a lot of progress.&gt;&gt; Note:  I’m not volunteering right now. I’ve got three other infrastructure&gt; projects in flight, all of which got enthused discussion at the start and&gt; now I’m the one sweating the details.&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; On Mar 13, 2018, at 9:23 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; I forgot in LE, turnouts don't have icons. So it seems this isn't going to&gt; be easy.&gt;&gt;&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36261026/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Layout Editor: changing icons for a turnout</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@al...&gt; - 2018-03-14 00:44:10</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/94BA8D06-94E2-4B7F-976C-A1F0D276636E%40alexandriasoftware.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I would love to see the Editors decoupled from their displays (all of them really), so that a headless JMRI instance could display a panel in a web server.I tried about three years to begin that, but after about six months gave up on it—this was before we switched to git, and there was strong and vocal opposition to doing the separation.So yes, disentangling model from view is of long term benefit, and is hard (see how hard it is turning out to be even for the WiThrottle), although it may be, at this point, easier to start over from scratch than to modify existing code.Randall Wood&gt; On Mar 13, 2018, at 19:37, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Maybe time to revisit a discussion about how/whether to focus/unfocus Layout Editor.&gt; &gt; As a reminder:  When David Duchamp wrote the basics of layout editor, it _wasn’t_ intended to be something that would be used to run a railroad.  It was for Editing information about the Layout:  How track was connected, where signal(heads)s were located, etc.  Panel Editor, and later Control Panel Editor, were meant to be for Editing of Panels you’d use to Control, so they had lots of visual controls.  LE didn’t.&gt; &gt; Over time, LE received some updates to show the status of track, etc.  It’s nothing near the level of CATS in that respect, but it’s definitely moving in the direction of being useful for layout operation.&gt; &gt; But LE is still fundamentally an Editor of Layout information, and so is very tightly tied to that information.  Unlike PE and CPE, which can provide multiple flexible views across a single underlying (model) railroad, LE is ties the underlying objects directly to their display:  That’s why multiple turnouts with the same address, overlapping sections, etc are difficult.&gt; &gt; It would be a huge effort to change that, but it might be worthwhile.  The hard part would be the initial separation of view from model; they’re very tightly tangled by many interventions to add monolithic code so that the LayoutEditor class is now 10670 lines long with 122 case statements and over 900 if statements. Several methods are hundreds of lines long with one over a thousand.&gt; &gt; This code is brittle, and getting brittler.  &gt; &gt; Do we want to keep welding on bells and whistles, in hopes we can keep it together incrementally? (For an example of the likely end point, see <a href="http://top-gear-car.blogspot.com/2011/12/1969-mustang-skull-art-car-falls-on.html" rel="nofollow">http://top-gear-car.blogspot.com/2011/12/1969-mustang-skull-art-car-falls-on.html</a> )&gt; &gt; Do we want to (try to) organize some people to work on improving its internals (instead of extending it’s externals)?  That’s tricky, thankless work in this environment: The odds are that it’ll generate a lot of carping before it generates a lot of progress.  &gt; &gt; Note:  I’m not volunteering right now. I’ve got three other infrastructure projects in flight, all of which got enthused discussion at the start and now I’m the one sweating the details.  &gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt;&gt; On Mar 13, 2018, at 9:23 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I forgot in LE, turnouts don't have icons. So it seems this isn't going to&gt;&gt; be easy.&gt; &gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36260966">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36260966/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Layout Editor: changing icons for a turnout</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-03-13 23:38:00</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Maybe time to revisit a discussion about how/whether to focus/unfocus Layout Editor.As a reminder:  When David Duchamp wrote the basics of layout editor, it _wasn’t_ intended to be something that would be used to run a railroad.  It was for Editing information about the Layout:  How track was connected, where signal(heads)s were located, etc.  Panel Editor, and later Control Panel Editor, were meant to be for Editing of Panels you’d use to Control, so they had lots of visual controls.  LE didn’t.Over time, LE received some updates to show the status of track, etc.  It’s nothing near the level of CATS in that respect, but it’s definitely moving in the direction of being useful for layout operation.But LE is still fundamentally an Editor of Layout information, and so is very tightly tied to that information.  Unlike PE and CPE, which can provide multiple flexible views across a single underlying (model) railroad, LE is ties the underlying objects directly to their display:  That’s why multiple turnouts with the same address, overlapping sections, etc are difficult.It would be a huge effort to change that, but it might be worthwhile.  The hard part would be the initial separation of view from model; they’re very tightly tangled by many interventions to add monolithic code so that the LayoutEditor class is now 10670 lines long with 122 case statements and over 900 if statements. Several methods are hundreds of lines long with one over a thousand.This code is brittle, and getting brittler.  Do we want to keep welding on bells and whistles, in hopes we can keep it together incrementally? (For an example of the likely end point, see <a href="http://top-gear-car.blogspot.com/2011/12/1969-mustang-skull-art-car-falls-on.html" rel="nofollow">http://top-gear-car.blogspot.com/2011/12/1969-mustang-skull-art-car-falls-on.html</a> )Do we want to (try to) organize some people to work on improving its internals (instead of extending it’s externals)?  That’s tricky, thankless work in this environment: The odds are that it’ll generate a lot of carping before it generates a lot of progress.  Note:  I’m not volunteering right now. I’ve got three other infrastructure projects in flight, all of which got enthused discussion at the start and now I’m the one sweating the details.  Bob&gt; On Mar 13, 2018, at 9:23 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I forgot in LE, turnouts don't have icons. So it seems this isn't going to&gt; be easy.--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>How do we place something on the panel that is controlling a turnout output,but is not a turnout? In this case it is a set of relays that control thepower for staging tracks. So I want to use a status lamp type display toshow which are powered on. But while we can change icons for sensors veryeasily, it is not obvious how to do that with a turnout object. I know Icould use Logix or Routes and create a sensor that follows the turnout, butis that really the best way? I can also just go into the xml and edit whichicons are used, but I like to think if there is something I need to do,other users might have the same idea but not be able to edit xml.What do others think of this?-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36250485/">Re: [Jmri-developers] NS-2008 calls for Medium Approach Medium, but mast is only two heads</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Suzie &lt;suzie_tall@ya...&gt; - 2018-03-12 07:41:55</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi KenI think it is a cut and paste error. It is normal to do the mappings for  the most capable mast (in this case the triple head), then copy and paste  it in to the lesser masts making appropriate changes for the aspects that  cannot be displayed. In this case it looks like the entries for Medium  speed have not been removed or modified on the double head mast.The only 'Medium' aspects that can be displayed on the double head mast  are Medium Approach, Medium Clear, and Approach Medium. In practice a  double head mast would not be used when signalling medium speed in to  medium speed so the error should not be seen, but it is nice to have a  catch mapping that will display something useful in the event of misuse of  a double head mast or a block speed error.Suzie x</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36250484">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header">

         <td class="email-body"><pre>My hypothesis is that the problem is in the user-interface.xml file in the active profile.  There’s an element there that refers to the sensor table, something like:       &lt;table xmlns="" name="jmri.jmrit.beantable.SensorTableAction:Internal"&gt;            &lt;columns&gt;                &lt;column hidden="false" name="Comment" order="3" width="194"/&gt;                &lt;column hidden="true" name="Active Delay" order="8" width="75"/&gt;                &lt;column hidden="false" name="User Name" order="1" width="194"/&gt;                &lt;column hidden="false" name="State" order="2" width="88"/&gt;                &lt;column hidden="false" name="Inverted" order="5" width="62"/&gt;                &lt;column hidden="true" name="InActive Delay" order="9" width="75"/&gt;                &lt;column hidden="true" name="Use Global Delay" order="7" width="75"/&gt;                &lt;column hidden="false" name="System Name" order="0" width="74"/&gt;            &lt;/columns&gt;            &lt;sortOrder&gt;                &lt;sortKey column="0" sortOrder="ASCENDING"/&gt;            &lt;/sortOrder&gt;        &lt;/table&gt;except the “sortKey” element is causing a problem.             <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36250482/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Help authoring tools</a></b>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>If by “product documentation” you mean suitable for printing, then it gets complicated.  Things like Your Favorite Office Suite can usually safe a document as either paper format or for the web, but it gets tricky to have them both look good.There are more complicated tools that take a single version of a document and then render that various ways, but they’re not particular simple.I think it would be fine if you wrote some html pages that were both in JMRI (on web and in the help; those are actually the same files see <a href="http://jmri.org/help/en/html/doc/Technical/Help.shtml" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/help/en/html/doc/Technical/Help.shtml</a> )I’d be happy to help you change the Header.shtml, Footer.shtml and Style.shtml include files and CSS that (most) JMRI help pages use to draw the decorations: Having different versions of those on your web site would allow you to use the same MyPage.shtml and have it look different.And linking is certainly fine.Bob&gt; On Mar 11, 2018, at 11:27 AM, Andrew Crosland via Jmri-developers &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Can anyone recommend any tools or work flows that would help manufacturers, i.e.me :), to minimise duplication of effort in maintaining&gt; - Product documentation&gt; - Own web site&gt; - JMRI Help pages (on-line and in the software)&gt; &gt; Free and lightweight would be ideal :)&gt; &gt; Would it be acceptable to link to the JMRI website as the authoritative source, assuming I bring that up to date?&gt; &gt; Andrew&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Could you get this panel file and user preferences files, please?For some reason, Swing things there’s a Long (floating point) value where a String is expected while sorting on a column.  I can’t tell which column, but it’s the one that the table was sorted on when the user preferences (e.g. table settings) were stored the previous time.Cleaning out the user preferences (not the connection preferences, the automatically stored table ones) should bypass this, but I’d like to see what the underlying cause was.Bob&gt; On Mar 11, 2018, at 7:18 PM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Anybody have a clue on this one?             <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36250478/">Re: [Jmri-developers] User with table sort problem</a></b>

           <small>From: Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@ch...&gt; - 2018-03-12 03:03:35</small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Ken,Glad you are involved with this one.My interest in helping Ted was looking at the CMRI connection possibly causing the problem.  I wanted to verify if CMRI was the culprit, I could address the issue.  The Arduino environment is an UNO and Ted uses the CMRI.cpp sketch.  An initial node address problem was corrected early in the testing.  The CMRI serial side seems to be OK.Initial back and forth discussion (off list) was related to confirming the connections and table data, and trying to duplicate the problem on my system.Ted sent me a copy of his xml panel file and I ran it under 4.10 and 4.11.3. There was one issue with the Powerline connection which I disabled.  Otherwise the tables, including the Sensor table showed up normally and I could see traffic in the serial monitor.  I'm running on OSX, he is on Windows.I made a panel with just two sensors and one CMRI node.  I sent that to him to try with the added request to disable all of the connections except CMRI.  The most recent test was to open the sensor table using the Startup preference, this apparently worked as the sensor table was displayed.  I am not sure if Ted was able to run a test with just a CMRI connection.That is where we left the testing as of this morning.  Ted will be out of town next week.The debug path I was on was to isolate the comm environment to just CMRI to see if the sensor table appeared.  There are two additional connections, Loconet and Powerline, which have sensors assigned.  The CMRI only environment worked, then adding each of the other connections back in might shed some light on this.With all of the updates which have been applied to his system environment, the problem might be mixed and matched files in the JMRI directory or the OS.  I noticed in one of the log files that JMRI is running out of Program Files (x86).I am available to continue to help out on this.Thanks,Chuck CataniaOn Mar 11, 2018, at 7:18 PM, Ken Cameron wrote:&gt; Anybody have a clue on this one? I've tried his panel against simulator&gt; connections (LocoNet, X10, CMRI) and had no problems. But for him, the&gt; sensor table is a no-show after the sort blows up. This is using the current&gt; head on my simulator 11 Mar 21:30EDT, but he has been trying 4.10, from the&gt; logs I've received.&gt; &gt; He has an Arduino connected but the board only has a few active pins right&gt; now. However, he is configured as a SMINI node in the node configurator for&gt; the connection. Says it worked for a long time. But then some Windows&gt; updates, then Java, then JMRI updates and now this is happening. But trying&gt; to go back to prior versions of JMRI isn't working either. I've not used an&gt; Arduino this way so I'm not sure about the right configuration for this sort&gt; of setup.&gt; &gt; We've worked it down to if we disconnect the Arduino (or leave it without&gt; power) then the sensor table shows up and no error. So I strongly feel it is&gt; something coming in on the data from the Arduino/CMRI link that puts&gt; something odd into the sensor table, and that causes the fault.&gt; &gt; Chuck, you were mentioned as having helped him get the Arduino running in&gt; the first place. I don't know how long ago that was. But you or some other&gt; Arduino guru might have some clues here too. The user is Ted Dimm, he's&gt; going to be offline for much of the week. I'm asking for help to come up&gt; with ideas for when he returns.&gt; &gt; The trace:&gt; &gt; 2018-03-07 17:55:52,670 beantable.ListedTableFrame            ERROR - Error&gt; when adding jmri.jmrit.beantable.SensorTableTabAction to display [Listed&gt;          <td class="email-body"><pre>Anybody have a clue on this one? I've tried his panel against simulatorconnections (LocoNet, X10, CMRI) and had no problems. But for him, thesensor table is a no-show after the sort blows up. This is using the currenthead on my simulator 11 Mar 21:30EDT, but he has been trying 4.10, from thelogs I've received.He has an Arduino connected but the board only has a few active pins rightnow. However, he is configured as a SMINI node in the node configurator forthe connection. Says it worked for a long time. But then some Windowsupdates, then Java, then JMRI updates and now this is happening. But tryingto go back to prior versions of JMRI isn't working either. I've not used anArduino this way so I'm not sure about the right configuration for this sortof setup.We've worked it down to if we disconnect the Arduino (or leave it withoutpower) then the sensor table shows up and no error. So I strongly feel it issomething coming in on the data from the Arduino/CMRI link that putssomething odd into the sensor table, and that causes the fault.Chuck, you were mentioned as having helped him get the Arduino running inthe first place.         <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi KenYes playing with the speeds will let you try a lot of things. Setting the  speeds to 'Medium' will display the error. It requires the route after the  signal mast to be 'Medium' speed, and the next mast to be showing a  'Medium' speed aspect. If you have a triple head mast you will see the  Medium Approach Medium aspect displayed fine, but a double head mast will  error because of the incorrect mapping to a non-existent appearance.I will try and get the mapping for the double head mast resolved but I am  a bit short of time at the moment to work on it and test it properly.Suzie x&gt; Message: 1&gt; Date: Sun, 11 Mar 2018 09:01:00 -0400&gt; From: "Ken Cameron" &lt;kcameron@...&gt;&gt; To: "'Discussions between JMRI developers'"&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] NS-2008 calls for Medium Approach&gt; 	Medium, but mast is only two heads&gt; Message-ID: &lt;124601d3b939$02dfeb60$089fc220$@twcny.rr.com&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"&gt;&gt; Suzie,&gt;&gt; I have my little test setup now. Yes in my case the path is known to be&gt; clear, so restricting isn't good. On my test I'm not seeing the M-A-M  &gt; but I&gt; only modeled a couple of blocks for the test. The panel is using all&gt; Internal. I manually set the two right hand signals to clear. The sensors&gt; are for the blocks. This let me focus on the signals and what combined  &gt; for&gt; what. But I'm thinking it picked restricting because the default speed  &gt; for&gt; turnouts is restricting. Playing with that speed changes things.&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; -------------- next part --------------&gt; A non-text attachment was scrubbed...&gt; Name: TurnoutApproach.xml&gt; Type: text/xml&gt; Size: 27036 bytes&gt; Desc: not available&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; Subject: Digest Footer&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; End of Jmri-developers Digest, Vol 140, Issue 22&gt; ************************************************-- Using Opera's mail client: <a href="http://www.opera.com/mail/" rel="nofollow">http://www.opera.com/mail/</a></pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36250467/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LE track segments not responding to right click for popup</a></b>

           <small>From: Dave Sand &lt;dave@sa...&gt; - 2018-03-11 03:30:06</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/54BBF777-0008-4C09-9432-A13E1CCD55D7%40sandsys.org/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Ken,Take a look at the Options &gt;&gt; Turnout Options &gt;&gt; Turnout Circle Size.This value is also used for click detection of other track objects, such as track segments and anchor points.When the size is large, the click area for the anchor points can cover a small track segment which results in an anchor point context menu.  This will also impact track segments that connect two turnouts.Dave Sand&gt; On Mar 10, 2018, at 8:55 PM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I had to go through the 'unblocked track' to find them. Is this part of work&gt; somebody is doing? This was pulled from head about 0GMT 11 March.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36250463/">Re: [Jmri-developers] NS-2008 calls for Medium Approach Medium, but mast is only two heads</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Suzie &lt;suzie_tall@ya...&gt; - 2018-03-09 21:06:51</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>There are quite a few scenarios in the signal systems where a mast cannot  show a suitable distant aspect for the next mast - on the prototype they  would have chosen the correct mast of course, but we cannot stop modellers  putting any old mast in as a distant, and this can happen quite a lot on  modular layouts where slightly mismatched modules are joined together.  When I create a system I try and put in a suitable mapping for every  possible scenario so even if there is a mismatched pair of masts something  other than stop will be displayed that will convey some useful information  to the driver which is usually of a more restrictive nature. Don't think  that because you have a triple head mast you can show every distant  aspect, this is especially true of speed systems where often a medium mast  cannot show a distant for limited or vice versa - NS-2008 does not have an  aspect for medium approach limited or limited approach medium, or even  limited approach limited.The error shown is due to an error in the mapping for the double head mast  where there is a mapping entry telling it to display the medium approach  medium aspect which it can't do because this is a triple head aspect (red  over yellow over green). This is one of those scenarios where there should  be a fix, in this case I would probably map to medium approach (red over  flashing yellow) as the next best choice, but some modellers might prefer  a different aspect. I did have a little play with the mappings on this  mast, but they do need a slightly more thorough tidy up to get rid of the  errors when strange pairings occur.Having approach displayed in advance of restricting is a common fix when  the mast cannot show approach restricting (usually a double head aspect),  but it is not unreasonable because the line may be blocked immediately  after the signal showing restricting and stop may be required - if the  block is known to be clear something other than restricting should be  displayed because under restricting you need to assume the line is blocked  unless you can see otherwise with your own eyes.Some of the systems still have incomplete mappings so mappings are only  present for the more common aspects, with the others leading to a stop  aspect on the distant mast (requiring a flag or radio override from the  signalman in the tower).Suzie x&gt;&gt; Message: 1&gt; Date: Thu, 8 Mar 2018 11:40:15 -0500&gt; From: "Ken Cameron" &lt;kcameron@...&gt;&gt; To: "'Discussions between JMRI developers'"&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: [Jmri-developers] NS-2008 calls for Medium Approach Medium,&gt; 	but mast is only two heads&gt; Message-ID: &lt;0d5101d3b6fc$24679ba0$6d36d2e0$@twcny.rr.com&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain;	charset="us-ascii"&gt;&gt; I suspect the rules would have made the railroad install a three head  &gt; mast&gt; at the location. In typical model railroad fashion, the layout is using  &gt; only&gt; single and double head masts. I found this while playing with the default&gt; speed for turnouts on the diverging route. The issue was how far out the&gt; trains would get less than clear before getting to a double end staging&gt; yard. It was built with #8 turnouts to make it reasonable for the speed  &gt; to&gt; not need to slow a lot when running through the different tracks.&gt;&gt; Might it be possible to make the rules a little more MR friendly without&gt; corrupting the prototypical behavior, if you build and install the right&gt; prototypical signals?&gt;&gt; 2018-03-08 10:54:19,748 implementation.VirtualSignalMast      WARN  -&gt; attempting to set invalid aspect: Medium Approach Medium on mast: M4T&gt; [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt; 2018-03-08 10:54:19,749 implementation.DefaultSignalMastLogic ERROR -&gt; Exception while setting Signal Logic attempting to set invalid aspect:&gt; Medium Approach Medium on mast: M4T [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt; 2018-03-08 10:57:21,903 implementation.VirtualSignalMast      WARN  -&gt; attempting to set invalid aspect: Medium Approach Medium on mast: M1T&gt; [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt; 2018-03-08 10:57:21,903 implementation.DefaultSignalMastLogic ERROR -&gt; Exception while setting Signal Logic attempting to set invalid aspect:&gt; Medium Approach Medium on mast: M1T [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt;&gt; I suspect Suzie and Dick will have clues about this.&gt;&gt; I also have the case where a single head signal is advance of a double  &gt; head&gt; signal. When the double head is showing 'Restricting', the single head is&gt; showing 'Approach'. But there is still a whole block beyond the double  &gt; head&gt; before hitting the 'Stop' signal. I think the issue is the NS rules  &gt; didn't&gt; have a double head that would be a diverging approach. So this might tie&gt; back to the 'Medium Approach Medium' issue. Looking at the NS rules it  &gt; seems&gt; they have a number of aspects that only use three heads or one, but not a&gt; two head.&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; Message: 2&gt; Date: Thu, 8 Mar 2018 11:50:05 -0500&gt; From: "Ken Cameron" &lt;kcameron@...&gt;&gt; To: "'Discussions between JMRI developers'"&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Neat feature in current Mac WiThrottle&gt; 	- work light&gt; Message-ID: &lt;0d5401d3b6fd$84b56d60$8e204820$@twcny.rr.com&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain;	charset="us-ascii"&gt;&gt; Matt,&gt;&gt; His icon was the yellow plastic type work spot light. You might make a  &gt; blue&gt; style or other. I don't know how fancy the interface is and if you get  &gt; any&gt; choice of coloring that light. I seem to recall that being a feature on  &gt; some&gt; phones. Not sure (if possible) that it would be of any use to offer  &gt; colors.&gt; Red for flagging the end of a train? Green when in the clear for an&gt; approaching train?&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; Message: 3&gt; Date: Thu, 8 Mar 2018 09:52:56 -0800&gt; From: "Robin Becker" &lt;rbgroups@...&gt;&gt; To: "'Discussions between JMRI developers'"&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Neat feature in current Mac WiThrottle&gt; 	- work light&gt; Message-ID: &lt;01a601d3b706$4aa8a750$dff9f5f0$@n3ix.com&gt;&gt; Content-Type: text/plain; charset="utf-8"&gt;&gt; We looked at this a couple years ago and did not implement a flash  &gt; feature in EngineDriver because the minimum API did not support it.&gt;&gt;&gt; Robin&gt;&gt;&gt; Robin Becker&gt;&gt; San Diego, CA&gt;&gt;&gt; From: Matthew Harris [mailto:matthew.john.harris@...]&gt; Sent: Thursday, March 08, 2018 8:22 AM&gt; To: Discussions about changes to the code, design, intent, etc  &gt; &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Neat feature in current Mac WiThrottle -  &gt; work light&gt;&gt;&gt; Nice idea - I'll take a quick look at it.&gt;&gt;&gt; Best regards,&gt;&gt;&gt; Matt H&gt;&gt;&gt; On 8 Mar 2018 17:20, "Steve Todd" &lt;mstevetodd@...  &gt; &lt;mailto:mstevetodd@...&gt; &gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; Hi Ken,&gt;&gt;&gt; No, EngineDriver does not have that feature. I've added it to the ToDo  &gt; list.&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks!&gt;&gt;   SteveT&gt;&gt;&gt; On Thu, Mar 8, 2018 at 11:09 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...  &gt; &lt;mailto:kcameron@...&gt; &gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; Had a club member trying it out on his iPhone. I spotted a yellow icon on&gt; the screen. It turned on the light feature of the phone. Rather cool for&gt; night operations or some of the darker corners of a layout. I don't  &gt; recall&gt; seeing something like that on the Engine Driver. Or did I miss that?&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.jmri.org>" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org&gt;</a>;&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org>" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org&gt;</a>;&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.cnymod.com>" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com&gt;</a>;&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org>" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org&gt;</a>;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...  &gt; &lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...  &gt; &lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; -------------- next part --------------&gt; An HTML attachment was scrubbed...&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; Message: 4&gt; Date: Fri, 9 Mar 2018 12:51:52 +0000&gt; From: Lynn Grandle &lt;LGrandle@...&gt;&gt; To: "jmri-developers@..."&gt; 	&lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: [Jmri-developers] Race condition in withrottle causes&gt; 	problems with withrottle startup&gt; Message-ID:&gt; 	&lt;BN6PR2201MB1074684A62AFFCF4FF2F5186DEDE0@...&gt;&gt; 	&gt; Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Hi:&gt;&gt;&gt; Somewhere between the 4.8 and 4.10 release of JMRI a major modification  &gt; was made to the withrottle software.  The modification was to make use  &gt; of the ZeroConf capabilities of most of the modern OS.  The modification  &gt; was done well, but it produced a race condition in the  &gt; UserInterface.java code.  This race condition occurs because directly  &gt; after the UserInterface calls the FacelessServer routine to set up the  &gt; listener port, it calls the ZeroConf register routine without waiting  &gt; for the port to actually be created.  On a fast machine with multiple  &gt; CPUs this would normally not be a problem, as the create should be  &gt; completed before the register.  But on older and cheaper machines this  &gt; is not the case( both my old linux and windows boxes have this  &gt; problem).  The result is that the Withrottle panel continues to display  &gt; "PENDING" even after the port is available to hosts over the Wifi and it  &gt; never gets out of the pending state.  The WiThrottle panel does not  &gt; display the manual configuration information at all.&gt;&gt;&gt; If you turn on the debugging output for the withrottle you will actually  &gt; get a message that the registration failed.  I would suggest that a  &gt; sleep be placed in the UserInterface code to wait 100 or 200 millseconds  &gt; before the register call is made.  I have also noticed other  &gt; instabilities in the Withrottle code after the 4.8 release, but this was  &gt; the most noticeable one, so it is the first one that I tried to find out  &gt; what was happening.&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt; -------------- next part --------------&gt; An HTML attachment was scrubbed...&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; Subject: Digest Footer&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------&gt;&gt; End of Jmri-developers Digest, Vol 140, Issue 18&gt; ************************************************-- Using Opera's mail client: <a href="http://www.opera.com/mail/" rel="nofollow">http://www.opera.com/mail/</a></pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36250461/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Race condition in withrottle causes problems with withrottle startup</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Paul Bender &lt;paul.bender@ac...&gt; - 2018-03-09 15:21:52</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/F83CB783-89A2-4FBD-BF38-63E7C2A76A67%40acm.org/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob,Sent from my iPad&gt; On Mar 9, 2018, at 7:51 AM, Lynn Grandle &lt;LGrandle@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Somewhere between the 4.8 and 4.10 release of JMRI a major modification was made to the withrottle software.  The modification was to make use of the ZeroConf capabilities of most of the modern OS.  The modification was done well, but it produced a race condition in the UserInterface.java code.  This race condition occurs because directly after the UserInterface calls the FacelessServer routine to set up the listener port, it calls the ZeroConf register routine without waiting for the port to actually be created.  On a fast machine with multiple CPUs this would normally not be a problem, as the create should be completed before the register.  But on older and cheaper machines this is not the case( both my old linux and windows boxes have this problem).  The result is that the Withrottle panel continues to display "PENDING" even after the port is available to hosts over the Wifi and it never gets out of the pending state.  The WiThrottle panel does not display the manual configuration information at all.Can you tell me if you see this in the current daily builds available at the link below?  The UI in Version 4.10 doesn’t actually use the faceless server, but has its own server built in.  That was split out in the last month.<a href="http://jmri.tagadab.com/jenkins/job/Development/job/Packages/" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.tagadab.com/jenkins/job/Development/job/Packages/</a>Thanks,Paul</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36250460">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36250460/">[Jmri-developers] Race condition in withrottle causes problems with withrottle startup</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Lynn Grandle &lt;LGrandle@ms...&gt; - 2018-03-09 12:52:00</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/BN6PR2201MB1074684A62AFFCF4FF2F5186DEDE0%40BN6PR2201MB1074.namprd22.prod.outlook.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi:Somewhere between the 4.8 and 4.10 release of JMRI a major modification was made to the withrottle software.  The modification was to make use of the ZeroConf capabilities of most of the modern OS.  The modification was done well, but it produced a race condition in the UserInterface.java code.  This race condition occurs because directly after the UserInterface calls the FacelessServer routine to set up the listener port, it calls the ZeroConf register routine without waiting for the port to actually be created.  On a fast machine with multiple CPUs this would normally not be a problem, as the create should be completed before the register.  But on older and cheaper machines this is not the case( both my old linux and windows boxes have this problem).  The result is that the Withrottle panel continues to display "PENDING" even after the port is available to hosts over the Wifi and it never gets out of the pending state.  The WiThrottle panel does not display the manual configuration information at all.If you turn on the debugging output for the withrottle you will actually get a message that the registration failed.  I would suggest that a sleep be placed in the UserInterface code to wait 100 or 200 millseconds before the register call is made.  I have also noticed other instabilities in the Withrottle code after the 4.8 release, but this was the most noticeable one, so it is the first one that I tried to find out what was happening.Bob</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36250459">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36250459/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Neat feature in current Mac WiThrottle - work light</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Robin Becker &lt;rbgroups@n3...&gt; - 2018-03-08 17:53:04</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/01a601d3b706%244aa8a750%24dff9f5f0%24%40n3ix.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>We looked at this a couple years ago and did not implement a flash feature in EngineDriver because the minimum API did not support it. Robin Robin BeckerSan Diego, CA From: Matthew Harris [mailto:matthew.john.harris@...] Sent: Thursday, March 08, 2018 8:22 AMTo: Discussions about changes to the code, design, intent, etc &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Neat feature in current Mac WiThrottle - work light Nice idea - I'll take a quick look at it.            <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36250457/">[Jmri-developers] NS-2008 calls for Medium Approach Medium, but mast is only two heads</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-03-08 16:40:26</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I suspect the rules would have made the railroad install a three head mastat the location. In typical model railroad fashion, the layout is using onlysingle and double head masts. I found this while playing with the defaultspeed for turnouts on the diverging route. The issue was how far out thetrains would get less than clear before getting to a double end stagingyard. It was built with #8 turnouts to make it reasonable for the speed tonot need to slow a lot when running through the different tracks.Might it be possible to make the rules a little more MR friendly withoutcorrupting the prototypical behavior, if you build and install the rightprototypical signals?2018-03-08 10:54:19,748 implementation.VirtualSignalMast      WARN  -attempting to set invalid aspect: Medium Approach Medium on mast: M4T[AWT-EventQueue-0]2018-03-08 10:54:19,749 implementation.DefaultSignalMastLogic ERROR -Exception while setting Signal Logic attempting to set invalid aspect:Medium Approach Medium on mast: M4T [AWT-EventQueue-0]2018-03-08 10:57:21,903 implementation.VirtualSignalMast      WARN  -attempting to set invalid aspect: Medium Approach Medium on mast: M1T[AWT-EventQueue-0]2018-03-08 10:57:21,903 implementation.DefaultSignalMastLogic ERROR -Exception while setting Signal Logic attempting to set invalid aspect:Medium Approach Medium on mast: M1T [AWT-EventQueue-0]I suspect Suzie and Dick will have clues about this.I also have the case where a single head signal is advance of a double headsignal. When the double head is showing 'Restricting', the single head isshowing 'Approach'. But there is still a whole block beyond the double headbefore hitting the 'Stop' signal. I think the issue is the NS rules didn'thave a double head that would be a diverging approach. So this might tieback to the 'Medium Approach Medium' issue. Looking at the NS rules it seemsthey have a number of aspects that only use three heads or one, but not atwo head.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Drew,Thanks for the info on the smart home infrastructure.  You also pointed outseveral reasons why I'm not really considering publishing this app.Keeping it in my sandbox and playing with it on my home layout is onething.  Providing a robust solution that is secure, flexible, and doesn'tbreak my bank hosting a cloud service is an entirely different matter.Based on my experience so far, I really don't think Alexa would be wellsuited to controlling locomotives.  It seems to be fine enough (if evenjust as a novelty) for things like turnouts, routes, maybe querying trackoccupancy or giving voice control to dispatcher activities, but as youpointed out, there's too much latency and too many possibilities of errorsfor a real-time control application.  I'm not sure I'd even consider "goingthere" based on what I know so far.I *might* *might* *might* consider cooking up an Alexa-specific interfacefor JMRI (maybe just in my own personal fork) to enable some differentcapabilities from the WiThrottle interface, but that's pretty low priorityand I really should spend what time I have available for JMRI on fixing upDCC++ and VSDecoder before I go adding yet another half-baked feature.Still it's been a fun project!- MarkOn Tue, Mar 6, 2018 at 9:08 AM Drew H &lt;thejadedmonkey@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Gmail was having problems connecting to the sourceforge server. My&gt; apologies if this is a duplicate send.&gt;&gt; Mark,&gt;&gt; Most smarthome applications/appliances have a companion service that runs&gt; in the cloud, and a user account that ties it together. Your iPhone app has&gt; a unique key (in the form of your account into) that connects to the cloud&gt; service. Your home device has the same unique key and opens a connection to&gt; the cloud service (so there's no firewall issues). From there it's a simple&gt; matter of the cloud service coordinating communication between the app and&gt; the device at home.&gt;&gt; Usually oauth 2 is used for user authentication, although technically I&gt; guess you could use any sufficiently random and protected key/value paring.&gt;&gt; Adding alexa/cortana/google assistant as a feature is technically just a&gt; matter of writing a skill that points to the static DNS entry for your&gt; cloud service.&gt;&gt; Naturally, expanding this to JMRI would be an issue as cloud hosting isn't&gt; free, and MS/Amazon/Google charge with usage... the more successful it is&gt; as a product, the more expensive it is to maintain.&gt;&gt; The other issue to consider is security. If we're talking the ability to&gt; control thousands of dollars of trains via voice, would be be prudent to:&gt;&gt; 1) limit control to a subset of WiThrottle functions or only control&gt; already moving trains, etc... and&gt;&gt; 2) The age old adage of "Just because we can, doesn't mean we should".&gt; Especially if you consider lag, not hearing properly, etc... I think that&gt; this should come with a big red warning label.&gt;&gt; 3) Security: if we don't use user accounts for authentication (and all of&gt; the resulting infrastructure), we'll need a key that is visible to an end&gt; user. This could, theoretically, be used by another person to set up their&gt; Alexa to control your layout, perhaps without you even realizing it.&gt;&gt; Drew&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36245595/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Alexa</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Drew H &lt;thejadedmonkey@gm...&gt; - 2018-03-06 14:08:16</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CAOhDmVU4feH5e6Qx8VdFfGtGm_asOf42%3DJ1miORiCTp_dwSHcA%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Gmail was having problems connecting to the sourceforge server. Myapologies if this is a duplicate send.Mark,Most smarthome applications/appliances have a companion service that runsin the cloud, and a user account that ties it together. Your iPhone app hasa unique key (in the form of your account into) that connects to the cloudservice. Your home device has the same unique key and opens a connection tothe cloud service (so there's no firewall issues). From there it's a simplematter of the cloud service coordinating communication between the app andthe device at home.Usually oauth 2 is used for user authentication, although technically Iguess you could use any sufficiently random and protected key/value paring.Adding alexa/cortana/google assistant as a feature is technically just amatter of writing a skill that points to the static DNS entry for yourcloud service.Naturally, expanding this to JMRI would be an issue as cloud hosting isn'tfree, and MS/Amazon/Google charge with usage... the more successful it isas a product, the more expensive it is to maintain.The other issue to consider is security. If we're talking the ability tocontrol thousands of dollars of trains via voice, would be be prudent to:1) limit control to a subset of WiThrottle functions or only controlalready moving trains, etc... and2) The age old adage of "Just because we can, doesn't mean we should".Especially if you consider lag, not hearing properly, etc... I think thatthis should come with a big red warning label.3) Security: if we don't use user accounts for authentication (and all ofthe resulting infrastructure), we'll need a key that is visible to an enduser. This could, theoretically, be used by another person to set up theirAlexa to control your layout, perhaps without you even realizing it.Drew</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Randall,I suspect that it is not uncommon for users to have multiple displays with varying DPI values - especially for those of us who would rather spend our limited funds on models rather than on computer technology.For example, I have a relatively-modern laptop computer with display of about 172 dpi, connected to an old secondary (something)-VGA monitor at about 100 dpi.  I have various JMRI windows placed on each display, with no JMRI window "crossing" the boundary between displays.  Yes, one must carefully craft panels and choose font sizes, and/or one must live with poor display utilization and/or deal with readability issues.Regards,Bob M.</pre></td>
