         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36243581/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Large Roster folder</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@al...&gt; - 2018-03-05 02:08:25</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>You don’t have fixed sizes for images in JMRI; different versions of Java on different OSes may render differently.  As of JDK 9 for Windows and Linux, and JDK 8 for macOS, the pixel size of an image may not match the logical pixel size of its frame, because the image will be rendered at pixels matching the display DPi, while the frame’s pixel size is the logical DPi. This means that an image in a 32x32 logical pixel frame needs to be 32x32 pixels for one monitor, but may need to be 64x64 or even 96x96 on another monitor. Note that this is a per-monitor problem; however if we assume that most users with multiple monitors use monitors with similar DPi on a single computer (it’s really difficult not to if only because of how text changes between to monitors with different DPi), the problem then becomes one of making sure we get the 32x32 image sized correctly for the computer, which is easy to cache locally and reuse; whereas having a single 32x32 in a profile that must be shared puts us in a position where we cannot trust the image to be scaled correctly.Randall WoodAlexandria Softwarerandall.h.wood@...<a href="http://alexandriasoftware.com" rel="nofollow">http://alexandriasoftware.com</a>&gt; On Mar 4, 2018, at 20:38, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Randall,&gt; &gt; Right now there are three places that have finite sizes for the image: icon,&gt; list page lower left, media page in roster entry. Since those are some fixed&gt; x by y, resizing for those is warranted. Keeping the original is still fine,&gt; that would leave that available for things like the remote phone, that only&gt; needs one picture at a time, for the larger resolution. But even then I'd&gt; ask our phone software people about what they are sizing for or how their&gt; end deals with the format.&gt; &gt; Our problem is the roster list having to process the WHOLE folder just for&gt; the sake of the icon which is so small I'd say it wouldn't be that big of a&gt; loss if we skipped it. And that the whole UI of JMRI grinds to a halt while&gt; that happens.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Randall,Right now there are three places that have finite sizes for the image: icon,list page lower left, media page in roster entry. Since those are some fixedx by y, resizing for those is warranted. Keeping the original is still fine,that would leave that available for things like the remote phone, that onlyneeds one picture at a time, for the larger resolution. But even then I'dask our phone software people about what they are sizing for or how theirend deals with the format.Our problem is the roster list having to process the WHOLE folder just forthe sake of the icon which is so small I'd say it wouldn't be that big of aloss if we skipped it. And that the whole UI of JMRI grinds to a halt whilethat happens.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Dave,On my system the original files (5M) take about 8-12 minutes for the rosterlisting page to open. If I use a copy that has the small files (30k), it isabout 8-15 seconds. So the amount of time is significant with 600 entries(about 450 had images). The user's system takes more like 15-20 minutes forthe roster list page to come up.But during that time, JMRI stops interacting on all screens.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Gerry,In Editor mode under the Options menu is a menu item, Panel scrollbars which lets you select none, vertical, horizontal, or both.  When you exit Editor mode, the scroll bars remain.Is this the behavior you wanted?Chuck CataniaOn Mar 4, 2018, at 9:34 AM, Gerald Wolfson &lt;wolfsonga@...&gt; wrote:&gt; It's the other two. I have created a panel and turned off editing mode. The user is making the result use half of his screen and therefore only sees half of the panel but there are no scroll bars so he can move it and see the other half. Is there away to turn them on for non-edit mode?&gt; &gt; &gt; On Mar 4, 2018 10:50 AM, "Ken Cameron" &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Gerry,&gt; &gt; Of the three editors, PE, CPE, LE: which one do you mean?         <div class="title"> 
         <h1 itemprop="name"><a href="/p/jmri/" itemprop="url">JMRI Model Railroad Interface</a></h1> 
         <h3 class="summary"> Java applications to control a model railroad layout. </h3> 
         <h3 class="brought-by"> Brought to you by: <a href="/u/jacobsen/">jacobsen</a>, <a href="/u/kevin-dickerson/">kevin-dickerson</a>, <a href="/u/matthewharris/">matthewharris</a>, <a href="/u/plocher/">plocher</a>, <a href="/u/zoo/">zoo</a> </h3> 
        </div>
       </div> 
      </div>

          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36243538/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Large Roster folder</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@al...&gt; - 2018-03-05 00:34:10</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>The reason we cache locally is that different computers have different constraints; a R-Pi Zero will need to resize more aggressively than an iMac, and even different generations of iMacs may behave very differently.As for your not being able to read an engine number in a photograph; that may be a factor of that particular photograph, and really cannot make a judgement call in the RosterEntry class how the image, when requested, will be used; that image may be requested for display at a large size on an iPad (modern iPads have a max pixel size and native resolution that was unheard of in consumer computers not even five years ago); it may be requested for display in a table at some very small size.Data sync services are very good about syncing once unless the item to is removed or replaced; you don’t need to worry about that; we do however need to worry about caching across a network, especially is we are going to cache at multiple sizes—how do we deconflict that, or avoid spamming a computer that is part of the Dropbox syncing, but doesn’t really have the fast drive to deal with lots of unwanted files?Randall WoodAlexandria Softwarerandall.h.wood@...<a href="http://alexandriasoftware.com" rel="nofollow">http://alexandriasoftware.com</a>&gt; On Mar 4, 2018, at 19:18, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Bob J,&gt; &gt; I was wondering about the memory too. I was surprised that the process size&gt; didn't grow much. So to me that is pointing to it not holding the original&gt; files, but maybe only the reduced size. Yet if I exit the roster list window&gt; and then later go back and open it again, it still takes as long to rebuild&gt; the view. So I'm thinking they aren't held very long and maybe are getting&gt; GC or something that is causing them to get rebuilt again.&gt; &gt; I do think this needs to join the list of things that can take a long time&gt; and we should be: letting the user know it is busy, and doing it in a way&gt; that only that part of JMRI is having to wait. I suspect coming up with a&gt; utility class to implement a 'waiting, N of Z' processing would be handy in&gt; a number of places.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob J,I was wondering about the memory too. I was surprised that the process sizedidn't grow much. So to me that is pointing to it not holding the originalfiles, but maybe only the reduced size. Yet if I exit the roster list windowand then later go back and open it again, it still takes as long to rebuildthe view. So I'm thinking they aren't held very long and maybe are gettingGC or something that is causing them to get rebuilt again.I do think this needs to join the list of things that can take a long timeand we should be: letting the user know it is busy, and doing it in a waythat only that part of JMRI is having to wait. I suspect coming up with autility class to implement a 'waiting, N of Z' processing would be handy ina number of places.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-header">

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36243527/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Large Roster folder</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@gm...&gt; - 2018-03-05 00:15:26</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/66D8653D-4A64-4691-B9B7-3747969ECB29%40gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>But when a user drags an image to the Media panes, we don't actually move or use the original user-provided image. We create our own copy for use in the "roster" folder, so I wouldn't feel too bad about transforming the image as we create our copy.My DAM software creates a thumbnail of every image I drag/import to it (although it stores the within the catalogue file rather than in a folder) and likewise doesn't touch the original.But there's the issue of retrospectively transforming existing images in the roster folder.What are the CPU/elapsed time overheads of an in-memory transform of every image every time we open JMRI?Sent from my iPad-- DaveThe New England Convention 2018<a href="http://www.newenglandmodelrailwayclub.com/content/convention.shtml" rel="nofollow">http://www.newenglandmodelrailwayclub.com/content/convention.shtml</a>&gt; On 4 Mar 2018, at 11:26 PM, Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; That said, we *can* do an in-memory transform to the correct pixel size (we do this in the web server), so we are not retaining the full image in memory (we don’t do image editing, so don’t need to retain the original), but I would not want to manage the image the user provided.</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Randall,I would say the right place IS the roster folder because it would be syncedwith other systems. Why force the distribution network to keep sending backand forth lots of big files when the smaller ones would work fine.Bob J,One thing I think that would be worth mentioning to users is theconsideration of the file size and impact on performance. Mentioning theview in the roster is only a X by Y view, having pictures of higherresolution doesn't help. So I'm leaning to at least a warning on the rostermedia page based on the image size on that page.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-header">

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36243517/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Large Roster folder</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@al...&gt; - 2018-03-04 23:48:35</small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>We display this *at the size* a web client requests. We can’t scale up; only down, so we can’t replace the user’s images. There is nothing wrong with caching images (so long as the cached images are stored in a cache, not in a profile folder that may be expensively synced around), but the original cannot be lost. The roster table is not the only place using roster images.Randall WoodAlexandria Softwarerandall.h.wood@...<a href="http://alexandriasoftware.com" rel="nofollow">http://alexandriasoftware.com</a>&gt; On Mar 4, 2018, at 17:43, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Randall,&gt; &gt; The problem is we are doing an in memory transform, each and every time.&gt; &gt; The biggest argument for why we resize is the windows we display it in. One&gt; is very small, the icon on the line in the roster view, maybe 15-20 pixel&gt; high (same as font size). Then the view size when you select it in the lower&gt; left corner of the roster view, it is a couple of hundred pixel high and&gt; wide. Both of these uses beg for caching the right size than computing it&gt; every time. I don't think the views in the phone throttle are all that much&gt; bigger in the displays. So all these views are quite a bit less that the&gt; supplied photo. None of them would give the chance of seeing the resolution&gt; for the original.&gt; &gt; But as I pointed out, the biggest issue this finds is that it is happening&gt; in the AWT thread and locking all the other panes of JMRI so the user gets&gt; no interaction. Next is holding the whole display while the icons are being&gt; built, isn't very good, you only need 20 or 30 at a time. Many programs&gt; would show the other fields and then the icons would show up as it gets to&gt; them.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36243514">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36243514/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Large Roster folder</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-03-04 23:44:13</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>It’s more complicated than that.First, it’s not the transform that showed up in the trace, it was the load.Java loads images asynchronously, which is good.  But when the render request comes in, which is intrinsically on the AWT thread, it doesn’t have a good way to defer waiting for the load to complete unless it knows the image metrics (size, mostly) already.  And providing that before the load is complete is complicated: It’d involve saving the information from a _prior_ run.There are other possibilities, like writing a renderer that knows to redraw when the image is complete, in the process perhaps changing the layout of the display, or perhaps being smarter about a fixed layout, or probably lots of things.  I can’t think of one that’s not going to be difficult to get right, though of course that doesn’t mean one doesn’t exist.Next, there’s the problem that Java does not normally drop loaded images from memory.  You’d have to write something that managed, and if need be reloaded, those. That’d involve some careful redo of the JMRI code, because a retained reference (of which there seem to be quite a few) would cause problems.  Maybe a handle-based approach would help? Or maybe not.After that, there might be a problem with related transforms.  Not sure I see that yet, but if it’s there, it also has to be solved or it’ll make the above two solutions pointless.Maybe somebody will get interested in digging into some of that code and building something that does the right thing. It’s not a high priority for me:  I don’t see a need to spend days on tricky code to save one user (admittedly a club) maybe 20 minutes of reformatting images.  But somebody else might have a different set of priorities.Bob&gt; On Mar 4, 2018, at 2:43 PM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Randall,&gt; &gt; The problem is we are doing an in memory transform, each and every time.&gt; &gt; The biggest argument for why we resize is the windows we display it in. One&gt; is very small, the icon on the line in the roster view, maybe 15-20 pixel&gt; high (same as font size). Then the view size when you select it in the lower&gt; left corner of the roster view, it is a couple of hundred pixel high and&gt; wide. Both of these uses beg for caching the right size than computing it&gt; every time. I don't think the views in the phone throttle are all that much&gt; bigger in the displays. So all these views are quite a bit less that the&gt; supplied photo. None of them would give the chance of seeing the resolution&gt; for the original.&gt; &gt; But as I pointed out, the biggest issue this finds is that it is happening&gt; in the AWT thread and locking all the other panes of JMRI so the user gets&gt; no interaction. Next is holding the whole display while the icons are being&gt; built, isn't very good, you only need 20 or 30 at a time. Many programs&gt; would show the other fields and then the icons would show up as it gets to&gt; them.--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36243483">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36243483/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Large Roster folder</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-03-04 22:43:55</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Randall,The problem is we are doing an in memory transform, each and every time.The biggest argument for why we resize is the windows we display it in. Oneis very small, the icon on the line in the roster view, maybe 15-20 pixelhigh (same as font size). Then the view size when you select it in the lowerleft corner of the roster view, it is a couple of hundred pixel high andwide. Both of these uses beg for caching the right size than computing itevery time. I don't think the views in the phone throttle are all that muchbigger in the displays. So all these views are quite a bit less that thesupplied photo. None of them would give the chance of seeing the resolutionfor the original.But as I pointed out, the biggest issue this finds is that it is happeningin the AWT thread and locking all the other panes of JMRI so the user getsno interaction. Next is holding the whole display while the icons are beingbuilt, isn't very good, you only need 20 or 30 at a time. Many programswould show the other fields and then the icons would show up as it gets tothem.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36243380/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Large Roster folder</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: &lt;db123@be...&gt; - 2018-03-04 20:21:21</small> 
           <div class="attachments">

           </div> 
          </div> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I have used "PhotoFiltre" for this, but it was a number of years ago.<a href="https://photofiltre.en.softonic.com/" rel="nofollow">https://photofiltre.en.softonic.com/</a>RegardsDaniel2018-03-04 15:16 skrev Ken Cameron:&gt; As a test I'm going to find a utility and batch resize all the images &gt; and&gt; see how that performs. On the size of number of entries, I know at &gt; least two&gt; individuals with 500+ locos, so I'm thinking the big issue is the &gt; photos.&gt; &gt; It would seem that the system is somehow making the small thumbnail for &gt; the&gt; roster page display, caching that (use timestamp of original) would be &gt; one&gt; idea.&gt; &gt; But longer term fixes, that's something we should kick around and see &gt; what&gt; others might figure out. The biggest bug right now seems that this &gt; locks the&gt; whole swing thread rendering all of JMRI unusable.&gt; &gt; What tools do people suggest for doing a batch convert of these files &gt; to&gt; smaller images? I've not done this in years and can't recall what I &gt; used&gt; back then. I want to see what the response speed is if all these photos &gt; were&gt; sized small.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36243318/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Help With Thread States</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-03-04 19:09:37</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Can you see where the PARKed thread is waiting?AFAIK, a thread has to park itself, it can’t be parked by anything outside itself.  The java.concurrent classes use that as a lighter-weight form of collaborative synchronization, as it’s just cheaper than a true lock.  So I suspect that you’ve _something_ _else_ that’s waiting before it proceeds, which is causing some other part of a java.concurrent class to be hung up.I.e. if you can see where the TrafficController thread is in PARK, see if that’s inside some java.concurrent object, and look for _other_ uses of that object that have been held.Bob&gt; On Mar 4, 2018, at 10:14 AM, Andrew Crosland &lt;andrew@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I am still trying to figure out performance issues with the SPROG soft command station causing packets to not get to the rails as often as they should.&gt; &gt; It's mostly working well now and I don't see any particular issues on my Windows desktop.&gt; &gt; The real problem occurs on an Raspberry Pi. I am using Visual VM on my Windows machine to remotely monitor DP3 running on the Rpi and also have a VNC connection for the DP3 gui. Closing the VNC connection does not help. I never managed to get the NetBeans profiler to connect to a remote process.&gt; &gt; The RPi is generally slower than the Windows desktop (no surprise there). The real problem is that I periodically (say every 1 s) see a delay between packets of over 2.5 s. This causes the locos to slow and then pick up again (I don't want to play with the decoder packet timeout just yet).&gt; &gt; I tried turning on debug with "log4j.category.jmri.jmrix=DEBUG". That causes DP3 to become very sluggish on the RPi, presumably due to all the extra logging activity, but I did get enough data to see that the traffic controller is wait()'ing 2.5 s before being notify()'ed of a reply. A SPROG does not take that long to reply to the packets in question. There was no DP3 debug output from any other threads during the wait.&gt; &gt; Now, using Visual VM I see the traffic controller thread state changes from WAIT to PARK state for the duration of the delay.&gt; &gt; What causes a thread to become PARK'ed without explicitly calling it's park() methid?&gt; &gt; I see no other "smoking gun" in the Visual VM output, e.g. heap, garbage collection all look normal.&gt; &gt; My suspicion is that it is something to do with the RPi having a slow flash file system and periodically doing some housekeeping.&gt; &gt; Can anyone offer any insight?&gt; &gt; Andrew&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36243281/">[Jmri-developers] Help With Thread States</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Andrew Crosland &lt;andrew@cr...&gt; - 2018-03-04 18:15:02</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/em2ccccb4d-2144-4a6a-99af-cb47f367cf77%40sprog-pc/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I am still trying to figure out performance issues with the SPROG soft command station causing packets to not get to the rails as often as they should.It's mostly working well now and I don't see any particular issues on my Windows desktop.The real problem occurs on an Raspberry Pi. I am using Visual VM on my Windows machine to remotely monitor DP3 running on the Rpi and also have a VNC connection for the DP3 gui. Closing the VNC connection does not help. I never managed to get the NetBeans profiler to connect to a remote process.The RPi is generally slower than the Windows desktop (no surprise there). The real problem is that I periodically (say every 1 s) see a delay between packets of over 2.5 s. This causes the locos to slow and then pick up again (I don't want to play with the decoder packet timeout just yet).I tried turning on debug with "log4j.category.jmri.jmrix=DEBUG". That causes DP3 to become very sluggish on the RPi, presumably due to all the extra logging activity, but I did get enough data to see that the traffic controller is wait()'ing 2.5 s before being notify()'ed of a reply. A SPROG does not take that long to reply to the packets in question. There was no DP3 debug output from any other threads during the wait.Now, using Visual VM I see the traffic controller thread state changes from WAIT to PARK state for the duration of the delay.What causes a thread to become PARK'ed without explicitly calling it's park() methid?I see no other "smoking gun" in the Visual VM output, e.g. heap, garbage collection all look normal.My suspicion is that it is something to do with the RPi having a slow flash file system and periodically doing some housekeeping.Can anyone offer any insight?Andrew</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I have created a project at <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/projects/3?" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/projects/3?</a> to track what needs to be done to move off SourceForge.If you think of things not listed in that project, create an issue of them and add them to the project please.Note that I do not recommend abandoning or closing the project (as someone could take it over), but definitely turning it into an “archive”.Randall WoodJMRI Developer - <a href="http://jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org</a>Alexandria Software - <a href="http://alexandriasoftware.com" rel="nofollow">http://alexandriasoftware.com</a>Northern Virginia NTRAK - <a href="http://nvntrak.org" rel="nofollow">http://nvntrak.org</a>&gt; On Mar 1, 2018, at 14:23, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; On Feb 18, 2018, at 6:10 PM, Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; - Web Site: I would like to move the web site from SF.net, but also would like to make its content static (this has an advantage for JMRI users—everything that relies on PHP (except the bug reporting tool) is shipped with JMRI, but neither the JMRI help viewer or web server can render PHP or SSI) so it can be hosted anywhere, not just anywhere that supports Apache HTTPD with a PHP module. I’ll follow up with a separate more concrete proposal on how we could do that.&gt; &gt; There are three places that the web site uses PHP:&gt; &gt; *) The bug reporting tool - we control both ends, so could change it to something else (and already have, as it used to use email)&gt; &gt; *) A few bits of automation for the the release building, which can certainly be done on the command line&gt; &gt; *) The indexing pages for the various directories of images:  <a href="http://jmri.org/resources/icons/image.php" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/resources/icons/image.php</a> (though SF.net is currently down, so that link isn’t working)&gt; &gt; An ant task to build static index pages would be an OK replacement for that last one.&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Its also legitimate to ask why we should change the image that the user selected to use (BTW 5 MB per JPEG is about the color/pixel density a camera on a good smartphone produces, but its not a large image by any standards these days (I work with customers who’s images are 40GB per frame).That said, we *can* do an in-memory transform to the correct pixel size (we do this in the web server), so we are not retaining the full image in memory (we don’t do image editing, so don’t need to retain the original), but I would not want to manage the image the user provided.Randall Wood&gt; On Mar 3, 2018, at 22:56, db123@... &lt;mailto:db123@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Not all users are familiar with how to resize images. The same problem can be seen on web forums there some users have problems with images that are to big to post on the forum.&gt; &gt; A solution could be to add some code to automatic resize new images to the roster. And if that code was added, it would also be nice to be able to run that code on existing images in the roster.&gt; &gt; Regards&gt; Daniel&gt; &gt; &gt; 2018-03-04 04:30 skrev Bob Jacobsen:&gt;&gt; Java images are (by default) loaded into memory and kept there.&gt;&gt; So 1.8GB of roster pictures is going to be a problem until somebody&gt;&gt; makes the JMRI code in that area _much_ smarter.&gt;&gt; But the real problem is the 5Mb (which is probably 5MB) pictures.  Why so big?&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt; On Mar 3, 2018, at 9:01 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@... &lt;mailto:kcameron@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm trying to debug a startup/hang issue with a layout. I think I've&gt;&gt;&gt; isolated it to the roster. Each roster entry has a picture, a 5Mb picture.&gt;&gt;&gt; And there are nearly 600 locos in the roster. So the whole folder is about&gt;&gt;&gt; 1.8Gb.&gt;&gt;&gt; I suspect something isn't what the code was expecting for size or count.&gt;&gt;&gt; Either the startup hangs for 10 or more minutes and sometimes the shutdown&gt;&gt;&gt; hangs for at least that long or worse. Frequently they end up killing the&gt;&gt;&gt; process to shutdown.&gt;&gt;&gt; I've got a copy of it on my laptop now. So I'm looking for things to check.&gt;&gt;&gt; Now we know that for the most part shrinking those pictures down to 100k&gt;&gt;&gt; each would look almost as good for the roster. But since the camera shot all&gt;&gt;&gt; these at this size, we should look into this. Anyone with ideas and hints of&gt;&gt;&gt; what part of the code could be causing it to get lost would help. I'll try&gt;&gt;&gt; to do some thread analysis once I've got everything. Couldn't use a USB&gt;&gt;&gt; stick, having to network to get my copy.&gt;&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.jmri.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org/&gt;</a>;&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!          <td class="email-body"><pre>Its also legitimate to ask why we should change the image that the user selected to use (BTW 5 MB per JPEG is about the color/pixel density a camera on a good smartphone produces, but its not a large image by any standards these days (I work with customers who’s images are 40GB per frame).That said, we *can* do an in-memory transform to the correct pixel size (we do this in the web server), so we are not retaining the full image in memory (we don’t do image editing, so don’t need to retain the original), but I would not want to manage the image the user provided.Randall Wood&gt; On Mar 3, 2018, at 22:56, db123@... wrote:&gt; &gt; Not all users are familiar with how to resize images.          <td class="email-body"><pre>As a test I'm going to find a utility and batch resize all the images andsee how that performs. On the size of number of entries, I know at least twoindividuals with 500+ locos, so I'm thinking the big issue is the photos.It would seem that the system is somehow making the small thumbnail for theroster page display, caching that (use timestamp of original) would be oneidea.But longer term fixes, that's something we should kick around and see whatothers might figure out. The biggest bug right now seems that this locks thewhole swing thread rendering all of JMRI unusable.What tools do people suggest for doing a batch convert of these files tosmaller images? I've not done this in years and can't recall what I usedback then. I want to see what the response speed is if all these photos weresized small.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36242734/">Re: [Jmri-developers] 4.11.3 error messages</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@al...&gt; - 2018-03-04 05:00:08</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/6A59B3D9-1850-4194-849A-0F0C194BE587%40alexandriasoftware.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Our tables do not support any bulk actions at all, so claiming these check boxes support that is a straw man argument. That said, individual actions taken on individual sensors is, by definition, not bulk anyway.Putting individual per-object buttons in columns do not change that. Providing users with duplicate, indistinguishable columns (when given two OpenLCB connections) that are always enabled (even for the wrong connection) and show no indication of not acting when a user clicks on them (other than stack traces) because there are multiple connections is being actively hostile to users. Providing users with enabled, but non-responsive controls in columns for non-OpenLCB connections is also just a bad UI.These columns need to be fixed both in the sense that they throw errors and they are poor UI.Randall Wood&gt; On Mar 1, 2018, at 00:41, Balazs Racz &lt;balazs.racz@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Ken,&gt; &gt; almost all the columns can be switched on and off in the footer. If you don't like a column or set of columns, switch it off. I think columns can also individually be hidden by right clicking the table header.&gt; &gt; The table format is useful when you have to do a bulk operation over a large number of objects, or you recognize there has been some inconsistency in how you set up your objects and need to find the outliers for yourself to fix. Needing to go "edit", then find the tab, click the tab header, check-double-check, click inside if wrong, type new value, then hit save is quite a bit more painful. You are accustomed to doing a bunch of stuff by directly opening the XML so it's not an issue for you.&gt; &gt; For system-specific properties, they can be edited in the generic "properties" tab of the edit dialog.&gt; &gt; thanks,&gt; Balazs&gt; &gt; On Thu, Mar 1, 2018 at 4:24 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@... &lt;mailto:kcameron@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt; My other view on this is what we should bother having as columns in the&gt; first place and what to leave for the 'edit' display. IMHO, everything&gt; should be in the edit and some should be columns. That's not the case, but&gt; my opinion. When you open the edit, you have a single bean object, so issues&gt; like which options and such from the connection are all known.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.jmri.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org/&gt;</a>;&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org/&gt;</a>;&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.cnymod.com/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com/&gt;</a>;&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org/&gt;</a>;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!          <td class="email-body"><pre>Not all users are familiar with how to resize images. The same problem can be seen on web forums there some users have problems with images that are to big to post on the forum.A solution could be to add some code to automatic resize new images to the roster. And if that code was added, it would also be nice to be able to run that code on existing images in the roster.RegardsDaniel2018-03-04 04:30 skrev Bob Jacobsen:&gt; Java images are (by default) loaded into memory and kept there.&gt; &gt; So 1.8GB of roster pictures is going to be a problem until somebody&gt; makes the JMRI code in that area _much_ smarter.&gt; &gt; But the real problem is the 5Mb (which is probably 5MB) pictures.  Why &gt; so big?&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt;&gt; On Mar 3, 2018, at 9:01 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I'm trying to debug a startup/hang issue with a layout. I think I've&gt;&gt; isolated it to the roster. Each roster entry has a picture, a 5Mb &gt;&gt; picture.&gt;&gt; And there are nearly 600 locos in the roster. So the whole folder is &gt;&gt; about&gt;&gt; 1.8Gb.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I suspect something isn't what the code was expecting for size or &gt;&gt; count.&gt;&gt; Either the startup hangs for 10 or more minutes and sometimes the &gt;&gt; shutdown&gt;&gt; hangs for at least that long or worse. Frequently they end up killing &gt;&gt; the&gt;&gt; process to shutdown.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I've got a copy of it on my laptop now. So I'm looking for things to &gt;&gt; check.&gt;&gt; Now we know that for the most part shrinking those pictures down to &gt;&gt; 100k&gt;&gt; each would look almost as good for the roster. But since the camera &gt;&gt; shot all&gt;&gt; these at this size, we should look into this. Anyone with ideas and &gt;&gt; hints of&gt;&gt; what part of the code could be causing it to get lost would help. I'll &gt;&gt; try&gt;&gt; to do some thread analysis once I've got everything.          <td class="email-body"><pre>Java images are (by default) loaded into memory and kept there.So 1.8GB of roster pictures is going to be a problem until somebody makes the JMRI code in that area _much_ smarter.But the real problem is the 5Mb (which is probably 5MB) pictures.  Why so big?Bob&gt; On Mar 3, 2018, at 9:01 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I'm trying to debug a startup/hang issue with a layout. I think I've&gt; isolated it to the roster. So the whole folder is about&gt; 1.8Gb.&gt; &gt; I suspect something isn't what the code was expecting for size or count.&gt; Either the startup hangs for 10 or more minutes and sometimes the shutdown&gt; hangs for at least that long or worse. Frequently they end up killing the&gt; process to shutdown.&gt; &gt; I've got a copy of it on my laptop now. So I'm looking for things to check.&gt; Now we know that for the most part shrinking those pictures down to 100k&gt; each would look almost as good for the roster. But since the camera shot all&gt; these at this size, we should look into this. Anyone with ideas and hints of&gt; what part of the code could be causing it to get lost would help. I'll try&gt; to do some thread analysis once I've got everything.          <td class="email-body"><pre>I'm trying to debug a startup/hang issue with a layout. I think I'veisolated it to the roster. Each roster entry has a picture, a 5Mb picture.And there are nearly 600 locos in the roster. So the whole folder is about1.8Gb.I suspect something isn't what the code was expecting for size or count.Either the startup hangs for 10 or more minutes and sometimes the shutdownhangs for at least that long or worse. Frequently they end up killing theprocess to shutdown.I've got a copy of it on my laptop now. So I'm looking for things to check.Now we know that for the most part shrinking those pictures down to 100keach would look almost as good for the roster. But since the camera shot allthese at this size, we should look into this. Anyone with ideas and hints ofwhat part of the code could be causing it to get lost would help.             <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36242002/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Alexa</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Mark Underwood &lt;msunderwd@gm...&gt; - 2018-03-01 23:01:30</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CADq1XSx1o-YQq0O67C1HXSD3y6NdRsbx0R%3Dwin3sPOc%2BhQNvaQ%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Right. I think actually *being* the dispatcher presumes a level of AI thatis beyond my skill level. And probably unnecessary anyway.More like Alexa is the human dispatchers voice interface to JMRIs tools andalso the “radio” for voice- called OS and things like that.I think we are on the same page with that, I just may not be using theright words.I agree the test assistant would be a great use.Biggest problem is dealing with AWS access to JMRI through a dynamic IP.May need some kind of cloud layout registry service to make that workoutside of the sandbox. I am researching how smart home appliances solvethis as a model.On Thu, Mar 1, 2018 at 1:08 PM Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Mark,&gt;&gt; I was thinking more of it being a junior dispatcher and the senior giving&gt; the major directions. Then the software would take it from there. But the&gt; 2nd person testing support is a big one for me. Your mention of with&gt; Dispatcher gives a way for the 'just in time' updating of train locations&gt; to&gt; release cars for other trains. Some layouts use a traffic manager position,&gt; usually next to the dispatcher. They would interact with Dispatcher to&gt; update and generate the switch lists on the fly.&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Thanks. I agree the way the wait may stall the AWT thread is not good. I don't know why it was written that way but I think it goes back to the very first SPROG support. I had always assumed there was other similar code but I don't see any other 'waitForReply' variables. It probably worked OK when SPROG was just a programmer. The soft command station has been causing a few headaches recently.There is a comment "Updated January 2010 for gnu io (RXTX) - Andrew Berridge.  * Removed Runnable implementation and methods for it."Maybe there was originally a separate thread.Can I get the pre-RXTX form Git, or does it predate our use of Git?I think I do need to use a queue to accept asynchronous messages from various sources and fire them off to the hardware one at a time with a strict message/reply pairing.Andrew------ Original Message ------From: "Bob Jacobsen" &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;To: "Andrew Crosland" &lt;andrew@...&gt;; "Discussions between JMRI developers" &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Sent: 01/03/2018 18:35:08Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Help needed with synchronized method&gt;‘wait(..)” drops the lock (you’ll see it called a “monitor” in some &gt;places).  That’s intentional.&gt;&gt;The wait/notify are meant to go together, working cooperatively.  So &gt;they’re meant to be coded together.&gt;&gt;`synchronized` isn’t a good way to hold something off for a long time.  &gt;It’s really meant to make sure individual methods don’t overlap, not &gt;long operations.&gt;&gt;For example, if synchronized kept the AWT thread from advancing in the &gt;example below, effectively freezing it in place, that’s probably not &gt;the desired outcome.&gt;&gt;Many of the TrafficManagers use a producer/consumer approach, where &gt;there’s a quick synchronize operation to put messages on a queue, and a &gt;thread that takes things off it.  The notify() operation then makes &gt;sure the reading thread is awake to look at it.&gt;&gt;Bob&gt;&gt;&gt;On Mar 1, 2018, at 10:20 AM, Andrew Crosland &lt;andrew@...&gt; &gt;&gt;wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;The SPROG traffic controller has a synchronized method to send t the &gt;&gt;hardware:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     public synchronized void sendSprogMessage(SprogMessage m, &gt;&gt;SprogListener replyTo) {&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         log.debug("Entering sendSprogMessage()");&gt;&gt;         if (waitingForReply) {&gt;&gt;             try {&gt;&gt;                 log.debug("Waiting for a reply");&gt;&gt;                 wait(100); // Will wait until notify()ed or 100ms &gt;&gt;timeout&gt;&gt;             } catch (InterruptedException e) {&gt;&gt;                 log.debug("waitingForReply interrupted");&gt;&gt;             }&gt;&gt;         }&gt;&gt;         log.debug("Setting waitingForReply");&gt;&gt;         waitingForReply = true;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         log.debug("sendSprogMessage message: [{}] id: {}", &gt;&gt;m.toString(isSIIBootMode()), m.getId());&gt;&gt;         // remember who sent this&gt;&gt;//        log.debug("Updating last sender {}");&gt;&gt;         lastSender = replyTo;&gt;&gt;         lastId = m.getId();&gt;&gt;         // notify all _other_ listeners&gt;&gt;         notifyMessage(m, replyTo);&gt;&gt;         this.sendSprogMessage(m);&gt;&gt;     }&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;The wait(100) is terminated by a notify when a reply is despatched:&gt;&gt;     private void sendreply() {&gt;&gt;         //send the reply&gt;&gt;         log.debug("dispatch reply of length {}", &gt;&gt;this.reply.getNumDataElements());&gt;&gt;         {&gt;&gt;             final SprogReply thisReply = this.reply;&gt;&gt;             final SprogListener thisLastSender = this.lastSender;&gt;&gt;             final int thisLastId = this.lastId;&gt;&gt;             if (unsolicited) {&gt;&gt;                 log.debug("Unsolicited Reply");&gt;&gt;                 thisReply.setUnsolicited();&gt;&gt;             }&gt;&gt;             // Insert the id&gt;&gt;             thisReply.setId(thisLastId);&gt;&gt;             final SprogTrafficController thisTC = this;&gt;&gt;             thisTC.notifyReply(thisReply, thisLastSender);&gt;&gt;         }&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         // Do this after reply is despatched to avoid this.reply and &gt;&gt;.lastSender&gt;&gt;         // being overwritten by a new reply&gt;&gt;         synchronized (this) {&gt;&gt;             log.debug("Clearing waitingForReply");&gt;&gt;             waitingForReply = false;&gt;&gt;             notify();&gt;&gt;         }&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         //Create a new reply, ready to be filled&gt;&gt;         this.reply = new SprogReply();&gt;&gt;     }&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;notifyReply() used to be called from a runnable but I don't want it to &gt;&gt;run on the swing thread, so now call it directly.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;The problem is that two threads are executing the synchronized code&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;slot thread sets waitForReply:&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,763 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;Entering sendSprogMessage() [SPROG slot thread]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,763 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;Setting waitingForReply [SPROG slot thread]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,765 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;sendSprogMessage message: [O 01 3F 8C B2] id: 17124 [SPROG slot &gt;&gt;thread]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,768 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;sendSprogMessage written to ostream [SPROG slot thread]&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;slot thread has exited the synchronized method. Swing thread enters &gt;&gt;and waits due to waitForReply already set:&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,770 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;Entering sendSprogMessage() [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,770 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;Waiting for a reply [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; reply to the first message arrives from hardware:&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,778 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;dispatch reply of length 3 [COM5]&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; waitForReply is cleared and notify() called:&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;Clearing waitingForReply [COM5]&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; At this point the swing thread should wake up from the wait() and &gt;&gt;resume execution of the synchronized method, but the slot thread &gt;&gt;enters that method and sets waitingFor Reply:&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;Entering sendSprogMessage() [SPROG slot thread]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;Setting waitingForReply [SPROG slot thread]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;sendSprogMessage message: [O 02 3F 94 A9] id: 17127 [SPROG slot &gt;&gt;thread]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,780 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;sendSprogMessage written to ostream [SPROG slot thread]&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; slot thread exits the synchronized method and now the swing thread &gt;&gt;resumes:&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,780 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;Setting waitingForReply [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,782 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;sendSprogMessage message: [S] id: 17125 [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,783 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;sendSprogMessage written to ostream [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,786 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;dispatch reply of length 3 [COM5]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,788 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;Clearing waitingForReply [COM5]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,794 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;dispatch reply of length 26 [COM5]&gt;&gt;2018-03-01 17:54:32,796 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - &gt;&gt;Clearing waitingForReply [COM5]&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;My understanding of synchronized methods and wait() may be flawed (or &gt;&gt;I've been staring at the code for too long and cannot see the flaw). &gt;&gt;Can anyone help me understand why one thread is pre-empted by another &gt;&gt;within a synchronized method? How to prevent it?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;Andrew&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! &gt;&gt;<a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt;&gt;Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt;Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;--&gt;Bob Jacobsen&gt;jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; On Feb 18, 2018, at 6:10 PM, Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; - Web Site: I would like to move the web site from SF.net, but also would like to make its content static (this has an advantage for JMRI users—everything that relies on PHP (except the bug reporting tool) is shipped with JMRI, but neither the JMRI help viewer or web server can render PHP or SSI) so it can be hosted anywhere, not just anywhere that supports Apache HTTPD with a PHP module. I’ll follow up with a separate more concrete proposal on how we could do that.There are three places that the web site uses PHP:*) The bug reporting tool - we control both ends, so could change it to something else (and already have, as it used to use email)*) A few bits of automation for the the release building, which can certainly be done on the command line*) The indexing pages for the various directories of images:  <a href="http://jmri.org/resources/icons/image.php" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/resources/icons/image.php</a> (though SF.net is currently down, so that link isn’t working)An ant task to build static index pages would be an OK replacement for that last one.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36241999/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Help needed with synchronized method</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-03-01 18:35:22</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>‘wait(..)” drops the lock (you’ll see it called a “monitor” in some places).  That’s intentional. The wait/notify are meant to go together, working cooperatively.  So they’re meant to be coded together.`synchronized` isn’t a good way to hold something off for a long time.  It’s really meant to make sure individual methods don’t overlap, not long operations.  For example, if synchronized kept the AWT thread from advancing in the example below, effectively freezing it in place, that’s probably not the desired outcome.Many of the TrafficManagers use a producer/consumer approach, where there’s a quick synchronize operation to put messages on a queue, and a thread that takes things off it.  The notify() operation then makes sure the reading thread is awake to look at it.Bob&gt; On Mar 1, 2018, at 10:20 AM, Andrew Crosland &lt;andrew@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; The SPROG traffic controller has a synchronized method to send t the hardware:&gt; &gt;     public synchronized void sendSprogMessage(SprogMessage m, SprogListener replyTo) {&gt; &gt;         log.debug("Entering sendSprogMessage()");&gt;         if (waitingForReply) {&gt;             try {&gt;                 log.debug("Waiting for a reply");&gt;                 wait(100); // Will wait until notify()ed or 100ms timeout&gt;             } catch (InterruptedException e) {&gt;                 log.debug("waitingForReply interrupted");&gt;             }&gt;         }&gt;         log.debug("Setting waitingForReply");&gt;         waitingForReply = true;&gt; &gt;         log.debug("sendSprogMessage message: [{}] id: {}", m.toString(isSIIBootMode()), m.getId());&gt;         // remember who sent this&gt; //        log.debug("Updating last sender {}");&gt;         lastSender = replyTo;&gt;         lastId = m.getId();&gt;         // notify all _other_ listeners&gt;         notifyMessage(m, replyTo);&gt;         this.sendSprogMessage(m);&gt;     }&gt; &gt; The wait(100) is terminated by a notify when a reply is despatched:&gt;     private void sendreply() {&gt;         //send the reply&gt;         log.debug("dispatch reply of length {}", this.reply.getNumDataElements());&gt;         {&gt;             final SprogReply thisReply = this.reply;&gt;             final SprogListener thisLastSender = this.lastSender;&gt;             final int thisLastId = this.lastId;&gt;             if (unsolicited) {&gt;                 log.debug("Unsolicited Reply");&gt;                 thisReply.setUnsolicited();&gt;             }&gt;             // Insert the id&gt;             thisReply.setId(thisLastId);&gt;             final SprogTrafficController thisTC = this;&gt;             thisTC.notifyReply(thisReply, thisLastSender);&gt;         }&gt; &gt;         // Do this after reply is despatched to avoid this.reply and .lastSender&gt;         // being overwritten by a new reply&gt;         synchronized (this) {&gt;             log.debug("Clearing waitingForReply");&gt;             waitingForReply = false;&gt;             notify();&gt;         }&gt;         &gt;         //Create a new reply, ready to be filled&gt;         this.reply = new SprogReply();&gt;     }&gt; &gt; notifyReply() used to be called from a runnable but I don't want it to run on the swing thread, so now call it directly.&gt; &gt; The problem is that two threads are executing the synchronized code&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;slot thread sets waitForReply:&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,763 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Entering sendSprogMessage() [SPROG slot thread]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,763 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Setting waitingForReply [SPROG slot thread]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,765 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage message: [O 01 3F 8C B2] id: 17124 [SPROG slot thread]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,768 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage written to ostream [SPROG slot thread]&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;slot thread has exited the synchronized method. Swing thread enters and waits due to waitForReply already set:&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,770 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Entering sendSprogMessage() [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,770 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Waiting for a reply [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; reply to the first message arrives from hardware:&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,778 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - dispatch reply of length 3 [COM5]&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; waitForReply is cleared and notify() called:&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Clearing waitingForReply [COM5]&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; At this point the swing thread should wake up from the wait() and resume execution of the synchronized method, but the slot thread enters that method and sets waitingFor Reply:&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Entering sendSprogMessage() [SPROG slot thread]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Setting waitingForReply [SPROG slot thread]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage message: [O 02 3F 94 A9] id: 17127 [SPROG slot thread]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,780 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage written to ostream [SPROG slot thread]&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; slot thread exits the synchronized method and now the swing thread resumes:&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,780 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Setting waitingForReply [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,782 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage message: [S] id: 17125 [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,783 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage written to ostream [AWT-EventQueue-0]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,786 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - dispatch reply of length 3 [COM5]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,788 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Clearing waitingForReply [COM5]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,794 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - dispatch reply of length 26 [COM5]&gt; 2018-03-01 17:54:32,796 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Clearing waitingForReply [COM5]&gt; &gt; My understanding of synchronized methods and wait() may be flawed (or I've been staring at the code for too long and cannot see the flaw). Can anyone help me understand why one thread is pre-empted by another within a synchronized method? How to prevent it?&gt; &gt; Andrew&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36241998/">[Jmri-developers] scrollbars in non-edit mode for Panel Editor?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Gerald Wolfson &lt;wolfsonga@gm...&gt; - 2018-03-01 18:20:57</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CALQk5-Mfxzcoxu3DjvwqJRxLK%3DSsfO8_5nzmp9DOdM4vwA4Snw%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre> Hi,  I was wondering if there is any way to turn on the scrollbars when not inedit mode for a panel created in the panel editor? There are times when thepanel is dragged from the right to make it half the screen it is sized forbut without the scrollbars you can not get to the other part of the screen.Is there something to set or is this a feature that just ain't there?=gerry=</pre></td>

       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36241997">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36241997/">[Jmri-developers] Help needed with synchronized method</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Andrew Crosland &lt;andrew@cr...&gt; - 2018-03-01 18:20:42</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/emeaefe0e7-6fd9-4bd4-922c-b74605e5a0b7%40sprog-pc/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>The SPROG traffic controller has a synchronized method to send t the hardware:     public synchronized void sendSprogMessage(SprogMessage m, SprogListener replyTo) {         log.debug("Entering sendSprogMessage()");         if (waitingForReply) {             try {                 log.debug("Waiting for a reply");                 wait(100); // Will wait until notify()ed or 100ms timeout             } catch (InterruptedException e) {                 log.debug("waitingForReply interrupted");             }         }         log.debug("Setting waitingForReply");         waitingForReply = true;         log.debug("sendSprogMessage message: [{}] id: {}", m.toString(isSIIBootMode()), m.getId());         // remember who sent this//        log.debug("Updating last sender {}");         lastSender = replyTo;         lastId = m.getId();         // notify all _other_ listeners         notifyMessage(m, replyTo);         this.sendSprogMessage(m);     }The wait(100) is terminated by a notify when a reply is despatched:     private void sendreply() {         //send the reply         log.debug("dispatch reply of length {}", this.reply.getNumDataElements());         {             final SprogReply thisReply = this.reply;             final SprogListener thisLastSender = this.lastSender;             final int thisLastId = this.lastId;             if (unsolicited) {                 log.debug("Unsolicited Reply");                 thisReply.setUnsolicited();             }             // Insert the id             thisReply.setId(thisLastId);             final SprogTrafficController thisTC = this;             thisTC.notifyReply(thisReply, thisLastSender);         }         // Do this after reply is despatched to avoid this.reply and .lastSender         // being overwritten by a new reply         synchronized (this) {             log.debug("Clearing waitingForReply");             waitingForReply = false;             notify();         }         //Create a new reply, ready to be filled         this.reply = new SprogReply();     }notifyReply() used to be called from a runnable but I don't want it to run on the swing thread, so now call it directly.The problem is that two threads are executing the synchronized code &gt;&gt;&gt;slot thread sets waitForReply:2018-03-01 17:54:32,763 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Entering sendSprogMessage() [SPROG slot thread]2018-03-01 17:54:32,763 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Setting waitingForReply [SPROG slot thread]2018-03-01 17:54:32,765 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage message: [O 01 3F 8C B2] id: 17124 [SPROG slot thread]2018-03-01 17:54:32,768 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage written to ostream [SPROG slot thread] &gt;&gt;&gt;slot thread has exited the synchronized method. Swing thread enters and waits due to waitForReply already set:2018-03-01 17:54:32,770 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Entering sendSprogMessage() [AWT-EventQueue-0]2018-03-01 17:54:32,770 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Waiting for a reply [AWT-EventQueue-0] &gt;&gt;&gt; reply to the first message arrives from hardware:2018-03-01 17:54:32,778 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - dispatch reply of length 3 [COM5] &gt;&gt;&gt; waitForReply is cleared and notify() called:2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Clearing waitingForReply [COM5] &gt;&gt;&gt; At this point the swing thread should wake up from the wait() and resume execution of the synchronized method, but the slot thread enters that method and sets waitingFor Reply:2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Entering sendSprogMessage() [SPROG slot thread]2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Setting waitingForReply [SPROG slot thread]2018-03-01 17:54:32,779 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage message: [O 02 3F 94 A9] id: 17127 [SPROG slot thread]2018-03-01 17:54:32,780 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage written to ostream [SPROG slot thread] &gt;&gt;&gt; slot thread exits the synchronized method and now the swing thread resumes:2018-03-01 17:54:32,780 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Setting waitingForReply [AWT-EventQueue-0]2018-03-01 17:54:32,782 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage message: [S] id: 17125 [AWT-EventQueue-0]2018-03-01 17:54:32,783 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - sendSprogMessage written to ostream [AWT-EventQueue-0]2018-03-01 17:54:32,786 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - dispatch reply of length 3 [COM5]2018-03-01 17:54:32,788 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Clearing waitingForReply [COM5]2018-03-01 17:54:32,794 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - dispatch reply of length 26 [COM5]2018-03-01 17:54:32,796 sprog.SprogTrafficController          DEBUG - Clearing waitingForReply [COM5]My understanding of synchronized methods and wait() may be flawed (or I've been staring at the code for too long and cannot see the flaw). Can anyone help me understand why one thread is pre-empted by another within a synchronized method? How to prevent it?Andrew</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Mark,I was thinking more of it being a junior dispatcher and the senior givingthe major directions. Then the software would take it from there. But the2nd person testing support is a big one for me. Your mention of withDispatcher gives a way for the 'just in time' updating of train locations torelease cars for other trains. Some layouts use a traffic manager position,usually next to the dispatcher. They would interact with Dispatcher toupdate and generate the switch lists on the fly.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Ken,almost all the columns can be switched on and off in the footer. If youdon't like a column or set of columns, switch it off. I think columns canalso individually be hidden by right clicking the table header.The table format is useful when you have to do a bulk operation over alarge number of objects, or you recognize there has been some inconsistencyin how you set up your objects and need to find the outliers for yourselfto fix. Needing to go "edit", then find the tab, click the tab header,check-double-check, click inside if wrong, type new value, then hit save isquite a bit more painful. You are accustomed to doing a bunch of stuff bydirectly opening the XML so it's not an issue for you.For system-specific properties, they can be edited in the generic"properties" tab of the edit dialog.thanks,BalazsOn Thu, Mar 1, 2018 at 4:24 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; My other view on this is what we should bother having as columns in the&gt; first place and what to leave for the 'edit' display. IMHO, everything&gt; should be in the edit and some should be columns. That's not the case, but&gt; my opinion. When you open the edit, you have a single bean object, so&gt; issues&gt; like which options and such from the connection are all known.&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Pretty cool!Loved it.DanFrom: Mark Underwood&lt;mailto:msunderwd@...&gt;Sent: Wednesday, February 28, 2018 8:25 AMTo: Discussions between JMRI developers&lt;mailto:jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: [Jmri-developers] AlexaI thought you guys might find this most recent distraction of mine interesting...<a href="https://youtu.be/dwbY77zIAag" rel="nofollow">https://youtu.be/dwbY77zIAag</a>I wrote an Alexa Skill that uses the WiThrottle interface to talk to JMRI.For now it can just turn on/off the track power and throw turnouts. I plan to add a few other things (querying block occupancy, etc.) but I think there's too much latency to do things like drive trains.I don't really have any plans of publishing this skill, nor do I think it should be directly integrated into JMRI. It's just another thing that can interface with it.  I might share the skill and associated Lambda code on my own GitHub or something.  I did this "for fun" for my own use and as a learning experience.  Besides, the work required to expose a local JMRI instance to the outside internet from within the typical home is (while not that hard for the technically inclined) rather beyond the average modeler's skill set.I'm curious, though, what y'alls thoughts are about it, and if you have any ideas of what I could do with it...- MarkPS: I used "JMRI" as the activation name for the skill because I couldn't think of anything better. If there's an issue with that, I can change it, but as I said I don't really plan on actually letting this out into the wild.</pre></td>
        </tr>
