           <small>From: Balazs Racz &lt;balazs.racz@gm...&gt; - 2018-02-28 13:25:53</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CACVivUzNpWoQXUDz3AcgVY%2BpLB9MOswuU6NEXEM0HgGt0WhNdw%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>i think those columns will duplicate and that's the problem. Specificallythe difficulty is who creates the renderer for the column.- if the columns come from the different connections that are from the samesystem, then presumably they will have the same renderer. But they mightstill have a different renderer instance. If we use different columns, wecan use the specific renderer from the systemconnection, but will clash onthe column's internal name. Also this is a weird user experience.- if we want to share the column, what do we do about the renderer? Thecolumn name will be fine though. Also if there happens to be two differentsystems with the same column name, now we're in trouble because we'lldefinitely be using the wrong renderer.On Wed, Feb 28, 2018 at 1:37 PM, Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@...&gt; wrote:&gt; If you have multiple LCC connections are table columns duplicated that&gt; should not be?&gt;&gt; Randall Wood&gt;&gt; On Feb 28, 2018, at 07:27, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; Balazs,&gt;&gt; I did remove the 2nd LCC connection and the messages went away. So they&gt; come&gt; back with a 2nd connection. I don't have a 4.11.2 available right now to&gt; try&gt; regression.&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;</pre></td>

           <small>From: Gerald Wolfson &lt;wolfsonga@gm...&gt; - 2018-02-28 13:16:02</small>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I am definitely in favor of moving it somewhere and getting it back on theair. I have not been able to work on  XtrackcadReader for over three weeksand it is really broken with the changes to XtrkCAD. It abhorts all the xmloutput but the header. So no translations can be done.=gerry=On Sun, Feb 18, 2018 at 4:28 PM, Elestedt, Fredrik &lt;fredrik@...&gt;wrote:&gt; Hi,&gt;&gt; I would prefer to move to google groups. And it might be possible to save&gt; the archive: <a href="https://gist.github.com/tdonohue/cd2a643c5fca5f140cfd" rel="nofollow">https://gist.github.com/tdonohue/cd2a643c5fca5f140cfd</a> and&gt; <a href="https://github.com/wojdyr/fityk/wiki/MigrationToGoogleGroups" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/wojdyr/fityk/wiki/MigrationToGoogleGroups</a>&gt; Those should hopefully transfer everything.&gt;&gt; Why not move the website onto GitHub Pages? It's simple and free.&gt; Alternatively a GitLab pages account could be set up as well - they have&gt; support for SSL on custom domains as well.&gt; <a href="https://help.github.com/articles/using-a-custom-domain-with-github-pages/" rel="nofollow">https://help.github.com/articles/using-a-custom-domain-with-github-pages/</a>&gt;&gt; // Fredrik&gt;&gt;&gt; On Sat, Feb 17, 2018 at 8:55 PM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; SourceForge.net will eventually come back up and make our web site&gt;&gt; available, though there’s no way to estimate when.  They’re historical&gt;&gt; record is that they have a day-scale problem about once a year.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Is it time to move away from relying on them?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The two remaining services they host are:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; *) This mailing list, along with a couple others:&gt;&gt; <a href="https://sourceforge.net/p/jmri/mailman/" rel="nofollow">https://sourceforge.net/p/jmri/mailman/</a>   We could probably find another&gt;&gt; place to host those lists, perhaps Google groups or some other site.  There&gt;&gt; are some costs to moving: there’s a little bit of automation that would&gt;&gt; have to change, people might have to adjust their mail filters, and I doubt&gt;&gt; we could transfer the archive.  On the other hand, this is one of the core&gt;&gt; ways JMRI is coordinated, it it’s a pain to have to work around an outage.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; *) The web site (which has received the most attention this week)  By&gt;&gt; itself, it’s a pretty standard site. Steve Rawlinson has kindly provided a&gt;&gt; temporary server that’s hosting it now.  But a more permanent move would&gt;&gt; require quite a bit of adjustment:  Setting up Jenkins to automatically&gt;&gt; update a different server, adding redirects on SF.net (so that Google&gt;&gt; doesn’t keep directing traffic to the old aliases), updating links (they&gt;&gt; should say jmri org, not jmri.sf.org, but not all do), changing text in&gt;&gt; various places, other things I haven’t thought of, etc.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; We could run two independent sites, in case one went down, on the&gt;&gt; jmri.org and jmri.net domains.  That might be more tricky than it’s&gt;&gt; worth, however.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thoughts?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; ------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>A column “identity” is the value set/retrieved using <a href="https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/javax/swing/table/TableColumn.html#getIdentifier" rel="nofollow">https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/javax/swing/table/TableColumn.html#getIdentifier</a>-- and <a href="https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/javax/swing/table/TableColumn.html#setIdentifier-java.lang.Object" rel="nofollow">https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/javax/swing/table/TableColumn.html#setIdentifier-java.lang.Object</a>- &lt;<a href="https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/javax/swing/table/TableColumn.html#setIdentifier-java.lang.Object->" rel="nofollow">https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/javax/swing/table/TableColumn.html#setIdentifier-java.lang.Object-&gt;</a>;Randall Wood&gt; On Feb 18, 2018, at 14:58, Balazs Racz &lt;balazs.racz@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Ken,&gt; &gt; These columns are the ones I added in 4.11.2; can you check if you get the same errors when you open the same profile in 4.11.2? There might be something in the profile as well to trigger this problem, it seems you have more than one OpenLCB connection, which could be a culprit for example.&gt; &gt; Afaik saving table state means the order of columns and how wide they are, but I have no idea what a column "identity" is. I might have done something wrong in the system-specific column implementation.&gt; &gt; cheers,&gt; Balazs&gt; &gt; On Sun, Feb 18, 2018 at 2:38 PM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@... &lt;mailto:kcameron@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt; When opening the tables, these messages show in the console. I don't know&gt; the importance of these but I'm guessing something isn't matching something.&gt; I think for now we know that they should be ignored.&gt; &gt; 2018-02-18 08:34:46,847 swing.JmriJTablePersistenceManager    ERROR -&gt; Columns in table jmri.jmrit.beantable.TurnoutTableAction:All share the&gt; identity "Authoritative"; saving table state will not be reliable.          <td class="email-body"><pre>They should not be ignored—they are errors in OpenLCB-specific GUI code that need to be dealt with. These errors prevent users of OpenLCB from having any changes they make to tables be reliably saved.These messages are deliberately marked as errors because not addressing them produces profile settings that are corrupted.Randall Wood&gt; On Feb 18, 2018, at 08:38, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; When opening the tables, these messages show in the console. I don't know&gt; the importance of these but I'm guessing something isn't matching something.&gt; I think for now we know that they should be ignored.&gt; &gt; 2018-02-18 08:34:46,847 swing.JmriJTablePersistenceManager    ERROR -&gt; Columns in table jmri.jmrit.beantable.TurnoutTableAction:All share the&gt; identity "Authoritative"; saving table state will not be reliable.          <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi,I would prefer to move to google groups. And it might be possible to savethe archive: <a href="https://gist.github.com/tdonohue/cd2a643c5fca5f140cfd" rel="nofollow">https://gist.github.com/tdonohue/cd2a643c5fca5f140cfd</a> and<a href="https://github.com/wojdyr/fityk/wiki/MigrationToGoogleGroups" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/wojdyr/fityk/wiki/MigrationToGoogleGroups</a>Those should hopefully transfer everything.Why not move the website onto GitHub Pages? It's simple and free.Alternatively a GitLab pages account could be set up as well - they havesupport for SSL on custom domains as well.<a href="https://help.github.com/articles/using-a-custom-domain-with-github-pages/" rel="nofollow">https://help.github.com/articles/using-a-custom-domain-with-github-pages/</a>// FredrikOn Sat, Feb 17, 2018 at 8:55 PM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; SourceForge.net will eventually come back up and make our web site&gt; available, though there’s no way to estimate when.  They’re historical&gt; record is that they have a day-scale problem about once a year.&gt;&gt; Is it time to move away from relying on them?&gt;&gt; The two remaining services they host are:&gt;&gt; *) This mailing list, along with a couple others:&gt; <a href="https://sourceforge.net/p/jmri/mailman/" rel="nofollow">https://sourceforge.net/p/jmri/mailman/</a>   We could probably find another&gt; place to host those lists, perhaps Google groups or some other site.  There&gt; are some costs to moving: there’s a little bit of automation that would&gt; have to change, people might have to adjust their mail filters, and I doubt&gt; we could transfer the archive.  On the other hand, this is one of the core&gt; ways JMRI is coordinated, it it’s a pain to have to work around an outage.&gt;&gt; *) The web site (which has received the most attention this week)  By&gt; itself, it’s a pretty standard site. Steve Rawlinson has kindly provided a&gt; temporary server that’s hosting it now.  But a more permanent move would&gt; require quite a bit of adjustment:  Setting up Jenkins to automatically&gt; update a different server, adding redirects on SF.net (so that Google&gt; doesn’t keep directing traffic to the old aliases), updating links (they&gt; should say jmri org, not jmri.sf.org, but not all do), changing text in&gt; various places, other things I haven’t thought of, etc.&gt;&gt; We could run two independent sites, in case one went down, on the jmri.org&gt; and jmri.net domains.  That might be more tricky than it’s worth, however.&gt;&gt; Thoughts?&gt;&gt; Bob&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

To: john.plocher@... &lt;mailto:john.plocher@...&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Hello, admin of SourceForge project jmri:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Due to upcoming network changes at SourceForge, the IP address for &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; hosting&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; jmri.org &lt;<a href="http://jmri.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/&gt;</a>; will soon change.  Because DNS for your &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; site is managed outside of our&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; network, you will need to log into your domain name's respective &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; DNS control&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; panel and update its IP address to point to our new network.  We &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; recommend&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; performing this update as soon as possible to prevent downtime for &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; your site.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The former IP addresses will be retired no later than February 14, &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 2018.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Please see the settings below and update the records for your domain&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; accordingly.  If you have any questions, don't hesitate to contact &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; us at&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; sfnet_ops@... &lt;mailto:sfnet_ops@...&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Updated DNS Settings for jmri.org &lt;<a href="http://jmri.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/&gt;</a>;:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   A-Record    216.105.38.10&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; If any of these are subdomains (like 'www.') then we recommend &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; using a CNAME&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; instead of A record.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   CNAME vhost.sourceforge.net &lt;<a href="http://vhost.sourceforge.net/>" rel="nofollow">http://vhost.sourceforge.net/&gt;</a>;.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; If your DNS provider has a feature that lets you create an "A" &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; record from a&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; domain name (sometimes called an "ANAME" virtual record) you can use&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; vhost.sourceforge.net &lt;<a href="http://vhost.sourceforge.net/>" rel="nofollow">http://vhost.sourceforge.net/&gt;</a>; for the root &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; of a domain.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Our documentation for hosting custom domains is at&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="https://sourceforge.net/p/forge/documentation/Custom%20VHOSTs/" rel="nofollow">https://sourceforge.net/p/forge/documentation/Custom%20VHOSTs/</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thank you for your understanding and continued support,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; SourceForge DevOps &amp; Support&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; sfnet_ops@... &lt;mailto:sfnet_ops@...&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org &lt;<a href="http://Slashdot.org>" rel="nofollow">http://Slashdot.org&gt;</a>;!            <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36239986/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Time to move off SourceForge?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@al...&gt; - 2018-02-27 22:30:40</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/601B2110-6D33-4923-A440-9460EC2F43FF%40alexandriasoftware.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I am all for abandoning SourceForge.For the services we use SourceForge for:- Release Distribution: I think we can simply stop posting new releases to SourceForge and begin directing everyone to use the GitHub releases.- Web Site: I would like to move the web site from SF.net &lt;<a href="http://sf.net/>" rel="nofollow">http://sf.net/&gt;</a>;, but also would like to make its content static (this has an advantage for JMRI users—everything that relies on PHP (except the bug reporting tool) is shipped with JMRI, but neither the JMRI help viewer or web server can render PHP or SSI) so it can be hosted anywhere, not just anywhere that supports Apache HTTPD with a PHP module. I’ll follow up with a separate more concrete proposal on how we could do that.- Mailing Lists: There some scripts on github for migrating from mailman to Google Groups. I am all for using one of these to retain the mailing list archives from SourceForge within Google Groups, but am not adverse to using other services (but do not want to use Yahoo either).Randall Wood&gt; On Feb 17, 2018, at 14:55, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; SourceForge.net will eventually come back up and make our web site available, though there’s no way to estimate when.  They’re historical record is that they have a day-scale problem about once a year.&gt; &gt; Is it time to move away from relying on them?&gt; &gt; The two remaining services they host are:&gt; &gt; *) This mailing list, along with a couple others:  <a href="https://sourceforge.net/p/jmri/mailman/" rel="nofollow">https://sourceforge.net/p/jmri/mailman/</a>   We could probably find another place to host those lists, perhaps Google groups or some other site.  There are some costs to moving: there’s a little bit of automation that would have to change, people might have to adjust their mail filters, and I doubt we could transfer the archive.  On the other hand, this is one of the core ways JMRI is coordinated, it it’s a pain to have to work around an outage.&gt; &gt; *) The web site (which has received the most attention this week)  By itself, it’s a pretty standard site. Steve Rawlinson has kindly provided a temporary server that’s hosting it now.  But a more permanent move would require quite a bit of adjustment:  Setting up Jenkins to automatically update a different server, adding redirects on SF.net (so that Google doesn’t keep directing traffic to the old aliases), updating links (they should say jmri org, not jmri.sf.org, but not all do), changing text in various places, other things I haven’t thought of, etc.&gt; &gt; We could run two independent sites, in case one went down, on the jmri.org and jmri.net domains.  That might be more tricky than it’s worth, however. &gt; &gt; Thoughts?&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob,Had some off-list communications with Jan and it is confirmed as beinglocale related. The issue you mention does seem to be linked to this.I've got a couple of ideas for a resolution.Best regards,Matt HOn 27 Feb 2018 05:59, "Bob Jacobsen" &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:This might be related to Issue #1745<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/1745" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/1745</a>Bob&gt; On Feb 26, 2018, at 12:45 PM, Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; Hi all,&gt;&gt; Sorry for putting anyone on the wrong leg.&gt; I just checked and the Pipo had locale settings Dutch and the laptopEnglish.&gt; I changed the locale on the Pipo to English and also use JMRI 4.10 andnow the Logix works on the Pipo as well.&gt; The moment I change the locale again to Dutch the Logix stops working.&gt;&gt; When in locale Dutch and you edit the logix it will throw an errorrelated to the logical condition.&gt; It says (R1 and R2) and (R3 or R4) and the error it throws is related toit.&gt; I know the first part doesn't really need to be between brackets.&gt; Hope this helps in trying to find the root cause of the bug.&gt;&gt; Best regards,&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt; On 25/02/2018 21:41, Jan Boen wrote:&gt;&gt; Hi all,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I developed quite some Logix under JMRI 4.8 and this worked perfectly onmy laptop (Intel I7) as well as on my Pipo X9 (Z3736F, Windows 10, 2GB RAM).&gt;&gt; I upgraded both laptop and Pipo X9 to JMRI 4.10.&gt;&gt; On the laptop all works perfectly alas on the Pipo X9 the Logix doesn'twork properly any more.&gt;&gt; I will gladly share the XML file with you.&gt;&gt; What happens is that as part of a Logix at the end of the execution aninternal sensor (RESET) is set to the state active.&gt;&gt; This state triggers another logix which then resets a lot of internalsensors to inactive.&gt;&gt; On the Pipo X9 the RESET internal sensor is not set which then stops theproper execution.&gt;&gt; At the same time on the Pipo X9 I have the impression that certain otherelements in the Logix aren't properly working any more. Can't tell for sureyet.&gt;&gt; I tried downgrading to 4.8 on the Pipo X9 but alas the XML won't loadany more as new attributes (i.e. font) have been added in the XML wherebythe XML no longer loads in 4.8.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Any short term fix would be highly welcome as my layout is due toparticipate at an event shortly and I have to train some operators in thenext couple of weeks.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks,&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>This might be related to Issue #1745<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/1745" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/issues/1745</a>Bob&gt; On Feb 26, 2018, at 12:45 PM, Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Hi all,&gt; &gt; Sorry for putting anyone on the wrong leg.&gt; I just checked and the Pipo had locale settings Dutch and the laptop English.&gt; I changed the locale on the Pipo to English and also use JMRI 4.10 and now the Logix works on the Pipo as well.&gt; The moment I change the locale again to Dutch the Logix stops working.&gt; &gt; When in locale Dutch and you edit the logix it will throw an error related to the logical condition.&gt; It says (R1 and R2) and (R3 or R4) and the error it throws is related to it.&gt; I know the first part doesn't really need to be between brackets.&gt; Hope this helps in trying to find the root cause of the bug.&gt; &gt; Best regards,&gt; &gt; &gt; Jan&gt; &gt; On 25/02/2018 21:41, Jan Boen wrote:&gt;&gt; Hi all,&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I developed quite some Logix under JMRI 4.8 and this worked perfectly on my laptop (Intel I7) as well as on my Pipo X9 (Z3736F, Windows 10, 2GB RAM).&gt;&gt; I upgraded both laptop and Pipo X9 to JMRI 4.10.&gt;&gt; On the laptop all works perfectly alas on the Pipo X9 the Logix doesn't work properly any more.&gt;&gt; I will gladly share the XML file with you.&gt;&gt; What happens is that as part of a Logix at the end of the execution an internal sensor (RESET) is set to the state active.&gt;&gt; This state triggers another logix which then resets a lot of internal sensors to inactive.&gt;&gt; On the Pipo X9 the RESET internal sensor is not set which then stops the proper execution.&gt;&gt; At the same time on the Pipo X9 I have the impression that certain other elements in the Logix aren't properly working any more. Can't tell for sure yet.&gt;&gt; I tried downgrading to 4.8 on the Pipo X9 but alas the XML won't load any more as new attributes (i.e. font) have been added in the XML whereby the XML no longer loads in 4.8.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Any short term fix would be highly welcome as my layout is due to participate at an event shortly and I have to train some operators in the next couple of weeks.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Thanks,&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Jan&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Jan,To change the font, select *Font &gt;&gt; Font* from the context menu.I don’t see a problem with the bold option.  Maybe the default font doesnot have bold.Dave Sand----- Original message -----From: Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt;To: JMRI Developers &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: [Jmri-developers] Defining font of a text labelDate: Mon, 26 Feb 2018 22:13:02 +0100Hi,JMRI 4.10 - production version.When adding text labels to a panel you get options for changingattributes such as size and style.Though you can change to e.g. bold and it shown in the preview theattribute is not saved.So in the actual panel the font doesn't change.Also in the XML it shows that Tahoma is being used as font but there isno way in the panel editor to change the font to be used and thatis a pity.In the older version of JMRI it seems to have used Tahoma Bold / 12 ptand this is now Tahoma / 12 pt.When you check the properties it shows a regular font while on thescreen it shows a bold version.Best regards,Jan</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi,JMRI 4.10 - production version.When adding text labels to a panel you get options for changing attributes such as size and style.Though you can change to e.g. bold and it shown in the preview the attribute is not saved.So in the actual panel the font doesn't change.Also in the XML it shows that Tahoma is being used as font but there is no way in the panel editor to change the font to be used and that is a pity.In the older version of JMRI it seems to have used Tahoma Bold / 12 pt and this is now Tahoma / 12 pt.When you check the properties it shows a regular font while on the screen it shows a bold version.Best regards,Jan</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi all,I developed quite some Logix under JMRI 4.8 and this worked perfectly on my laptop (Intel I7) as well as on my Pipo X9 (Z3736F, Windows 10, 2GB RAM).I upgraded both laptop and Pipo X9 to JMRI 4.10.On the laptop all works perfectly alas on the Pipo X9 the Logix doesn't work properly any more.I will gladly share the XML file with you.What happens is that as part of a Logix at the end of the execution an internal sensor (RESET) is set to the state active.This state triggers another logix which then resets a lot of internal sensors to inactive.On the Pipo X9 the RESET internal sensor is not set which then stops the proper execution.At the same time on the Pipo X9 I have the impression that certain other elements in the Logix aren't properly working any more. Can't tell for sure yet.I tried downgrading to 4.8 on the Pipo X9 but alas the XML won't load any more as new attributes (i.e. font) have been added in the XML whereby the XML no longer loads in 4.8.Any short term fix would be highly welcome as my layout is due to participate at an event shortly and I have to train some operators in the next couple of weeks.Thanks,Jan</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>When I have a LCC type layout I've got two issues:1. If I have no other layout connection, the 'Defaults' are all Internal.           <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36237409/">[Jmri-developers] Order of items in panel file</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: George Warner &lt;geowar1@ma...&gt; - 2018-02-24 23:04:12</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/1B7AB508-AE8B-4723-91FF-0FE594403EB2%40mac.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>On Fri, 23 Feb 2018 21:08:49 -0500,Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@... &lt;mailto:randall.h.wood@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt; The only reason I recall that order could be important would be to ensure objects are available in the correct order to fulfill dependencies (ie make sure a sensor is created before a turnout needs it). If we have mechanisms for handling those scenarios without relTwo quick notes:1) Only panel specific objects maintain creation order; shared objects (like turnouts and blocks) are always stored in lexical order. (To determine this I manually edited several panel files and re-ordered elements in arrays. I then loaded and re-saved the panel files. In all cases the shared objects reverted to lexical order and the non-shared objects maintained creation order).Based on this conclusion my suggestion would be for shared objects to be shared in alphanumeric order (to make manual editing easier when necessary).2) Blocks are saved twice: once with minimal information and then again with full information. This is so that all blocks will be created (by the first (minimal) block object) before the full block objects are loaded that contain path information that may depend on other blocks (that may not have been created otherwise).I fixed this quite a while back by having the block (xml) loading code load in two passes: on the 1st pass it just creates the block objects (with minimal information) and on the 2nd pass updates those block objects (by loading all information).I didn't change the saving code at that time; it's still saving all blocks twice as before. I did test to see if not saving the minimal block elements would break the load and it did not.Given the other xml schema changes (that break current panel files from loading on older JMRI's) it should be safe to modify the block saving code to eliminate the 1st pass (that saves the minimal blocks).-- Enjoy,George WarnereMail, Message, or FaceTime: &lt;geowar1@...&gt;</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36237068">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36237068/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Order of items in panel file</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@ch...&gt; - 2018-02-24 14:59:05</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I was speaking as a user at the 5,000 ft level.The order of data displayed in various tables is relevent to the user's perspective.  How the under-the-hood magic is done is not a concern of the user. The built in table column sort function has been sufficient for most data display requirements, so far.   Table load speed performance and access is what I think you are trying to address.To your original question: I prefer a nice sort.Thanks,Chuck CataniaOn Feb 23, 2018, at 6:05 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; I don’t understand the point you’re making, sorry.&gt; &gt; The tables have column sorters on them that are independent of the storage order, as do things like the selectors in the Layout Editor, etc.  (That’s where all the time is going:  Doing access-by-access sorts of those)  Is that the concern in the 1st line?&gt; &gt; As to the second line:  The current system _doesn’t_ sort, and preserves the existing order.  That’s what I’m asking about:  Does that order need to be preserved?&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt;&gt; On Feb 23, 2018, at 5:57 PM, Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I view sorting as a tool function against a data set.  Whether the file order is the default display order or not, the ability to sort the loaded table data in a user familiar/user readable form is what should be considered.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; The stored data order in the database will get propagated into tables per the indexing technique employed.  If doing an initial sort after the internal tables are loaded, helps the access and process speed later, that should be considered.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Chuck Catania&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; On Feb 23, 2018, at 5:23 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Historically, the order of the items in a panel file are:&gt;&gt;&gt; *) listed in the order created&gt;&gt;&gt; *) which means that a load/store keeps the order the same.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; I.e. the &lt;sensor&gt; items that define specific Sensors keep their order within their particular &lt;sensors&gt; element (which represents their SensorManager).&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; How important is it to keep this?&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; I’m updating the various Manager implementations to keep a sorted list of element (e.g. the internal list of Sensors is kept in sorted order) to save a _bunch_ of time during execution:  Various display pieces of code takes copies of that content and sorts it each time.  Keeping it sorted from the start will save a bunch of time when e.g. opening table with a number of lists in comboboxes.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; It’s certainly possible to keep separate in-creation-order and in-sort-order lists and give separate accessors to those.  But it’s a bit more space (not that much, really), and Just Feels Ugly.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Hence the question:  Is the preserved order in the files important?  Or would having a nice sort actually be better?&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!       <table id="msg36236843">

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36236843/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Order of items in panel file</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-02-24 03:46:21</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>It was quite a while at first before I noticed the order stayed (like 2 or 3years). I had presumed it would generate the save in whatever order it usedand wasn't related to the load. But since nothing I did mattered as to orderof elements, I never gave it another thought.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; On Feb 23, 2018, at 6:21 PM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Bob,&gt; &gt; You are only meaning a possible change to the order of elements within a&gt; class of elements, correct?Right. &gt; We still keep the case of some classes are in&gt; 'twice' to deal with crosslinking between elements (blocks for example). For&gt; others, that's the list the elements first to create the objects, but with&gt; no details. The second listing fills in all the data, making the&gt; crosslinking as needed, but no issue with some object being missing. Only a&gt; few data types need this.Right. AFAIK, we don’t actually need to write the groups twice anymore. Now that Logic Conditionals are properly local, we could just write groups once and process that one group twice. But I haven’t coded &amp; tested that to be really sure. &gt; Even though we like to think most users don't ever see the insides of their&gt; xml files, we know a number of us end up in there on a regular basis. An&gt; order, consistent, is what matters so we have an easy time finding things&gt; when debugging issues. So if it helps things down the line to make the hash&gt; upfront, I can see the value there.Do you think anybody is going to care that e.g. the prefer of their Sensor items will now be in sorted order? “I moved that one to the front, why did it get moved?”Also, it’s system name order. I can imagine somebody did a manual sort into e.g. user name order. Bob&gt; How having to sort the data every time&gt; some display of the items is being built, that I can see is not good. When&gt; we started making some of the tables us lists within a cell, I can see that&gt; effort growing the load very fast as things grow.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob,You are only meaning a possible change to the order of elements within aclass of elements, correct? We still keep the case of some classes are in'twice' to deal with crosslinking between elements (blocks for example). Forothers, that's the list the elements first to create the objects, but withno details. The second listing fills in all the data, making thecrosslinking as needed, but no issue with some object being missing. Only afew data types need this.Even though we like to think most users don't ever see the insides of theirxml files, we know a number of us end up in there on a regular basis. Anorder, consistent, is what matters so we have an easy time finding thingswhen debugging issues. So if it helps things down the line to make the hashupfront, I can see the value there. How having to sort the data every timesome display of the items is being built, that I can see is not good. Whenwe started making some of the tables us lists within a cell, I can see thateffort growing the load very fast as things grow.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>The only reason I recall that order could be important would be to ensure objects are available in the correct order to fulfill dependencies (ie make sure a sensor is created before a turnout needs it). If we have mechanisms for handling those scenarios without relying on load order, then there is no reason I can think of to be concerned about it in the file.Randall WoodAlexandria Softwarerandall.h.wood@...<a href="http://alexandriasoftware.com" rel="nofollow">http://alexandriasoftware.com</a>&gt; On Feb 23, 2018, at 20:57, Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I view sorting as a tool function against a data set.  Whether the file order is the default display order or not, the ability to sort the loaded table data in a user familiar/user readable form is what should be considered.&gt; &gt; The stored data order in the database will get propagated into tables per the indexing technique employed.  If doing an initial sort after the internal tables are loaded, helps the access and process speed later, that should be considered.&gt; &gt; Chuck Catania&gt; &gt; &gt;&gt; On Feb 23, 2018, at 5:23 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Historically, the order of the items in a panel file are:&gt;&gt; *) listed in the order created&gt;&gt; *) which means that a load/store keeps the order the same.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I.e. the &lt;sensor&gt; items that define specific Sensors keep their order within their particular &lt;sensors&gt; element (which represents their SensorManager).&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; How important is it to keep this?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I’m updating the various Manager implementations to keep a sorted list of element (e.g. the internal list of Sensors is kept in sorted order) to save a _bunch_ of time during execution:  Various display pieces of code takes copies of that content and sorts it each time.  Keeping it sorted from the start will save a bunch of time when e.g. opening table with a number of lists in comboboxes.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; It’s certainly possible to keep separate in-creation-order and in-sort-order lists and give separate accessors to those.  But it’s a bit more space (not that much, really), and Just Feels Ugly.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Hence the question:  Is the preserved order in the files important?  Or would having a nice sort actually be better?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I don’t understand the point you’re making, sorry.The tables have column sorters on them that are independent of the storage order, as do things like the selectors in the Layout Editor, etc.  (That’s where all the time is going:  Doing access-by-access sorts of those)  Is that the concern in the 1st line?As to the second line:  The current system _doesn’t_ sort, and preserves the existing order.  That’s what I’m asking about:  Does that order need to be preserved?Bob&gt; On Feb 23, 2018, at 5:57 PM, Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I view sorting as a tool function against a data set.  Whether the file order is the default display order or not, the ability to sort the loaded table data in a user familiar/user readable form is what should be considered.&gt; &gt; The stored data order in the database will get propagated into tables per the indexing technique employed.  If doing an initial sort after the internal tables are loaded, helps the access and process speed later, that should be considered.&gt; &gt; Chuck Catania&gt; &gt; &gt; On Feb 23, 2018, at 5:23 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; Historically, the order of the items in a panel file are:&gt;&gt; *) listed in the order created&gt;&gt; *) which means that a load/store keeps the order the same.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I.e. the &lt;sensor&gt; items that define specific Sensors keep their order within their particular &lt;sensors&gt; element (which represents their SensorManager).&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; How important is it to keep this?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I’m updating the various Manager implementations to keep a sorted list of element (e.g. the internal list of Sensors is kept in sorted order) to save a _bunch_ of time during execution:  Various display pieces of code takes copies of that content and sorts it each time.  Keeping it sorted from the start will save a bunch of time when e.g. opening table with a number of lists in comboboxes.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; It’s certainly possible to keep separate in-creation-order and in-sort-order lists and give separate accessors to those.  But it’s a bit more space (not that much, really), and Just Feels Ugly.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Hence the question:  Is the preserved order in the files important?  Or would having a nice sort actually be better?&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36236794/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Order of items in panel file</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Chuck Catania &lt;cpcrr@ch...&gt; - 2018-02-24 01:57:10</small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I view sorting as a tool function against a data set.  Whether the file order is the default display order or not, the ability to sort the loaded table data in a user familiar/user readable form is what should be considered.  The stored data order in the database will get propagated into tables per the indexing technique employed.  If doing an initial sort after the internal tables are loaded, helps the access and process speed later, that should be considered.Chuck CataniaOn Feb 23, 2018, at 5:23 PM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; Historically, the order of the items in a panel file are:&gt; *) listed in the order created&gt; *) which means that a load/store keeps the order the same.&gt; &gt; I.e. the &lt;sensor&gt; items that define specific Sensors keep their order within their particular &lt;sensors&gt; element (which represents their SensorManager).&gt; &gt; How important is it to keep this?&gt; &gt; I’m updating the various Manager implementations to keep a sorted list of element (e.g. the internal list of Sensors is kept in sorted order) to save a _bunch_ of time during execution:  Various display pieces of code takes copies of that content and sorts it each time.  Keeping it sorted from the start will save a bunch of time when e.g. opening table with a number of lists in comboboxes.&gt; &gt; It’s certainly possible to keep separate in-creation-order and in-sort-order lists and give separate accessors to those.  But it’s a bit more space (not that much, really), and Just Feels Ugly.&gt; &gt; Hence the question:  Is the preserved order in the files important?  Or would having a nice sort actually be better?&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36236775/">[Jmri-developers] Order of items in panel file</a></b>

           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-02-24 01:24:09</small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Historically, the order of the items in a panel file are:*) listed in the order created*) which means that a load/store keeps the order the same.I.e. the &lt;sensor&gt; items that define specific Sensors keep their order within their particular &lt;sensors&gt; element (which represents their SensorManager).How important is it to keep this?I’m updating the various Manager implementations to keep a sorted list of element (e.g. the internal list of Sensors is kept in sorted order) to save a _bunch_ of time during execution:  Various display pieces of code takes copies of that content and sorts it each time.  Keeping it sorted from the start will save a bunch of time when e.g. opening table with a number of lists in comboboxes.It’s certainly possible to keep separate in-creation-order and in-sort-order lists and give separate accessors to those.  But it’s a bit more space (not that much, really), and Just Feels Ugly.Hence the question:  Is the preserved order in the files important?  Or would having a nice sort actually be better?Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>

          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36236350/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-02-23 17:34:43</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Dick,So my take on the identify report will be correct for direct input/outputpins. But the alt pins will not report the current state of the toggle.Using the pushbutton example, it would report invalid, when the button isthen pushed after that report, it would produce the events for the nextstate. So sometimes an external user would have figured the toggle to be'off' but the next event sent would be another off event. So anything tryingto trigger from the toggle going from on to off, it would miss thistransition if it using its internal on to off transition (I'm thinking likeJMRI Logix). Instead if the trigger was figuring on 'I got the off event, itmust have been on, then it would consider correctly. But any internal logicthat was relying on a state machine following the toggle, it would be wronguntil the next time the pin was pressed.The conclusion would be that a toggle input is not worth using the identifyinformation. A toggle would be been better off with an unknown answerinstead of valid or invalid in this case. So any state machine trying toreplicate the state of the toggle should be written to ignore the identifyinformation and remain unknown until the first event comes in.Or did I miss something in how this would work? I'm not seeing it as a bigissue, but one that designers would need to keep in mind.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

You can also download it directly or view it online with the links on <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/releases/tag/v4.10" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/releases/tag/v4.10</a>Bob&gt; On Feb 23, 2018, at 7:43 AM, Lynn Grandle &lt;LGrandle@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt;  &gt; Hi:&gt; &gt; I know I am slow and have asked this question before, but where can I find the source to the 4.10 release.            <div>

         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36236146/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@rr...&gt; - 2018-02-23 13:32:45</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Ken,Just got this e-mail. We have decided to always check the actual input line. In the case of an alternate action button, this means that if it is not active, then the report will be 'invalid' even when the node remembers what it was last. However if the input line itself is active, then it will report as 'valid'. This allows alt action lines to be mixed with momentary lines. Of course there needs to be some local visual feedback in that case.Dick :)On 02/18/2018 08:21 PM, Ken Cameron wrote:&gt; I think one the issue with this is if the P/C is a simple input/output or if&gt; it is a state machine. A single input line, closed or open as the values, it&gt; would see the current state of the line and report valid/invalid&gt; accordingly. The state is based on the current voltage on the pin. For an&gt; output, same idea, is the circuit currently driving or not driving the&gt; output.&gt;&gt; But if something is doing more than that, example would be a single line&gt; pushbutton supporting an alt-type output (push once, ON, push again, OFF),&gt; then you have a state machine and it would have to consider the current&gt; state for the identify messages. You would never get a report based on the&gt; status of the input itself, you would always hear from the state machine.&gt; The state machine would have the valid/invalid or unknown if it has not&gt; initialized.&gt;&gt; Now if the state machine is not part of the input (or output) circuit, then&gt; it has its own events to consider for the outputs and I'm not so sure about&gt; it identifying its inputs. While it would know which input was the last&gt; event received, if any of the inputs were currently reporting unknown, would&gt; that alter what it should reply?&gt;&gt; So to me is seems we don't have a blanket here, we have to consider how each&gt; is configured. So back to an example of RR-CirKits Signal-LCC board. For an&gt; output, it knows if the output is on or off, so it can respond accurately&gt; for those events. An input pin, will have to know the mode it is operating&gt; and then knows if the raw pin state is meaningful or if the toggle state is&gt; meaningful. For a signal mast, it would use the matching state machine&gt; (since the outputs may be blinking) for responding. Now a logic cell, that's&gt; tricky, only if it thought all the inputs were considered not unknown could&gt; it then say one way of the other, any doubts would be unknown as the answer.&gt;&gt; The above seems to break in to two classes of objects. One class is what I'd&gt; call an atomic P/C, it can always tell if it is a true or false based on the&gt; matching input or output. The second class is the state machine, it is an&gt; N-event concoction and its memory of the last decision it made is what it&gt; can respond with.&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36233199/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-02-21 19:13:40</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I think one the issue with this is if the P/C is a simple input/output or ifit is a state machine. A single input line, closed or open as the values, itwould see the current state of the line and report valid/invalidaccordingly. The state is based on the current voltage on the pin. For anoutput, same idea, is the circuit currently driving or not driving theoutput. But if something is doing more than that, example would be a single linepushbutton supporting an alt-type output (push once, ON, push again, OFF),then you have a state machine and it would have to consider the currentstate for the identify messages. You would never get a report based on thestatus of the input itself, you would always hear from the state machine.The state machine would have the valid/invalid or unknown if it has notinitialized.Now if the state machine is not part of the input (or output) circuit, thenit has its own events to consider for the outputs and I'm not so sure aboutit identifying its inputs. While it would know which input was the lastevent received, if any of the inputs were currently reporting unknown, wouldthat alter what it should reply?So to me is seems we don't have a blanket here, we have to consider how eachis configured. So back to an example of RR-CirKits Signal-LCC board. For anoutput, it knows if the output is on or off, so it can respond accuratelyfor those events. An input pin, will have to know the mode it is operatingand then knows if the raw pin state is meaningful or if the toggle state ismeaningful. For a signal mast, it would use the matching state machine(since the outputs may be blinking) for responding. Now a logic cell, that'stricky, only if it thought all the inputs were considered not unknown couldit then say one way of the other, any doubts would be unknown as the answer.The above seems to break in to two classes of objects. One class is what I'dcall an atomic P/C, it can always tell if it is a true or false based on thematching input or output. The second class is the state machine, it is anN-event concoction and its memory of the last decision it made is what itcan respond with.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36231995/">Re: [Jmri-developers] How is JmriBeanComboBox supposed to work for the user?</a></b>

           <small>From: Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@gm...&gt; - 2018-02-20 11:21:16</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/B3977F5E-9D6A-4626-838C-9CF766EF63CD%40gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Ken,We will have to agree to disagree on this one.We seem to have  jumped from discussing :- Sort order in JmriBeanComboBox, where objects like Sensor Names have a regular pattern.Sorting a long list of this nature for typeahead preselection makes good sense.To:- Sort order for enumVal ComboBoxes in decoder definitions, where item names are usually locale-specific words/phrases with no regular pattern.Forcibly sorting a relatively short list of this nature for typeahead preselection has little benefit and may well destroy any functional grouping or other order considered important by the definition creator.The former I heartily concur with, the latter I consider inappropriate and strongly object to.Sent from my iPad-- Dave&gt; On 20 Feb 2018, at 12:33 PM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; If the values were translated (due to locale) then the sort should also be&gt; following the locale. That would seem good. At least it seems it would work.</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Dave,If the values were translated (due to locale) then the sort should also befollowing the locale. That would seem good. At least it seems it would work.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>The sort order chosen by ESU for its software and manuals is based roughly on descending likelihood of use. An alphabetic sort would also be very language-specific in this case (do you choose English, German...?), unlike turnout tables, etc.Sent from my iPad-- Dave in Australia&gt; On 17 Feb 2018, at 12:32 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I would have thought that for user convenience having them sorted would make&gt; finding the feature easier.</pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36230415/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@rr...&gt; - 2018-02-19 03:18:58</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Balazs,Thank you very much. This is the direct answer that I have been looking for. I already pretty much understand the theory of how it should work. What I needed to know is how it actually works, and 'The same' is the kind of answer that I have been seeking.Dick :)On 02/18/2018 03:43 PM, Balazs Racz wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; On Fri, Feb 16, 2018 at 2:49 PM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@... &gt; &lt;mailto:dick@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;     Bob,&gt;     I am still unclear on a point or two.&gt;&gt;     First our hardware does not know if it is connected to a button or&gt;     a switch. You indicate in '2)' below that the proper button&gt;     responses should be 'Valid' or 'Unknown' based on the current&gt;     'pressed' or 'unpressed' situation. Would that be OK for a toggle&gt;     switch as well?&gt;&gt;     My second related question is about 'Invalid'. Does anything in&gt;     JMRI actually respond to 'Invalid' by changing state, or does it&gt;     internally act the same&gt;&gt;&gt; Since 4.11.2 it acts the same.&gt;&gt;     as 'Unknown'?&gt;&gt;     It should be obvious from my questions that we are trying to&gt;     figure out the correct response for our hardware without making&gt;     the user tell the hardware if he has buttons or toggle switches&gt;     connected. (could be IR detectors or current detectors) The only&gt;     distinguishing difference is that a toggle switch normally has at&gt;     least two PCER messages associated with it, and a button usually&gt;     only has one PCER. (unless something needs to actually echo the&gt;     button position itself)&gt;&gt;     Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt;     On 02/16/2018 01:09 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt;         I don’t know the current answer for Turnouts and Sensors; the&gt;         relevant code has been modified since I last worked on it in&gt;         detail.&gt;&gt;         For the OlcbSignalHead, received (1) PCEventID messages, and&gt;         (2) ConsumerIdentified and ProducerIdentified messages with&gt;         “valid” will set the state machine to the related aspect.&nbsp;&gt;         (Note that even when JMRI produces an aspect eventID, it is&gt;         the _reception_ of that PCEventID message that causes the&gt;         state machine update) That will in turn trigger internal&gt;         updates in JMRI, which icons, table entry, etc should follow;&gt;         no OpenLCB messages should be directly emitted by that process&gt;         but others might follow from activated signal logic, etc.&nbsp; The&gt;         Producers and Consumers associated with that signal head will&gt;         follow the state of the signal head:&nbsp; Once it’s initialized&gt;         (internally or externally), the Producer and Consumer for the&gt;         current aspect will reply valid if queried and the rest will&gt;         reply invalid.&nbsp; Until it’s initialized, they all reply unknown.&gt;&gt;         Not sure what “If so, how?” is asking. Code, maybe? c.f.&gt;         <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312</a>&gt;         &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312&gt;</a>;&gt;&gt;         Note that those are the right answers for a signal head, which&gt;         is implementing a common distributed state machine.&nbsp; For such&gt;         a thing, "multiple () conflicting Identified messages” only&gt;         arise from a misconfigured system, typically multiple&gt;         _unsynchronized_ controllers.&nbsp; So that right answer to “Is the&gt;         order … relevant” the answer is “Yes: Make sure that its&gt;         externally controlled to do what you want it to do”.&gt;&gt;&gt;         Turnouts and Sensors should be doing a similar thing with&gt;         their state. Once the web site comes back up, check the&gt;         Javadoc for OlcbTurnout; there’s a figure there that (IIRC)&gt;         shows the intended behavior, but I don’t know the status of&gt;         the code.&gt;&gt;&gt;         Now, beyond JMRI OlcbSignalHead, to talk about the general&gt;         case:&nbsp; If you configure a _system_ in which each participating&gt;         part is _NOT_ aware of the entire state, then they should be&gt;         set up to know that they don’t know.&gt;&gt;         Consider two momentary buttons that control a lamp on/off.&gt;         There are multiple approaches to choose from:&gt;&gt;         1)&nbsp; The two button nodes could track the _entire_ state.&nbsp; Each&gt;         could listen to the other, and together agree who was pressed&gt;         last and what the overall state is.&nbsp; In that case, they could&gt;         certainly reply with valid and invalid to represent that&gt;         state. Test for the reader:&nbsp; What should they say when one is&gt;         pressed and the other not?&nbsp; Neither pressed? Both pressed?&gt;         Hint:&nbsp; It’s a _state_; it has to be remembered.&gt;&gt;         2) They could understand that they don’t have the entire&gt;         state.&nbsp; Then, they don’t know any _state_, just status.&nbsp; &nbsp;So&gt;         each “pressed” Producer is valid while pressed, unknown while&gt;         not pressed.&nbsp; (The “unpressed” Producer, if it exists, is&gt;         similar: valid if unpressed, unknown while pressed.)&nbsp; If&gt;         neither button is pressed, neither knows the state: Only the&gt;         lamp knows.&nbsp; Seems reasonable, no? If both buttons are&gt;         pressed, the state is inconsistent (“Don’t do that”), and&gt;         again only the lamp knows for sure whether it’s on or not.&gt;         Again, that’s reasonable.&gt;&gt;         3) They could be set up to represent _separate_ states for&gt;         button 1, button 2 and the lamp if you really wanted to know&gt;         in detail What’s Happening Right Now; this can also be useful&gt;         if one button commands lots of different things to happen&gt;         semi-independently.&nbsp; (Technically, this is called “multiple&gt;         weakly-coupled state machines”) Then each button returns&gt;         valid/invalid based on the local condition, as does the lamp:&nbsp;&gt;         Check which node sent the ConsumerIdentified message to know&gt;         what the valid/invalid means.&gt;&gt;         Bottom line:&nbsp; There is _no_ _single_ _desirable_ behavior for&gt;         Producer/Consumer Identified valid/invalid/unknown.&nbsp; They are&gt;         a _capability_ to be used when setting up the distributed&gt;         control system.&nbsp; Different uses will use them differently. If&gt;         a common distributed state machine works, that’s great: you&gt;         can use them that way.&nbsp; If you’re not setting up one of those,&gt;         use them differently to do what you want done.&gt;&gt;         Bob&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;             On Feb 15, 2018, at 9:00 AM, Dick Bronson&gt;             &lt;dick@... &lt;mailto:dick@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;             Hi,&gt;             There is an ongoing off-line discussion on how OpenLCB&gt;             Producer Identified and Consumer Identified responses do&gt;             or should work. The main issue relates to what happens&gt;             when multiple locations have push button controls, and&gt;             what happens when there are multiple copies of JMRI running.&gt;&gt;             I think the key questions that need answers from the JMRI&gt;             developers are:&gt;&gt;             1) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message*&gt;             modify a Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;             2) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message*&gt;             modify a Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;             3) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message*&gt;             modify a Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;             4) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message*&gt;             modify a Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;             5) Is the order in which multiple but possibly conflicting&gt;             Identified messages are received *for the same event*&gt;             relevant for (1), (2), (3) and (4)?&gt;&gt;             The current Tower-LCC and Signal-LCC initialization&gt;             behavior for an input line is:&gt;             a) When true, the event associated with true will report&gt;             Producer Identified valid and the event associated with&gt;             false will report Producer Identified invalid.&gt;             b) When false, the event associated with true will report&gt;             Producer Identified invalid and the event associated with&gt;             false will report Producer Identified valid.&gt;&gt;             The issue is that a line connected to a push button will&gt;             normally respond as 'b)'. The question is; "how does JMRI&gt;             respond to this, if at all"?&gt;&gt;             Dick :)&gt;&gt;             ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;             Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's&gt;             most&gt;             engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;             _______________________________________________&gt;             Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;             Jmri-developers@...&gt;             &lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;             <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;             &lt;<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers>" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers&gt;</a>;&gt;&gt;         --&gt;         Bob Jacobsen&gt;         jacobsen@... &lt;mailto:jacobsen@...&gt; +1-510-708-5988&gt;         &lt;tel:%2B1-510-708-5988&gt; AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt;         ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;         Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;         engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;         _______________________________________________&gt;         Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;         Jmri-developers@...&gt;         &lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;         <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;         &lt;<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers>" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers&gt;</a>;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;     Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;     engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;     _______________________________________________&gt;     Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;     Jmri-developers@...&gt;     &lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;     <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;     &lt;<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers>" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers&gt;</a>;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!
