      </table> 
      <table id="msg36230180">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36230180/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Balazs Racz &lt;balazs.racz@gm...&gt; - 2018-02-18 20:43:59</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CACVivUxDEhM%3D6uVPUskff8-qKVVKxK7nziexx%3DOiQPiDcTEuHQ%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>On Fri, Feb 16, 2018 at 2:49 PM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Bob,&gt; I am still unclear on a point or two.&gt;&gt; First our hardware does not know if it is connected to a button or a&gt; switch. You indicate in '2)' below that the proper button responses should&gt; be 'Valid' or 'Unknown' based on the current 'pressed' or 'unpressed'&gt; situation. Would that be OK for a toggle switch as well?&gt;&gt; My second related question is about 'Invalid'. Does anything in JMRI&gt; actually respond to 'Invalid' by changing state, or does it internally act&gt; the sameSince 4.11.2 it acts the same.&gt; as 'Unknown'?&gt;&gt; It should be obvious from my questions that we are trying to figure out&gt; the correct response for our hardware without making the user tell the&gt; hardware if he has buttons or toggle switches connected. (could be IR&gt; detectors or current detectors) The only distinguishing difference is that&gt; a toggle switch normally has at least two PCER messages associated with it,&gt; and a button usually only has one PCER. (unless something needs to actually&gt; echo the button position itself)&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt; On 02/16/2018 01:09 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; I don’t know the current answer for Turnouts and Sensors; the relevant&gt;&gt; code has been modified since I last worked on it in detail.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; For the OlcbSignalHead, received (1) PCEventID messages, and (2)&gt;&gt; ConsumerIdentified and ProducerIdentified messages with “valid” will set&gt;&gt; the state machine to the related aspect.  (Note that even when JMRI&gt;&gt; produces an aspect eventID, it is the _reception_ of that PCEventID message&gt;&gt; that causes the state machine update) That will in turn trigger internal&gt;&gt; updates in JMRI, which icons, table entry, etc should follow; no OpenLCB&gt;&gt; messages should be directly emitted by that process but others might follow&gt;&gt; from activated signal logic, etc.  The Producers and Consumers associated&gt;&gt; with that signal head will follow the state of the signal head:  Once it’s&gt;&gt; initialized (internally or externally), the Producer and Consumer for the&gt;&gt; current aspect will reply valid if queried and the rest will reply&gt;&gt; invalid.  Until it’s initialized, they all reply unknown.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Not sure what “If so, how?” is asking. Code, maybe?  c.f.&gt;&gt; <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix</a>&gt;&gt; /openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Note that those are the right answers for a signal head, which is&gt;&gt; implementing a common distributed state machine.  For such a thing,&gt;&gt; "multiple () conflicting Identified messages” only arise from a&gt;&gt; misconfigured system, typically multiple _unsynchronized_ controllers.  So&gt;&gt; that right answer to “Is the order … relevant” the answer is “Yes:  Make&gt;&gt; sure that its externally controlled to do what you want it to do”.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Turnouts and Sensors should be doing a similar thing with their state.&gt;&gt; Once the web site comes back up, check the Javadoc for OlcbTurnout; there’s&gt;&gt; a figure there that (IIRC) shows the intended behavior, but I don’t know&gt;&gt; the status of the code.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Now, beyond JMRI OlcbSignalHead, to talk about the general case:  If you&gt;&gt; configure a _system_ in which each participating part is _NOT_ aware of the&gt;&gt; entire state, then they should be set up to know that they don’t know.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Consider two momentary buttons that control a lamp on/off. There are&gt;&gt; multiple approaches to choose from:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 1)  The two button nodes could track the _entire_ state.  Each could&gt;&gt; listen to the other, and together agree who was pressed last and what the&gt;&gt; overall state is.  In that case, they could certainly reply with valid and&gt;&gt; invalid to represent that state.  Test for the reader:  What should they&gt;&gt; say when one is pressed and the other not?  Neither pressed?  Both pressed?&gt;&gt; Hint:  It’s a _state_; it has to be remembered.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 2) They could understand that they don’t have the entire state.  Then,&gt;&gt; they don’t know any _state_, just status.   So each “pressed” Producer is&gt;&gt; valid while pressed, unknown while not pressed.  (The “unpressed” Producer,&gt;&gt; if it exists, is similar: valid if unpressed, unknown while pressed.)  If&gt;&gt; neither button is pressed, neither knows the state:  Only the lamp knows.&gt;&gt; Seems reasonable, no? If both buttons are pressed, the state is&gt;&gt; inconsistent (“Don’t do that”), and again only the lamp knows for sure&gt;&gt; whether it’s on or not. Again, that’s reasonable.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 3) They could be set up to represent _separate_ states for button 1,&gt;&gt; button 2 and the lamp if you really wanted to know in detail What’s&gt;&gt; Happening Right Now; this can also be useful if one button commands lots of&gt;&gt; different things to happen semi-independently.  (Technically, this is&gt;&gt; called “multiple weakly-coupled state machines”) Then each button returns&gt;&gt; valid/invalid based on the local condition, as does the lamp:  Check which&gt;&gt; node sent the ConsumerIdentified message to know what the valid/invalid&gt;&gt; means.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Bottom line:  There is _no_ _single_ _desirable_ behavior for&gt;&gt; Producer/Consumer Identified valid/invalid/unknown.  They are a&gt;&gt; _capability_ to be used when setting up the distributed control system.&gt;&gt; Different uses will use them differently.  If a common distributed state&gt;&gt; machine works, that’s great: you can use them that way.  If you’re not&gt;&gt; setting up one of those, use them differently to do what you want done.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Feb 15, 2018, at 9:00 AM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Hi,&gt;&gt;&gt; There is an ongoing off-line discussion on how OpenLCB Producer&gt;&gt;&gt; Identified and Consumer Identified responses do or should work. The main&gt;&gt;&gt; issue relates to what happens when multiple locations have push button&gt;&gt;&gt; controls, and what happens when there are multiple copies of JMRI running.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think the key questions that need answers from the JMRI developers are:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 1) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a&gt;&gt;&gt; Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 2) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a&gt;&gt;&gt; Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 3) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a&gt;&gt;&gt; Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 4) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a&gt;&gt;&gt; Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 5) Is the order in which multiple but possibly conflicting Identified&gt;&gt;&gt; messages are received *for the same event* relevant for (1), (2), (3) and&gt;&gt;&gt; (4)?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The current Tower-LCC and Signal-LCC initialization behavior for an&gt;&gt;&gt; input line is:&gt;&gt;&gt; a) When true, the event associated with true will report Producer&gt;&gt;&gt; Identified valid and the event associated with false will report Producer&gt;&gt;&gt; Identified invalid.&gt;&gt;&gt; b) When false, the event associated with true will report Producer&gt;&gt;&gt; Identified invalid and the event associated with false will report Producer&gt;&gt;&gt; Identified valid.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The issue is that a line connected to a push button will normally&gt;&gt;&gt; respond as 'b)'. The question is; "how does JMRI respond to this, if at&gt;&gt;&gt; all"?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; ------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi Jan,What browser are you using? That symptom often occurs when using a browserthat does not support the WebSocket protocol. <a href="http://websocket.org/echo.html" rel="nofollow">http://websocket.org/echo.html</a>I'd suggest trying your panel in another browser and see what results.Feel free to send me your panel and screen shots if you'd like.--SteveTOn Sun, Feb 18, 2018 at 4:33 AM, Jan Boen &lt;jan.boen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Hi,&gt;&gt; I created a simple control panel in JMRI.&gt; Used copy/paste for duplicating things.&gt; In JMRI/PanelPro my panel show completely.&gt; Via the web browser/JMRI web server part of the track items are not&gt; showing.&gt; I've built several panels before and this is the first time this happens.&gt; JMRI is latest v4.10 production version.&gt; I can provide the JMRI XML files and screen shots if that helps.&gt;&gt; Thanks,&gt;&gt;&gt; Jan&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>4.11.3 test version has substantially improved this issue.  I gather from the notes that its thanks to Randall for the improvements. On the Windows 7 machine that was previously taking 1 minute to get to the PanelPro screen, it is now around 5 or 6 seconds.  Which is back in the realm of "sensible" for this particular machine.    (Reasonably fast hardware with a SSD for the operating system and applications.)Once the PanelPro screen is present, I can use the menus, open tables, start commands, etc. as I would expect.    I've carried out any tests against a layout.  - Nigel-----Original Message-----From: Ken Cameron [mailto:kcameron@...] Sent: 09 February 2018 22:41To: 'Discussions between JMRI developers'Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startupIf other font in the preference, you get the default until the font list finishes loading, then it switches to the new font. And it is retroactive, the early part of the console switches to the new font too.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a> _______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36230043/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-02-18 18:00:45</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Answering in a slightly different order:*) Is there anything in JMRI that responds to invalid? (Late edit: Balazs just replied about Turnouts, but I haven’t had time to work that through)  There’s nothing in OlcbSignalMast that responds to a ProducerIdentified or ConsumerIdentified with “invalid”. Those messages don’t identify a state to which to transition.  Since the OlcbSignalMast is (trying to) track a state, it doesn’t have reason to react to “invalid”.But that’s not to say that there will never be something that reacts to that.  There certainly could be.*) hardware doesn’t know about button vs switch:  Well, maybe.  This is more Turnout control that SignalMasts, but consider the case of a turnout (the email below used a lamp, but it’s similar) connected to a switch on a single input vs connected to two buttons on two separate inputs, perhaps on separate nodes.  Those really are different.The place where invalid/valid/unknown starts to have multiple options is when there’s more than a 1-1 connection.  If you have one input line, with two Producers for “input on” and “input off”, and one output line, with two Consumers for “output on” and “output off”, _and_ _nothing_ _else_, then it’s simple:  The input controls the output 100%, each Producer is either valid or invalid, never unknown, and the startup is clear:  Consumers pay attention to the (one and only) Producer of their event.  Done.This simplicity comes from two things, both critical:  (a) outside logic ensures that exactly one of those Producers drives the output state at a time:  The switch can only be one way, and (except while changing), it’s always one way; (b) There’s exactly one Producer that matters for each output state.If you want to be able to relax those conditions, so you can e.g. have a bunch of buttons around that do various things (select a path through a ladder; set the turnouts to main vs siding vs industry track; have some buttons set up complete paths and others just control one turnout) then you _don’t_ have those (a) and (b) conditions.  That’s when invalid matters.Example:  Two momentary pushbuttons in two places that set a turnout diverging vs normal. Each button appears on an input line, but the (a) condition is not met.  How do you configure the control system to know these are not two separate slide switches that behave as above, completely controlling?  (If they were, which one would control if they conflict?)  You can set the “input line inactive” Producer to an EventID nobody cares about, so the “input active” Producer on one button fires a Consumer that sets normal and the “input active” on the other fires a Consumer that sets diverging; the “input inactive” Producers don’t fire a Consumer that does anything.  OK, but what should valid/invalid/unknown do on those four Producers?(I’m leaving that as a question, because I’ve been over this so many times that presenting the answer clearly isn’t working. Maybe it’s time to switch to teacher mode: It’s not about what I say, it’s about what the reader learns. Maybe having the reader think it through would have more impact)Bob&gt; On Feb 16, 2018, at 5:49 AM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Bob,&gt; I am still unclear on a point or two.&gt; &gt; First our hardware does not know if it is connected to a button or a switch. You indicate in '2)' below that the proper button responses should be 'Valid' or 'Unknown' based on the current 'pressed' or 'unpressed' situation. Would that be OK for a toggle switch as well?&gt; &gt; My second related question is about 'Invalid'. Does anything in JMRI actually respond to 'Invalid' by changing state, or does it internally act the same as 'Unknown'?&gt; &gt; It should be obvious from my questions that we are trying to figure out the correct response for our hardware without making the user tell the hardware if he has buttons or toggle switches connected. (could be IR detectors or current detectors) The only distinguishing difference is that a toggle switch normally has at least two PCER messages associated with it, and a button usually only has one PCER. (unless something needs to actually echo the button position itself)&gt; &gt; Dick :)&gt; &gt; On 02/16/2018 01:09 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt;&gt; I don’t know the current answer for Turnouts and Sensors; the relevant code has been modified since I last worked on it in detail.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; For the OlcbSignalHead, received (1) PCEventID messages, and (2) ConsumerIdentified and ProducerIdentified messages with “valid” will set the state machine to the related aspect.  (Note that even when JMRI produces an aspect eventID, it is the _reception_ of that PCEventID message that causes the state machine update) That will in turn trigger internal updates in JMRI, which icons, table entry, etc should follow; no OpenLCB messages should be directly emitted by that process but others might follow from activated signal logic, etc.  The Producers and Consumers associated with that signal head will follow the state of the signal head:  Once it’s initialized (internally or externally), the Producer and Consumer for the current aspect will reply valid if queried and the rest will reply invalid.  Until it’s initialized, they all reply unknown.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Not sure what “If so, how?” is asking. Code, maybe?  c.f. <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Note that those are the right answers for a signal head, which is implementing a common distributed state machine.  For such a thing, "multiple () conflicting Identified messages” only arise from a misconfigured system, typically multiple _unsynchronized_ controllers.  So that right answer to “Is the order … relevant” the answer is “Yes:  Make sure that its externally controlled to do what you want it to do”.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Turnouts and Sensors should be doing a similar thing with their state. Once the web site comes back up, check the Javadoc for OlcbTurnout; there’s a figure there that (IIRC) shows the intended behavior, but I don’t know the status of the code.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Now, beyond JMRI OlcbSignalHead, to talk about the general case:  If you configure a _system_ in which each participating part is _NOT_ aware of the entire state, then they should be set up to know that they don’t know.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Consider two momentary buttons that control a lamp on/off. There are multiple approaches to choose from:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; 1)  The two button nodes could track the _entire_ state.  Each could listen to the other, and together agree who was pressed last and what the overall state is.  In that case, they could certainly reply with valid and invalid to represent that state.  Test for the reader:  What should they say when one is pressed and the other not?  Neither pressed?  Both pressed? Hint:  It’s a _state_; it has to be remembered.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; 2) They could understand that they don’t have the entire state.  Then, they don’t know any _state_, just status.   So each “pressed” Producer is valid while pressed, unknown while not pressed.  (The “unpressed” Producer, if it exists, is similar: valid if unpressed, unknown while pressed.)  If neither button is pressed, neither knows the state:  Only the lamp knows.  Seems reasonable, no? If both buttons are pressed, the state is inconsistent (“Don’t do that”), and again only the lamp knows for sure whether it’s on or not. Again, that’s reasonable.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; 3) They could be set up to represent _separate_ states for button 1, button 2 and the lamp if you really wanted to know in detail What’s Happening Right Now; this can also be useful if one button commands lots of different things to happen semi-independently.  (Technically, this is called “multiple weakly-coupled state machines”) Then each button returns valid/invalid based on the local condition, as does the lamp:  Check which node sent the ConsumerIdentified message to know what the valid/invalid means.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bottom line:  There is _no_ _single_ _desirable_ behavior for Producer/Consumer Identified valid/invalid/unknown.  They are a _capability_ to be used when setting up the distributed control system.  Different uses will use them differently.  If a common distributed state machine works, that’s great: you can use them that way.  If you’re not setting up one of those, use them differently to do what you want done.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt;  &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; On Feb 15, 2018, at 9:00 AM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Hi,&gt;&gt;&gt; There is an ongoing off-line discussion on how OpenLCB Producer Identified and Consumer Identified responses do or should work. The main issue relates to what happens when multiple locations have push button controls, and what happens when there are multiple copies of JMRI running.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; I think the key questions that need answers from the JMRI developers are:&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; 1) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; 2) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; 3) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; 4) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; 5) Is the order in which multiple but possibly conflicting Identified messages are received *for the same event* relevant for (1), (2), (3) and (4)?&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; The current Tower-LCC and Signal-LCC initialization behavior for an input line is:&gt;&gt;&gt; a) When true, the event associated with true will report Producer Identified valid and the event associated with false will report Producer Identified invalid.&gt;&gt;&gt; b) When false, the event associated with true will report Producer Identified invalid and the event associated with false will report Producer Identified valid.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; The issue is that a line connected to a push button will normally respond as 'b)'. The question is; "how does JMRI respond to this, if at all"?&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt;&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36229547/">[Jmri-developers] Time to move off SourceForge?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-02-17 19:55:17</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>SourceForge.net will eventually come back up and make our web site available, though there’s no way to estimate when.  They’re historical record is that they have a day-scale problem about once a year.Is it time to move away from relying on them?The two remaining services they host are:*) This mailing list, along with a couple others:  <a href="https://sourceforge.net/p/jmri/mailman/" rel="nofollow">https://sourceforge.net/p/jmri/mailman/</a>   We could probably find another place to host those lists, perhaps Google groups or some other site.  There are some costs to moving: there’s a little bit of automation that would have to change, people might have to adjust their mail filters, and I doubt we could transfer the archive.  On the other hand, this is one of the core ways JMRI is coordinated, it it’s a pain to have to work around an outage.*) The web site (which has received the most attention this week)  By itself, it’s a pretty standard site. Steve Rawlinson has kindly provided a temporary server that’s hosting it now.  But a more permanent move would require quite a bit of adjustment:  Setting up Jenkins to automatically update a different server, adding redirects on SF.net (so that Google doesn’t keep directing traffic to the old aliases), updating links (they should say jmri org, not jmri.sf.org, but not all do), changing text in various places, other things I haven’t thought of, etc.We could run two independent sites, in case one went down, on the jmri.org and jmri.net domains.  That might be more tricky than it’s worth, however. Thoughts?Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36228866/">Re: [Jmri-developers] How is JmriBeanComboBox supposed to work for the user?</a></b>

           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-02-16 14:45:56</small>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Right. Completely understood, right way for it to be.  But it makes it less of a good example of a long combo box for e.g. Sensor names, as those are sorted by name.  The best example is your approach of loading a long file, and then getting the editor to show those as a regular JComboBox.Once SourceForge is back up so I can send the announcement email for JMRI 4.11.3, the next step will be to PR some changes in this area.Bob&gt; On Feb 15, 2018, at 11:05 PM, Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; That's because in this case the entries are internationally in numeric value order, as per the ESU manuals and LokProgrammer software.&gt; &gt; Dave&gt; &gt; On 14 February 2018 at 16:48, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I was looking at the LokSound V4.0, because I happened to have that up for something else.  Function Outputs pane, click on one, then type a couple characters of a name.  It’s not the greatest example, because the entries aren’t in order; you don’t see the other entries that start with the same characters.&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

      <table id="msg36228865">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36228865/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@rr...&gt; - 2018-02-16 13:49:35</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob,I am still unclear on a point or two.First our hardware does not know if it is connected to a button or a switch. You indicate in '2)' below that the proper button responses should be 'Valid' or 'Unknown' based on the current 'pressed' or 'unpressed' situation. Would that be OK for a toggle switch as well?My second related question is about 'Invalid'. Does anything in JMRI actually respond to 'Invalid' by changing state, or does it internally act the same as 'Unknown'?It should be obvious from my questions that we are trying to figure out the correct response for our hardware without making the user tell the hardware if he has buttons or toggle switches connected. (could be IR detectors or current detectors) The only distinguishing difference is that a toggle switch normally has at least two PCER messages associated with it, and a button usually only has one PCER. (unless something needs to actually echo the button position itself)Dick :)On 02/16/2018 01:09 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; I don’t know the current answer for Turnouts and Sensors; the relevant code has been modified since I last worked on it in detail.&gt;&gt; For the OlcbSignalHead, received (1) PCEventID messages, and (2) ConsumerIdentified and ProducerIdentified messages with “valid” will set the state machine to the related aspect.  (Note that even when JMRI produces an aspect eventID, it is the _reception_ of that PCEventID message that causes the state machine update) That will in turn trigger internal updates in JMRI, which icons, table entry, etc should follow; no OpenLCB messages should be directly emitted by that process but others might follow from activated signal logic, etc.  The Producers and Consumers associated with that signal head will follow the state of the signal head:  Once it’s initialized (internally or externally), the Producer and Consumer for the current aspect will reply valid if queried and the rest will reply invalid.  Until it’s initialized, they all reply unknown.&gt;&gt; Not sure what “If so, how?” is asking. Code, maybe?  c.f. <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312</a>&gt;&gt; Note that those are the right answers for a signal head, which is implementing a common distributed state machine.  For such a thing, "multiple () conflicting Identified messages” only arise from a misconfigured system, typically multiple _unsynchronized_ controllers.  So that right answer to “Is the order … relevant” the answer is “Yes:  Make sure that its externally controlled to do what you want it to do”.&gt;&gt;&gt; Turnouts and Sensors should be doing a similar thing with their state. Once the web site comes back up, check the Javadoc for OlcbTurnout; there’s a figure there that (IIRC) shows the intended behavior, but I don’t know the status of the code.&gt;&gt;&gt; Now, beyond JMRI OlcbSignalHead, to talk about the general case:  If you configure a _system_ in which each participating part is _NOT_ aware of the entire state, then they should be set up to know that they don’t know.&gt;&gt; Consider two momentary buttons that control a lamp on/off. There are multiple approaches to choose from:&gt;&gt; 1)  The two button nodes could track the _entire_ state.  Each could listen to the other, and together agree who was pressed last and what the overall state is.  In that case, they could certainly reply with valid and invalid to represent that state.  Test for the reader:  What should they say when one is pressed and the other not?  Neither pressed?  Both pressed? Hint:  It’s a _state_; it has to be remembered.&gt;&gt; 2) They could understand that they don’t have the entire state.  Then, they don’t know any _state_, just status.   So each “pressed” Producer is valid while pressed, unknown while not pressed.  (The “unpressed” Producer, if it exists, is similar: valid if unpressed, unknown while pressed.)  If neither button is pressed, neither knows the state:  Only the lamp knows.  Seems reasonable, no? If both buttons are pressed, the state is inconsistent (“Don’t do that”), and again only the lamp knows for sure whether it’s on or not. Again, that’s reasonable.&gt;&gt; 3) They could be set up to represent _separate_ states for button 1, button 2 and the lamp if you really wanted to know in detail What’s Happening Right Now; this can also be useful if one button commands lots of different things to happen semi-independently.  (Technically, this is called “multiple weakly-coupled state machines”) Then each button returns valid/invalid based on the local condition, as does the lamp:  Check which node sent the ConsumerIdentified message to know what the valid/invalid means.&gt;&gt; Bottom line:  There is _no_ _single_ _desirable_ behavior for Producer/Consumer Identified valid/invalid/unknown.  They are a _capability_ to be used when setting up the distributed control system.  Different uses will use them differently.  If a common distributed state machine works, that’s great: you can use them that way.  If you’re not setting up one of those, use them differently to do what you want done.&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;   &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Feb 15, 2018, at 9:00 AM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Hi,&gt;&gt; There is an ongoing off-line discussion on how OpenLCB Producer Identified and Consumer Identified responses do or should work. The main issue relates to what happens when multiple locations have push button controls, and what happens when there are multiple copies of JMRI running.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I think the key questions that need answers from the JMRI developers are:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 1) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 2) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 3) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 4) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; 5) Is the order in which multiple but possibly conflicting Identified messages are received *for the same event* relevant for (1), (2), (3) and (4)?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The current Tower-LCC and Signal-LCC initialization behavior for an input line is:&gt;&gt; a) When true, the event associated with true will report Producer Identified valid and the event associated with false will report Producer Identified invalid.&gt;&gt; b) When false, the event associated with true will report Producer Identified invalid and the event associated with false will report Producer Identified valid.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; The issue is that a line connected to a push button will normally respond as 'b)'. The question is; "how does JMRI respond to this, if at all"?&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Dick :)&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I believe that part of the data center move would result in the IP addresseschanging. There was a notice that we (Bob J) had to make sure the DNSrecords changed at the same time to reflect the move.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

      <table id="msg36228349">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36228349/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@tw...&gt; - 2018-02-16 13:40:38</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I think the point that Bob makes is that within JMRI we may end up needing a'State Machine' object. As he says the signal mast puts a number of eventstogether and has the concept of a one of N active events (with N-1 inactiveevents). As the description covers, our JMRI concept of a sensor MAY be asimple two state machine. If it is, then it too would know which (ifinitialized) is valid. On the other hand, if it was just acting like thepushbutton primitive, it would only be active while being pushed. Anotherexample for this would be the three position direction switch on the classicdispatching panel. That handle can be up, left, or right. Each would beequal to an event. But the individual event wouldn't know what the otherswere last doing. But the state machine for the direction switch would knowwhich was the last position and which is the 'valid' event.So I see this bringing up the idea of state which hasn't been given a lot ofthought so far. I think it is going to be critical to the successful use ofLCC for systems. But I think it might expose some of the 'holes' in ourunderstanding of how events can be used with great success.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36228863">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36228863/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Balazs Racz &lt;balazs.racz@gm...&gt; - 2018-02-16 13:34:55</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CACVivUx6wN98hyyPP7CXppj%3Dtdz5Z9JU2YSE98YdMrUZs_wXAw%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>TL;DR: if the customer has problems, upgrade to 4.11.2 or later, if thatfixed the problems, do not read on. I fixed a bug in my code based on Bob'sdocumentation; that fix hit in 4.11.2.Here is the decision tree for Turnouts and Sensors (warning: it'scomplicated)Turnouts that are in "DIRECT" feedback mode completely ignore all messagesthat come from the layout.Turnouts that are in "MONITORING" mode behave the same way as Sensors.Producer and Consumer identified are always treated as the same.&gt;From now on I assume we're talking about a Turnout message where the eventid == Thrown (all others are symmetric) and the turnout is in MONITORINGmode with default settings.&gt; On Feb 15, 2018, at 9:00 AM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Hi,&gt; &gt; There is an ongoing off-line discussion on how OpenLCB Producer&gt; Identified and Consumer Identified responses do or should work. The main&gt; issue relates to what happens when multiple locations have push button&gt; controls, and what happens when there are multiple copies of JMRI running.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; I think the key questions that need answers from the JMRI developers are:&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; 1) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a&gt; Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;If T has state UNKNOWN, T will be set to THROWN and icons updated.If T has state THROWN and message says `valid` nothing happens.If T has state CLOSED and message says `valid` and the setting "Listen toState messages" is true (default), T will be set to THROWN and iconsupdated.If T has state CLOSED and message says `valid` and the setting "Listen toState messages" is false, nothing happens.If version is 4.11.2 or later and message says `invalid` nothing happens.If version is older and message says `invalid` T will be set to CLOSED andicons updated. This causes bad behavior when pushbuttons are used to throwa turnout.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; 2) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a&gt; Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;This only applies to turnouts with "DIRECT" feedback mode, and nothinghappens.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; 3) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a&gt; Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;Same as Producer identified valid or invalid.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; 4) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a&gt; Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt;This only applies to turnouts with "DIRECT" feedback mode, and nothinghappens.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; 5) Is the order in which multiple but possibly conflicting Identified&gt; messages are received *for the same event* relevant for (1), (2), (3) and&gt; (4)?&gt;Yes it is important.Before 4.11.2 the latest message would stick but there will be multipletransitions inbetween. If the messages arrive in undeterministic order theresulting state and icon is undeterministic.After 4.11.2 the set of messages that act is smaller, because invalidmessages will never act, so you'll get into this situation less often. With"Listen to State messages" == true (default) you will get the latestmessage's state, with "Listen to State messages" == false you will geteither no effect (if the turnout had a definite state) or you get the firstever reply with 'valid' state in it (if the turnout had UNKNOWN state).&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; The current Tower-LCC and Signal-LCC initialization behavior for an&gt; input line is:&gt; &gt; a) When true, the event associated with true will report Producer&gt; Identified valid and the event associated with false will report Producer&gt; Identified invalid.&gt; &gt; b) When false, the event associated with true will report Producer&gt; Identified invalid and the event associated with false will report Producer&gt; Identified valid.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; The issue is that a line connected to a push button will normally&gt; respond as 'b)'. The question is; "how does JMRI respond to this, if at&gt; all"?&gt;If both buttons are released, and JMRI is 4.11.2 or later, then no reactionwill happen, provided that the network is correctly configured.Balazs&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Dick :)&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; &gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; &gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; &gt; _______________________________________________&gt; &gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; &gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; &gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Dave,I would have thought that for user convenience having them sorted would makefinding the feature easier. But then I ask, would a hover  text be able totell the user what the underlying value was? That way if you needed to knowabout the 14th item it would tell you which is which, but the display orderwould normally show the human sensible order which is usually a lexicalsort. Since the idea of the decoder pane is to present the confusing machineformat of data in something easier for the human to deal with.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36228146/">[Jmri-developers] ref: DMX, what's the status</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: David Parks &lt;bearwestern@co...&gt; - 2018-02-16 08:52:48</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/007201d3a566%24ea5e1d40%24bf1a57c0%24%40net/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Ken I believe that possibly the best use for JMRI with respect to DMX is to useJMRI to queue an external DMX controller for the desired theatrical effects.The variation of scripted scenarios available from even the cheapest andvery elementary DMX controller box is far beyond what might reasonably beadded to JMRI.  I believe a JMRI connection is of value, but the higherlevel DMX commands might be left to the existing and relatively cheapcontroller hardware.  Virtually all the controllers have adequate scenecreation support software.  I am working on variable color temperatureambient lighting in conjunction with time of day, mood, and weather specialtheatrical effects. The necessary DMX lighting scenarios will reside the in controller and berequested by JMRI.  The common time line is yet to be decided, but may becontained in a MIDI file.  There is currently an elementary DMX JMRIconnection tied to the light table. David Parks " &lt;kcameron@...&gt;To: "'Discussions between JMRI developers'"            &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: [Jmri-developers] DMX, what's the statusMessage-ID: &lt;0d7101d3a4fb$e71165e0$b53431a0$@twcny.rr.com&gt;Content-Type: text/plain;         charset="US-ASCII" We are thinking of using JMRI for a DMX control in a museum setting.          <td class="email-body"><pre>Dave Sands example is actually a better one, as it’s with Sensors and Turnouts.          <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36227949/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-02-16 06:13:37</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I don’t know the current answer for Turnouts and Sensors; the relevant code has been modified since I last worked on it in detail. For the OlcbSignalHead, received (1) PCEventID messages, and (2) ConsumerIdentified and ProducerIdentified messages with “valid” will set the state machine to the related aspect.  (Note that even when JMRI produces an aspect eventID, it is the _reception_ of that PCEventID message that causes the state machine update) That will in turn trigger internal updates in JMRI, which icons, table entry, etc should follow; no OpenLCB messages should be directly emitted by that process but others might follow from activated signal logic, etc.  The Producers and Consumers associated with that signal head will follow the state of the signal head:  Once it’s initialized (internally or externally), the Producer and Consumer for the current aspect will reply valid if queried and the rest will reply invalid.  Until it’s initialized, they all reply unknown.Not sure what “If so, how?” is asking. Code, maybe?  c.f. <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbSignalMast.java#L312</a>Note that those are the right answers for a signal head, which is implementing a common distributed state machine.  For such a thing, "multiple () conflicting Identified messages” only arise from a misconfigured system, typically multiple _unsynchronized_ controllers.  So that right answer to “Is the order … relevant” the answer is “Yes:  Make sure that its externally controlled to do what you want it to do”.Turnouts and Sensors should be doing a similar thing with their state. Once the web site comes back up, check the Javadoc for OlcbTurnout; there’s a figure there that (IIRC) shows the intended behavior, but I don’t know the status of the code.Now, beyond JMRI OlcbSignalHead, to talk about the general case:  If you configure a _system_ in which each participating part is _NOT_ aware of the entire state, then they should be set up to know that they don’t know.Consider two momentary buttons that control a lamp on/off. There are multiple approaches to choose from:1)  The two button nodes could track the _entire_ state.  Each could listen to the other, and together agree who was pressed last and what the overall state is.  In that case, they could certainly reply with valid and invalid to represent that state.  Test for the reader:  What should they say when one is pressed and the other not?  Neither pressed?  Both pressed? Hint:  It’s a _state_; it has to be remembered.2) They could understand that they don’t have the entire state.  Then, they don’t know any _state_, just status.   So each “pressed” Producer is valid while pressed, unknown while not pressed.  (The “unpressed” Producer, if it exists, is similar: valid if unpressed, unknown while pressed.)  If neither button is pressed, neither knows the state:  Only the lamp knows.  Seems reasonable, no? If both buttons are pressed, the state is inconsistent (“Don’t do that”), and again only the lamp knows for sure whether it’s on or not. Again, that’s reasonable.3) They could be set up to represent _separate_ states for button 1, button 2 and the lamp if you really wanted to know in detail What’s Happening Right Now; this can also be useful if one button commands lots of different things to happen semi-independently.  (Technically, this is called “multiple weakly-coupled state machines”) Then each button returns valid/invalid based on the local condition, as does the lamp:  Check which node sent the ConsumerIdentified message to know what the valid/invalid means.Bottom line:  There is _no_ _single_ _desirable_ behavior for Producer/Consumer Identified valid/invalid/unknown.  They are a _capability_ to be used when setting up the distributed control system.  Different uses will use them differently.  If a common distributed state machine works, that’s great: you can use them that way.  If you’re not setting up one of those, use them differently to do what you want done.Bob &gt; On Feb 15, 2018, at 9:00 AM, Dick Bronson &lt;dick@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Hi,&gt; There is an ongoing off-line discussion on how OpenLCB Producer Identified and Consumer Identified responses do or should work. The main issue relates to what happens when multiple locations have push button controls, and what happens when there are multiple copies of JMRI running.&gt; &gt; I think the key questions that need answers from the JMRI developers are:&gt; &gt; 1) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt; &gt; 2) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt; &gt; 3) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt; &gt; 4) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?&gt; &gt; 5) Is the order in which multiple but possibly conflicting Identified messages are received *for the same event* relevant for (1), (2), (3) and (4)?&gt; &gt; The current Tower-LCC and Signal-LCC initialization behavior for an input line is:&gt; a) When true, the event associated with true will report Producer Identified valid and the event associated with false will report Producer Identified invalid.&gt; b) When false, the event associated with true will report Producer Identified invalid and the event associated with false will report Producer Identified valid.&gt; &gt; The issue is that a line connected to a push button will normally respond as 'b)'. The question is; "how does JMRI respond to this, if at all"?&gt; &gt; Dick :)&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36227582/">Re: [Jmri-developers] LCC-Tower - Request for Valid Producer and Consumer of a particular event</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Dick Bronson &lt;dick@rr...&gt; - 2018-02-16 01:34:23</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi,There is an ongoing off-line discussion on how OpenLCB Producer Identified and Consumer Identified responses do or should work. The main issue relates to what happens when multiple locations have push button controls, and what happens when there are multiple copies of JMRI running.I think the key questions that need answers from the JMRI developers are:1) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?2) Does a Producer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?3) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Consumer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?4) Does a Consumer Identified valid or invalid *message* modify a Producer (icon/table) *state* in JMRI? If so, how?5) Is the order in which multiple but possibly conflicting Identified messages are received *for the same event* relevant for (1), (2), (3) and (4)?The current Tower-LCC and Signal-LCC initialization behavior for an input line is:a) When true, the event associated with true will report Producer Identified valid and the event associated with false will report Producer Identified invalid.b) When false, the event associated with true will report Producer Identified invalid and the event associated with false will report Producer Identified valid.The issue is that a line connected to a push button will normally respond as 'b)'. The question is; "how does JMRI respond to this, if at all"?Dick :)</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36227581/">[Jmri-developers] DMX, what's the status</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: George Warner &lt;geowar1@ma...&gt; - 2018-02-16 00:04:35</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/4D19304A-09E5-4B23-ACBD-DC1D65FE9A26%40mac.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>On Tue, 13 Feb 2018 13:53:11 -0500, "Ken Cameron" &lt;kcameron@... &lt;mailto:kcameron@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt; We are thinking of using JMRI for a DMX control in a museum setting. I know&gt; somebody's been working on it but I'm not sure what the current progress is&gt; on it. Also which 'known' device interfaces are there?I've got three USB ==&gt; DMX512 dongles by three manufacturers… that all use the same Vendor and Product ID's.Here's two of them on amazon:USB to DMX Interface Adapter LED DMX512 Studio Computer PC Stage Lighting Controller Dimmer For LED Effect Master-Slave Led Flat &lt;<a href="https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XXDH8VY/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&amp;psc=1>" rel="nofollow">https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XXDH8VY/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&amp;psc=1&gt;</a>;XINFLY USB To DMX 512,Interface Adapter Controller Dmx512 PC Stage Lighting Controller Dimmer Dongle Freestyler &lt;<a href="https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00W52VIOS/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&amp;psc=1>" rel="nofollow">https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00W52VIOS/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&amp;psc=1&gt;</a>;All three of them work just fine with JMRI on macOS… however users (yourself?) have reported problems on Windows.As far as I can tell the issue is that Window's won't let JMRI open the DMX (usb) devices. If you open the JMRI Debug menu's "USB Devices" item a window should open listing all the USB hubs and the nodes on them.If you select a USB hub or node (in the left hand list view) and it's Manufacturer and/or (Product) Names (in the right hand detail view) are blank then this is because the OS won't let JMRI open the device.As to why this is or how to fix it I haven't a clue… I'm strictly a macOS developer.-- Enjoy,George WarnereMail, Message, or FaceTime: &lt;geowar1@...&gt;</pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>On Tue, 13 Feb 2018 13:53:11 -0500, "Ken Cameron" &lt;kcameron@... &lt;mailto:kcameron@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt; We are thinking of using JMRI for a DMX control in a museum setting. I know&gt; somebody's been working on it but I'm not sure what the current progress is&gt; on it. Also which 'known' device interfaces are there?I've got three USB ==&gt; DMX512 dongles by three manufacturers… that all use the same Vendor and Product ID's.All three of them work just fine with JMRI on macOS… however users (yourself?) have reported problems on Windows.As far as I can tell the issue is that Window's won't let JMRI open the DMX (usb) devices. If you open the JMRI Debug menu's "USB Devices" item a window should open listing all the USB hubs and the nodes on them.If you select a USB hub or node (in the left hand list view) and it's Manufacturer and/or (Product) Names (in the right hand detail view) are blank then this is because the OS won't let JMRI open the device.As to why this is or how to fix it I haven't a clue… I'm strictly a macOS developer.-- Enjoy,George WarnereMail, Message, or FaceTime: &lt;geowar1@...&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36226150/">[Jmri-developers] How is JmriBeanComboBox supposed to work for the user?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: George Warner &lt;geowar1@ma...&gt; - 2018-02-15 22:57:25</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/4993915D-4D1E-480D-BA94-22747859677D%40mac.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>On Tue, 13 Feb 2018 08:34:53 -0500, jmri-developers-request@... wrote:&gt; I am a strong supporter of the need for the field to be editable. I work on&gt; layouts with hundreds of entries in the lists. Having to scroll those lists&gt; is way to slow, I know the value I want. I'd revert to direct edit of the&gt; XML before accepting any change that would prevent direct entry for a&gt; selection. Since I work with sensible naming conventions, I know the name&gt; for the object before I start.The "broken" behavior is caused by making the combo box editable (not by any of my (highlighting) modifications);This turns on a text field where text can be entered directly instead of requiring the user to choose an item from the drop down list. Unfortunately this also causes the text field to consume the keyboard events that would normally be sent to the drop down list to allow quicker navigation there.There are several solutions; each with their own pros and cons:1) Don't make the text box editable. Pros: regain alphanumeric navigation of drop down list; cons: loose ability to directly type in names.2) Make it so that when the drop down list is opened the combo box forwards keystrokes to it instead of the text box (Move keyboard focus).	Pros: you regain "normal" (non-editable combo box) behavior; cons: may be non-trivial to implement.3) Rewrite the drop down list building code to only show entries that contain the string typed in the text field.	Pros: Narrows the choices for large layouts with lots of turnouts. Cons: Users may not realize why (non-matchings) turnouts aren't being listed in the drop down list.Options 1 and 3 have pretty big cons leaving option 2 as the lesser of 3 evils and what I'd recommend.YOMV. ;-)-- Enjoy,George WarnereMail, Message, or FaceTime: &lt;geowar1@...&gt;</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Here is a good demonstration of non-editable combo box actions. 1. Use David Park's SensorLoad.xml 2. Go to *Tools &gt;&gt; Logix* 3. Select *Options &gt;&gt; Use Combo Name Boxes* 4. Create a new Logix and Conditional 5. Select *Add State Variable* 6. Select *Sensor* 7. In the name field type *wm* 8. Hit the down arrowOn my 13" MBA, the list is positioned at the first *WM...* entry andshows the next 50 entries.  Now I can use the arrow keys to move tothe desired row and press enter or use the mouse to click on thedesired row.The text based positioning is not case sensitive.  I can usually type upto 3 characters.  If I do *con*, that gets me *Conn ArriveBOW-x* whichhappens to be unique.Dave Sand----- Original message -----From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;To: Discussions between JMRI developers &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] How is JmriBeanComboBox supposed to work for the user?Date: Tue, 13 Feb 2018 06:45:07 -0800Could you _please_ do the test I recommended earlier of checking howtyping on a real JComboBox works?If you “know the value (you) want” and start typing it, a (not modifiedand hence broken) JComboBox goes straight to that value.Bob&gt; On Feb 13, 2018, at 5:34 AM, Ken Cameron&gt; &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; I am a strong supporter of the need for the field to be editable.&gt; I work on&gt; layouts with hundreds of entries in the lists. Having to scroll&gt; those lists&gt; is way to slow, I know the value I want. I'd revert to direct&gt; edit of the&gt; XML before accepting any change that would prevent direct entry for a&gt; selection. Since I work with sensible naming conventions, I know&gt; the name&gt; for the object before I start.--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I am a strong supporter of the need for the field to be editable. I work onlayouts with hundreds of entries in the lists. Having to scroll those listsis way to slow, I know the value I want. I'd revert to direct edit of theXML before accepting any change that would prevent direct entry for aselection. Since I work with sensible naming conventions, I know the namefor the object before I start.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I have seen what I assume is a related issue with 4.10, but have not had the opportunity to investigate fully. I see the WiThrottle come up, but it is not advertising the current name, and is not readily found. A Phone that has the right address in it can find the connection manually, but cannot auto-connect. Back to 4.8 and it works fine. Same on Mac, Win 10 or Pi.BillBill Chownorrrbrit2004@...<a href="comhttp://bchown.com/" rel="nofollow">comhttp://bchown.com/</a>     On Monday, February 12, 2018, 3:06:33 PM PST, Lynn Grandle &lt;LGrandle@...&gt; wrote:     Hi:Put up the 4.10 distribution on our club machine about a week ago and have been having problems with connecting to the withrottle server with both engine driver and withrottle.&nbsp; The Withrottle panel will going into a pending state or takes a long time to get out of the Pending state when it first comes up.&nbsp; It was such a problem that I have downgraded the JMRI on that machine to the 4.6 distribution and it works fine.&nbsp; We did have it at the 4.8 distribution and did not notice a problem.&nbsp; Went to 4.6 because that was the distribution kit that I had on the machine ( machine not on internet, and wifi hot spots are just too dam slow to download a distribution on).&nbsp; Will try and get a 4.8 distribution back on it this week.&nbsp;While I still had 4.10 on the machine, I would check the listener for new connections with netstat and when it would not connect the listener was gone.&nbsp; No other errors logged to the console, or displayed on the withrottle server panel --&nbsp; Sometime it would show pending, sometime not when this happened. Since this problem was brought to my attention by a phone call from members that wanted to run on Saturday, I did not have the time to turn on the debugging to see what other information I could gather.&nbsp; My question to the group is-- has anyone else seen this problem?&nbsp; Is it a known problem and is there a solution for it other than staying at 4.8.&nbsp; Host is a window 10 machine with patches current as of the middle of Jan.&nbsp; Have not had time to bring machine home and get this months patches for the OS.Bob------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>  </pre></td>
