         <td class="email-body"><pre>Would really like a thread dump to be sure, but I think Ken’s stack trace is showing that the blocked thread is [main], not Swing/AWT. That’s consistent with the earlier comment that tables can be used, etc, while waiting through the delay for the center window to appear. Of course, any fix that defers work until later will be invoked off Swing/AWT, so has to be done carefully. Bob&gt; On Feb 9, 2018, at 8:04 AM, Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; We do *all* control decisions on the main EDT thread. That means that holding up that thread for a minute while a JMRI throttle is running means that throttle cannot (for example) stop a train if that thread is blocked. This appears to be blocking that thread, so are you suggesting that it’s acceptable to introduce this delay later?&gt; &gt; Note that I didn’t design this to preload; I don’t know why we think it’s a good idea to allow the fonts in the console be tweaked to the degree we do, but I do know that we do a lot of preloading of things this to reduce the likelihood that anything in JMRI will block layout control.&gt; &gt; Randall Wood&gt; Alexandria Software&gt; randall.h.wood@...&gt; <a href="http://alexandriasoftware.com" rel="nofollow">http://alexandriasoftware.com</a>&gt; &gt;&gt; On Feb 9, 2018, at 10:46, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; But to delay startup computing hundreds of fonts that never get used is even&gt;&gt; worse. Now you are correct that since this is a time consuming task, it&gt;&gt; needs to be a separate thread.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; This still gets back to the poor user experience of slow starts due to&gt;&gt; something hardly needed.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; So I could see that the font list is fetch, but the details about the fonts&gt;&gt; continue to run in background. Only when something needed to know those&gt;&gt; other types might it wait for the thread to finish.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Another idea would be that the used fonts are held in the preferences. As&gt;&gt; part of startup, it would fetch all the details for those fonts only and&gt;&gt; defer the processing of the rest of the fonts while everything else&gt;&gt; continues to run.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; If anything interacting with the user causes a timing issue with the threads&gt;&gt; interacting with the layout, that part of the code is flawed and should be&gt;&gt; fixed. It is the wrong way to protect faulty code (running in the wrong&gt;&gt; threads) by trying to preprocess the world. Fix the real problem I think Bob&gt;&gt; J would say.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Randall, so based on that your argument doesn't hold water (or should hold&gt;&gt; up the loading of the system).&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt;&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>We do *all* control decisions on the main EDT thread. That means that holding up that thread for a minute while a JMRI throttle is running means that throttle cannot (for example) stop a train if that thread is blocked. This appears to be blocking that thread, so are you suggesting that it’s acceptable to introduce this delay later?Note that I didn’t design this to preload; I don’t know why we think it’s a good idea to allow the fonts in the console be tweaked to the degree we do, but I do know that we do a lot of preloading of things this to reduce the likelihood that anything in JMRI will block layout control.Randall WoodAlexandria Softwarerandall.h.wood@...<a href="http://alexandriasoftware.com" rel="nofollow">http://alexandriasoftware.com</a>&gt; On Feb 9, 2018, at 10:46, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; But to delay startup computing hundreds of fonts that never get used is even&gt; worse. Now you are correct that since this is a time consuming task, it&gt; needs to be a separate thread.&gt; &gt; This still gets back to the poor user experience of slow starts due to&gt; something hardly needed.&gt; &gt; So I could see that the font list is fetch, but the details about the fonts&gt; continue to run in background. Only when something needed to know those&gt; other types might it wait for the thread to finish.&gt; &gt; Another idea would be that the used fonts are held in the preferences. As&gt; part of startup, it would fetch all the details for those fonts only and&gt; defer the processing of the rest of the fonts while everything else&gt; continues to run.&gt; &gt; If anything interacting with the user causes a timing issue with the threads&gt; interacting with the layout, that part of the code is flawed and should be&gt; fixed. It is the wrong way to protect faulty code (running in the wrong&gt; threads) by trying to preprocess the world. Fix the real problem I think Bob&gt; J would say.&gt; &gt; Randall, so based on that your argument doesn't hold water (or should hold&gt; up the loading of the system).&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>But to delay startup computing hundreds of fonts that never get used is evenworse. Now you are correct that since this is a time consuming task, itneeds to be a separate thread.This still gets back to the poor user experience of slow starts due tosomething hardly needed.So I could see that the font list is fetch, but the details about the fontscontinue to run in background. Only when something needed to know thoseother types might it wait for the thread to finish.Another idea would be that the used fonts are held in the preferences. Aspart of startup, it would fetch all the details for those fonts only anddefer the processing of the rest of the fonts while everything elsecontinues to run.If anything interacting with the user causes a timing issue with the threadsinteracting with the layout, that part of the code is flawed and should befixed. It is the wrong way to protect faulty code (running in the wrongthreads) by trying to preprocess the world. Fix the real problem I think BobJ would say.Randall, so based on that your argument doesn't hold water (or should holdup the loading of the system).-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36221558/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startup</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-02-09 15:40:46</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; On Feb 9, 2018, at 6:43 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Focusing closely on the loop, it seems the delays are always in the line&gt; doing all the floating point stuff to see if something looks proportional or&gt; not. It’s not “the floating point stuff”.  It would take a _huge_ number of computations to use up a minute.I expect that the time is spent _loading_ the fonts so that each one can have each of its glyphs scanned for size.  That requires pulling every font off disk (or SDD or whatever) if there’s not meta-information that would allow a quicker answer to f.getStringBounds("W", frc).getWidth()&gt; On Feb 9, 2018, at 7:06 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; From this view it would seem that if we presumed that the character fonts&gt; were proportional, we'd be right almost every time. And that test seems to&gt; be the crux of why this takes so long. So if there was a delay when&gt; something cared about the difference, it would only be a second or few to&gt; the user at the time that decision needed to know the difference.Not sure I understand what you’re suggesting.  If it’s guess and accept that guess is sometimes wrong, I doubt that’s OK.  Remember that the default for the console, which i use because I’ve never needed to change it (why does anybody care what the console font is?), is a mono-spaced font; that’s the most common use case.But maybe the mono-vs-propotional info doesn’t really mean anything.  What’s it used for?  Can the code scan just one font later on, when it’s selected?&gt; On Feb 9, 2018, at 7:18 AM, Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; The only reason we do this is to get lists of fonts by attribute. It is far better to delay starting JMRI than it is to lock up JMRI in the middle of use, given that JMRI may be reading and writing to/from a layout and may interrupt control to get that list if we don’t pre-stage it.I think that’s overstated.I can’t reproduce this, and we _still_ don’t have a thread trace, but what I think is happening is:   A background thread is working to load the font info   Main initialization is asking the JmriConfigurationManager to load (an in-line call)	that works down to the individual Providers		one of which is SystemConsolePreferencesManager			which wants to setFontFamily				which stalls because it’s synchronized against the thread loading the fontsSo the questions become: What’s lost in deferring the SystemConsolePreferencesManager.setFontFamily until later? Does setFontFamily require a complete scan before the set operation is complete?We don’t actually know the answer to those yet, but I can give you two hypotheses on downstream impact:*) setFamily (but not complete scan) is needed to open the Console item from the Help menu - it can’t show that window until it’s font is known.*) The complete scan is needed to open the Console’s pane in the preferences - it wants to show the entire list.Both of those are occasional operations that can wait a bit (with or without popping an “Wait a second while I work” notice), and in most cases the background thread will be complete before they’re needed anyway. Bottom line:  Multiple people are being delayed _every_ _time_ by a noticeable amount of time (a minute?!), so long that it’s a complaint.  We should fix it right (see above).  But if we can’t fix it right, then we should minimize the impact by having people suffer that delay only when they need to because they asked for something that requires it.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>The only reason we do this is to get lists of fonts by attribute. It is far better to delay starting JMRI than it is to lock up JMRI in the middle of use, given that JMRI may be reading and writing to/from a layout and may interrupt control to get that list if we don’t pre-stage it.Randall Wood&gt; On Feb 9, 2018, at 10:06, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Further viewing shows me that almost all of the fonts score as being&gt; proportional. On my system:&gt; 439 Fonts&gt; 30 Symbol&gt; 37 Monospaced&gt; 372 Proportional&gt; &gt; From this view it would seem that if we presumed that the character fonts&gt; were proportional, we'd be right almost every time. And that test seems to&gt; be the crux of why this takes so long. So if there was a delay when&gt; something cared about the difference, it would only be a second or few to&gt; the user at the time that decision needed to know the difference.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I should have included the lines. The extra log.info() is how I was seeingwhich was taking how long.                // next line is the FE_FLOATING_POINT_EQUALITY annotatedabove                if (f.getStringBounds("I", frc).getWidth()                        == (w = f.getStringBounds("W", frc).getWidth())                        &amp;&amp; w == f.getStringBounds(" ", frc).getWidth()) {                    // Yes, they're all the same width - add to themonospaced list                    monospaced.add(s);                    log.info("Added mono font: {}", s);                } else {                    // No, they're different widths - add to theproportional list                    proportional.add(s);                    log.info("Added prop font: {}", s);                }And that all in the util/swing/FontComboUtil.java-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Focusing closely on the loop, it seems the delays are always in the linedoing all the floating point stuff to see if something looks proportional ornot. A 'quick' font takes around 100mS for that but many are more like acouple of hundred mS but other are multiples of seconds.I guess I can see building a list of fonts is valid. But holding up whilefiguring out which are proportional or not, I'm not sure that's worth theeffort.          <td class="email-body"><pre>Here is the trace for the main thread, it is waiting on the thread spawnedto read the fonts.Thread [main] (Suspended)		waiting for: Class&lt;T&gt; (jmri.util.swing.FontComboUtil) (id=30)		FontComboUtil.prepareFontLists() line: 95		FontComboUtil.getFonts(int) line: 58		SystemConsolePreferencesManager.setFontFamily(String) line: 170		SystemConsolePreferencesManager.initialize(Profile) line: 54		JmriConfigurationManager.initializeProvider(PreferencesManager,Profile) line: 264		JmriConfigurationManager.lambda$load$1(Profile, PreferencesManager)line: 183		412925308.accept(Object) line: not available		ArrayList$ArrayListSpliterator&lt;E&gt;.forEachRemaining(Consumer&lt;? superE&gt;) line: not available		ReferencePipeline$Head&lt;E_IN,E_OUT&gt;.forEach(Consumer&lt;? super E_OUT&gt;)line: not available		JmriConfigurationManager.load(URL, boolean) line: 182		JmriConfigurationManager.load(File, boolean) line: 170		PanelPro(Apps).&lt;init&gt;() line: 258		PanelPro.&lt;init&gt;() line: 40		PanelPro.main(String[]) line: 102	-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36221296/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startup</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Nigel Cliffe &lt;nigel.cliffe@ou...&gt; - 2018-02-09 11:41:33</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/HE1PR0302MB2604453D312B1CA940977FE698F20%40HE1PR0302MB2604.eurprd03.prod.outlook.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>There are seven messages in the thread at my machine, non from Bob.  However, over on JMRI Users, I eventually found a message on Wednesday about a “Thread Trace”.  Which has links to Java VisualVM  as something that might work for Windows.No idea what that is, the link shows some sort of application doing stuff.  If I search for it to install it from Oracle/Java, no results.  Which is then guesswork time for me.  Clearly something needed on my machine, but no idea what it is.I remain willing to help.   But,  the tools have to be at my level of computer understanding.From: Randall Wood [mailto:randall.h.wood@...]Sent: 09 February 2018 11:20To: Discussions between JMRI developersSubject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startupEarlier in this thread Bob Jacobsen outlined what tools to use to get a stack trace.Randall WoodOn Feb 9, 2018, at 06:10, Nigel Cliffe &lt;nigel.cliffe@...&lt;mailto:nigel.cliffe@...&gt;&gt; wrote:Please provide details of how to give you a “stack-track” in normal language, and I’ll provide one.On my machine its 1 minute to load JMRI vs. 2 seconds to load MS Excel vs. 15 seconds to load Autodesk DWG viewer (a slow-loading application), GIMP (which loads lots of fonts) is 12 seconds.   I can’t find any other applications above 15 seconds to load.   JMRI is the stupidly slow outlier.-          NigelFrom: Randall Wood [mailto:randall.h.wood@...]Sent: 09 February 2018 10:33To: Discussions between JMRI developersSubject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startupJMRI offers users the ability to use arbitrary fonts in a number of places, so we have to be able to list those fonts (and to list them by type — monospaced, proportional, character, symbol, etc).The design intent is to ensure the application remains responsive *once started* (its better for JMRI to start slowly than to have someone opening a window cause JMRI to be non-responsive to changes on the layout, even for just a brief period), we:1. pre-build lists of fonts for display in the font chooser widgets2. pre-build the preferences window, which depends on 1 (as it has multiple font chooser widgets)That said, we can’t understand what is causing the delay unless someone who experiences the delay provides a stack trace. It is likely that some part of 1 and/or 2 above is being performed on the the event dispatch thread, which is undesirable in this case.Randall WoodOn Feb 9, 2018, at 04:04, Nigel Cliffe &lt;nigel.cliffe@...&lt;mailto:nigel.cliffe@...&gt;&gt; wrote:I'd want to know *why* JMRI needs to look at hundreds of fonts at startup.   It needs a couple to run the GUI, and that's it.Any others should be loaded when a panel, or other element, requiring extra fonts is created or loaded.  And, even with a panel, the fonts should be minimal unless someone asks for "curley-whurly-weird-font" or "replica 1873 typeface".I'm not a programmer, but to my mind, efficient software comes from asking what tasks are required and only doing those.  Avoid doing "extra" stuff.This startup speed issue needs fixing, its making JMRI impossibly slow on my Win7 machine.- Nigel-----Original Message-----From: Ken Cameron [mailto:kcameron@...]Sent: 09 February 2018 03:51To: 'Discussions between JMRI developers'Subject: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startupIt seems that the system console manager waits for the prepareFontLists() to complete and if a PC has hundreds of fonts this can take minutes. While the loop processes many fonts in a few milliseconds, some fonts for the same tests to see if a font looks like monospace, proportional, etc... can take seconds. Now from the history, this part of the code hasn't changed in 6 years.The problem is that startup doesn't finish because of this. So why does the system console manager need to wait for the font lists and why does the mainline of startup have to wait for the system console manager?One thing that surprised me what that it was calculating the font features.I had thought that there would have been metainformation with the font that have answered these questions.I'm suspecting that something in Windows has changed of late that impacted this timing. I've noticed over the last year or two it kept getting worse.In the last few months I've seen more 'normal' users seeing this too. So I finally looked into it, and this is what I had found. So the first question for some of you on other than Windows: how long does it take? It manifests itself as a delay where the panels may have loaded, scripts have run, but it waits before you see the final main screen. If you turn on DEBUG for everything you then can scan the log for two messages. The first "Prepare font lists..." is when it starts scanning the fonts. The second is "...font lists built". See the time between those two items. I said DEBUG everything only so you can focus on what else is going on and when the second message happens. I'm finding it gets quite a while in the log between the last message before the "...font lists built" and that message.Or is this just a Windows issue?-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org<http://www.jmri.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org&lt;http://www.jmri.org/&gt;</a>; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org<http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org&lt;http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org/&gt;</a>; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com<http://www.cnymod.com/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com&lt;http://www.cnymod.com/&gt;</a>; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org<http://www.syracusemodelrr.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org&lt;http://www.syracusemodelrr.org/&gt;</a>;------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org&lt;<a href="http://Slashdot.org>!http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://Slashdot.org&gt;!http://sdm.link/slashdot</a> _______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...&lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org&lt;<a href="http://Slashdot.org>" rel="nofollow">http://Slashdot.org&gt;</a>;! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...&lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org&lt;<a href="http://slashdot.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://slashdot.org/&gt;</a>;!          <td class="email-body"><pre>Earlier in this thread Bob Jacobsen outlined what tools to use to get a stack trace.Randall Wood&gt; On Feb 9, 2018, at 06:10, Nigel Cliffe &lt;nigel.cliffe@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Please provide details of how to give you a “stack-track” in normal language, and I’ll provide one.&nbsp; &lt;&gt;&gt;  &gt; On my machine its 1 minute to load JMRI vs. 2 seconds to load MS Excel vs. 15 seconds to load Autodesk DWG viewer (a slow-loading application), GIMP (which loads lots of fonts) is 12 seconds.   I can’t find any other applications above 15 seconds to load.   JMRI is the stupidly slow outlier.      &gt;  &gt;  &gt; -          Nigel&gt;  &gt;  &gt; From: Randall Wood [mailto:randall.h.wood@...] &gt; Sent: 09 February 2018 10:33&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startup&gt;  &gt; JMRI offers users the ability to use arbitrary fonts in a number of places, so we have to be able to list those fonts (and to list them by type — monospaced, proportional, character, symbol, etc).&gt;  &gt; The design intent is to ensure the application remains responsive *once started* (its better for JMRI to start slowly than to have someone opening a window cause JMRI to be non-responsive to changes on the layout, even for just a brief period), we:&gt; 1. pre-build lists of fonts for display in the font chooser widgets&gt; 2. pre-build the preferences window, which depends on 1 (as it has multiple font chooser widgets)&gt;  &gt; That said, we can’t understand what is causing the delay unless someone who experiences the delay provides a stack trace. It is likely that some part of 1 and/or 2 above is being performed on the the event dispatch thread, which is undesirable in this case.&gt;  &gt; Randall Wood&gt;  &gt; On Feb 9, 2018, at 04:04, Nigel Cliffe &lt;nigel.cliffe@... &lt;mailto:nigel.cliffe@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;  &gt; &gt; I'd want to know *why* JMRI needs to look at hundreds of fonts at startup.   It needs a couple to run the GUI, and that's it.  &gt; Any others should be loaded when a panel, or other element, requiring extra fonts is created or loaded.  And, even with a panel, the fonts should be minimal unless someone asks for "curley-whurly-weird-font" or "replica 1873 typeface".     &gt; &gt; I'm not a programmer, but to my mind, efficient software comes from asking what tasks are required and only doing those.  Avoid doing "extra" stuff. &gt; &gt; &gt; This startup speed issue needs fixing, its making JMRI impossibly slow on my Win7 machine.  &gt; &gt; - Nigel&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; -----Original Message-----&gt; From: Ken Cameron [mailto:kcameron@... &lt;mailto:kcameron@...&gt;] &gt; Sent: 09 February 2018 03:51&gt; To: 'Discussions between JMRI developers'&gt; Subject: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startup&gt; &gt; It seems that the system console manager waits for the prepareFontLists() to complete and if a PC has hundreds of fonts this can take minutes. While the loop processes many fonts in a few milliseconds, some fonts for the same tests to see if a font looks like monospace, proportional, etc... can take seconds. Now from the history, this part of the code hasn't changed in 6 years.&gt; &gt; The problem is that startup doesn't finish because of this. So why does the system console manager need to wait for the font lists and why does the mainline of startup have to wait for the system console manager?&gt; &gt; One thing that surprised me what that it was calculating the font features.&gt; I had thought that there would have been metainformation with the font that have answered these questions.&gt; &gt; I'm suspecting that something in Windows has changed of late that impacted this timing. I've noticed over the last year or two it kept getting worse.&gt; In the last few months I've seen more 'normal' users seeing this too. So I finally looked into it, and this is what I had found. So the first question for some of you on other than Windows: how long does it take? It manifests itself as a delay where the panels may have loaded, scripts have run, but it waits before you see the final main screen. If you turn on DEBUG for everything you then can scan the log for two messages. The first "Prepare font lists..." is when it starts scanning the fonts. The second is "...font lists built". See the time between those two items. I said DEBUG everything only so you can focus on what else is going on and when the second message happens. I'm finding it gets quite a while in the log between the last message before the "...font lists built" and that message.&gt; &gt; Or is this just a Windows issue?&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.jmri.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org/&gt;</a>;&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org/&gt;</a>;&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.cnymod.com/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com/&gt;</a>;&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a> &lt;<a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org/&gt;</a>;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!<a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a> &lt;<a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot>" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot&gt;</a>; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@... &lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a> &lt;<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers>" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers&gt;</a>;&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!          <td class="email-body"><pre>I started PanelPro and a Panel comes up. And I can select "Edit / Open Editor" in the Panel menu and I can select and unselect the checkboxes in the Panel Editor dialog long before the main PanelPro window appears. I might be wrong, but I don't get the impression that the event dispatch thread is locked. The GUI seems to work fine during this long period. And I'm running Windows 8.1 and is seeing the long startup time for PanelPro.Regards,Daniel2018-02-09 11:33 skrev Randall Wood:&gt; That said, we can’t understand what is causing the delay unless&gt; someone who experiences the delay provides a stack trace.         <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Please provide details of how to give you a “stack-track” in normal language, and I’ll provide one.On my machine its 1 minute to load JMRI vs. 2 seconds to load MS Excel vs. 15 seconds to load Autodesk DWG viewer (a slow-loading application), GIMP (which loads lots of fonts) is 12 seconds.   I can’t find any other applications above 15 seconds to load.   JMRI is the stupidly slow outlier.-          NigelFrom: Randall Wood [mailto:randall.h.wood@...]Sent: 09 February 2018 10:33To: Discussions between JMRI developersSubject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startupJMRI offers users the ability to use arbitrary fonts in a number of places, so we have to be able to list those fonts (and to list them by type — monospaced, proportional, character, symbol, etc).The design intent is to ensure the application remains responsive *once started* (its better for JMRI to start slowly than to have someone opening a window cause JMRI to be non-responsive to changes on the layout, even for just a brief period), we:1. pre-build lists of fonts for display in the font chooser widgets2. pre-build the preferences window, which depends on 1 (as it has multiple font chooser widgets)That said, we can’t understand what is causing the delay unless someone who experiences the delay provides a stack trace. It is likely that some part of 1 and/or 2 above is being performed on the the event dispatch thread, which is undesirable in this case.Randall WoodOn Feb 9, 2018, at 04:04, Nigel Cliffe &lt;nigel.cliffe@...&lt;mailto:nigel.cliffe@...&gt;&gt; wrote:I'd want to know *why* JMRI needs to look at hundreds of fonts at startup.   It needs a couple to run the GUI, and that's it.Any others should be loaded when a panel, or other element, requiring extra fonts is created or loaded.  And, even with a panel, the fonts should be minimal unless someone asks for "curley-whurly-weird-font" or "replica 1873 typeface".I'm not a programmer, but to my mind, efficient software comes from asking what tasks are required and only doing those.  Avoid doing "extra" stuff.This startup speed issue needs fixing, its making JMRI impossibly slow on my Win7 machine.- Nigel-----Original Message-----From: Ken Cameron [mailto:kcameron@...]Sent: 09 February 2018 03:51To: 'Discussions between JMRI developers'Subject: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startupIt seems that the system console manager waits for the prepareFontLists() to complete and if a PC has hundreds of fonts this can take minutes. While the loop processes many fonts in a few milliseconds, some fonts for the same tests to see if a font looks like monospace, proportional, etc... can take seconds. Now from the history, this part of the code hasn't changed in 6 years.The problem is that startup doesn't finish because of this. So why does the system console manager need to wait for the font lists and why does the mainline of startup have to wait for the system console manager?One thing that surprised me what that it was calculating the font features.I had thought that there would have been metainformation with the font that have answered these questions.I'm suspecting that something in Windows has changed of late that impacted this timing. I've noticed over the last year or two it kept getting worse.In the last few months I've seen more 'normal' users seeing this too. So I finally looked into it, and this is what I had found. So the first question for some of you on other than Windows: how long does it take? It manifests itself as a delay where the panels may have loaded, scripts have run, but it waits before you see the final main screen. If you turn on DEBUG for everything you then can scan the log for two messages. The first "Prepare font lists..." is when it starts scanning the fonts. The second is "...font lists built". See the time between those two items. I said DEBUG everything only so you can focus on what else is going on and when the second message happens. I'm finding it gets quite a while in the log between the last message before the "...font lists built" and that message.Or is this just a Windows issue?-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org<http://www.jmri.org>" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org&lt;http://www.jmri.org&gt;</a>; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org<http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org>" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org&lt;http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org&gt;</a>; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com<http://www.cnymod.com>" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com&lt;http://www.cnymod.com&gt;</a>; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org<http://www.syracusemodelrr.org>" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org&lt;http://www.syracusemodelrr.org&gt;</a>;------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a> _______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...&lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...&lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>JMRI offers users the ability to use arbitrary fonts in a number of places, so we have to be able to list those fonts (and to list them by type — monospaced, proportional, character, symbol, etc).The design intent is to ensure the application remains responsive *once started* (its better for JMRI to start slowly than to have someone opening a window cause JMRI to be non-responsive to changes on the layout, even for just a brief period), we:1. pre-build lists of fonts for display in the font chooser widgets2. pre-build the preferences window, which depends on 1 (as it has multiple font chooser widgets)That said, we can’t understand what is causing the delay unless someone who experiences the delay provides a stack trace. It is likely that some part of 1 and/or 2 above is being performed on the the event dispatch thread, which is undesirable in this case.Randall Wood&gt; On Feb 9, 2018, at 04:04, Nigel Cliffe &lt;nigel.cliffe@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; &gt; I'd want to know *why* JMRI needs to look at hundreds of fonts at startup.   It needs a couple to run the GUI, and that's it.  &gt; Any others should be loaded when a panel, or other element, requiring extra fonts is created or loaded.  And, even with a panel, the fonts should be minimal unless someone asks for "curley-whurly-weird-font" or "replica 1873 typeface".     &gt; &gt; I'm not a programmer, but to my mind, efficient software comes from asking what tasks are required and only doing those.  Avoid doing "extra" stuff. &gt; &gt; &gt; This startup speed issue needs fixing, its making JMRI impossibly slow on my Win7 machine.  &gt; &gt; - Nigel&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; -----Original Message-----&gt; From: Ken Cameron [mailto:kcameron@...] &gt; Sent: 09 February 2018 03:51&gt; To: 'Discussions between JMRI developers'&gt; Subject: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startup&gt; &gt; It seems that the system console manager waits for the prepareFontLists() to complete and if a PC has hundreds of fonts this can take minutes. While the loop processes many fonts in a few milliseconds, some fonts for the same tests to see if a font looks like monospace, proportional, etc... can take seconds. Now from the history, this part of the code hasn't changed in 6 years.&gt; &gt; The problem is that startup doesn't finish because of this. So why does the system console manager need to wait for the font lists and why does the mainline of startup have to wait for the system console manager?&gt; &gt; One thing that surprised me what that it was calculating the font features.&gt; I had thought that there would have been metainformation with the font that have answered these questions.&gt; &gt; I'm suspecting that something in Windows has changed of late that impacted this timing. I've noticed over the last year or two it kept getting worse.&gt; In the last few months I've seen more 'normal' users seeing this too. So I finally looked into it, and this is what I had found. So the first question for some of you on other than Windows: how long does it take? It manifests itself as a delay where the panels may have loaded, scripts have run, but it waits before you see the final main screen. If you turn on DEBUG for everything you then can scan the log for two messages. The first "Prepare font lists..." is when it starts scanning the fonts. The second is "...font lists built". See the time between those two items. I said DEBUG everything only so you can focus on what else is going on and when the second message happens. I'm finding it gets quite a while in the log between the last message before the "...font lists built" and that message.&gt; &gt; Or is this just a Windows issue?&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a> _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36221125/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startup</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Nigel Cliffe &lt;nigel.cliffe@ou...&gt; - 2018-02-09 09:04:31</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I'd want to know *why* JMRI needs to look at hundreds of fonts at startup.   It needs a couple to run the GUI, and that's it.  Any others should be loaded when a panel, or other element, requiring extra fonts is created or loaded.  And, even with a panel, the fonts should be minimal unless someone asks for "curley-whurly-weird-font" or "replica 1873 typeface".     I'm not a programmer, but to my mind, efficient software comes from asking what tasks are required and only doing those.  Avoid doing "extra" stuff. This startup speed issue needs fixing, its making JMRI impossibly slow on my Win7 machine.  - Nigel-----Original Message-----From: Ken Cameron [mailto:kcameron@...] Sent: 09 February 2018 03:51To: 'Discussions between JMRI developers'Subject: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startupIt seems that the system console manager waits for the prepareFontLists() to complete and if a PC has hundreds of fonts this can take minutes. While the loop processes many fonts in a few milliseconds, some fonts for the same tests to see if a font looks like monospace, proportional, etc... can take seconds. Now from the history, this part of the code hasn't changed in 6 years.The problem is that startup doesn't finish because of this. So why does the system console manager need to wait for the font lists and why does the mainline of startup have to wait for the system console manager?One thing that surprised me what that it was calculating the font features.I had thought that there would have been metainformation with the font that have answered these questions.I'm suspecting that something in Windows has changed of late that impacted this timing. I've noticed over the last year or two it kept getting worse.In the last few months I've seen more 'normal' users seeing this too. So I finally looked into it, and this is what I had found. So the first question for some of you on other than Windows: how long does it take? It manifests itself as a delay where the panels may have loaded, scripts have run, but it waits before you see the final main screen. If you turn on DEBUG for everything you then can scan the log for two messages. The first "Prepare font lists..." is when it starts scanning the fonts. The second is "...font lists built". See the time between those two items. I said DEBUG everything only so you can focus on what else is going on and when the second message happens. I'm finding it gets quite a while in the log between the last message before the "...font lists built" and that message.Or is this just a Windows issue?-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a> _______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Ken,Here are the results from macOS 10.13.3.233 Fonts according to Font Book.2018-02-08 22:01:49,057 apps.Apps                             DEBUG - Prepare font lists... [PrepareFontListsThread]2018-02-08 22:01:49,058 swing.FontComboUtil                   DEBUG - Prepare font lists... [PrepareFontListsThread]2018-02-08 22:01:49,338 swing.FontComboUtil                   DEBUG - ...font lists built [PrepareFontListsThread]2018-02-08 22:01:49,338 apps.Apps                             DEBUG - ...Font lists built [PrepareFontListsThread]Dave Sand----- Original message -----From: Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt;To: Discussions between JMRI developers &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Subject: [Jmri-developers] Slow JMRI startupDate: Thu, 8 Feb 2018 22:51:06 -0500It seems that the system console manager waits for the prepareFontLists() tocomplete and if a PC has hundreds of fonts this can take minutes. While theloop processes many fonts in a few milliseconds, some fonts for the sametests to see if a font looks like monospace, proportional, etc... can takeseconds. Now from the history, this part of the code hasn't changed in 6years.The problem is that startup doesn't finish because of this. So why does thesystem console manager need to wait for the font lists and why does themainline of startup have to wait for the system console manager?One thing that surprised me what that it was calculating the font features.I had thought that there would have been metainformation with the font thathave answered these questions.I'm suspecting that something in Windows has changed of late that impactedthis timing. I've noticed over the last year or two it kept getting worse.In the last few months I've seen more 'normal' users seeing this too. So Ifinally looked into it, and this is what I had found. So the first questionfor some of you on other than Windows: how long does it take? It manifestsitself as a delay where the panels may have loaded, scripts have run, but itwaits before you see the final main screen. If you turn on DEBUG foreverything you then can scan the log for two messages. The first "Preparefont lists..." is when it starts scanning the fonts. The second is "...fontlists built". See the time between those two items. I said DEBUG everythingonly so you can focus on what else is going on and when the second messagehappens. I'm finding it gets quite a while in the log between the lastmessage before the "...font lists built" and that message.Or is this just a Windows issue?-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>It seems that the system console manager waits for the prepareFontLists() tocomplete and if a PC has hundreds of fonts this can take minutes. While theloop processes many fonts in a few milliseconds, some fonts for the sametests to see if a font looks like monospace, proportional, etc... can takeseconds. Now from the history, this part of the code hasn't changed in 6years.The problem is that startup doesn't finish because of this. So why does thesystem console manager need to wait for the font lists and why does themainline of startup have to wait for the system console manager?One thing that surprised me what that it was calculating the font features.I had thought that there would have been metainformation with the font thathave answered these questions.I'm suspecting that something in Windows has changed of late that impactedthis timing.            <small>From: Dave Heap &lt;dgheap@gm...&gt; - 2018-02-08 04:38:32</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/9E9782FE-D310-4D89-B90F-C01C63CD0E43%40gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>See below:&gt; On 8 Feb 2018, at 1:44 PM, Richard Dombrowski &lt;mgtd52usa@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; When adding a new loco to the roster, I see three different modes, direct, paged and Register.&gt; &gt; What's the difference?Direct mode the fastest method of reading CVs and is supported by almost all modern decoders and DCC systems. (It reads a CVs with 8 or so operations by basically asking if each bit in the CV is set, with a no-response timeout meaning No).Paged mode is much slower but is the only mode supported by some older decoders. (It can take up to 256 operations to read a CV as it basically asks; is it 0, is it 1,..., is it 255?  with a no-response timeout meaning No).Register mode is a very old mode that can only access a limited number of CVs. It is rarely used these day.&gt; &gt; I see it starts in Direct, and if the program doesn't get a response it switches to Paged.  ??See above. Tries the fastest mode first and swaps to the slower mode if it times out more than twice.&gt; &gt; And here's version 2 of the Introduction.&gt; &gt; Finally, what does JMRI stand for?  Joint Model Railroad Initiative perhapsJava Model Railroad Interface.&lt;<a href="https://sites.google.com/site/markgurries/home/about-mark-gurries/jmri-decoder-pro-history>" rel="nofollow">https://sites.google.com/site/markgurries/home/about-mark-gurries/jmri-decoder-pro-history&gt;</a>;Dave</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36216942/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Start of Decoder Pro Manual</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Richard Dombrowski &lt;mgtd52usa@ou...&gt; - 2018-02-06 02:33:24</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/DM5PR2201MB14170F4EB925D5A9AACC70D1A6FD0%40DM5PR2201MB1417.namprd22.prod.outlook.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Thanks for your responses, I will incorporate these changes.richSent from SurfaceFrom: Peter Ulvestad&lt;mailto:ulvestad@...&gt;Sent: ‎Saturday‎, ‎February‎ ‎3‎, ‎2018 ‎10‎:‎10‎ ‎PMTo: jmri-developers&lt;mailto:jmri-developers@...&gt;# 7 is wrong (or very incomplete).Writing 8 to CV 8 is not correct to reset every decoder brand, you would also need to use the single CV programmer to do it. The best way is to use the reset in every definition, click on reset in the main menu for that roster entry and select factory reset from the drop down menu followed by the appropriate item in the next window.#5 I personally wouldn't bother with. That is why I use JMRI to program AND to keep track of everything. You can export as csv file if you really wanted to but I wouldn't bother.Peter________________________________From: "Richard Dombrowski" &lt;mgtd52usa@...&gt;To: jmri-developers@...Sent: Saturday, 3 February, 2018 17:18:04Subject: [Jmri-developers] Start of Decoder Pro ManualThis is the first draft of an introduction to the manual.            <small>From: Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@al...&gt; - 2018-02-04 10:20:49</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/B8B1AA70-4290-4684-851C-70299C1BCC71%40alexandriasoftware.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Thank you.Randall Wood&gt; On Feb 4, 2018, at 00:37, Paul Bender &lt;paul.bender@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; On 02/03/2018 04:00 PM, Randall Wood wrote:&gt;&gt; When I run either `mvn test -Dtest=jmri.RunCucumberTest` or `ant test-single -Dtest.includes=jmri.RunCucumberTest`, the results are:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; 0 Scenarios&gt;&gt; 0 Steps&gt;&gt; 0m0.014s&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; How do I run just the cucumber tests?&gt; &gt; The default is to ignore anything labeled with the webtest tag, and all of the current tests are labeled that way.&gt; &gt; On the command line you can change the tags&gt; &gt; try running&gt; &gt; `mvn test -Dcucumber.options="--tags 'not @Ignore'" -Dtest=jmri.RunCucumberTest`&gt; &gt; or&gt; &gt; `mvn test -Dcucumber.options="--tags '@webtest'" -Dtest=jmri.RunCucumberTest`&gt; &gt; The "--tags..." option overrides the tags specified in jmri.RunCucumberTest.&gt; &gt; The first of the two commands mimics what travis does to actually run the scenarios.  Appveyor overrides the tag with an option in build.xml.&gt; &gt; There used to be another set of tests that were rendered invalid by a subsequent change to consisting support, so those were removed, and I haven't had time to add more.  The defaults are in place because I don't want to force people running the unit tests to have specific browsers installed.  (I'll eventually add the not Ignore tag to the default tags).&gt; &gt; The scenarios are also tagged with @firefox and @chrome, so you can restrict the running tests to a single browser.&gt; &gt; Paul&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36214961/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Run just the Cucumber tests</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Paul Bender &lt;paul.bender@ac...&gt; - 2018-02-04 05:37:41</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>On 02/03/2018 04:00 PM, Randall Wood wrote:&gt; When I run either `mvn test -Dtest=jmri.RunCucumberTest` or `ant test-single -Dtest.includes=jmri.RunCucumberTest`, the results are:&gt;&gt; 0 Scenarios&gt; 0 Steps&gt; 0m0.014s&gt;&gt; How do I run just the cucumber tests?The default is to ignore anything labeled with the webtest tag, and all of the current tests are labeled that way.On the command line you can change the tagstry running`mvn test -Dcucumber.options="--tags 'not @Ignore'" -Dtest=jmri.RunCucumberTest`or`mvn test -Dcucumber.options="--tags '@webtest'" -Dtest=jmri.RunCucumberTest`The "--tags..." option overrides the tags specified in jmri.RunCucumberTest.The first of the two commands mimics what travis does to actually run the scenarios.  Appveyor overrides the tag with an option in build.xml.There used to be another set of tests that were rendered invalid by a subsequent change to consisting support, so those were removed, and I haven't had time to add more.  The defaults are in place because I don't want to force people running the unit tests to have specific browsers installed.  (I'll eventually add the not Ignore tag to the default tags).The scenarios are also tagged with @firefox and @chrome, so you can restrict the running tests to a single browser.Paul</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36214898">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36214898/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Start of Decoder Pro Manual</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Peter Ulvestad &lt;ulvestad@te...&gt; - 2018-02-04 03:10:11</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/251761853.36090528.1517713803169.JavaMail.zimbra%40mailid.telus.net/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre># 7 is wrong (or very incomplete). Writing 8 to CV 8 is not correct to reset every decoder brand, you would also need to use the single CV programmer to do it. The best way is to use the reset in every definition, click on reset in the main menu for that roster entry and select factory reset from the drop down menu followed by the appropriate item in the next window. #5 I personally wouldn't bother with. That is why I use JMRI to program AND to keep track of everything. You can export as csv file if you really wanted to but I wouldn't bother. Peter From: "Richard Dombrowski" &lt;mgtd52usa@...&gt; To: jmri-developers@... Sent: Saturday, 3 February, 2018 17:18:04 Subject: [Jmri-developers] Start of Decoder Pro Manual This is the first draft of an introduction to the manual. Next I will be reading the User's Guide and the Short Tour. I already have some initial thoughts but I have to put them on paper first, type them up and then forward to the group.          <td class="email-body"><pre>Thanks!The remote settings now look good.  One last problem to sort out: Why "git branch --list -vv MRCS-Metrics” didn’t show _anything_. I copied that branch name from your earlier email. Is that not correct?  You should see something like either (note these are my branches; _all_ the details will differ for you)% git branch --list -vv temp-label-changed-preference-panes  temp-label-changed-preference-panes 1529342d5a share iconor ideally it will have an link in brackets like:% git branch --list -vv bj-abstractmanager-performance* bj-abstractmanager-performance 3e0904c7a7 [origin/bj-abstractmanager-performance] refactor to add lower base classSo please double-check the branch name (“git branch” will list all) and try the "git branch --list -vv MRCS-Metrics” command with the correct one if it’s different, or let me know that it really is correct and not listing anything.Bob&gt;          <td class="email-body"><pre>Sounds good, I'll start soon after I read what has been written and my basement heats up.Sent from SurfaceFrom: Randall Wood&lt;mailto:randall.h.wood@...&gt;Sent: ‎Thursday‎, ‎February‎ ‎1‎, ‎2018 ‎8‎:‎17‎ ‎PMTo: jmri-developers&lt;mailto:jmri-developers@...&gt;I would recommend you just openly ask questions on this list.Since you have LibreOffice, you can save your manual using the “docbook” format (its under File-&gt;Save As…). This is an XML format that we can then automatically process into HTML for the web site, PDFs to download, or HTML for the help content (which is subtly different than the HTML for the web site), and other formats.Randall WoodJMRI Developer - <a href="http://jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org</a>Alexandria Software - <a href="http://alexandriasoftware.com" rel="nofollow">http://alexandriasoftware.com</a>Northern Virginia NTRAK - <a href="http://nvntrak.org" rel="nofollow">http://nvntrak.org</a>On Feb 1, 2018, at 20:04, Richard Dombrowski &lt;mgtd52usa@...&lt;mailto:mgtd52usa@...&gt;&gt; wrote:I wish to attempt to write a manual for Decoder Pro. Dave Heap advised me to reach out to the development team. My initial thought is to first, link up with a ‘mentor’ and then to forward screenshots with my interpretations of the commands and questions concerning the commands I do not understand. Or you may chose to respond individually rather than have a mentor. Whatever works is fine with me. Then I would write an explanation of each tab in each window for approval. I will have to investigate if I can write an .xml file. I use Libra Office. I hope to learn more about this detailed program and possibly mitigate the numerous postings concerning users problems. So I intend to make the manual quite basic.RichSent from Surface------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org&lt;<a href="http://slashdot.org/>" rel="nofollow">http://slashdot.org/&gt;</a>;! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...&lt;mailto:Jmri-developers@...&gt;<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

           <small>From: Richard Dombrowski &lt;mgtd52usa@ou...&gt; - 2018-02-02 18:58:23</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/DM5PR2201MB1417B71607E07B68966D5880A6F90%40DM5PR2201MB1417.namprd22.prod.outlook.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Great idea, when we were in the restaurant business, (now retired) each section of our policies was another file due to many changes.  I have found the operations manual to be excellent, I intend to concentrate on Decoder Pro.RichSent from SurfaceFrom: Ken Cameron&lt;mailto:kcameron@...&gt;Sent: ‎Friday‎, ‎February‎ ‎2‎, ‎2018 ‎9‎:‎23‎ ‎AMTo: jmri-developers&lt;mailto:jmri-developers@...&gt;My two bits about a manual. First, review what has been written before.Second, consider making it modular. Trying to write an all-in-one manual isa huge effort. I think that is what bogged down some of the prior writers.The other reason for considering modular writing is that the code getsupdated the same way. So one section might need changing this year but theother parts are fine. This way you can focus your efforts better.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>------------------------------------------------------------------------------Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's mostengaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>_______________________________________________Jmri-developers mailing listJmri-developers@...<a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>My two bits about a manual. First, review what has been written before.Second, consider making it modular. Trying to write an all-in-one manual isa huge effort. I think that is what bogged down some of the prior writers.The other reason for considering modular writing is that the code getsupdated the same way. So one section might need changing this year but theother parts are fine. This way you can focus your efforts better.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Hi,  An optional suggestion: One of the ways we use to reduce the overheadcaused by GUI refresh requests was to insert a 1 second trap routine at thepoint the incoming refresh messages are received by the display updateservice routine. This trap would start a 1 second time and begin buildingan aggregated refresh request for each message that  arrived  during  thatperiod. Then at the end of 1 second it would send it on to the displayupdate service and throwaway the incoming collection it had aggregated. Ifmore were coming in, it would start another 1 second period of aggregationor if not just idle and wait for more. This really reduced the displayupdate interference and the human using the display never even noticed.Just a possible  option,=gerry=On Wed, Jan 31, 2018 at 11:38 PM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Bob,&gt;&gt; From that description, one place I've seen lots of activity is the sensor&gt; and turnout table, the latter in particular if the feedback is displayed.&gt; Normal case, the status (sensor: active/inactive, turnout: double that for&gt; the feedback). Now picture that with a bunch of turnouts related to signals&gt; and how many might change in the 20-30 lines on the screen (for a&gt; signal-turnout, the feedback should only be following the command, but&gt; still&gt; a second field updating on that line) when one signal cascades it's change&gt; to the others in advance.&gt;&gt; Yes if something got changed poorly, this could cascade to a huge amount of&gt; action.&gt;&gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>On Wed, Jan 31, 2018 at 12:45 PM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; If a JTable implementation is coded right, the only activity is due to&gt; either changes (and most of the columns only change when the user changes&gt; them) or due to having to redraw something due to a screen layout change:&gt; Another window moved off the table &amp; uncovers it, or table resized or&gt; scrolled.  That should be really efficient. It doesn’t scale as N*X.&gt;&gt; But it’s possible to code the JMRI-specific part of the rendering badly,&gt; so that each small bit of activity is expensive.  That seems to be what’s&gt; happening here.&gt;I agree.I have in the meantime another repro case. If you can get to thinking aboutcaching etc this weekend it would be worth for you to try this as well incase a common fix can solve both:- open panelpro. do not load any XML file yet- open the turnouts table- now load the panel file I sent (with a few k turnouts and a few k sensors)there will be similar slowness. I have observed a problem related toloading last year in the summer but at that time there was some relativelyharmless fix to it.thanks,Balazs&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt; On Jan 31, 2018, at 8:02 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; This thread has brought up a worry about the tables. It seems that as we&gt; add&gt; &gt; columns, that increases the potential workload by N*X, N - number of&gt; &gt; entries, X - number of new columns being displayed. If much is going on,&gt; &gt; that could be a lot of things updating all the time. The concept of the&gt; edit&gt; &gt; button being the right choice for some items instead of adding columns&gt; &gt; should be kept in mind. Just because some option/data is added to an&gt; element&gt; &gt; doesn't mean it is meaningful as a column.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; Now if the model behind the table is sensible, we might only have the&gt; issue&gt; &gt; of the visible N that have changes to deal with. The rest shouldn't&gt; impact&gt; &gt; the UI at all. At least that's what I thought the idea was meaning to do.&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; &gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; &gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; &gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; &gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; &gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; &gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; &gt; _______________________________________________&gt; &gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; &gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; &gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;&gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36211686/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Performance regression in 4.11.2 in turnout table pagination</a></b>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>If a JTable implementation is coded right, the only activity is due to either changes (and most of the columns only change when the user changes them) or due to having to redraw something due to a screen layout change:  Another window moved off the table &amp; uncovers it, or table resized or scrolled.  That should be really efficient. It doesn’t scale as N*X.But it’s possible to code the JMRI-specific part of the rendering badly, so that each small bit of activity is expensive.  That seems to be what’s happening here.Bob&gt; On Jan 31, 2018, at 8:02 AM, Ken Cameron &lt;kcameron@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; This thread has brought up a worry about the tables. It seems that as we add&gt; columns, that increases the potential workload by N*X, N - number of&gt; entries, X - number of new columns being displayed. If much is going on,&gt; that could be a lot of things updating all the time. The concept of the edit&gt; button being the right choice for some items instead of adding columns&gt; should be kept in mind. Just because some option/data is added to an element&gt; doesn't mean it is meaningful as a column.&gt; &gt; Now if the model behind the table is sensible, we might only have the issue&gt; of the visible N that have changes to deal with. The rest shouldn't impact&gt; the UI at all. At least that's what I thought the idea was meaning to do.&gt; &gt; -Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team&gt; <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a>&gt; <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a>&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>This thread has brought up a worry about the tables. It seems that as we addcolumns, that increases the potential workload by N*X, N - number ofentries, X - number of new columns being displayed. If much is going on,that could be a lot of things updating all the time. The concept of the editbutton being the right choice for some items instead of adding columnsshould be kept in mind. Just because some option/data is added to an elementdoesn't mean it is meaningful as a column.Now if the model behind the table is sensible, we might only have the issueof the visible N that have changes to deal with. The rest shouldn't impactthe UI at all. At least that's what I thought the idea was meaning to do.-Ken Cameron, Member JMRI Dev Team <a href="http://www.jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.jmri.org</a> <a href="http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.fingerlakeslivesteamers.org</a> <a href="http://www.cnymod.com" rel="nofollow">http://www.cnymod.com</a> <a href="http://www.syracusemodelrr.org" rel="nofollow">http://www.syracusemodelrr.org</a></pre></td>

      <table id="msg36211261">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36211261/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Performance regression in 4.11.2 in turnout table pagination</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-01-31 15:48:30</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>I don’t see that as an Error log call anywhere.  The one that’s debug-leve in 4.11.2 (the final tag) is in the loadRenderEditMaps call within an anonymous class created by makeJTable (in the TurnoutTableAction class).  It gets invoked in the rendering sequence as part of getRenderer(row, column).The getRenderer code there seems to rebuild the render maps if i.e. rendererMapSensor1.get(t) returns null (while displaying the SENSOR1COL).  Not sure why that should be happening repeatedly, though. I would have thought that was an initialization step.Bob&gt; On Jan 31, 2018, at 7:12 AM, Balazs Racz &lt;balazs.racz@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; 2018-01-31 07:10:08,565 beantable.TurnoutTableAction          ERROR - initialize for Turnout "MT02.01.57.00.00.6C.00.3C;02.01.57.00.00.6C.00.3D" Sensor "null" [AWT-EventQueue-0]--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Here’s a clue:     [java] "AWT-EventQueue-0" #14 prio=6 os_prio=31 tid=0x00007fca99336000 nid=0x12d03 runnable [0x00007000025bf000]     [java]    java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE     [java] 	at jmri.util.AlphanumComparator.compare(AlphanumComparator.java:103)     [java] 	at jmri.util.SystemNameComparator.compare(SystemNameComparator.java:37) 	at java.util.TreeSet.addAll(TreeSet.java:312)     [java] 	at jmri.managers.AbstractProxyManager.lambda$getSystemNameArray$69(AbstractProxyManager.java:397)     [java] 	at
