jmri.util.swing.JmriBeanComboBox.getDisplayList(JmriBeanComboBox.java:145)     [java] 	at jmri.util.swing.JmriBeanComboBox.updateComboBox(JmriBeanComboBox.java:122)     [java] 	at jmri.util.swing.JmriBeanComboBox.setSelectedBean(JmriBeanComboBox.java:413)     [java] 	at jmri.jmrit.beantable.TurnoutTableAction$1$4.getRenderer(TurnoutTableAction.java:750)     [java] 	at jmri.jmrit.beantable.TurnoutTableAction$1$4.getCellRenderer(TurnoutTableAction.java:713)     [java] 	at javax.swing.plaf.basic.BasicTableUI.paintCell(BasicTableUI.java:2113)     [java] 	at javax.swing.plaf.basic.BasicTableUI.paintCells(BasicTableUI.java:2016)     [java] 	at javax.swing.plaf.basic.BasicTableUI.paint(BasicTableUI.java:1812)     [java] 	at javax.swing.plaf.ComponentUI.update(ComponentUI.java:161)and a related one:     [java] 	at java.util.ComparableTimSort.mergeLo(ComparableTimSort.java:693)     [java] 	at java.util.ComparableTimSort.mergeAt(ComparableTimSort.java:477)     [java] 	at java.util.ComparableTimSort.mergeCollapse(ComparableTimSort.java:400)     [java] 	at java.util.ComparableTimSort.sort(ComparableTimSort.java:209)     [java] 	at java.util.Arrays.sort(Arrays.java:1312)     [java] 	at java.util.Arrays.sort(Arrays.java:1506)     [java] 	at java.util.ArrayList.sort(ArrayList.java:1454)     [java] 	at jmri.managers.AbstractManager.getSystemNameList(AbstractManager.java:293)     [java] 	at jmri.managers.AbstractProxyManager.lambda$getSystemNameArray$69(AbstractProxyManager.java:397)     [java] 	at jmri.managers.AbstractProxyManager$$Lambda$128/389067726.accept(Unknown Source)     [java] 	at java.util.ArrayList$ArrayListSpliterator.forEachRemaining(ArrayList.java:1374)     [java] 	at java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline$Head.forEach(ReferencePipeline.java:580)     [java] 	at jmri.managers.AbstractProxyManager.getSystemNameArray(AbstractProxyManager.java:396)     [java] 	at jmri.util.swing.JmriBeanComboBox.getDisplayList(JmriBeanComboBox.java:145)     [java] 	at jmri.util.swing.JmriBeanComboBox.updateComboBox(JmriBeanComboBox.java:122)     [java] 	at jmri.util.swing.JmriBeanComboBox.setSelectedBean(JmriBeanComboBox.java:413)     [java] 	at jmri.jmrit.beantable.TurnoutTableAction$BeanBoxRenderer.getTableCellRendererComponent(TurnoutTableAction.java:1848)     [java] 	at javax.swing.JTable.prepareRenderer(JTable.java:5723)     [java] 	at javax.swing.plaf.basic.BasicTableUI.paintCell(BasicTableUI.java:2114)It looks like it’s spending a lot of time dealing with an entire list of NamedBeans from getSystemNameList and getSystemNameArray operations.  Those have been in sort-order for a while, so I don’t think that’s the cause of the slow-down by itself.  There might be a scaling issue in the changes to AbstractProxyManager to properly handle system name strings. In particular, the getNamedBeanList() method (which underlies getSystemNameList() and getSystemNameArray() ) does a bunch of work each time it’s called.  If it’s being called for e.g. each turnout’s feedback sensors (i.e. every time) that can easily get out of hand on a large-N layout.  So you may be looking for the combination of- too much combinatoric work in getSystemNameList or similar- invoked too often in JmriBeanComboBox- which changes to the table redisplay are invoking too oftenYou might be able to find that last one with git bisect on your additions to the table; the other two were latent, and it’d be harder to disentangle them that way.I can look at the first one this weekend.  It shouldn’t be too hard to cache those results (I _think_, but haven’t confirmed, that it can listen to the underlying managers to invalidate the cache)Bob&gt; On Jan 30, 2018, at 9:58 PM, Balazs Racz &lt;balazs.racz@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Hey,&gt; &gt; I have tried to use 4.11.2 at David Parks' layout and got into some serious slowness when trying to scroll in the Turnouts table.&gt; I am attaching the XML file that produces the problem. I stripped away everything to the minimum needed to produce the problem. Here are the ingredients:&gt; - a lot of turnouts&gt; - a lot of OpenLCB sensors&gt; - open the panel file from <a href="https://sites.google.com/site/balazsracz/jmri-1/cw-turnouts-and-sensors.xml?attredirects=0&amp;d=1" rel="nofollow">https://sites.google.com/site/balazsracz/jmri-1/cw-turnouts-and-sensors.xml?attredirects=0&amp;d=1</a> (sorry too big to attach)&gt; - open the turnouts table&gt; - tick "show feedback information" checkbox in the bottom (if it is not checked the problem goes away)&gt; - try to scroll down or up, page down/page up or resize the window&gt; &gt; What I see is that it takes about 30 CPU-seconds to scroll one page down. During these 30 seconds JMRI is unresponsive to any UI action, so the AWT thread seems to be blocked by some computation.&gt; &gt; Does anyone know what changed between 4.11.2 and 4.11.1 that might have caused this slowness?&gt; --Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36211190/">Re: [Jmri-developers] what to do with JmriExceptions</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@ma...&gt; - 2018-01-31 14:49:14</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>&gt; On Jan 30, 2018, at 8:01 PM, Balazs Racz &lt;balazs.racz@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I'm writing some swing code that will call functions on JMRI objects that throw JmriException (NamedBean.setState <a href="http://jmri.org/JavaDoc/doc/jmri/NamedBean.html#setState-int" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/JavaDoc/doc/jmri/NamedBean.html#setState-int</a>- )&gt; &gt; What is the procedure to handle the JmriException that gets thrown? Usually when I am doing something like an ActionListener from a Button, I can't throw it, so I need some form of handling.Lots of places just log it, and then stop doing whatever they were attempting to do.  That’s a bit unfriendly, because somebody might be e.g. repeatedly mashing a button trying to get something to happen. Most people don’t look in the log.  But the usual causes are due to problems with input, and I guess people expect the user to eventually figure that out.	throw new JmriException("Hardware Address passed should be a number”); 	throw new JmriException("Unable to convert " + curAddress + " to a valid Hardware Address”);I’ve recently started handling similar errors as:                log.error("User Name \"{}\" is already in use", nam);                if (!GraphicsEnvironment.isHeadless()) {                    String msg = Bundle.getMessage("WarningUserName", new Object[]{("" + nam)});                    JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(null, msg,                            Bundle.getMessage("WarningTitle"),                            JOptionPane.ERROR_MESSAGE);                }                return false;(The “return false” is basically “give up and end operation”)  This handles both headless and graphical uses reasonably _but_ it’s a pain to have to create a lot of internationalized warnings (though that might be inevitable) and it’s hard to do it automatically from a JmriException that might have multiple causes.AFAIK, JmriException itself isn’t internationalized:  When you ask for getLocalizedMessage, you’re going to get the default English getMessage() text.   What might be good is something like:                log.error(“Exception: {}”, ex);                if (!GraphicsEnvironment.isHeadless()) {                    String msg = Bundle.getMessage("Warning", new Object[]{("" + nam)});                    JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(null, msg,                            ex.getLocalizedMessage,                            JOptionPane.ERROR_MESSAGE);                }                return false;(syntax not checked) then we could, as time is available (i.e. slowly), I18N the more-common "new JmriException” lines.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table id="msg36210919">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header">

           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36210919/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Performance regression in 4.11.2 in turnout table pagination</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@al...&gt; - 2018-01-31 10:48:44</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/5A1698AE-8160-4979-9926-F3D011326A10%40alexandriasoftware.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Judging from <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/compare/v4.11.1...v4.11.2" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/compare/v4.11.1...v4.11.2</a> &lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/compare/v4.11.1...v4.11.2>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/compare/v4.11.1...v4.11.2&gt;</a>;, GitHub user balazsracz added support for displaying Turnout properties and for allowing users to “reset” the turnout state between those releases.Randall WoodJMRI Developer - <a href="http://jmri.org" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org</a>Alexandria Software - <a href="http://alexandriasoftware.com" rel="nofollow">http://alexandriasoftware.com</a>Northern Virginia NTRAK - <a href="http://nvntrak.org" rel="nofollow">http://nvntrak.org</a>&gt; On Jan 31, 2018, at 00:58, Balazs Racz &lt;balazs.racz@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Hey,&gt; &gt; I have tried to use 4.11.2 at David Parks' layout and got into some serious slowness when trying to scroll in the Turnouts table.&gt; I am attaching the XML file that produces the problem. I stripped away everything to the minimum needed to produce the problem. Here are the ingredients:&gt; - a lot of turnouts&gt; - a lot of OpenLCB sensors&gt; - open the panel file from <a href="https://sites.google.com/site/balazsracz/jmri-1/cw-turnouts-and-sensors.xml?attredirects=0&amp;d=1" rel="nofollow">https://sites.google.com/site/balazsracz/jmri-1/cw-turnouts-and-sensors.xml?attredirects=0&amp;d=1</a> &lt;<a href="https://sites.google.com/site/balazsracz/jmri-1/cw-turnouts-and-sensors.xml?attredirects=0&amp;d=1>" rel="nofollow">https://sites.google.com/site/balazsracz/jmri-1/cw-turnouts-and-sensors.xml?attredirects=0&amp;d=1&gt;</a>; (sorry too big to attach)&gt; - open the turnouts table&gt; - tick "show feedback information" checkbox in the bottom (if it is not checked the problem goes away)&gt; - try to scroll down or up, page down/page up or resize the window&gt; &gt; What I see is that it takes about 30 CPU-seconds to scroll one page down. During these 30 seconds JMRI is unresponsive to any UI action, so the AWT thread seems to be blocked by some computation.&gt; &gt; Does anyone know what changed between 4.11.2 and 4.11.1 that might have caused this slowness?&gt; &gt; thanks,&gt; Balazs&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Sorry, misunderstood.A couple things you could do, depending on what’s needed.  If you just need the blocks, layoutblocks, etc, but not the actual graphical panel, you could remove the &lt;LayoutEditor&gt; element from your XML file.  If you do need to load and show the panel, you can close it after it’s no longer needed with this snippet (From java/test/jmri/jmrit/display/layoutEditor/LayoutEditorWindowTest.java, which also shows how to load a sample file):	// Find new window by name (should be more distinctive, comes from sample file)        EditorFrameOperator to = new EditorFrameOperator("My Layout");        // It's up at this point, and can be manipulated        // Ask to close window        to.closeFrameWithConfirmations();The EditorFrameOperator constructor will wait until it finds that Frame, and the proceed.  That’s what the 2nd comment means.Bob&gt; On Jan 29, 2018, at 9:44 PM, Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; There are the two LE windows left that create warnings which appears to be a common occurrence for many tests.  I was hoping that I overlooked some cleanup process. &gt; &gt; Dave Sand &gt; &gt; ----- Original message -----&gt; From: Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Entry/Exit Test Project&gt; Date: Mon, 29 Jan 2018 21:22:07 -0800&gt; &gt; Not certain I’m answering the right question, but if you load the file in @Before or the start of each test, all you have to do at the end is to reset the InstanceManager. Nothing of the file is left around except what’s in InstanceManager.&gt; &gt; Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Not certain I’m answering the right question, but if you load the file in @Before or the start of each test, all you have to do at the end is to reset the InstanceManager. Nothing of the file is left around except what’s in InstanceManager. Bob&gt; On Jan 29, 2018, at 9:14 PM, Dave Sand &lt;dave@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I am going to be updating and expanding the tests for the Entry/Exit facility.&gt; &gt; Since NX relies on LayoutEditor panels, I have developed a test panel XML file that contains two panels and is partially configured to enable testing various NX activities without having to recreate the LE setup each time.&gt; &gt; Ideally the xml file would be loaded at the beginning of each class test and disposed after all of the tests for that class have been run.  I realize that there is no sequence to tests so they will need to not interfere with each other.&gt; &gt; I have searched the test code but I have not been able to find a good example.&gt; &gt; Dave Sand&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I am going to be updating and expanding the tests for the Entry/Exit facility.Since NX relies on LayoutEditor panels, I have developed a test panel XML file that contains two panels and is partially configured to enable testing various NX activities without having to recreate the LE setup each time.Ideally the xml file would be loaded at the beginning of each class test and disposed after all of the tests for that class have been run.  I realize that there is no sequence to tests so they will need to not interfere with each other.I have searched the test code but I have not been able to find a good example.Dave Sand</pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>This also works, even with slashes (but no .java). It’’s convenient for cut&amp;pasting in the class you want from e.g. a find command../runtest.csh jmri/jmrix/AbstractThrottleTestBob&gt; On Jan 29, 2018, at 8:53 AM, Steve Rawlinson &lt;steve@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; What am I doing wrong here?&gt; &gt; seafury[~/IdeaProjects/JMRI]$ ant -Djavac.includes=jmri/jmrix/AbstractThrottleTest.java -Dtest.includes=jmri/jmrix/AbstractThrottleTest.java  test-single&gt; Buildfile: /Users/steve/IdeaProjects/JMRI/build.xml&gt; &gt; [...]&gt; &gt; runtime-library-selection:&gt;     [echo] arch.lib.path /Users/steve/IdeaProjects/JMRI/lib/macosx/x86_64:/Users/steve/IdeaProjects/JMRI/lib/macosx&gt; &gt; test-single:&gt;    [junit] Running jmri/jmrix/AbstractThrottleTest.javaTest&gt;    [junit] Testsuite: jmri/jmrix/AbstractThrottleTest.javaTest&gt;    [junit] Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 0 sec&gt;    [junit] Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 0 sec&gt;    [junit]&gt;    [junit] Null Test:  Caused an ERROR&gt;    [junit] jmri/jmrix/AbstractThrottleTest.javaTest&gt;    [junit] java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: jmri/jmrix/AbstractThrottleTest.javaTest&gt;    [junit]     at java.lang.Class.forName0(Native Method)&gt;    [junit]     at java.lang.Class.forName(Class.java:264)&gt;    [junit]&gt;    [junit]&gt;    [junit] Test jmri/jmrix/AbstractThrottleTest.javaTest FAILED&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>On 01/26/2018 03:38 PM, Andrew Crosland wrote:&gt; Adding a call to instance.dispose() in the teardown() method of &gt; DCCppThrottleTest.java removes the 140+ timers and the thread count &gt; goes down by a corresponding amount.if you look at <a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/pull/4818" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/pull/4818</a> you'll note that I've removed the timer altogether from DCCppThrottle.That particular timer was in place because the DCCpp code was copied from the lenz code, and a few tweaks made, but the irrelevant parts were not completely cleaned up.  The in the DCCpp code, the timer actually never caused any data to be sent to either the command station or the user interface because DCCpp doesn't support the concept this is used for in the Lenz throttle.Paul</pre></td>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Adding a call to instance.dispose() in the teardown() method of DCCppThrottleTest.java removes the 140+ timers and the thread count goes down by a corresponding amount.A lot of the 2000+ threads seem to be due to open lcb tests. Threads are left in the waiting state:"openlcb-datagram-queue" prio=5 tid=4936 WAITING     at sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)     at java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.park(LockSupport.java:175)     at java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject.await(AbstractQueuedSynchronizer.java:2039)        Local Variable: java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$Node#507        Local Variable: java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject#6289     at java.util.concurrent.LinkedBlockingQueue.take(LinkedBlockingQueue.java:442)        Local Variable: java.util.concurrent.locks.ReentrantLock#21230        Local Variable: java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicInteger#3140        Local Variable: java.util.concurrent.LinkedBlockingQueue#3121     at org.openlcb.implementations.DatagramMeteringBuffer$Consumer.run(DatagramMeteringBuffer.java:213)        Local Variable: org.openlcb.implementations.DatagramMeteringBuffer$Consumer#93     at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)A lot of other timer threads seem to be associated with these.Andrew------ Original Message ------From: "Bob Jacobsen" &lt;jacobsen@...&gt;To: "Andrew Crosland" &lt;andrew@...&gt;; "Discussions between JMRI developers" &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Sent: 25/01/2018 20:43:34Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Curious test behavior - extra unneeded invocations of setup()&gt;There are a couple dozen places in the code (including a couple I &gt;wrote) that treat java.util.Timer objects as throw-aways: create, have &gt;it fire, done. But they’re not like that. They’re heavyweight objects &gt;that continue to exist and expect to be given more work.&gt;&gt;They need to be cancel’d when done. But instead of doing that, it would &gt;be better to switch those calls to jmri.util.Threading calls. That &gt;centralizes their management while simplifying the code.&gt;&gt;Bob&gt;&gt;&gt;On Jan 25, 2018, at 11:54 AM, Andrew Crosland &lt;andrew@...&gt; &gt;&gt;wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;I may be misinterpreting what's going on, but you can see in the &gt;&gt;attached screenshot of live threads that there are some DCC4PC Sensor &gt;&gt;Poll threads that do not terminate.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;Then a lot of timers are created by dccpp. Looking at the heap dump &gt;&gt;they seem to be associated with dccpp throttles:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;"Timer-79" prio=5 tid=831 TIMED_WAITING&gt;&gt;    at java.lang.Object.wait(Native Method)&gt;&gt;    at java.util.TimerThread.mainLoop(Timer.java:552)&gt;&gt;       Local Variable: jmri.jmrix.dccpp.DCCppThrottle$1#141&gt;&gt;    at java.util.TimerThread.run(Timer.java:505)&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;There are 140+ instances of DCCppThrottle left after all dccpp tests &gt;&gt;have finished.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;Andrew&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;------ Original Message ------&gt;&gt;From: "Dave Heap" &lt;dgheap@...&gt;&gt;&gt;To: "Andrew Crosland" &lt;andrew@...&gt;; "Discussions between &gt;&gt;JMRI developers" &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt;Sent: 25/01/2018 19:14:34&gt;&gt;Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Curious test behavior - extra unneeded &gt;&gt;invocations of setup()&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;Screenshots can be embedded on messages to this list.&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;Sent from my iPad&gt;&gt;&gt;--&gt;&gt;&gt;Dave&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;On 26 Jan 2018, at 4:33 AM, Andrew Crosland &lt;andrew@...&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;I don't think I can add attachments here, but I have a few peoples &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;direct e-mail addresses if a screen shot would be of interest.&gt;&gt;&lt;2brezl3k.png&gt;&gt;&gt;------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt;Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt;engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org!          <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36205247/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Curious test behavior - extra unneeded invocations of setup()</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Paul Bender &lt;paul.bender@ac...&gt; - 2018-01-26 05:47:59</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>On 01/25/2018 02:44 AM, Bob Jacobsen wrote:&gt; I don’t understand why resetWindows() should be that slow, but I &gt; haven’t looked at it in detail. &lt;snip&gt;&gt; If not, what do people thing about moving it to an @AfterClass method, &gt; so it’s only done once per class instead of per test?  Yes, that does &gt; reduce the independence of the CI tests, but we’re also running &gt; fully-independent tests in Jenkins once a day.The issue I have with moving the that is if you are running two consecutive tests that use the same window, the second test is likely to get a dirty version of the window and may very well fail because the test must be written from the point of view of a clean slate, but a dirty window isn't.Unfortunately, when you ask Jemmy to find a window by name, if there are two of them with the same name, we don't know which one Jemmy will give us.  The same basic issue exists with JFCUnit (which we basically no longer use) and with the support JmriJFrame has for finding frames.This applies both to things we can control within the test (if we create something directly, we can usually name it) and to frames created by the class under test (dialogs, for example) and it really can cause a lot of test issues.Paul</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I haven’t made much progress on understanding "approximately one second (for) JunitJtil.resetWindows()” because I’m not able to consistently reproduce that.  Any suggestions on where to look?I did find one occurrence of a long delay (2+ seconds) that was due to the AWT/Swing thread being locked. Unfortunately, it unlocked and ran before I thought to grab a complete dump, so I don’t know exactly what was going on. I haven’t seen it occur since.That perhaps points to a class of possible causes for delays in resetWindows():  The work of resetWindows is on the AWT/Swing thread (which is should be), so that if something constrains the AWT/Swing thread the close can be delayed.  But the problem isn’t the resetWindows, it’s whatever is constraining the thread.Bob--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36204961/">[Jmri-developers] SC Warrant help file invisible?</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: dcc2 &lt;dcc2@eb...&gt; - 2018-01-25 21:34:10</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/A8DCD690-C4BC-41F1-9D5C-A450B9418D26%40ebroerse.nl/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>While studying the package.jmri.jmrit.logix. help on line, I came across this page on Signal Controlled Warrants: <a href="http://jmri.org/help/en/package/jmri/jmrit/logix/SCWarrant.shtml" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/help/en/package/jmri/jmrit/logix/SCWarrant.shtml</a> &lt;<a href="http://jmri.org/help/en/package/jmri/jmrit/logix/SCWarrant.shtml>" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/help/en/package/jmri/jmrit/logix/SCWarrant.shtml&gt;</a>;The file was created in 2016 and does also show up when opening the enclosing folder in a browser at <a href="http://jmri.org/help/en/package/jmri/jmrit/logix/" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/help/en/package/jmri/jmrit/logix/</a> &lt;<a href="http://jmri.org/help/en/package/jmri/jmrit/logix/>" rel="nofollow">http://jmri.org/help/en/package/jmri/jmrit/logix/&gt;</a>;However, it’s not visible in GitHub as part of JMRI/JMRI HEAD of  master- Can someone explain this, and perhaps point me the original?- Are the contents still current? Is it supposed to be identical to the Fast Reacting Warrant type?Egbert</pre></td>

      <table id="msg36204912">
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36204912/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Subtypes of Turnouts (was Re: Additions to Turnout Table controls</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Balazs Racz &lt;balazs.racz@gm...&gt; - 2018-01-25 20:45:50</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/CACVivUwpmvCm%2BGFFR-oEdtnxmbxN6KEioaDFbe7c0f6WKu0YRw%40mail.gmail.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>Some answers below based on how I did the configurability of openlcbturnouts.On Sat, Jan 20, 2018 at 5:53 PM, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; Bob M raised the question of different subtypes of turnouts, for example&gt; ones that send via LocoNet and/or DCC messages.&gt;&gt; I think it’s useful to distinguish between permanent subtypes and&gt; temporary settings.&gt;&gt; A system can provide different implementations; inside the system, they’re&gt; different types with different behaviors.  They can be created via&gt; different system names (e.g. if the name is PTB1 you get a different type&gt; than if create PTZ1), via configuration of the system itself, etc.    With&gt; these, there’s no runtime option that changes from one behavior to another,&gt; hence the code is much simpler.&gt;There is one major difference between system name and property / runoptionbased configuration.- the system name is available at the constructor time- properties are changed by the user on the fly; also when a panel XML isloaded, the properties are loaded later than the namedbean objects arecreated.This difference can be worked around (see here&lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/configurexml/OlcbTurnoutManagerXml.java#L41>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/configurexml/OlcbTurnoutManagerXml.java#L41&gt;</a>;andhere&lt;<a href="https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbTurnoutManager.java#L84>" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/JMRI/JMRI/blob/master/java/src/jmri/jmrix/openlcb/OlcbTurnoutManager.java#L84&gt;</a>;)but it's ugly code.&gt;&gt; Or you can have runtime options that change the behavior.  “Invert” is a&gt; good example of this.  We don’t have separate types for that you define LT1&gt; and LT1bar, you just change a run time option.&gt;&gt; (This is made more complicated by the “TurnoutOperations” facility, which&gt; can be system-specific, but I think that’s a wrong way to go in the long&gt; run)&gt;&gt; The examples we’ve been talking about are invert-like, in that you might&gt; want to try them one way or the other on your layout.  Having an option&gt; that allows you to select that makes sense to me:  Having to create an&gt; entirely new Turnout and change over the configuration to use that new one&gt; is too heavyweight.&gt;&gt; So how to add options?  I think Balazs is right that using the (already&gt; present) bean properties is a good approach. They’re flexible, in that a&gt; property like “WorkFaster” can be added to one turnout or type of turnout&gt; easily, without having it have to be known elsewhere.&gt;&gt; But how to present them in the GUI?  That raises some subquestions:&gt;&gt; 1) Who decides which properties to present in the BeanTable?  It’s a&gt; general facility, can be used for multiple purposes, not all of which make&gt; sense to appear in the TurnoutTable (one of the layouts I maintain uses it&gt; on SignalHeads for a purpose that shouldn’t be in the table and shouldn’t&gt; be persisted); where is it recorded what appears in the table?&gt;For OpenLCB, it was the OlcbTurnoutManager that decided which properties toshow in the BeanTable by exporting those two withNamedBeanPropertyDescriptors.Note that these columns will not show by default -- the user has to click acheckbox in the bottom to show system specific properties.&gt; 2) Ditto for persistence.&gt;By default all NamedBean setProperty/getProperty values are persisted bythe base class of the ConfigurationManagerXml. The code author does nothave to do anything to make this happen.&gt;&gt; 3) There’s a localization issue for both the property name and the&gt; property content.&gt;For the name, my proposal was to make the NamedBeanPropertyDescriptorreturn the localized string for the column name. I'd like to also add ahelp text to show for the ToolTip but that's hard. Since the expectation isthat these are localized, they should be coming from the Bundle of thespecific manager class, e.g. OlcbTurnoutManager.For the value, it's harder. Boolean is a simple case, because only acheckbox is needed. If we want something like a JComboBox then we're introuble, because there is no general facility today. Furthermore, it'sdifficult because the Manager from jmri.jmrix creates theNamedBeanPropertyDescriptor classes, but it's not acceptable to have swingcode in the manager to define a TableCellRenderer (btw is this statementtrue?); neither is there access cross-package to the jmti.jmrit.beantablepackage where there are some default renderers. Right now thesystem-specific column facility only works for types for which the defaultrenderer is okay (Boolean definitely and maybe Integer but I haven't tried).&gt;&gt; So, although I think it’s fine to _control_ the turnout with properties, I&gt; think that the person who programs that capability should also provide an&gt; plugin for the table that presents and allows editing (as appropriate) of&gt; those properties.&gt;It would be good to know some use-cases to work with; maybe we could createa few generic renderers that can adapt to those use-cases. Then we canadjust the NamedBeanPropertyDescriptor class to enable parametrizing thoserenderers.One example I've been thnking about is the Pullup/Pulldown in the Sensortable. I see this is implemented by DccPP, but is there any other system? Ithink it's weird and out of place, because other systems use the systemspecific configuration method (e.g. CVs for loconet or in openlcb the CDIconfiguration dialog) to configure things like pullup/pulldown on aper-port basis.Maybe we could migrate these to system-specific properties in order tosimplify the UI of all other systems.&gt;&gt; As for persistence, that’s already being done by-system, by-manager&gt; through the ConfigureXML mechanism. So, if you add a meaningful property to&gt; e.g. XyzTurnouts, you should add load and store of those to&gt; XyzTurnoutManagerXml.  We can add some helper methods to the super class&gt; (e.g. a storeProperty(name) and loadProperty(name) method), etc, but&gt; control over which properties are stored and loaded, post-schema validity&gt; checks, etc should be done there.&gt;As said above, the custom property hash map is already persisted withgeneric code, so no custom code is needed for those properties.thanks,Balazs&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; —&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt;&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------&gt; ------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt;</pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>

        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>There are a couple dozen places in the code (including a couple I wrote) that treat java.util.Timer objects as throw-aways: create, have it fire, done. But they’re not like that. They’re heavyweight objects that continue to exist and expect to be given more work. They need to be cancel’d when done. But instead of doing that, it would be better to switch those calls to jmri.util.Threading calls. That centralizes their management while simplifying the code. Bob&gt; On Jan 25, 2018, at 11:54 AM, Andrew Crosland &lt;andrew@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; I may be misinterpreting what's going on, but you can see in the attached screenshot of live threads that there are some DCC4PC Sensor Poll threads that do not terminate.&gt; &gt; Then a lot of timers are created by dccpp. Looking at the heap dump they seem to be associated with dccpp throttles:&gt; &gt; "Timer-79" prio=5 tid=831 TIMED_WAITING&gt;    at java.lang.Object.wait(Native Method)&gt;    at java.util.TimerThread.mainLoop(Timer.java:552)&gt;       Local Variable: jmri.jmrix.dccpp.DCCppThrottle$1#141&gt;    at java.util.TimerThread.run(Timer.java:505)&gt; &gt; There are 140+ instances of DCCppThrottle left after all dccpp tests have finished.&gt; &gt; Andrew&gt; &gt; ------ Original Message ------&gt; From: "Dave Heap" &lt;dgheap@...&gt;&gt; To: "Andrew Crosland" &lt;andrew@...&gt;; "Discussions between JMRI developers" &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; Sent: 25/01/2018 19:14:34&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Curious test behavior - extra unneeded invocations of setup()&gt; &gt;&gt; Screenshots can be embedded on messages to this list.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Sent from my iPad&gt;&gt; --&gt;&gt; Dave&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; On 26 Jan 2018, at 4:33 AM, Andrew Crosland &lt;andrew@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; I don't think I can add attachments here, but I have a few peoples direct e-mail addresses if a screen shot would be of interest.&gt; &lt;2brezl3k.png&gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>------ Original Message ------From: "Paul Bender" &lt;paul.bender@...&gt;To: "Discussions between JMRI developers" &lt;jmri-developers@...&gt;Sent: 24/01/2018 23:47:56Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Curious test behavior - extra unneeded invocations of setup()&gt;As I mentioned in the comment on PR4818, by the time we get 1/4 of the &gt;way through the tests, there are about 2200 threads, and a there is a &gt;very large amount of memory associated with the test suite that the &gt;garbage collector is going through trying to reclaim heap space.  That &gt;has to be causing a slowdown of test suite execution.&gt;Using the NetBeans profiler is interesting. There are literally thousands of timers created, most of which are never destroyed. These show up in the thread trace so I assume a "waiting" timer constitutes a thread.olcb creates and does not kill a *lot* of threads which are left in wait or park state. dccpp and z21 are other culprits.I don't think I can add attachments here, but I have a few peoples direct e-mail addresses if a screen shot would be of interest.Andrew</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>I would much rather resetWindows run on every test an log an error for any window it resets; that way it is catching tests that don’t cleanup behind themselves. There are currently too many tests that don’t clean up behind themselves to just flip that switch though.Randall WoodAlexandria Softwarerandall.h.wood@...<a href="http://alexandriasoftware.com" rel="nofollow">http://alexandriasoftware.com</a>&gt; On Jan 25, 2018, at 02:44, Bob Jacobsen &lt;jacobsen@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Ah, thanks the for clarification. I misunderstood.&gt; &gt; I don’t understand why resetWindows() should be that slow, but I haven’t looked at it in detail.  &gt; &gt; If we could speed that up, that would be good.&gt; &gt; If not, what do people thing about moving it to an @AfterClass method, so it’s only done once per class instead of per test?  Yes, that does reduce the independence of the CI tests, but we’re also running fully-independent tests in Jenkins once a day.  &gt; &gt; I think Paul’s work on the large number of threads is quite important here.  On my MacBook Pro, 'ant alltest' really drags after a while and I think that reducing the amount of left-over stuff, including threads, would help that a lot)&gt; &gt; Bob&gt; &gt; &gt; &lt;PastedGraphic-1.png&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; On Jan 24, 2018, at 7:07 PM, B. Milhaupt &lt;dccexperimenter@...&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob J., &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; The repeated appearance of log.warn from testShow() is a function of the unique log.warn statements I placed in my hacked test.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; In my log, the messages of format "time1" thru "time28" represent one of 28 log.warn statements within the testShow() method.  I intended to try to find where time was lost within that method by looking at time deltas.  There is nothing unexpected in this part of the log; the test is executed exactly once and the 28 internal log.warn messages each show up exactly once, as expected.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; In my log, the messages of format "test 40" thru "test 42" represent one of three log.warn statements within the testCTor() method.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; As such, both the testShow() method and the testCTor() method were tested exactly once.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Your second concern, the resetWindows() call run time, is a valid one, not explainable by my test logging.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Regards,&gt;&gt; Bob M.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; -----Original Message-----&gt;&gt;&gt; From: Bob Jacobsen [mailto:jacobsen@...]&gt;&gt;&gt; Sent: Wednesday, January 24, 2018 5:30 PM&gt;&gt;&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers &lt;jmri-&gt;&gt;&gt; developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Curious test behavior - extra unneeded&gt;&gt;&gt; invocations of setup()&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &lt;snip&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; I think there are two other things here that are much more interesting.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; First, why does testShow() get called so many consecutive times?  We haven’t&gt;&gt;&gt; confirmed that setUp() is being called for inherited tests, but that’s a reasonable&gt;&gt;&gt; hypothesis for an OK reason).  I have no hypothesis for why testShow should be&gt;&gt;&gt; called more than once.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Second, if it’s taking "approximately one second (for) JunitJtil.resetWindows()”,&gt;&gt;&gt; that raises two questions:  Why is that so long, and can we make it shorter?&gt;&gt;&gt; Most of the time, that’s not needed; most tests don’t leave a window open.&gt;&gt;&gt; Ideally, it would never be needed: If we got serious about adding “close the&gt;&gt;&gt; window! Are you trying to heat the whole outside world?!” to each test that&gt;&gt;&gt; opens windows, we wouldn’t need it.  But even if we choose to leave it so that&gt;&gt;&gt; non-closed windows are handled, it would be good to know why it takes so&gt;&gt;&gt; long.&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt; Bob&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt;&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt;&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt;&gt; _______________________________________________&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt;&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt;&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>&gt; &gt; --&gt; Bob Jacobsen&gt; jacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG&gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Ah, thanks the for clarification. I misunderstood.I don’t understand why resetWindows() should be that slow, but I haven’t looked at it in detail.  If we could speed that up, that would be good.If not, what do people thing about moving it to an @AfterClass method, so it’s only done once per class instead of per test?  Yes, that does reduce the independence of the CI tests, but we’re also running fully-independent tests in Jenkins once a day.  I think Paul’s work on the large number of threads is quite important here.  On my MacBook Pro, 'ant alltest' really drags after a while and I think that reducing the amount of left-over stuff, including threads, would help that a lot)Bob&gt; On Jan 24, 2018, at 7:07 PM, B. Milhaupt &lt;dccexperimenter@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; Bob J., &gt; &gt; The repeated appearance of log.warn from testShow() is a function of the unique log.warn statements I placed in my hacked test.&gt; &gt; In my log, the messages of format "time1" thru "time28" represent one of 28 log.warn statements within the testShow() method.  I intended to try to find where time was lost within that method by looking at time deltas.  There is nothing unexpected in this part of the log; the test is executed exactly once and the 28 internal log.warn messages each show up exactly once, as expected.&gt; &gt; In my log, the messages of format "test 40" thru "test 42" represent one of three log.warn statements within the testCTor() method.&gt; &gt; As such, both the testShow() method and the testCTor() method were tested exactly once.&gt; &gt; Your second concern, the resetWindows() call run time, is a valid one, not explainable by my test logging.&gt; &gt; Regards,&gt; Bob M.&gt; &gt;&gt; -----Original Message-----&gt;&gt; From: Bob Jacobsen [mailto:jacobsen@...]&gt;&gt; Sent: Wednesday, January 24, 2018 5:30 PM&gt;&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers &lt;jmri-&gt;&gt; developers@...&gt;&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Curious test behavior - extra unneeded&gt;&gt; invocations of setup()&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; &lt;snip&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; I think there are two other things here that are much more interesting.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; First, why does testShow() get called so many consecutive times?  We haven’t&gt;&gt; confirmed that setUp() is being called for inherited tests, but that’s a reasonable&gt;&gt; hypothesis for an OK reason).  I have no hypothesis for why testShow should be&gt;&gt; called more than once.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Second, if it’s taking "approximately one second (for) JunitJtil.resetWindows()”,&gt;&gt; that raises two questions:  Why is that so long, and can we make it shorter?&gt;&gt; Most of the time, that’s not needed; most tests don’t leave a window open.&gt;&gt; Ideally, it would never be needed: If we got serious about adding “close the&gt;&gt; window! Are you trying to heat the whole outside world?!” to each test that&gt;&gt; opens windows, we wouldn’t need it.  But even if we choose to leave it so that&gt;&gt; non-closed windows are handled, it would be good to know why it takes so&gt;&gt; long.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; Bob&gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot</a>&gt; _______________________________________________&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a>--Bob Jacobsenjacobsen@... +1-510-708-5988 AIM, Skype JacobsenRG</pre></td>

         <td class="email-body"><pre>Bob J., The repeated appearance of log.warn from testShow() is a function of the unique log.warn statements I placed in my hacked test.In my log, the messages of format "time1" thru "time28" represent one of 28 log.warn statements within the testShow() method.  I intended to try to find where time was lost within that method by looking at time deltas.  There is nothing unexpected in this part of the log; the test is executed exactly once and the 28 internal log.warn messages each show up exactly once, as expected.In my log, the messages of format "test 40" thru "test 42" represent one of three log.warn statements within the testCTor() method.As such, both the testShow() method and the testCTor() method were tested exactly once.Your second concern, the resetWindows() call run time, is a valid one, not explainable by my test logging.Regards,Bob M.&gt; -----Original Message-----&gt; From: Bob Jacobsen [mailto:jacobsen@...]&gt; Sent: Wednesday, January 24, 2018 5:30 PM&gt; To: Discussions between JMRI developers &lt;jmri-&gt; developers@...&gt;&gt; Subject: Re: [Jmri-developers] Curious test behavior - extra unneeded&gt; invocations of setup()&gt; &lt;snip&gt;&gt; I think there are two other things here that are much more interesting.&gt; &gt; First, why does testShow() get called so many consecutive times?  We haven’t&gt; confirmed that setUp() is being called for inherited tests, but that’s a reasonable&gt; hypothesis for an OK reason).  I have no hypothesis for why testShow should be&gt; called more than once.&gt; &gt; Second, if it’s taking "approximately one second (for) JunitJtil.resetWindows()”,&gt; that raises two questions:  Why is that so long, and can we make it shorter?&gt; Most of the time, that’s not needed; most tests don’t leave a window open.&gt; Ideally, it would never be needed: If we got serious about adding “close the&gt; window! Are you trying to heat the whole outside world?!” to each test that&gt; opens windows, we wouldn’t need it.  But even if we choose to leave it so that&gt; non-closed windows are handled, it would be good to know why it takes so&gt; long.&gt; &gt; Bob</pre></td>

         <td class="email-header"> 
          <div> 
           <div>
            <b><a href="/p/jmri/mailman/message/36203597/">Re: [Jmri-developers] Curious test behavior - extra unneeded invocations of setup()</a></b>
           </div> 
           <small>From: Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@al...&gt; - 2018-01-25 01:48:59</small> 
           <div class="attachments"> 
            <small> <b>Attachments:</b> <a href="/p/jmri/mailman/attachment/13B73620-64EF-4554-B496-4559F68269A7%40alexandriasoftware.com/1/">Message as HTML</a> </small> 
           </div> 
          </div> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <td class="email-body"><pre>@BeforeClass is only of value if you need a computationally expensive setup once for a number of tests. @Before ensures a new setup for each test (avoiding the possibility that test B only succeeds if test A is run before it), so we need to use @Before to ensure that each test can succeed in a clean environment. (Note that maven and the Eclipse IDE can test individual methods, not just classes, with the JMRI project, so ensuring each test method has the correct setup is of value.)Paul Bender has chimed in; his comments were essentially that we don’t teardown/cleanup enough in our tests, but still leave too many artifacts in the JVM for following tests.Randall Wood&gt; On Jan 24, 2018, at 20:39, George Warner &lt;geowar1@...&gt; wrote:&gt; &gt; On Wed, 24 Jan 2018 14:07:53 -0500, Randall Wood &lt;randall.h.wood@... &lt;mailto:randall.h.wood@...&gt;&gt; wrote:&gt;&gt; The setUp and tearDown between each each test is a compromise between performance and an ideal test state. The ideal test state is that each test is run in its own JVM, but that takes easily three hours on a modern machine; so the setUp/tearDown between each test is as close as we can get to that without taking too long to test.&gt;&gt; &gt;&gt; We used to not have the setUp/tearDown routines, and found that tests were highly dependent on the order of execution without them, and even that over 100 tests could not even be run individually because they depended on the side effects of other tests. (Since that time we have also added a number of tests; however we still test only about 40% of the JMRI code base.)&gt; &gt; &gt; JUnit 4 supports a @BeforeClass that runs once before all @Tests. &gt; &gt; Used correctly it could eliminate a lot of unnecessary per-test overhead.&gt; &gt; I was hoping that Paul Bender would have piped in by now… he's (IMHO) the resident JUnit guru.&gt; &gt; I'd value his opinion / input on this.&gt; &gt; -- &gt; Enjoy,&gt; George Warner&gt; eMail, Message, or FaceTime: &lt;geowar1@... &lt;mailto:geowar1@...&gt;&gt;&gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; ------------------------------------------------------------------------------&gt; Check out the vibrant tech community on one of the world's most&gt; engaging tech sites, Slashdot.org! <a href="http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________" rel="nofollow">http://sdm.link/slashdot_______________________________________________</a>&gt; Jmri-developers mailing list&gt; Jmri-developers@...&gt; <a href="https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers" rel="nofollow">https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/jmri-developers</a></pre></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="excluded-count info">
